USA : queso fresco cheese"}, {"archive_id": "7893399", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis - USA (03): fatal, deli-sliced meats susp."}, {"archive_id": "7647773", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis - New Zealand (02): (BP) fatal, RFI"}, {"archive_id": "7614443", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis - New Zealand: (BP) fatal"}, {"archive_id": "7567091", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis - Europe (03): (Netherlands) fatal, smoked trout, recall, WGS"}, {"archive_id": "7562954", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis - Europe (02): Finland, MLST 6, whole genome sequencing"}, {"archive_id": "7333682", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis - Europe: Switzerland, fatal, cheese, susp, recall, RFI"}, {"archive_id": "7114952", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis - USA (02): (MN) restaurant, advisory", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=7114952", "date": "2019-10-03 12:58:52", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS - EUROPE (14): WHOLE GENOME SEQUENCING, LIVER PATE, FATAL, 2018\n***************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 3 Oct 2019\nSource: Food Safety News [edited]\nhttps://www.foodsafetynews.com/2019/10/austrian-listeria-outbreak-linked-to-liver-pate/\n\n\nA total of 13 people were part of a _Listeria_ outbreak after eating liver p\u00e2t\u00e9 in Austria at the end of this past year and 1 person died.\n\nThe outbreak strain had not been detected previously in Austria but no linked cases were found after an international alert, according to a report published in the journal Eurosurveillance [1].\n\nIn Austria, notification of invasive listeriosis infections are mandatory. The Austrian National Reference Laboratory for _Listeria_ (NRL) is responsible for whole genome sequence (WGS)-based typing of all isolates.\n\nOutbreak investigation\n----------------------\nIn late December 2018, the local health authority of Styria and the NRL confirmed an outbreak of febrile gastroenteritis, including one case of culture-confirmed _Listeria monocytogenes_ bacteremia, among 32 people at a tavern in mid-December [2018] as part of a celebration. They had consumed mixed platters with several meat products and p\u00e2t\u00e9s originating from an unnamed local production facility.\n\nAt the end of January this year [2019], the Austrian Ministry of Health imposed a mandate on the Austrian Agency of Health and Food Safety (AGES) to investigate the outbreak to identify the causative agent and likely source of infections, to detect and prevent further cases. The delay was due to closure of the tavern over the Christmas [2018] period.\n\nInformation from the local food authority on those involved restricted the incident to one local meat producer and three grocery shops. Items from this producer were offered at 6 locations, including the affected tavern and sold directly from the factory.\n\nOf 19 stool specimens from people with febrile gastroenteritis, 10 were positive for _L. monocytogenes_.\n\nA total of 73 food and environmental samples were analyzed for _Listeria monocytogenes_ with 2 food and one environmental sample positive. The food samples, smoked meat (Geselchtes) and liver p\u00e2t\u00e9 (Leberstreichwurst) were collected at the tavern. It was learned that they were produced by the same company. A gully water sample from January 2019 by Styrian health authorities at the production facility of this company also tested positive.\n\nActive case finding identified 2 more people with invasive listeriosis. They lived in the same 2 geographical districts as the tavern and production company. The 1st isolate was from a person in their early 80s who had not visited the tavern but developed symptoms in November 2018. This person, who died from the infection, had repeated consumption of liver p\u00e2t\u00e9 from the production company that was bought at a local market.\n\nThe 2nd isolate was from a case in their mid-50s with endophthalmitis, with onset of clinical symptoms in December 2018 but this person had not visited the tavern. They had regular consumption of liver p\u00e2t\u00e9 so it is possible this may have been produced at the implicated company.\n\nIn total, 7 females and 6 males aged 4 to 84 years old living within 24 km [15 mi] of Styria, were confirmed as outbreak cases.\n\nAfter the outbreak was confirmed in December [2018], cleaning of the tavern and at the production company was done by sanitation firms, under supervision of the local health authority. Only heat-treated products could be sold until _L. monocytogenes_ was not detected after repeated sampling. No more illnesses were found by the end of December [2018] and the outbreak was declared over.\n\nUse of epidemiological data and WGS-based typing confirmed the local outbreak due to a _Listeria monocytogenes_ IVb-CC4-ST4-CT7652 strain, not previously detected in Austria or anywhere else.\n\nA tavern offers a limited selection of traditional food, especially local meat products and cheese, in a buffet-like manner but has a functioning kitchen including fridge and freezer.\n\nThe researchers said it was possible that the time between food preparation and service might have been long, increasing the possibility for _Listeria_ to multiply. Traditional Austrian meat products such as liver p\u00e2t\u00e9 and jellied pork do not need heating prior to consumption and have been identified as potential risky food due to growth potential for _Listeria_.\n\n[Reference\n----------\n1. Cabal A, Allerberger F, Huhulescu S, et al. Listeriosis outbreak likely due to contaminated liver p\u00e2t\u00e9 consumed in a tavern, Austria, December 2018. Euro Surveill. 2019; 24(39): pii=1900274. https://doi.org/10.2807/1560-7917.ES.2019.24.39.1900274]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The abstract of the journal article referenced in the news report above has been extracted below:\n\n\"In late December 2018, an outbreak of listeriosis occurred after a group of 32 individuals celebrated in a tavern in Styria, Austria; traditional Austrian food (such as, meat, meat products, and cheese) was served. After the celebration, 11 individuals developed gastro-intestinal symptoms, including one case with severe sepsis. Cases had consumed mixed platters with several meat products and p\u00e2t\u00e9s originating from a local production facility (company X). Human, food and environmental samples taken from the tavern and company X were tested for _L. monocytogenes_. Whole genome sequence-based typing detected a novel _L. monocytogenes_ strain of serotype IVb, sequence type 4 and CT7652 in 15 samples; 12 human, 2 food and one environmental sample from company X with an allelic difference of 0 to 1. Active case finding identified 2 further cases who had not visited the tavern but tested positive for the outbreak strain. In total, 13 cases (7 females and 6 males; age range: 4-84 years) were identified. Liver p\u00e2t\u00e9 produced by company X was identified as the likely source of the outbreak. Control measures were implemented and since the end of December 2018, no more cases were detected.\"\n\nStyria is a state, or Bundesland, located in the southeast of Austria that borders Slovenia and the Austrian states of Upper Austria, Lower Austria, Salzburg, Burgenland, and Carinthia; the capital is the city of Graz (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Styria). A map showing the location of Styria can be found at https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Styria#/media/File:Steiermark_in_Austria.svg. - Mod.ML\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map of Austria: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/4075]\nSee Also\nListeriosis - Europe (10): (Spain) meat, fatal, miscarriages, UK tourist 20190907.6662490\nListeriosis - Europe (09): (Spain) meat, fatal, miscarriages, susp. tourist 20190901.6652320\nListeriosis - Europe (08): (Spain) meat product, recall, fatal 20190825.6640291\nListeriosis - Europe (07): (Spain) meat, recall, fatal 20190821.6634032\nListeriosis - Europe (06): (Spain) meat, recall, alert 20190817.6627473\nListeriosis - Europe (05): (UK) nosocomial, fatal, meat sandwiches 20190802.6601489\nListeriosis - Europe (04): (UK) nosocomial, fatal, meat sandwiches 20190608.6510327\nListeriosis - Europe (03): WGS, smoked fish, ex Estonia, fatal, 2014-19 20190606.6506263\nListeriosis - Europe (02): WGS, smoked fish, ex Estonia, fatal, 2016-19 20190328.6390799\nListeriosis - Europe: Denmark, fatal, WGS, smoked fish, ex Estonia, 2016-19 20190323.638338\n2018\n----\nListeriosis - Europe (07): Norway 20181228.6226705\nListeriosis - Europe (06): WGS, smoked/marinated salmon from Poland, 2015-18 20181031.6122165\nListeriosis - Europe (02): background 20180325.5709796\nListeriosis - Europe: fatal, ST6, frozen corn, 2015-18, recall 20180325.5708506\n.................................................sb/ml/mj/ml", "reports": [{"diseases": ["listeriosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2018-03-16 00:00:00", "2019-03-16 00:00:00", "2019-01-16 00:00:00", "2018-11-16 00:00:00", "2018-12-16 00:00:00", "2021-12-16 00:00:00", "2018-12-16 00:00:00", "2019-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-12 00:00:00", "2021-03-11 00:00:00", "2021-03-10 00:00:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2018-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Graz", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Spain", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Huhulescu S", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "France", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Switzerland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Austria", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "FATAL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Poland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Estonia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Burgenland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Bundesland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Salzburg", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Styria", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Lower Austria", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Slovenia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Denmark", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "7085372", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis - USA: fatal, enoki mushrooms, 2016-2019, recall, alert", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=7085372", "date": "2019-10-03 12:58:52", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS - EUROPE (14): WHOLE GENOME SEQUENCING, LIVER PATE, FATAL, 2018\n***************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 3 Oct 2019\nSource: Food Safety News [edited]\nhttps://www.foodsafetynews.com/2019/10/austrian-listeria-outbreak-linked-to-liver-pate/\n\n\nA total of 13 people were part of a _Listeria_ outbreak after eating liver p\u00e2t\u00e9 in Austria at the end of this past year and 1 person died.\n\nThe outbreak strain had not been detected previously in Austria but no linked cases were found after an international alert, according to a report published in the journal Eurosurveillance [1].\n\nIn Austria, notification of invasive listeriosis infections are mandatory. The Austrian National Reference Laboratory for _Listeria_ (NRL) is responsible for whole genome sequence (WGS)-based typing of all isolates.\n\nOutbreak investigation\n----------------------\nIn late December 2018, the local health authority of Styria and the NRL confirmed an outbreak of febrile gastroenteritis, including one case of culture-confirmed _Listeria monocytogenes_ bacteremia, among 32 people at a tavern in mid-December [2018] as part of a celebration. They had consumed mixed platters with several meat products and p\u00e2t\u00e9s originating from an unnamed local production facility.\n\nAt the end of January this year [2019], the Austrian Ministry of Health imposed a mandate on the Austrian Agency of Health and Food Safety (AGES) to investigate the outbreak to identify the causative agent and likely source of infections, to detect and prevent further cases. The delay was due to closure of the tavern over the Christmas [2018] period.\n\nInformation from the local food authority on those involved restricted the incident to one local meat producer and three grocery shops. Items from this producer were offered at 6 locations, including the affected tavern and sold directly from the factory.\n\nOf 19 stool specimens from people with febrile gastroenteritis, 10 were positive for _L. monocytogenes_.\n\nA total of 73 food and environmental samples were analyzed for _Listeria monocytogenes_ with 2 food and one environmental sample positive. The food samples, smoked meat (Geselchtes) and liver p\u00e2t\u00e9 (Leberstreichwurst) were collected at the tavern. It was learned that they were produced by the same company. A gully water sample from January 2019 by Styrian health authorities at the production facility of this company also tested positive.\n\nActive case finding identified 2 more people with invasive listeriosis. They lived in the same 2 geographical districts as the tavern and production company. The 1st isolate was from a person in their early 80s who had not visited the tavern but developed symptoms in November 2018. This person, who died from the infection, had repeated consumption of liver p\u00e2t\u00e9 from the production company that was bought at a local market.\n\nThe 2nd isolate was from a case in their mid-50s with endophthalmitis, with onset of clinical symptoms in December 2018 but this person had not visited the tavern. They had regular consumption of liver p\u00e2t\u00e9 so it is possible this may have been produced at the implicated company.\n\nIn total, 7 females and 6 males aged 4 to 84 years old living within 24 km [15 mi] of Styria, were confirmed as outbreak cases.\n\nAfter the outbreak was confirmed in December [2018], cleaning of the tavern and at the production company was done by sanitation firms, under supervision of the local health authority. Only heat-treated products could be sold until _L. monocytogenes_ was not detected after repeated sampling. No more illnesses were found by the end of December [2018] and the outbreak was declared over.\n\nUse of epidemiological data and WGS-based typing confirmed the local outbreak due to a _Listeria monocytogenes_ IVb-CC4-ST4-CT7652 strain, not previously detected in Austria or anywhere else.\n\nA tavern offers a limited selection of traditional food, especially local meat products and cheese, in a buffet-like manner but has a functioning kitchen including fridge and freezer.\n\nThe researchers said it was possible that the time between food preparation and service might have been long, increasing the possibility for _Listeria_ to multiply. Traditional Austrian meat products such as liver p\u00e2t\u00e9 and jellied pork do not need heating prior to consumption and have been identified as potential risky food due to growth potential for _Listeria_.\n\n[Reference\n----------\n1. Cabal A, Allerberger F, Huhulescu S, et al. Listeriosis outbreak likely due to contaminated liver p\u00e2t\u00e9 consumed in a tavern, Austria, December 2018. USA (03): fatal, bulk hard-boiled eggs, 2017-2019, alert", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6852412", "date": "2019-10-03 12:58:52", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS - EUROPE (14): WHOLE GENOME SEQUENCING, LIVER PATE, FATAL, 2018\n***************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 3 Oct 2019\nSource: Food Safety News [edited]\nhttps://www.foodsafetynews.com/2019/10/austrian-listeria-outbreak-linked-to-liver-pate/\n\n\nA total of 13 people were part of a _Listeria_ outbreak after eating liver p\u00e2t\u00e9 in Austria at the end of this past year and 1 person died.\n\nThe outbreak strain had not been detected previously in Austria but no linked cases were found after an international alert, according to a report published in the journal Eurosurveillance [1].\n\nIn Austria, notification of invasive listeriosis infections are mandatory. The Austrian National Reference Laboratory for _Listeria_ (NRL) is responsible for whole genome sequence (WGS)-based typing of all isolates.\n\nOutbreak investigation\n----------------------\nIn late December 2018, the local health authority of Styria and the NRL confirmed an outbreak of febrile gastroenteritis, including one case of culture-confirmed _Listeria monocytogenes_ bacteremia, among 32 people at a tavern in mid-December [2018] as part of a celebration. They had consumed mixed platters with several meat products and p\u00e2t\u00e9s originating from an unnamed local production facility.\n\nAt the end of January this year [2019], the Austrian Ministry of Health imposed a mandate on the Austrian Agency of Health and Food Safety (AGES) to investigate the outbreak to identify the causative agent and likely source of infections, to detect and prevent further cases. The delay was due to closure of the tavern over the Christmas [2018] period.\n\nInformation from the local food authority on those involved restricted the incident to one local meat producer and three grocery shops. Items from this producer were offered at 6 locations, including the affected tavern and sold directly from the factory.\n\nOf 19 stool specimens from people with febrile gastroenteritis, 10 were positive for _L. monocytogenes_.\n\nA total of 73 food and environmental samples were analyzed for _Listeria monocytogenes_ with 2 food and one environmental sample positive. The food samples, smoked meat (Geselchtes) and liver p\u00e2t\u00e9 (Leberstreichwurst) were collected at the tavern. It was learned that they were produced by the same company. A gully water sample from January 2019 by Styrian health authorities at the production facility of this company also tested positive.\n\nActive case finding identified 2 more people with invasive listeriosis. They lived in the same 2 geographical districts as the tavern and production company. The 1st isolate was from a person in their early 80s who had not visited the tavern but developed symptoms in November 2018. This person, who died from the infection, had repeated consumption of liver p\u00e2t\u00e9 from the production company that was bought at a local market.\n\nThe 2nd isolate was from a case in their mid-50s with endophthalmitis, with onset of clinical symptoms in December 2018 but this person had not visited the tavern. They had regular consumption of liver p\u00e2t\u00e9 so it is possible this may have been produced at the implicated company.\n\nIn total, 7 females and 6 males aged 4 to 84 years old living within 24 km [15 mi] of Styria, were confirmed as outbreak cases.\n\nAfter the outbreak was confirmed in December [2018], cleaning of the tavern and at the production company was done by sanitation firms, under supervision of the local health authority. Only heat-treated products could be sold until _L. monocytogenes_ was not detected after repeated sampling. No more illnesses were found by the end of December [2018] and the outbreak was declared over.\n\nUse of epidemiological data and WGS-based typing confirmed the local outbreak due to a _Listeria monocytogenes_ IVb-CC4-ST4-CT7652 strain, not previously detected in Austria or anywhere else.\n\nA tavern offers a limited selection of traditional food, especially local meat products and cheese, in a buffet-like manner but has a functioning kitchen including fridge and freezer.\n\nThe researchers said it was possible that the time between food preparation and service might have been long, increasing the possibility for _Listeria_ to multiply. After the celebration, 11 individuals developed gastro-intestinal symptoms, including one case with severe sepsis. Cases had consumed mixed platters with several meat products and p\u00e2t\u00e9s originating from a local production facility (company X). Human, food and environmental samples taken from the tavern and company X were tested for _L. monocytogenes_. Whole genome sequence-based typing detected a novel _L. monocytogenes_ strain of serotype IVb, sequence type 4 and CT7652 in 15 samples; 12 human, 2 food and one environmental sample from company X with an allelic difference of 0 to 1. Active case finding identified 2 further cases who had not visited the tavern but tested positive for the outbreak strain. In total, 13 cases (7 females and 6 males; age range: 4-84 years) were identified. Liver p\u00e2t\u00e9 produced by company X was identified as the likely source of the outbreak. Control measures were implemented and since the end of December 2018, no more cases were detected.\"\n\nStyria is a state, or Bundesland, located in the southeast of Austria that borders Slovenia and the Austrian states of Upper Austria, Lower Austria, Salzburg, Burgenland, and Carinthia; the capital is the city of Graz (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Styria). A map showing the location of Styria can be found at https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Styria#/media/File:Steiermark_in_Austria.svg. - Mod.ML\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map of Austria: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/4075]\nSee Also\nListeriosis - Europe (02): background 20180325.5709796\nListeriosis - Europe: fatal, ST6, frozen corn, 2015-18, recall 20180325.5708506\n.................................................sb/ml/mj/ml", "reports": [{"diseases": ["listeriosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2018-03-16 00:00:00", "2019-03-16 00:00:00", "2019-01-16 00:00:00", "2018-11-16 00:00:00", "2018-12-16 00:00:00", "2021-12-16 00:00:00", "2018-12-16 00:00:00", "2019-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-12 00:00:00", "2021-03-11 00:00:00", "2021-03-10 00:00:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2018-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Graz", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Spain", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Huhulescu S", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "France", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Switzerland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Austria", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "FATAL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Poland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Estonia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Burgenland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Bundesland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Salzburg", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Styria", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Lower Austria", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Slovenia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Denmark", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "6789767", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis - Europe (18): (Germany) fatal, WGS, meat, healthcare facilities", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6789767", "date": "2019-10-03 12:58:52", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS - EUROPE (14): WHOLE GENOME SEQUENCING, LIVER PATE, FATAL, 2018\n***************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 3 Oct 2019\nSource: Food Safety News [edited]\nhttps://www.foodsafetynews.com/2019/10/austrian-listeria-outbreak-linked-to-liver-pate/\n\n\nA total of 13 people were part of a _Listeria_ outbreak after eating liver p\u00e2t\u00e9 in Austria at the end of this past year and 1 person died.\n\nThe outbreak strain had not been detected previously in Austria but no linked cases were found after an international alert, according to a report published in the journal Eurosurveillance [1].\n\nIn Austria, notification of invasive listeriosis infections are mandatory. The Austrian National Reference Laboratory for _Listeria_ (NRL) is responsible for whole genome sequence (WGS)-based typing of all isolates.\n\nOutbreak investigation\n----------------------\nIn late December 2018, the local health authority of Styria and the NRL confirmed an outbreak of febrile gastroenteritis, including one case of culture-confirmed _Listeria monocytogenes_ bacteremia, among 32 people at a tavern in mid-December [2018] as part of a celebration. They had consumed mixed platters with several meat products and p\u00e2t\u00e9s originating from an unnamed local production facility.\n\nAt the end of January this year [2019], the Austrian Ministry of Health imposed a mandate on the Austrian Agency of Health and Food Safety (AGES) to investigate the outbreak to identify the causative agent and likely source of infections, to detect and prevent further cases. The delay was due to closure of the tavern over the Christmas [2018] period.\n\nInformation from the local food authority on those involved restricted the incident to one local meat producer and three grocery shops. Items from this producer were offered at 6 locations, including the affected tavern and sold directly from the factory.\n\nOf 19 stool specimens from people with febrile gastroenteritis, 10 were positive for _L. monocytogenes_.\n\nA total of 73 food and environmental samples were analyzed for _Listeria monocytogenes_ with 2 food and one environmental sample positive. The food samples, smoked meat (Geselchtes) and liver p\u00e2t\u00e9 (Leberstreichwurst) were collected at the tavern. It was learned that they were produced by the same company. A gully water sample from January 2019 by Styrian health authorities at the production facility of this company also tested positive.\n\nActive case finding identified 2 more people with invasive listeriosis. They lived in the same 2 geographical districts as the tavern and production company. The 1st isolate was from a person in their early 80s who had not visited the tavern but developed symptoms in November 2018. This person, who died from the infection, had repeated consumption of liver p\u00e2t\u00e9 from the production company that was bought at a local market.\n\nThe 2nd isolate was from a case in their mid-50s with endophthalmitis, with onset of clinical symptoms in December 2018 but this person had not visited the tavern. They had regular consumption of liver p\u00e2t\u00e9 so it is possible this may have been produced at the implicated company.\n\nIn total, 7 females and 6 males aged 4 to 84 years old living within 24 km [15 mi] of Styria, were confirmed as outbreak cases.\n\nAfter the outbreak was confirmed in December [2018], cleaning of the tavern and at the production company was done by sanitation firms, under supervision of the local health authority. Only heat-treated products could be sold until _L. monocytogenes_ was not detected after repeated sampling. No more illnesses were found by the end of December [2018] and the outbreak was declared over.\n\nUse of epidemiological data and WGS-based typing confirmed the local outbreak due to a _Listeria monocytogenes_ IVb-CC4-ST4-CT7652 strain, not previously detected in Austria or anywhere else.\n\nA tavern offers a limited selection of traditional food, especially local meat products and cheese, in a buffet-like manner but has a functioning kitchen including fridge and freezer.\n\nThe researchers said it was possible that the time between food preparation and service might have been long, increasing the possibility for _Listeria_ to multiply. Traditional Austrian meat products such as liver p\u00e2t\u00e9 and jellied pork do not need heating prior to consumption and have been identified as potential risky food due to growth potential for _Listeria_.\n\n[Reference\n----------\n1. Cabal A, Allerberger F, Huhulescu S, et al. Listeriosis outbreak likely due to contaminated liver p\u00e2t\u00e9 consumed in a tavern, Austria, December 2018. Euro Surveill. 2019; 24(39): pii=1900274. https://doi.org/10.2807/1560-7917.ES.2019.24.39.1900274]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The abstract of the journal article referenced in the news report above has been extracted below:\n\n\"In late December 2018, an outbreak of listeriosis occurred after a group of 32 individuals celebrated in a tavern in Styria, Austria; traditional Austrian food (such as, meat, meat products, and cheese) was served. After the celebration, 11 individuals developed gastro-intestinal symptoms, including one case with severe sepsis. Cases had consumed mixed platters with several meat products and p\u00e2t\u00e9s originating from a local production facility (company X). Human, food and environmental samples taken from the tavern and company X were tested for _L. monocytogenes_. Whole genome sequence-based typing detected a novel _L. monocytogenes_ strain of serotype IVb, sequence type 4 and CT7652 in 15 samples; 12 human, 2 food and one environmental sample from company X with an allelic difference of 0 to 1. Active case finding identified 2 further cases who had not visited the tavern but tested positive for the outbreak strain. In total, 13 cases (7 females and 6 males; age range: 4-84 years) were identified. Liver p\u00e2t\u00e9 produced by company X was identified as the likely source of the outbreak. Control measures were implemented and since the end of December 2018, no more cases were detected.\"\n\nStyria is a state, or Bundesland, located in the southeast of Austria that borders Slovenia and the Austrian states of Upper Austria, Lower Austria, Salzburg, Burgenland, and Carinthia; the capital is the city of Graz (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Styria). A map showing the location of Styria can be found at https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Styria#/media/File:Steiermark_in_Austria.svg. - Mod.ML\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map of Austria: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/4075]\nSee Also\nListeriosis - Europe (16): (Germany) fatal, WGS, meat, healthcare facilities", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6736570", "date": "2019-10-03 12:58:52", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS - EUROPE (14): WHOLE GENOME SEQUENCING, LIVER PATE, FATAL, 2018\n***************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 3 Oct 2019\nSource: Food Safety News [edited]\nhttps://www.foodsafetynews.com/2019/10/austrian-listeria-outbreak-linked-to-liver-pate/\n\n\nA total of 13 people were part of a _Listeria_ outbreak after eating liver p\u00e2t\u00e9 in Austria at the end of this past year and 1 person died.\n\nThe outbreak strain had not been detected previously in Austria but no linked cases were found after an international alert, according to a report published in the journal Eurosurveillance [1].\n\nIn Austria, notification of invasive listeriosis infections are mandatory. The Austrian National Reference Laboratory for _Listeria_ (NRL) is responsible for whole genome sequence (WGS)-based typing of all isolates.\n\nOutbreak investigation\n----------------------\nIn late December 2018, the local health authority of Styria and the NRL confirmed an outbreak of febrile gastroenteritis, including one case of culture-confirmed _Listeria monocytogenes_ bacteremia, among 32 people at a tavern in mid-December [2018] as part of a celebration. They had consumed mixed platters with several meat products and p\u00e2t\u00e9s originating from an unnamed local production facility.\n\nAt the end of January this year [2019], the Austrian Ministry of Health imposed a mandate on the Austrian Agency of Health and Food Safety (AGES) to investigate the outbreak to identify the causative agent and likely source of infections, to detect and prevent further cases. The delay was due to closure of the tavern over the Christmas [2018] period.\n\nInformation from the local food authority on those involved restricted the incident to one local meat producer and three grocery shops. Items from this producer were offered at 6 locations, including the affected tavern and sold directly from the factory.\n\nOf 19 stool specimens from people with febrile gastroenteritis, 10 were positive for _L. monocytogenes_.\n\nA total of 73 food and environmental samples were analyzed for _Listeria monocytogenes_ with 2 food and one environmental sample positive. The food samples, smoked meat (Geselchtes) and liver p\u00e2t\u00e9 (Leberstreichwurst) were collected at the tavern. It was learned that they were produced by the same company. A gully water sample from January 2019 by Styrian health authorities at the production facility of this company also tested positive.\n\nActive case finding identified 2 more people with invasive listeriosis. They lived in the same 2 geographical districts as the tavern and production company. The 1st isolate was from a person in their early 80s who had not visited the tavern but developed symptoms in November 2018. This person, who died from the infection, had repeated consumption of liver p\u00e2t\u00e9 from the production company that was bought at a local market.\n\nThe 2nd isolate was from a case in their mid-50s with endophthalmitis, with onset of clinical symptoms in December 2018 but this person had not visited the tavern. They had regular consumption of liver p\u00e2t\u00e9 so it is possible this may have been produced at the implicated company.\n\nIn total, 7 females and 6 males aged 4 to 84 years old living within 24 km [15 mi] of Styria, were confirmed as outbreak cases.\n\nAfter the outbreak was confirmed in December [2018], cleaning of the tavern and at the production company was done by sanitation firms, under supervision of the local health authority. Only heat-treated products could be sold until _L. monocytogenes_ was not detected after repeated sampling. No more illnesses were found by the end of December [2018] and the outbreak was declared over.\n\nUse of epidemiological data and WGS-based typing confirmed the local outbreak due to a _Listeria monocytogenes_ IVb-CC4-ST4-CT7652 strain, not previously detected in Austria or anywhere else.\n\nA tavern offers a limited selection of traditional food, especially local meat products and cheese, in a buffet-like manner but has a functioning kitchen including fridge and freezer.\n\nThe researchers said it was possible that the time between food preparation and service might have been long, increasing the possibility for _Listeria_ to multiply. Traditional Austrian meat products such as liver p\u00e2t\u00e9 and jellied pork do not need heating prior to consumption and have been identified as potential risky food due to growth potential for _Listeria_.\n\n[Reference\n----------\n1. Cabal A, Allerberger F, Huhulescu S, et al. Listeriosis outbreak likely due to contaminated liver p\u00e2t\u00e9 consumed in a tavern, Austria, December 2018. Euro Surveill. 2019; 24(39): pii=1900274. https://doi.org/10.2807/1560-7917.ES.2019.24.39.1900274]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The abstract of the journal article referenced in the news report above has been extracted below:\n\n\"In late December 2018, an outbreak of listeriosis occurred after a group of 32 individuals celebrated in a tavern in Styria, Austria; traditional Austrian food (such as, meat, meat products, and cheese) was served. After the celebration, 11 individuals developed gastro-intestinal symptoms, including one case with severe sepsis. Cases had consumed mixed platters with several meat products and p\u00e2t\u00e9s originating from a local production facility (company X). Human, food and environmental samples taken from the tavern and company X were tested for _L. monocytogenes_. Whole genome sequence-based typing detected a novel _L. monocytogenes_ strain of serotype IVb, sequence type 4 and CT7652 in 15 samples; 12 human, 2 food and one environmental sample from company X with an allelic difference of 0 to 1. Active case finding identified 2 further cases who had not visited the tavern but tested positive for the outbreak strain. In total, 13 cases (7 females and 6 males; age range: 4-84 years) were identified. Liver p\u00e2t\u00e9 produced by company X was identified as the likely source of the outbreak. Control measures were implemented and since the end of December 2018, no more cases were detected.\"\n\nStyria is a state, or Bundesland, located in the southeast of Austria that borders Slovenia and the Austrian states of Upper Austria, Lower Austria, Salzburg, Burgenland, and Carinthia; the capital is the city of Graz (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Styria). A map showing the location of Styria can be found at https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Styria#/media/File:Steiermark_in_Austria.svg. - Mod.ML\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map of Austria: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/4075]\nSee Also\nListeriosis - Europe (02): background 20180325.5709796\nListeriosis - Europe: fatal, ST6, frozen corn, 2015-18, recall 20180325.5708506\n.................................................sb/ml/mj/ml", "reports": [{"diseases": ["listeriosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2018-03-16 00:00:00", "2019-03-16 00:00:00", "2019-01-16 00:00:00", "2018-11-16 00:00:00", "2018-12-16 00:00:00", "2021-12-16 00:00:00", "2018-12-16 00:00:00", "2019-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-12 00:00:00", "2021-03-11 00:00:00", "2021-03-10 00:00:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2018-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Graz", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Spain", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Huhulescu S", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "France", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Switzerland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Austria", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "FATAL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Poland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Estonia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Burgenland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Bundesland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Salzburg", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Styria", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Lower Austria", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Slovenia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Denmark", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "6711608", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis - Europe (15): (Netherlands) fatal, WGS, cold cuts", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6711608", "date": "2019-10-03 12:58:52", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS - EUROPE (14): WHOLE GENOME SEQUENCING, LIVER PATE, FATAL, 2018\n***************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 3 Oct 2019\nSource: Food Safety News [edited]\nhttps://www.foodsafetynews.com/2019/10/austrian-listeria-outbreak-linked-to-liver-pate/\n\n\nA total of 13 people were part of a _Listeria_ outbreak after eating liver p\u00e2t\u00e9 in Austria at the end of this past year and 1 person died.\n\nThe outbreak strain had not been detected previously in Austria but no linked cases were found after an international alert, according to a report published in the journal Eurosurveillance [1].\n\nIn Austria, notification of invasive listeriosis infections are mandatory. The Austrian National Reference Laboratory for _Listeria_ (NRL) is responsible for whole genome sequence (WGS)-based typing of all isolates.\n\nOutbreak investigation\n----------------------\nIn late December 2018, the local health authority of Styria and the NRL confirmed an outbreak of febrile gastroenteritis, including one case of culture-confirmed _Listeria monocytogenes_ bacteremia, among 32 people at a tavern in mid-December [2018] as part of a celebration. They had consumed mixed platters with several meat products and p\u00e2t\u00e9s originating from an unnamed local production facility.\n\nAt the end of January this year [2019], the Austrian Ministry of Health imposed a mandate on the Austrian Agency of Health and Food Safety (AGES) to investigate the outbreak to identify the causative agent and likely source of infections, to detect and prevent further cases. The delay was due to closure of the tavern over the Christmas [2018] period.\n\nInformation from the local food authority on those involved restricted the incident to one local meat producer and three grocery shops. Items from this producer were offered at 6 locations, including the affected tavern and sold directly from the factory.\n\nOf 19 stool specimens from people with febrile gastroenteritis, 10 were positive for _L. monocytogenes_.\n\nA total of 73 food and environmental samples were analyzed for _Listeria monocytogenes_ with 2 food and one environmental sample positive. The food samples, smoked meat (Geselchtes) and liver p\u00e2t\u00e9 (Leberstreichwurst) were collected at the tavern. It was learned that they were produced by the same company. A gully water sample from January 2019 by Styrian health authorities at the production facility of this company also tested positive.\n\nActive case finding identified 2 more people with invasive listeriosis. They lived in the same 2 geographical districts as the tavern and production company. The 1st isolate was from a person in their early 80s who had not visited the tavern but developed symptoms in November 2018. This person, who died from the infection, had repeated consumption of liver p\u00e2t\u00e9 from the production company that was bought at a local market.\n\nThe 2nd isolate was from a case in their mid-50s with endophthalmitis, with onset of clinical symptoms in December 2018 but this person had not visited the tavern. They had regular consumption of liver p\u00e2t\u00e9 so it is possible this may have been produced at the implicated company.\n\nIn total, 7 females and 6 males aged 4 to 84 years old living within 24 km [15 mi] of Styria, were confirmed as outbreak cases.\n\nAfter the outbreak was confirmed in December [2018], cleaning of the tavern and at the production company was done by sanitation firms, under supervision of the local health authority. Only heat-treated products could be sold until _L. monocytogenes_ was not detected after repeated sampling. No more illnesses were found by the end of December [2018] and the outbreak was declared over.\n\nUse of epidemiological data and WGS-based typing confirmed the local outbreak due to a _Listeria monocytogenes_ IVb-CC4-ST4-CT7652 strain, not previously detected in Austria or anywhere else.\n\nA tavern offers a limited selection of traditional food, especially local meat products and cheese, in a buffet-like manner but has a functioning kitchen including fridge and freezer.\n\nThe researchers said it was possible that the time between food preparation and service might have been long, increasing the possibility for _Listeria_ to multiply. Traditional Austrian meat products such as liver p\u00e2t\u00e9 and jellied pork do not need heating prior to consumption and have been identified as potential risky food due to growth potential for _Listeria_.\n\n[Reference\n----------\n1. Cabal A, Allerberger F, Huhulescu S, et al. Listeriosis outbreak likely due to contaminated liver p\u00e2t\u00e9 consumed in a tavern, Austria, December 2018. Euro Surveill. 2019; 24(39): pii=1900274. https://doi.org/10.2807/1560-7917.ES.2019.24.39.1900274]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The abstract of the journal article referenced in the news report above has been extracted below:\n\n\"In late December 2018, an outbreak of listeriosis occurred after a group of 32 individuals celebrated in a tavern in Styria, Austria; traditional Austrian food (such as, meat, meat products, and cheese) was served. After the celebration, 11 individuals developed gastro-intestinal symptoms, including one case with severe sepsis. Cases had consumed mixed platters with several meat products and p\u00e2t\u00e9s originating from a local production facility (company X). Human, food and environmental samples taken from the tavern and company X were tested for _L. monocytogenes_. Whole genome sequence-based typing detected a novel _L. monocytogenes_ strain of serotype IVb, sequence type 4 and CT7652 in 15 samples; 12 human, 2 food and one environmental sample from company X with an allelic difference of 0 to 1. In total, 13 cases (7 females and 6 males; age range: 4-84 years) were identified. Liver p\u00e2t\u00e9 produced by company X was identified as the likely source of the outbreak. Control measures were implemented and since the end of December 2018, no more cases were detected.\"\n\nStyria is a state, or Bundesland, located in the southeast of Austria that borders Slovenia and the Austrian states of Upper Austria, Lower Austria, Salzburg, Burgenland, and Carinthia; the capital is the city of Graz (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Styria). Europe (02): background 20180325.5709796\nListeriosis - Europe: fatal, ST6, frozen corn, 2015-18, recall 20180325.5708506\n.................................................sb/ml/mj/ml", "reports": [{"diseases": ["listeriosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2018-03-16 00:00:00", "2019-03-16 00:00:00", "2019-01-16 00:00:00", "2018-11-16 00:00:00", "2018-12-16 00:00:00", "2021-12-16 00:00:00", "2018-12-16 00:00:00", "2019-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-12 00:00:00", "2021-03-11 00:00:00", "2021-03-10 00:00:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2018-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Graz", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Spain", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Huhulescu S", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "France", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Switzerland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Austria", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "FATAL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Poland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Estonia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Burgenland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Bundesland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Salzburg", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Styria", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Lower Austria", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Slovenia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Denmark", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "6696978", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis - Europe (13): WGS, smoked fish, ex Estonia, fatal, 2014-19"}, {"archive_id": "6680145", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis - Europe (12): (France) fatal, raw milk cheeses, recall"}, {"archive_id": "6670537", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis - Europe (11): (Spain) meat, fatal, miscarriages, Mallorca"}, {"archive_id": "6662490", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis - Europe (10): (Spain) meat, fatal, miscarriages, UK tourist", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6662490", "date": "2019-07-24 19:13:18", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS - AUSTRALIA (02): FATAL, SMOKED SALMON SUSPECTED\n************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 24 Jul 2019\nSource: BBC News [edited]\nhttps://www.bbc.com/news/world-australia-49094165\n\n\nTwo people have died from _Listeria_ infections in Australia after probably eating contaminated smoked salmon, officials say. A 3rd person also contracted the illness -- known as listeriosis -- but survived. The 3 cases happened in different states.\n\nLocal media reports that the contamination is believed to originate in Tasmania, which produces most Australian salmon.\n\nHealth officials warned people most at risk to avoid certain foods.\n\nThe people who died were both aged above 70 [years] and had underlying health conditions, said Australia's chief medical officer Prof Brendan Murphy.\n\nThe Tasmanian government said the state's salmon producers had been cleared of food safety breaches following the _Listeria_ cases in Victoria, New South Wales and Queensland.\n\nOfficials said pregnant women, the elderly, infants, and those with weakened immune systems were most at risk of severe symptoms. \"This is a timely reminder for people to ensure that food is handled, prepared and stored safely, and that those most at-risk of listeriosis avoid certain foods,\" Prof Murphy said in a statement on Wednesday [24 Jul 2019].\n\nWhat is listeriosis? It can be caught from food containing _Listeria_ bacteria, or close contact with farm animals. Cases usually involve unpasteurised milk or dairy products, such as Camembert and brie. Pre-packed foods, including sandwiches and pate, can also contain _Listeria_. Symptoms include high temperature, flu-like symptoms, vomiting and diarrhoea. Most people infected display no symptoms, but elderly and very young people are vulnerable.\n\nLast year [2018], a _Listeria_ outbreak traced to rockmelons killed 7 people across Australia. Other nations have also seen recent outbreaks. One in South Africa killed 180 people and was said to be the worst in history.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[_Listeria monocytogenes_ is widely distributed in the environment where it can form biofilms, which enables it to attach to solid surfaces and become extremely difficult to remove. It is found in the intestinal tract of many animals, including cattle, sheep, and humans, and is found in soil and water, especially in regions in close proximity to cattle farms, indicating that these animals may contribute to its dispersal in the environment through their fecal matter. The organism can be also found in agricultural land fertilized with sewage, and in silage, raw vegetables, raw meat and poultry, raw milk, soft cheeses, and kitchen premises, as well as in birds, crustaceans, fish, shellfish, ticks, and insects.\n\nRefrigerated smoked salmon is a recognized potential source for listeriosis, similar to other cold cut meats and non-heat treated cured smoked meats, being a ready-to-eat product that does not require further cooking before eating.\n\nEven if initial contamination adds only a few _Listeria _ organisms to the food, the contamination can be significant for refrigerated foods, because _Listeria_ can subsequently multiply at refrigerator temperatures to sufficient numbers to cause disease.\n\nGenotyping the clinical isolates from the 3 affected individuals, if they match, will establish whether we are dealing with a common-source outbreak, and genotyping isolates from smoked salmon eaten by the affected individuals would establish transmission pathways, if the genotypes from the smoked salmon and the clinical isolates match. - Mod.ML\n\nHealthMap/ProMED map available at:\nAustralia: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/186]\nSee Also\nListeriosis - Australia: (VI) fatal, nosocomial 20190223.6332766\n2018\n----\nListeriosis - Europe (06): WGS, smoked/marinated salmon from Poland, 2015-18 20181031.6122165\n2017\n----\nListeriosis - Denmark, Poland: smoked salmon, recall 20170902.5290728\n.................................................sb/ml/msp/ml", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "listeriosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2019-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-17 00:00:00", "2018-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2017-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Tasmania", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Queensland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Victoria", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Australia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "South Africa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Poland", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "6652320", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis - One in South Africa killed 180 people and was said to be the worst in history.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[_Listeria monocytogenes_ is widely distributed in the environment where it can form biofilms, which enables it to attach to solid surfaces and become extremely difficult to remove. It is found in the intestinal tract of many animals, including cattle, sheep, and humans, and is found in soil and water, especially in regions in close proximity to cattle farms, indicating that these animals may contribute to its dispersal in the environment through their fecal matter. The organism can be also found in agricultural land fertilized with sewage, and in silage, raw vegetables, raw meat and poultry, raw milk, soft cheeses, and kitchen premises, as well as in birds, crustaceans, fish, shellfish, ticks, and insects.\n\nRefrigerated smoked salmon is a recognized potential source for listeriosis, similar to other cold cut meats and non-heat treated cured smoked meats, being a ready-to-eat product that does not require further cooking before eating.\n\nEven if initial contamination adds only a few _Listeria _ organisms to the food, the contamination can be significant for refrigerated foods, because _Listeria_ can subsequently multiply at refrigerator temperatures to sufficient numbers to cause disease.\n\nGenotyping the clinical isolates from the 3 affected individuals, if they match, will establish whether we are dealing with a common-source outbreak, and genotyping isolates from smoked salmon eaten by the affected individuals would establish transmission pathways, if the genotypes from the smoked salmon and the clinical isolates match. - Mod.ML\n\nHealthMap/ProMED map available at:\nAustralia: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/186]\nSee Also\nListeriosis - Australia: (VI) fatal, nosocomial 20190223.6332766\n2018\n----\nListeriosis - Europe (06): WGS, smoked/marinated salmon from Poland, 2015-18 20181031.6122165\n2017\n----\nListeriosis - Denmark, Poland: smoked salmon, recall 20170902.5290728\n.................................................sb/ml/msp/ml", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "listeriosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2019-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-17 00:00:00", "2018-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2017-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Tasmania", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Queensland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Victoria", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Australia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "South Africa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Poland", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "6601489", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis - Europe (05): (UK) nosocomial, fatal, meat sandwiches", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6601489", "date": "2019-07-24 19:13:18", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS - AUSTRALIA (02): FATAL, SMOKED SALMON SUSPECTED\n************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 24 Jul 2019\nSource: BBC News [edited]\nhttps://www.bbc.com/news/world-australia-49094165\n\n\nTwo people have died from _Listeria_ infections in Australia after probably eating contaminated smoked salmon, officials say. A 3rd person also contracted the illness -- known as listeriosis -- but survived. The 3 cases happened in different states.\n\nLocal media reports that the contamination is believed to originate in Tasmania, which produces most Australian salmon.\n\nHealth officials warned people most at risk to avoid certain foods.\n\nThe people who died were both aged above 70 [years] and had underlying health conditions, said Australia's chief medical officer Prof Brendan Murphy.\n\nThe Tasmanian government said the state's salmon producers had been cleared of food safety breaches following the _Listeria_ cases in Victoria, New South Wales and Queensland.\n\nOfficials said pregnant women, the elderly, infants, and those with weakened immune systems were most at risk of severe symptoms. \"This is a timely reminder for people to ensure that food is handled, prepared and stored safely, and that those most at-risk of listeriosis avoid certain foods,\" Prof Murphy said in a statement on Wednesday [24 Jul 2019].\n\nWhat is listeriosis? It can be caught from food containing _Listeria_ bacteria, or close contact with farm animals. Cases usually involve unpasteurised milk or dairy products, such as Camembert and brie. Pre-packed foods, including sandwiches and pate, can also contain _Listeria_. Symptoms include high temperature, flu-like symptoms, vomiting and diarrhoea. Most people infected display no symptoms, but elderly and very young people are vulnerable.\n\nLast year [2018], a _Listeria_ outbreak traced to rockmelons killed 7 people across Australia. Other nations have also seen recent outbreaks. One in South Africa killed 180 people and was said to be the worst in history.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[_Listeria monocytogenes_ is widely distributed in the environment where it can form biofilms, which enables it to attach to solid surfaces and become extremely difficult to remove. It is found in the intestinal tract of many animals, including cattle, sheep, and humans, and is found in soil and water, especially in regions in close proximity to cattle farms, indicating that these animals may contribute to its dispersal in the environment through their fecal matter. The organism can be also found in agricultural land fertilized with sewage, and in silage, raw vegetables, raw meat and poultry, raw milk, soft cheeses, and kitchen premises, as well as in birds, crustaceans, fish, shellfish, ticks, and insects.\n\nRefrigerated smoked salmon is a recognized potential source for listeriosis, similar to other cold cut meats and non-heat treated cured smoked meats, being a ready-to-eat product that does not require further cooking before eating.\n\nEven if initial contamination adds only a few _Listeria _ organisms to the food, the contamination can be significant for refrigerated foods, because _Listeria_ can subsequently multiply at refrigerator temperatures to sufficient numbers to cause disease.\n\nGenotyping the clinical isolates from the 3 affected individuals, if they match, will establish whether we are dealing with a common-source outbreak, and genotyping isolates from smoked salmon eaten by the affected individuals would establish transmission pathways, if the genotypes from the smoked salmon and the clinical isolates match. - Mod.ML\n\nHealthMap/ProMED map available at:\nAustralia: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/186]\nSee Also\nListeriosis - Australia: (VI) fatal, nosocomial 20190223.6332766\n2018\n----\nListeriosis - Europe (06): WGS, smoked/marinated salmon from Poland, 2015-18 20181031.6122165\n2017\n----\nListeriosis - Australia (02): fatal, smoked salmon susp.", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6586028", "date": "2019-07-24 19:13:18", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS - AUSTRALIA (02): FATAL, SMOKED SALMON SUSPECTED\n************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 24 Jul 2019\nSource: BBC News [edited]\nhttps://www.bbc.com/news/world-australia-49094165\n\n\nTwo people have died from _Listeria_ infections in Australia after probably eating contaminated smoked salmon, officials say. A 3rd person also contracted the illness -- known as listeriosis -- but survived. The 3 cases happened in different states.\n\nLocal media reports that the contamination is believed to originate in Tasmania, which produces most Australian salmon.\n\nHealth officials warned people most at risk to avoid certain foods.\n\nThe people who died were both aged above 70 [years] and had underlying health conditions, said Australia's chief medical officer Prof Brendan Murphy.\n\nThe Tasmanian government said the state's salmon producers had been cleared of food safety breaches following the _Listeria_ cases in Victoria, New South Wales and Queensland.\n\nOfficials said pregnant women, the elderly, infants, and those with weakened immune systems were most at risk of severe symptoms. \"This is a timely reminder for people to ensure that food is handled, prepared and stored safely, and that those most at-risk of listeriosis avoid certain foods,\" Prof Murphy said in a statement on Wednesday [24 Jul 2019].\n\nWhat is listeriosis? It can be caught from food containing _Listeria_ bacteria, or close contact with farm animals. Cases usually involve unpasteurised milk or dairy products, such as Camembert and brie. Pre-packed foods, including sandwiches and pate, can also contain _Listeria_. Symptoms include high temperature, flu-like symptoms, vomiting and diarrhoea. Most people infected display no symptoms, but elderly and very young people are vulnerable.\n\nLast year [2018], a _Listeria_ outbreak traced to rockmelons killed 7 people across Australia. Other nations have also seen recent outbreaks. One in South Africa killed 180 people and was said to be the worst in history.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[_Listeria monocytogenes_ is widely distributed in the environment where it can form biofilms, which enables it to attach to solid surfaces and become extremely difficult to remove. It is found in the intestinal tract of many animals, including cattle, sheep, and humans, and is found in soil and water, especially in regions in close proximity to cattle farms, indicating that these animals may contribute to its dispersal in the environment through their fecal matter. The organism can be also found in agricultural land fertilized with sewage, and in silage, raw vegetables, raw meat and poultry, raw milk, soft cheeses, and kitchen premises, as well as in birds, crustaceans, fish, shellfish, ticks, and insects.\n\nRefrigerated smoked salmon is a recognized potential source for listeriosis, similar to other cold cut meats and non-heat treated cured smoked meats, being a ready-to-eat product that does not require further cooking before eating.\n\nEven if initial contamination adds only a few _Listeria _ organisms to the food, the contamination can be significant for refrigerated foods, because _Listeria_ can subsequently multiply at refrigerator temperatures to sufficient numbers to cause disease.\n\nGenotyping the clinical isolates from the 3 affected individuals, if they match, will establish whether we are dealing with a common-source outbreak, and genotyping isolates from smoked salmon eaten by the affected individuals would establish transmission pathways, if the genotypes from the smoked salmon and the clinical isolates match. - Denmark, Poland: smoked salmon, recall 20170902.5290728\n.................................................sb/ml/msp/ml", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "listeriosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2019-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-17 00:00:00", "2018-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2017-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Tasmania", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Queensland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Victoria", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Australia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "South Africa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Poland", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "6510327", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis - Europe (04): (UK) nosocomial, fatal, meat sandwiches", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6510327", "date": "2019-02-04 12:50:01", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS - USA: READY-TO-EAT PORK PATTIES, END OF OUTBREAK\n*************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 31 Jan 2019\nSource: Barfblog [edited]\nhttps://www.barfblog.com/2019/01/4-sickened-outbreak-of-listeria-linked-to-pork-products/\n\n\nThe US Centers for Disease Control reports that an outbreak of _Listeria monocytogenes_ infections linked to pork products produced by Long Phung Food Products appears to be over.\n\nOn [20 Nov 2018], 165368 C Corporation of Houston, Texas, doing business as Long Phung Food Products, recalled ready-to-eat pork products because they might have been contaminated with _Listeria_ bacteria.\n\nDo not eat, sell, or serve recalled products from Long Phung Food Products. The full list of recalled ready-to-eat pork patty rolls is on the USDA-FSIS website [https://www.fsis.usda.gov/wps/portal/fsis/topics/recalls-and-public-health-alerts/recall-case-archive/archive/2018/recall-116-2018-release]. Recalled products are labeled with establishment number \"EST. 13561\" inside the USDA [US Department of Agriculture] mark of inspection.\n\nRecalled pork patty rolls were produced on various dates from [21 May 2018, through 16 Nov 2018]. These items were shipped to distributors and retail locations nationwide. Recalled pork products should no longer be available in stores but may still be in home freezers.\n\nWash and sanitize drawers or shelves in refrigerators and freezers where recalled pork products were stored. Follow these 5 steps to clean your refrigerator [see https://www.cdc.gov/foodsafety/communication/clean-refrigerator-steps.html for specifics.]\n\nRetailers should clean and sanitize deli slicers and other areas where recalled pork products were prepared, stored, or served. Follow the manufacturer's recommendations for sanitizer strength and application to ensure it is effective.\n\nIf you develop symptoms of a _Listeria_ infection [see https://www.cdc.gov/listeria/symptoms.html for specifics] after eating recalled pork products, contact a healthcare provider and tell them you ate recalled pork products. This is especially important if you are pregnant, age 65 or older, or have a weakened immune system.\n\nAs of [29 Jan 2019], this outbreak appears to be over.\n\nA total of 4 people infected with the outbreak strain of _Listeria monocytogenes_ were reported from 4 states. _Listeria_ specimens from ill people were collected from [1 Jul 2017, to 24 Oct 2018]. 4 people were hospitalized. No deaths were reported. Epidemiologic and laboratory evidence [see https://www.cdc.gov/foodsafety/outbreaks/investigating-outbreaks/index.html for specifics] indicated that pork products from 165368 C. Corporation, doing business as Long Phung Food Products, were the likely source of the outbreak.\n\n[Byline: Doug Powell]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[An epidemiologic investigation had identified 4 confirmed cases of listeriosis in 4 states, linked to ready-to-eat pork patties. Whole genome sequencing results of samples collected at the Long Phung Food Products facility showed that _Listeria_ identified in the facility was closely related genetically to _Listeria_ isolated from the ill people. On 20 Nov 2018, 165368 C. Corporation, doing business as Long Phung Food Products, recalled ready-to-eat pork products. Listeriosis has a long incubation period, which ranges from 3 to 70 days. 70 days after the product recall on 29 Jan 2019, with no additional cases of listeriosis linked to the outbreak, the CDC declared the outbreak over. - Mod.ML\n\nHealthMap/ProMED map available at:\nUnited States: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/106]\nSee Also\n2018\n----\nListeriosis - USA (03): ready-to-eat pork patties, WGS, recall 20181122.6159661\n.................................................sb/ml/mj/ml", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "listeriosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2019-01-31 00:00:00", "2018-05-21 00:00:00", "2018-11-16 00:00:00", "2019-01-29 00:00:00", "2018-03-16 00:00:00", "2018-11-20 00:00:00", "2019-01-29 00:00:00", "2018-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Texas", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Houston", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "6506263", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis - The full list of recalled ready-to-eat pork patty rolls is on the USDA-FSIS website [https://www.fsis.usda.gov/wps/portal/fsis/topics/recalls-and-public-health-alerts/recall-case-archive/archive/2018/recall-116-2018-release]. Recalled products are labeled with establishment number \"EST. 13561\" inside the USDA [US Department of Agriculture] mark of inspection.\n\nRecalled pork patty rolls were produced on various dates from [21 May 2018, through 16 Nov 2018]. Follow the manufacturer's recommendations for sanitizer strength and application to ensure it is effective.\n\nIf you develop symptoms of a _Listeria_ infection [see https://www.cdc.gov/listeria/symptoms.html for specifics] after eating recalled pork products, contact a healthcare provider and tell them you ate recalled pork products. This is especially important if you are pregnant, age 65 or older, or have a weakened immune system.\n\nAs of [29 Jan 2019], this outbreak appears to be over.\n\nA total of 4 people infected with the outbreak strain of _Listeria monocytogenes_ were reported from 4 states. _Listeria_ specimens from ill people were collected from [1 Jul 2017, to 24 Oct 2018]. 4 people were hospitalized. No deaths were reported. Epidemiologic and laboratory evidence [see https://www.cdc.gov/foodsafety/outbreaks/investigating-outbreaks/index.html for specifics] indicated that pork products from 165368 C. Corporation, doing business as Long Phung Food Products, were the likely source of the outbreak.\n\n[Byline: Doug Powell]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[An epidemiologic investigation had identified 4 confirmed cases of listeriosis in 4 states, linked to ready-to-eat pork patties. Whole genome sequencing results of samples collected at the Long Phung Food Products facility showed that _Listeria_ identified in the facility was closely related genetically to _Listeria_ isolated from the ill people. On 20 Nov 2018, 165368 C. Corporation, doing business as Long Phung Food Products, recalled ready-to-eat pork products. Listeriosis has a long incubation period, which ranges from 3 to 70 days. 70 days after the product recall on 29 Jan 2019, with no additional cases of listeriosis linked to the outbreak, the CDC declared the outbreak over. - The full list of recalled ready-to-eat pork patty rolls is on the USDA-FSIS website [https://www.fsis.usda.gov/wps/portal/fsis/topics/recalls-and-public-health-alerts/recall-case-archive/archive/2018/recall-116-2018-release]. Recalled products are labeled with establishment number \"EST. 13561\" inside the USDA [US Department of Agriculture] mark of inspection.\n\nRecalled pork patty rolls were produced on various dates from [21 May 2018, through 16 Nov 2018]. These items were shipped to distributors and retail locations nationwide. Recalled pork products should no longer be available in stores but may still be in home freezers.\n\nWash and sanitize drawers or shelves in refrigerators and freezers where recalled pork products were stored. Follow the manufacturer's recommendations for sanitizer strength and application to ensure it is effective.\n\nIf you develop symptoms of a _Listeria_ infection [see https://www.cdc.gov/listeria/symptoms.html for specifics] after eating recalled pork products, contact a healthcare provider and tell them you ate recalled pork products. This is especially important if you are pregnant, age 65 or older, or have a weakened immune system.\n\nAs of [29 Jan 2019], this outbreak appears to be over.\n\nA total of 4 people infected with the outbreak strain of _Listeria monocytogenes_ were reported from 4 states. _Listeria_ specimens from ill people were collected from [1 Jul 2017, to 24 Oct 2018]. 4 people were hospitalized. No deaths were reported. Epidemiologic and laboratory evidence [see https://www.cdc.gov/foodsafety/outbreaks/investigating-outbreaks/index.html for specifics] indicated that pork products from 165368 C. Corporation, doing business as Long Phung Food Products, were the likely source of the outbreak.\n\n[Byline: Doug Powell]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[An epidemiologic investigation had identified 4 confirmed cases of listeriosis in 4 states, linked to ready-to-eat pork patties. Epidemiologic and laboratory evidence [see https://www.cdc.gov/foodsafety/outbreaks/investigating-outbreaks/index.html for specifics] indicated that pork products from 165368 C. Corporation, doing business as Long Phung Food Products, were the likely source of the outbreak.\n\n[Byline: Doug Powell]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[An epidemiologic investigation had identified 4 confirmed cases of listeriosis in 4 states, linked to ready-to-eat pork patties. Whole genome sequencing results of samples collected at the Long Phung Food Products facility showed that _Listeria_ identified in the facility was closely related genetically to _Listeria_ isolated from the ill people. On 20 Nov 2018, 165368 C. Corporation, doing business as Long Phung Food Products, recalled ready-to-eat pork products. Listeriosis has a long incubation period, which ranges from 3 to 70 days. 70 days after the product recall on 29 Jan 2019, with no additional cases of listeriosis linked to the outbreak, the CDC declared the outbreak over. - Europe: Denmark, fatal, WGS, smoked fish, ex Estonia, 2016-19", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6383386", "date": "2019-02-04 12:50:01", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS - USA: READY-TO-EAT PORK PATTIES, END OF OUTBREAK\n*************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 31 Jan 2019\nSource: Barfblog [edited]\nhttps://www.barfblog.com/2019/01/4-sickened-outbreak-of-listeria-linked-to-pork-products/\n\n\nThe US Centers for Disease Control reports that an outbreak of _Listeria monocytogenes_ infections linked to pork products produced by Long Phung Food Products appears to be over.\n\nOn [20 Nov 2018], 165368 C Corporation of Houston, Texas, doing business as Long Phung Food Products, recalled ready-to-eat pork products because they might have been contaminated with _Listeria_ bacteria.\n\nDo not eat, sell, or serve recalled products from Long Phung Food Products. The full list of recalled ready-to-eat pork patty rolls is on the USDA-FSIS website [https://www.fsis.usda.gov/wps/portal/fsis/topics/recalls-and-public-health-alerts/recall-case-archive/archive/2018/recall-116-2018-release]. Recalled products are labeled with establishment number \"EST. 13561\" inside the USDA [US Department of Agriculture] mark of inspection.\n\nRecalled pork patty rolls were produced on various dates from [21 May 2018, through 16 Nov 2018]. These items were shipped to distributors and retail locations nationwide. Recalled pork products should no longer be available in stores but may still be in home freezers.\n\nWash and sanitize drawers or shelves in refrigerators and freezers where recalled pork products were stored. Follow these 5 steps to clean your refrigerator [see https://www.cdc.gov/foodsafety/communication/clean-refrigerator-steps.html for specifics.]\n\nRetailers should clean and sanitize deli slicers and other areas where recalled pork products were prepared, stored, or served. Follow the manufacturer's recommendations for sanitizer strength and application to ensure it is effective.\n\nIf you develop symptoms of a _Listeria_ infection [see https://www.cdc.gov/listeria/symptoms.html for specifics] after eating recalled pork products, contact a healthcare provider and tell them you ate recalled pork products. This is especially important if you are pregnant, age 65 or older, or have a weakened immune system.\n\nAs of [29 Jan 2019], this outbreak appears to be over.\n\nA total of 4 people infected with the outbreak strain of _Listeria monocytogenes_ were reported from 4 states. _Listeria_ specimens from ill people were collected from [1 Jul 2017, to 24 Oct 2018]. 4 people were hospitalized. No deaths were reported. Epidemiologic and laboratory evidence [see https://www.cdc.gov/foodsafety/outbreaks/investigating-outbreaks/index.html for specifics] indicated that pork products from 165368 C. Corporation, doing business as Long Phung Food Products, were the likely source of the outbreak.\n\n[Byline: Doug Powell]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[An epidemiologic investigation had identified 4 confirmed cases of listeriosis in 4 states, linked to ready-to-eat pork patties.
