South Africa (11): fatal, ST6, WHO response", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5718496", "date": "2018-03-30 13:06:17", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS - SOUTH AFRICA (11): FATAL, ST6, WHO RESPONSE\n*********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 28 Mar 2018\nSource: WHO Emergencies preparedness, response, Disease Outbreak News (DONs) [edited]\nhttp://www.who.int/csr/don/28-march-2018-listeriosis-south-africa/en/\n\n\nIn South Africa, an outbreak of listeriosis, a serious foodborne disease, has been ongoing since the start of 2017. Between 1 Jan 2017 through 14 Mar 2018, 978 laboratory-confirmed listeriosis cases have been reported to the National Institute for Communicable Diseases (NICD) from all provinces. The majority of cases have come from 3 provinces: 581 (59 percent) from Gauteng, 118 (12 percent) from Western Cape and 70 (7 percent) from KwaZulu-Natal provinces, with the remaining cases coming from the other provinces in South Africa.\n\nThe outcome of illness is known for 674 patients, of whom 183 (27 percent) of them died; this case fatality rate is comparable to other recorded listeriosis outbreaks worldwide. Most of the cases are persons who have higher risks for a severe disease outcome, such as neonates, pregnant women, the elderly and immunocompromised persons. In this outbreak, 42 percent of the cases are neonates who were infected during pregnancy or delivery.\n\nWhole genome sequencing was performed on isolates from a large subset of patients. 91 percent of the strains belonged to _Listeria monocytogenes_ Sequence Type 6 (ST6). The same ST6 sequence type was identified in a widely consumed ready-to-eat processed meat product called \"Polony\" [Bologna sausage]. The same strain was also found in the processing environment of the manufacturer of the implicated product.\n\nOn 4 Mar 2018, the Ministry of Health, announced that this product was believed to be the source of the outbreak.\n\nThe food processing company and 3 of its retailers export to 15 countries (1) in the African region. All of these countries have issued recalls for the implicated products.\n\nEnvironmental samples from other food production companies in South Africa have also tested positive for _Listeria_, but with strains different from the outbreak strain. These companies have also issued food recalls. Some of their products have been exported to some of the countries mentioned above.\n\n9 percent of the reported cases in the present outbreak in South Africa were infected with different strains of _Listeria_ than the predominant ST6 outbreak strain. This may indicate that more than one outbreak is ongoing. Comprehensive investigations to identify the source of infection of these cases should be conducted.\n\nPublic health response\n----------------------\nThe country has activated a national multisectoral task force to coordinate investigation and response activities:\nThe Minister of Health, South Africa, held a press conference on 4 Mar 2018 to announce the source of the outbreak. Following the source identification, the national authorities have taken measures to limit further infections and associated mortality, including but not limited to the issuance of safety recall notices, compliance notices, and measures related to exportation of implicated products and risk communication with vulnerable groups.\n\nThe Southern African Development Community (SADC) Health Ministers held a meeting in Johannesburg on 15 Mar 2018, to share information and to enhance preparedness and response for listeriosis. Health Ministers were further reminded about their rights and obligations under the International Health Regulations (IHR) with regards to additional health measures for international travel and trade.\n\nListeriosis has been made a notifiable medical condition in South Africa since December 2017. National risk communication activities have been initiated since December 2017 around the \"WHO five keys to safer food messages.\"\n\nWHO risk assessment\n-------------------\nGlobally, this is the largest outbreak of listeriosis that has been detected. Due to the potentially long incubation period of listeriosis (1 to 3 weeks and up to 70 days) further cases are expected before the impact of the food recall is observed.\n\nFollowing the identification of the source of this outbreak, WHO is now concerned that the export of implicated products may have resulted in listeriosis cases in other countries. Detailed information on the implicated product batches exported to each of the identified 15 countries should be shared with WHO and the International Food Safety Authorities Network (INFOSAN) Secretariat. This will help to facilitate efficient recalls of these products.\n\nRecently, Namibia reported a confirmed case of listeriosis. It is important that this case and other possible cases be properly investigated and the implicated food sources identified. The isolated _Listeria_ strains should be sequenced to determine potential links to the outbreak in South Africa. Some of these countries may not have well-established surveillance systems and laboratory diagnostic services in place to detect cases of listeriosis. In such cases, WHO is ready to provide support and has reached out to 16 African nations (2 West African countries and 14 members of SADC) to provide support for preparedness and response.\n\nAn increase in public concern about the outbreak has been reflected in media reports and discussions in various social media platforms.\n\nWHO advice\n----------\nCountries should strengthen national food safety and disease surveillance systems as a prerequisite to prevent similar events in the future and to ensure a safe food supply for their populations. Additionally, countries are urged to pay closer attention to common foodborne pathogens such as _Salmonella_ species, _Campylobacter jejuni_, _Escherichia coli_, and _Listeria monocytogenes_, to make listeriosis a notifiable disease if not yet done, to make the best use of a new \"WHO manual to strengthen surveillance of and response to foodborne diseases,\" which was published in November 2017 and to refer to the \"WHO Factsheet on Listeriosis\". See below, in the \"Further Information\" section for links to these documents.\n\nResponsible authorities are encouraged to proactively provide public health advice on the prevention and control of listeriosis, including, strengthened risk communication, to address public concerns and promote outbreak control measures.\n\nWHO does not currently recommend any travel or trade restrictions in relation to this outbreak, other than the recall of processed meat products indicated by the South African Government.\n\nWhile WHO understands the desire by sovereign governments to take measures to protect the health of their populations, States Parties to the IHR have obligations not to take actions that significantly interfere with international travel and trade which are not based on scientific principles and which may be viewed as excessive. Indeed such measures contravene the spirit and purpose of the IHR, and can impede public health objectives.\n\nCurrently, 12 out of 15 countries have recalled the implicated processed meat products, and banned imports of the same, while 3 out of these countries have additionally banned imports of other food products. WHO continues to monitor the travel and trade measures taken by countries in relation to this outbreak and their compliance with requirements under the IHR.\n\nFor travellers, it is advisable to practice good food hygiene, such as avoiding uncooked food, avoiding food that has been kept at room temperature for several hours, and always washing hands thoroughly with soap and water before preparing or consuming food.\n\n1. The 15 countries include: Angola, Botswana, Democratic Republic of the Congo, Ghana, Lesotho, Madagascar, Malawi, Mauritius, Mozambique, Namibia, Nigeria, Swaziland, Uganda, Zambia, and Zimbabwe.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[HealthMap/ProMED-mail map\nSouth Africa: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/179]\nSee Also\nListeriosis - South Africa (03): fatal, increasing incidence, genotyping 20171206.5487695\nListeriosis - South Africa (02): fatal, increasing incidence, RFI 20171205.5484927\nListeriosis - South Africa: increasing incidence 20171025.5402225\n.................................................sb/ml/mj/jh", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "listeriosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-11 00:00:00", "2018-03-16 00:00:00", "2017-03-16 00:00:00", "2018-03-16 00:00:00", "2018-03-16 00:00:00", "2018-03-16 00:00:00", "2017-12-16 00:00:00", "2017-12-16 00:00:00", "2017-11-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2017-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Democratic Republic of the", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Namibia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Listeriosis - Namibia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "South Africa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Swaziland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Gauteng", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mozambique", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Zimbabwe", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Angola", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Uganda", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Nigeria", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Zambia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Botswana", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Johannesburg", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Lesotho", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ghana", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Congo", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "FATAL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Vienna", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Madagascar", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5709796", "headline": "PRO> Listeriosis - Europe (02): background", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5709796", "date": "2018-03-05 12:14:13", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS - SOUTH AFRICA (09): FATAL, HEALTH DEPARTMENT PRESS RELEASE\n***********************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sun 4 Mar 2018\nFrom: Charlene Jacobs <charlenea.jacobs@westerncape.gov.za> [edited]\n\n\nPress conference media statement from the Minister of Health Dr Aaron Motsoaledi, Department of Health, Republic of South Africa, regarding the update on the listeriosis outbreak in South Africa\n----------------------------------------------------------------------\n\"The situation now is as follows:\n\n\"As of [2 mar 2018], the total of laboratory-confirmed cases has risen to 948, still counting from January 2017. Of these 948, a total 659 patients have been traced and 180 of them have unfortunately died. This constitutes a 27 percent case fatality rate.\n\nIn our constant search for the source of the outbreak and the treatment of people who are affected, a team from the NICD [National Institute for Communicable Diseases] has interviewed 109 ill people to obtain details about foods they had eaten in the month before falling ill. 93 (85 percent) people reported eating ready-to-eat (RTE) processed meat products, of which polony was the most common, followed by viennas/sausages and then other 'cold meats'.\n\n\"On [Fri 12 Jan 2018], 9 children under the age of 5 years presented to Chris Hani Baragwanath Hospital with febrile gastroenteritis. The paediatrician suspected foodborne disease, including listeriosis, as a possible cause. The environmental health practitioners (EHPs) were informed and on the same day visited the cr\u00e8che, and obtained samples from 2 unrelated polony brands (manufactured by Enterprise and Rainbow Chicken Limited (RCL) respectively) and submitted these to the laboratory for testing.\n\n\"_Listeria monocytogenes_ was isolated from stool collected from one of the ill children, and from both of the polony specimens collected from the cr\u00e8che. These isolates were sent to the NICD Centre for Enteric Diseases, and underwent whole genome sequencing and genomic analysis. The ST6 sequence type was confirmed on all 3 isolates on [Sat 27 Jan 2018]. Remember that in the last press conference I informed you that from clinical isolates obtained from patients (patient blood), 9 sequence types of _L. monocytogenes_ were isolated and 91 percent were of sequence type 6 (ST6). We had then concluded that time that this outbreak is driven by ST6.\n\n\"I wish to further remind you that we had then taken a decision to visit all food-processing sites, food-packaging sites, as well as food production sites where possible.\n\n\"Following the lead from the tests performed on these children from Soweto and the food they had ingested, the EHPs, together with the NICD and DAFF representatives, accompanied by 3 technical advisors from the World Health Organisation in Geneva, visited a food-production site in Polokwane and conducted an extensive food product and environmental sampling.\n\n_L. monocytogenes_ was isolated from over 30 percent of the environmental samples collected from this site, which happens to be the Enterprise factory in Polokwane.\n\nTo conclude the investigation, whole genome sequencing analysis was performed from this Enterprise factory and the results became available midnight or last night [3 Mar 2018]. The outbreak strain, ST6, was confirmed in at least 16 environmental samples collected from this Enterprise facility.\n\n\"The conclusion from this is that the source of the present outbreak can be confirmed to be the Enterprise food-production facility in Polokwane.\n\n\"Additionally, preliminary results show that several ready-to-eat processed meat products from the Enterprise facility located in Germiston contain _L. monocytogenes_, but the sequence type is not known as yet.\n\n\"Investigation of the RCL Wolwehoek production facility is also underway. Polony products have tested positive for _L. monocytogenes_, but the sequence types of the isolates are NOT ST6. However, such contamination of ready-to-eat processed meat products constitutes a health risk. Also, over 10 percent of environmental samples collected by EHPs at this facility have tested positive for _L. monocytogenes_. The sequence types of these isolates are not known as yet.\n\n\"With the information at our disposal, we have decided on the following course of action:\n\"1. The National Consumer Commission (NCC) has in terms of Section 60(2) of the Consumer Protection Act this morning [4 Mar 2018] issued the manufacturers concerned with safety recall notices.\n\n\"Section 60(2) of the Consumer Protection Act states that:\nIf the NCC has reasonable grounds to believe that any goods may be unsafe, or that there is a potential risk to the public from the continued use of or exposure to the goods, and the producer or importer of those goods has not taken any steps required by an applicable code contemplated in subsection the Commission, by written notice, may require that producer to:\n(a) conduct an investigation contemplated in subsection (1); or\n(b) carry out a recall programme on any terms required by the Commission.\n\n\"The NCC will prepare a recall strategy in conjunction with the manufacturers and make further announcements to the public in due course.\nThe safety recall will affect the manufacturers' entire distribution networks, both domestic and international.\n\n\"2. Compliance notices will be issued to facilities in terms of the National Health Act.\nEnvironmental Health Practitioners appointed in terms of section 80(1) of the Act and duly registered as such in terms of section 83(5) of the National Health Amendment Act, 2013 (Act No. 12 of 2013) should upon finding that there are in terms of section 83 (1) and (2), existing conditions which:\n(a) constitutes a violation of the right contained in section 24(a) of the Constitution;\n(b) constitutes pollution detrimental to health;\n(c) is likely to cause a health nuisance; or\n(d) constitutes a health nuisance,\n\n\"3. In terms of registration for exports by the Department of Agriculture, Forestry and Fisheries (DAFF), the respective processing or manufacturing establishments namely RCL Foods with an export registration number ZA32 and Enterprise Foods with an export registration number ZA 33 have been temporarily suspected [suspended?] till further notice.\n\n\"4. We advise members of the public to avoid all processed meat products that are sold as ready-to-eat. While we know that polony is definitely implicated, there is a risk of cross-contamination of other ready-to-eat processed meat products, either at production, distribution or retail. This is because _Listeria_ on the exterior casing (packaging) of polony can be transferred to other products it comes into contact with, including viennas, russians, frankfurters, other sausages, and other 'cold meat' products that are typically not cooked before eating.\n\n\"Just a reminder that people at high risk for listeriosis include:\n- pregnant women;\n- neonates (1st 28 days of life);\n- very young infants;\n- elderly persons, older than 65 years of age, and\n- anyone with a weakened immune system (due to HIV infection, cancer, diabetes, kidney disease, liver disease, people with transplants and those on immunosuppressive therapy such as oral corticosteroids, chemotherapy, or anti-TNF therapy for auto-immune disease).\n\n\"The recall of these products does not mean that members of the public must now relax and stop the 5 food-safety rules, which we have recited many times, that is, washing your hands before handling food or when coming back from the bathroom; making sure that food is well cooked; isolating raw food from cooked food; making sure that food is at an appropriate temperature; and washing non-cooked food with clean running water; as well as using only pasteurised or boiled milk products.\n\n\"It means that the general status of hygiene of the population must still be a matter of priority to society as a whole, and must remain like that forever.\"\n\n\"For media enquiries, please contact:\nMr Popo Maja\nHead of Communications\nNational Department of Health\nCell: 0725853219/012 395 9591\nFoster Mohale\nDirector: Media Relations\nNational Department of Health\nCell: 0724323792/012 395 8180\n<Foster.mohale@health.gov.za>\"\n\n--\nCharlene Jacobs\n<charlenea.jacobs@westerncape.gov.za>\n\n[ProMED-mail thanks Charlene Jacobs for the official press conference media statement from Dr Aaron Motsoaledi, South Africa Minister of Health on the listeriosis outbreak in South Africa. - Australia (03): fatal, cantaloupe, more cases", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5691654", "date": "2018-03-05 12:14:13", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS - SOUTH AFRICA (09): FATAL, HEALTH DEPARTMENT PRESS RELEASE\n***********************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sun 4 Mar 2018\nFrom: Charlene Jacobs <charlenea.jacobs@westerncape.gov.za> [edited]\n\n\nPress conference media statement from the Minister of Health Dr Aaron Motsoaledi, Department of Health, Republic of South Africa, regarding the update on the listeriosis outbreak in South Africa\n----------------------------------------------------------------------\n\"The situation now is as follows:\n\n\"As of [2 mar 2018], the total of laboratory-confirmed cases has risen to 948, still counting from January 2017. Of these 948, a total 659 patients have been traced and 180 of them have unfortunately died. This constitutes a 27 percent case fatality rate.\n\nIn our constant search for the source of the outbreak and the treatment of people who are affected, a team from the NICD [National Institute for Communicable Diseases] has interviewed 109 ill people to obtain details about foods they had eaten in the month before falling ill. 93 (85 percent) people reported eating ready-to-eat (RTE) processed meat products, of which polony was the most common, followed by viennas/sausages and then other 'cold meats'.\n\n\"On [Fri 12 Jan 2018], 9 children under the age of 5 years presented to Chris Hani Baragwanath Hospital with febrile gastroenteritis. The paediatrician suspected foodborne disease, including listeriosis, as a possible cause. The environmental health practitioners (EHPs) were informed and on the same day visited the cr\u00e8che, and obtained samples from 2 unrelated polony brands (manufactured by Enterprise and Rainbow Chicken Limited (RCL) respectively) and submitted these to the laboratory for testing.\n\n\"_Listeria monocytogenes_ was isolated from stool collected from one of the ill children, and from both of the polony specimens collected from the cr\u00e8che. These isolates were sent to the NICD Centre for Enteric Diseases, and underwent whole genome sequencing and genomic analysis. The ST6 sequence type was confirmed on all 3 isolates on [Sat 27 Jan 2018]. Remember that in the last press conference I informed you that from clinical isolates obtained from patients (patient blood), 9 sequence types of _L. monocytogenes_ were isolated and 91 percent were of sequence type 6 (ST6). We had then concluded that time that this outbreak is driven by ST6.\n\n\"I wish to further remind you that we had then taken a decision to visit all food-processing sites, food-packaging sites, as well as food production sites where possible.\n\n\"Following the lead from the tests performed on these children from Soweto and the food they had ingested, the EHPs, together with the NICD and DAFF representatives, accompanied by 3 technical advisors from the World Health Organisation in Geneva, visited a food-production site in Polokwane and conducted an extensive food product and environmental sampling.\n\n_L. monocytogenes_ was isolated from over 30 percent of the environmental samples collected from this site, which happens to be the Enterprise factory in Polokwane.\n\nTo conclude the investigation, whole genome sequencing analysis was performed from this Enterprise factory and the results became available midnight or last night [3 Mar 2018]. The outbreak strain, ST6, was confirmed in at least 16 environmental samples collected from this Enterprise facility.\n\n\"The conclusion from this is that the source of the present outbreak can be confirmed to be the Enterprise food-production facility in Polokwane.\n\n\"Additionally, preliminary results show that several ready-to-eat processed meat products from the Enterprise facility located in Germiston contain _L. monocytogenes_, but the sequence type is not known as yet.\n\n\"Investigation of the RCL Wolwehoek production facility is also underway. Polony products have tested positive for _L. monocytogenes_, but the sequence types of the isolates are NOT ST6. However, such contamination of ready-to-eat processed meat products constitutes a health risk. Also, over 10 percent of environmental samples collected by EHPs at this facility have tested positive for _L. monocytogenes_. The sequence types of these isolates are not known as yet.\n\n\"With the information at our disposal, we have decided on the following course of action:\n\"1. The National Consumer Commission (NCC) has in terms of Section 60(2) of the Consumer Protection Act this morning [4 Mar 2018] issued the manufacturers concerned with safety recall notices.\n\n\"Section 60(2) of the Consumer Protection Act states that:\nIf the NCC has reasonable grounds to believe that any goods may be unsafe, or that there is a potential risk to the public from the continued use of or exposure to the goods, and the producer or importer of those goods has not taken any steps required by an applicable code contemplated in subsection the Commission, by written notice, may require that producer to:\n(a) conduct an investigation contemplated in subsection (1); or\n(b) carry out a recall programme on any terms required by the Commission.\n\n\"The NCC will prepare a recall strategy in conjunction with the manufacturers and make further announcements to the public in due course.\nThe safety recall will affect the manufacturers' entire distribution networks, both domestic and international.\n\n\"2. Compliance notices will be issued to facilities in terms of the National Health Act.\nEnvironmental Health Practitioners appointed in terms of section 80(1) of the Act and duly registered as such in terms of section 83(5) of the National Health Amendment Act, 2013 (Act No. 12 of 2013) should upon finding that there are in terms of section 83 (1) and (2), existing conditions which:\n(a) constitutes a violation of the right contained in section 24(a) of the Constitution;\n(b) constitutes pollution detrimental to health;\n(c) is likely to cause a health nuisance; or\n(d) constitutes a health nuisance,\n\n\"3. In terms of registration for exports by the Department of Agriculture, Forestry and Fisheries (DAFF), the respective processing or manufacturing establishments namely RCL Foods with an export registration number ZA32 and Enterprise Foods with an export registration number ZA 33 have been temporarily suspected [suspended?] till further notice.\n\n\"4. We advise members of the public to avoid all processed meat products that are sold as ready-to-eat. While we know that polony is definitely implicated, there is a risk of cross-contamination of other ready-to-eat processed meat products, either at production, distribution or retail. This is because _Listeria_ on the exterior casing (packaging) of polony can be transferred to other products it comes into contact with, including viennas, russians, frankfurters, other sausages, and other 'cold meat' products that are typically not cooked before eating.\n\n\"Just a reminder that people at high risk for listeriosis include:\n- pregnant women;\n- neonates (1st 28 days of life);\n- very young infants;\n- elderly persons, older than 65 years of age, and\n- anyone with a weakened immune system (due to HIV infection, cancer, diabetes, kidney disease, liver disease, people with transplants and those on immunosuppressive therapy such as oral corticosteroids, chemotherapy, or anti-TNF therapy for auto-immune disease).\n\n\"The recall of these products does not mean that members of the public must now relax and stop the 5 food-safety rules, which we have recited many times, that is, washing your hands before handling food or when coming back from the bathroom; making sure that food is well cooked; isolating raw food from cooked food; making sure that food is at an appropriate temperature; and washing non-cooked food with clean running water; as well as using only pasteurised or boiled milk products.\n\n\"It means that the general status of hygiene of the population must still be a matter of priority to society as a whole, and must remain like that forever.\"\n\n\"For media enquiries, please contact:\nMr Popo Maja\nHead of Communications\nNational Department of Health\nCell: 0725853219/012 395 9591\nFoster Mohale\nDirector: Media Relations\nNational Department of Health\nCell: 0724323792/012 395 8180\n<Foster.mohale@health.gov.za>\"\n\n--\nCharlene Jacobs\n<charlenea.jacobs@westerncape.gov.za>\n\n[ProMED-mail thanks Charlene Jacobs for the official press conference media statement from Dr Aaron Motsoaledi, South Africa Minister of Health on the listeriosis outbreak in South Africa. - Mod.ML\n\nHealthMap: South Africa: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/179]\nSee Also\nListeriosis - South Africa (08): fatal, more cases, source found, polony 20180305.5665592\nListeriosis - South Africa (07): fatal, more cases 20180224.5648305\nListeriosis - South Africa (06): fatal, more cases 20180218.5635764\nListeriosis - South Africa (05): fatal, more cases 20180131.5596282\nListeriosis - South Africa (04): comment 20180126.5586393\nListeriosis - South Africa (03): fatal, increasing incidence, ST6 20180122.5577247\nListeriosis - South Africa (02): fatal, increasing incidence, ST6 20180117.5566300\nListeriosis - South Africa: fatal, increasing incidence, ST6 20180108.5545556\n2017\n----\nListeriosis - South Africa (04): fatal, increasing incidence 20171217.5508986\nListeriosis - South Africa (03): fatal, increasing incidence, genotyping 20171206.5487695\nListeriosis - South Africa (02): fatal, increasing incidence, RFI 20171205.5484927\nListeriosis - South Africa: increasing incidence 20171025.5402225\n.................................................lm/ml/mj/lxl", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "listeriosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2017-01-16 00:00:00", "2018-03-16 00:00:00", "2018-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2017-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Soweto", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "South Africa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Geneva", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Polokwane", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5691653", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis - South Africa (10): fatal, more cases", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5691653", "date": "2018-03-05 12:14:13", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS - SOUTH AFRICA (09): FATAL, HEALTH DEPARTMENT PRESS RELEASE\n***********************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sun 4 Mar 2018\nFrom: Charlene Jacobs <charlenea.jacobs@westerncape.gov.za> [edited]\n\n\nPress conference media statement from the Minister of Health Dr Aaron Motsoaledi, Department of Health, Republic of South Africa, regarding the update on the listeriosis outbreak in South Africa\n----------------------------------------------------------------------\n\"The situation now is as follows:\n\n\"As of [2 mar 2018], the total of laboratory-confirmed cases has risen to 948, still counting from January 2017. Of these 948, a total 659 patients have been traced and 180 of them have unfortunately died. This constitutes a 27 percent case fatality rate.\n\nIn our constant search for the source of the outbreak and the treatment of people who are affected, a team from the NICD [National Institute for Communicable Diseases] has interviewed 109 ill people to obtain details about foods they had eaten in the month before falling ill. 93 (85 percent) people reported eating ready-to-eat (RTE) processed meat products, of which polony was the most common, followed by viennas/sausages and then other 'cold meats'.\n\n\"On [Fri 12 Jan 2018], 9 children under the age of 5 years presented to Chris Hani Baragwanath Hospital with febrile gastroenteritis. The paediatrician suspected foodborne disease, including listeriosis, as a possible cause. The environmental health practitioners (EHPs) were informed and on the same day visited the cr\u00e8che, and obtained samples from 2 unrelated polony brands (manufactured by Enterprise and Rainbow Chicken Limited (RCL) respectively) and submitted these to the laboratory for testing.\n\n\"_Listeria monocytogenes_ was isolated from stool collected from one of the ill children, and from both of the polony specimens collected from the cr\u00e8che. These isolates were sent to the NICD Centre for Enteric Diseases, and underwent whole genome sequencing and genomic analysis. The ST6 sequence type was confirmed on all 3 isolates on [Sat 27 Jan 2018]. Remember that in the last press conference I informed you that from clinical isolates obtained from patients (patient blood), 9 sequence types of _L. monocytogenes_ were isolated and 91 percent were of sequence type 6 (ST6). We had then concluded that time that this outbreak is driven by ST6.\n\n\"I wish to further remind you that we had then taken a decision to visit all food-processing sites, food-packaging sites, as well as food production sites where possible.\n\n\"Following the lead from the tests performed on these children from Soweto and the food they had ingested, the EHPs, together with the NICD and DAFF representatives, accompanied by 3 technical advisors from the World Health Organisation in Geneva, visited a food-production site in Polokwane and conducted an extensive food product and environmental sampling.\n\n_L. monocytogenes_ was isolated from over 30 percent of the environmental samples collected from this site, which happens to be the Enterprise factory in Polokwane.\n\nTo conclude the investigation, whole genome sequencing analysis was performed from this Enterprise factory and the results became available midnight or last night [3 Mar 2018]. The outbreak strain, ST6, was confirmed in at least 16 environmental samples collected from this Enterprise facility.\n\n\"The conclusion from this is that the source of the present outbreak can be confirmed to be the Enterprise food-production facility in Polokwane.\n\n\"Additionally, preliminary results show that several ready-to-eat processed meat products from the Enterprise facility located in Germiston contain _L. monocytogenes_, but the sequence type is not known as yet.\n\n\"Investigation of the RCL Wolwehoek production facility is also underway. Polony products have tested positive for _L. monocytogenes_, but the sequence types of the isolates are NOT ST6. However, such contamination of ready-to-eat processed meat products constitutes a health risk. Also, over 10 percent of environmental samples collected by EHPs at this facility have tested positive for _L. monocytogenes_. The sequence types of these isolates are not known as yet.\n\n\"With the information at our disposal, we have decided on the following course of action:\n\"1. The National Consumer Commission (NCC) has in terms of Section 60(2) of the Consumer Protection Act this morning [4 Mar 2018] issued the manufacturers concerned with safety recall notices.\n\n\"Section 60(2) of the Consumer Protection Act states that:\nIf the NCC has reasonable grounds to believe that any goods may be unsafe, or that there is a potential risk to the public from the continued use of or exposure to the goods, and the producer or importer of those goods has not taken any steps required by an applicable code contemplated in subsection the Commission, by written notice, may require that producer to:\n(a) conduct an investigation contemplated in subsection (1); or\n(b) carry out a recall programme on any terms required by the Commission.\n\n\"The NCC will prepare a recall strategy in conjunction with the manufacturers and make further announcements to the public in due course.\nThe safety recall will affect the manufacturers' entire distribution networks, both domestic and international.\n\n\"2. Compliance notices will be issued to facilities in terms of the National Health Act.\nEnvironmental Health Practitioners appointed in terms of section 80(1) of the Act and duly registered as such in terms of section 83(5) of the National Health Amendment Act, 2013 (Act No. 12 of 2013) should upon finding that there are in terms of section 83 (1) and (2), existing conditions which:\n(a) constitutes a violation of the right contained in section 24(a) of the Constitution;\n(b) constitutes pollution detrimental to health;\n(c) is likely to cause a health nuisance; or\n(d) constitutes a health nuisance,\n\n\"3. In terms of registration for exports by the Department of Agriculture, Forestry and Fisheries (DAFF), the respective processing or manufacturing establishments namely RCL Foods with an export registration number ZA32 and Enterprise Foods with an export registration number ZA 33 have been temporarily suspected [suspended?] till further notice.\n\n\"4. We advise members of the public to avoid all processed meat products that are sold as ready-to-eat. While we know that polony is definitely implicated, there is a risk of cross-contamination of other ready-to-eat processed meat products, either at production, distribution or retail. This is because _Listeria_ on the exterior casing (packaging) of polony can be transferred to other products it comes into contact with, including viennas, russians, frankfurters, other sausages, and other 'cold meat' products that are typically not cooked before eating.\n\n\"Just a reminder that people at high risk for listeriosis include:\n- pregnant women;\n- neonates (1st 28 days of life);\n- very young infants;\n- elderly persons, older than 65 years of age, and\n- anyone with a weakened immune system (due to HIV infection, cancer, diabetes, kidney disease, liver disease, people with transplants and those on immunosuppressive therapy such as oral corticosteroids, chemotherapy, or anti-TNF therapy for auto-immune disease).\n\n\"The recall of these products does not mean that members of the public must now relax and stop the 5 food-safety rules, which we have recited many times, that is, washing your hands before handling food or when coming back from the bathroom; making sure that food is well cooked; isolating raw food from cooked food; making sure that food is at an appropriate temperature; and washing non-cooked food with clean running water; as well as using only pasteurised or boiled milk products.\n\n\"It means that the general status of hygiene of the population must still be a matter of priority to society as a whole, and must remain like that forever.\"\n\n\"For media enquiries, please contact:\nMr Popo Maja\nHead of Communications\nNational Department of Health\nCell: 0725853219/012 395 9591\nFoster Mohale\nDirector: Media Relations\nNational Department of Health\nCell: 0724323792/012 395 8180\n<Foster.mohale@health.gov.za>\"\n\n--\nCharlene Jacobs\n<charlenea.jacobs@westerncape.gov.za>\n\n[ProMED-mail thanks Charlene Jacobs for the official press conference media statement from Dr Aaron Motsoaledi, South Africa Minister of Health on the listeriosis outbreak in South Africa. - Singapore: Australian rockmelons, NOT", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5678316", "date": "2018-03-05 12:14:13", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS - SOUTH AFRICA (09): FATAL, HEALTH DEPARTMENT PRESS RELEASE\n***********************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sun 4 Mar 2018\nFrom: Charlene Jacobs <charlenea.jacobs@westerncape.gov.za> [edited]\n\n\nPress conference media statement from the Minister of Health Dr Aaron Motsoaledi, Department of Health, Republic of South Africa, regarding the update on the listeriosis outbreak in South Africa\n----------------------------------------------------------------------\n\"The situation now is as follows:\n\n\"As of [2 mar 2018], the total of laboratory-confirmed cases has risen to 948, still counting from January 2017. Of these 948, a total 659 patients have been traced and 180 of them have unfortunately died. This constitutes a 27 percent case fatality rate.\n\nIn our constant search for the source of the outbreak and the treatment of people who are affected, a team from the NICD [National Institute for Communicable Diseases] has interviewed 109 ill people to obtain details about foods they had eaten in the month before falling ill. 93 (85 percent) people reported eating ready-to-eat (RTE) processed meat products, of which polony was the most common, followed by viennas/sausages and then other 'cold meats'.\n\n\"On [Fri 12 Jan 2018], 9 children under the age of 5 years presented to Chris Hani Baragwanath Hospital with febrile gastroenteritis. The paediatrician suspected foodborne disease, including listeriosis, as a possible cause. The environmental health practitioners (EHPs) were informed and on the same day visited the cr\u00e8che, and obtained samples from 2 unrelated polony brands (manufactured by Enterprise and Rainbow Chicken Limited (RCL) respectively) and submitted these to the laboratory for testing.\n\n\"_Listeria monocytogenes_ was isolated from stool collected from one of the ill children, and from both of the polony specimens collected from the cr\u00e8che. These isolates were sent to the NICD Centre for Enteric Diseases, and underwent whole genome sequencing and genomic analysis. The ST6 sequence type was confirmed on all 3 isolates on [Sat 27 Jan 2018]. Remember that in the last press conference I informed you that from clinical isolates obtained from patients (patient blood), 9 sequence types of _L. monocytogenes_ were isolated and 91 percent were of sequence type 6 (ST6). We had then concluded that time that this outbreak is driven by ST6.\n\n\"I wish to further remind you that we had then taken a decision to visit all food-processing sites, food-packaging sites, as well as food production sites where possible.\n\n\"Following the lead from the tests performed on these children from Soweto and the food they had ingested, the EHPs, together with the NICD and DAFF representatives, accompanied by 3 technical advisors from the World Health Organisation in Geneva, visited a food-production site in Polokwane and conducted an extensive food product and environmental sampling.\n\n_L. monocytogenes_ was isolated from over 30 percent of the environmental samples collected from this site, which happens to be the Enterprise factory in Polokwane.\n\nTo conclude the investigation, whole genome sequencing analysis was performed from this Enterprise factory and the results became available midnight or last night [3 Mar 2018]. The outbreak strain, ST6, was confirmed in at least 16 environmental samples collected from this Enterprise facility.\n\n\"The conclusion from this is that the source of the present outbreak can be confirmed to be the Enterprise food-production facility in Polokwane.\n\n\"Additionally, preliminary results show that several ready-to-eat processed meat products from the Enterprise facility located in Germiston contain _L. monocytogenes_, but the sequence type is not known as yet.\n\n\"Investigation of the RCL Wolwehoek production facility is also underway. Polony products have tested positive for _L. monocytogenes_, but the sequence types of the isolates are NOT ST6. However, such contamination of ready-to-eat processed meat products constitutes a health risk. Also, over 10 percent of environmental samples collected by EHPs at this facility have tested positive for _L. monocytogenes_. The sequence types of these isolates are not known as yet.\n\n\"With the information at our disposal, we have decided on the following course of action:\n\"1. The National Consumer Commission (NCC) has in terms of Section 60(2) of the Consumer Protection Act this morning [4 Mar 2018] issued the manufacturers concerned with safety recall notices.\n\n\"Section 60(2) of the Consumer Protection Act states that:\nIf the NCC has reasonable grounds to believe that any goods may be unsafe, or that there is a potential risk to the public from the continued use of or exposure to the goods, and the producer or importer of those goods has not taken any steps required by an applicable code contemplated in subsection the Commission, by written notice, may require that producer to:\n(a) conduct an investigation contemplated in subsection (1); or\n(b) carry out a recall programme on any terms required by the Commission.\n\n\"The NCC will prepare a recall strategy in conjunction with the manufacturers and make further announcements to the public in due course.\nThe safety recall will affect the manufacturers' entire distribution networks, both domestic and international.\n\n\"2. Compliance notices will be issued to facilities in terms of the National Health Act.\nEnvironmental Health Practitioners appointed in terms of section 80(1) of the Act and duly registered as such in terms of section 83(5) of the National Health Amendment Act, 2013 (Act No. 12 of 2013) should upon finding that there are in terms of section 83 (1) and (2), existing conditions which:\n(a) constitutes a violation of the right contained in section 24(a) of the Constitution;\n(b) constitutes pollution detrimental to health;\n(c) is likely to cause a health nuisance; or\n(d) constitutes a health nuisance,\n\n\"3. In terms of registration for exports by the Department of Agriculture, Forestry and Fisheries (DAFF), the respective processing or manufacturing establishments namely RCL Foods with an export registration number ZA32 and Enterprise Foods with an export registration number ZA 33 have been temporarily suspected [suspended?] till further notice.\n\n\"4. We advise members of the public to avoid all processed meat products that are sold as ready-to-eat. While we know that polony is definitely implicated, there is a risk of cross-contamination of other ready-to-eat processed meat products, either at production, distribution or retail. This is because _Listeria_ on the exterior casing (packaging) of polony can be transferred to other products it comes into contact with, including viennas, russians, frankfurters, other sausages, and other 'cold meat' products that are typically not cooked before eating.\n\n\"Just a reminder that people at high risk for listeriosis include:\n- pregnant women;\n- neonates (1st 28 days of life);\n- very young infants;\n- elderly persons, older than 65 years of age, and\n- anyone with a weakened immune system (due to HIV infection, cancer, diabetes, kidney disease, liver disease, people with transplants and those on immunosuppressive therapy such as oral corticosteroids, chemotherapy, or anti-TNF therapy for auto-immune disease).\n\n\"The recall of these products does not mean that members of the public must now relax and stop the 5 food-safety rules, which we have recited many times, that is, washing your hands before handling food or when coming back from the bathroom; making sure that food is well cooked; isolating raw food from cooked food; making sure that food is at an appropriate temperature; and washing non-cooked food with clean running water; as well as using only pasteurised or boiled milk products.\n\n\"It means that the general status of hygiene of the population must still be a matter of priority to society as a whole, and must remain like that forever.\"\n\n\"For media enquiries, please contact:\nMr Popo Maja\nHead of Communications\nNational Department of Health\nCell: 0725853219/012 395 9591\nFoster Mohale\nDirector: Media Relations\nNational Department of Health\nCell: 0724323792/012 395 8180\n<Foster.mohale@health.gov.za>\"\n\n--\nCharlene Jacobs\n<charlenea.jacobs@westerncape.gov.za>\n\n[ProMED-mail thanks Charlene Jacobs for the official press conference media statement from Dr Aaron Motsoaledi, South Africa Minister of Health on the listeriosis outbreak in South Africa. - Mod.ML\n\nHealthMap: South Africa: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/179]\nSee Also\nListeriosis - South Africa (08): fatal, more cases, source found, polony 20180305.5665592\nListeriosis - South Africa (07): fatal, more cases 20180224.5648305\nListeriosis - South Africa (06): fatal, more cases 20180218.5635764\nListeriosis - South Africa (05): fatal, more cases 20180131.5596282\nListeriosis - South Africa (04): comment 20180126.5586393\nListeriosis - South Africa (03): fatal, increasing incidence, ST6 20180122.5577247\nListeriosis - South Africa (02): fatal, increasing incidence, ST6 20180117.5566300\nListeriosis - South Africa: fatal, increasing incidence, ST6 20180108.5545556\n2017\n----\nListeriosis - South Africa (04): fatal, increasing incidence 20171217.5508986\nListeriosis - South Africa (03): fatal, increasing incidence, genotyping 20171206.5487695\nListeriosis - South Africa (02): fatal, increasing incidence, RFI 20171205.5484927\nListeriosis - South Africa: increasing incidence 20171025.5402225\n.................................................lm/ml/mj/lxl", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "listeriosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2017-01-16 00:00:00", "2018-03-16 00:00:00", "2018-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2017-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Soweto", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "South Africa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Geneva", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Polokwane", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5672344", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis - Of these 948, a total 659 patients have been traced and 180 of them have unfortunately died. This constitutes a 27 percent case fatality rate.\n\nIn our constant search for the source of the outbreak and the treatment of people who are affected, a team from the NICD [National Institute for Communicable Diseases] has interviewed 109 ill people to obtain details about foods they had eaten in the month before falling ill. 93 (85 percent) people reported eating ready-to-eat (RTE) processed meat products, of which polony was the most common, followed by viennas/sausages and then other 'cold meats'.\n\n\"On [Fri 12 Jan 2018], 9 children under the age of 5 years presented to Chris Hani Baragwanath Hospital with febrile gastroenteritis. These isolates were sent to the NICD Centre for Enteric Diseases, and underwent whole genome sequencing and genomic analysis. The ST6 sequence type was confirmed on all 3 isolates on [Sat 27 Jan 2018]. Remember that in the last press conference I informed you that from clinical isolates obtained from patients (patient blood), 9 sequence types of _L. monocytogenes_ were isolated and 91 percent were of sequence type 6 (ST6). We had then concluded that time that this outbreak is driven by ST6.\n\n\"I wish to further remind you that we had then taken a decision to visit all food-processing sites, food-packaging sites, as well as food production sites where possible.\n\n\"Following the lead from the tests performed on these children from Soweto and the food they had ingested, the EHPs, together with the NICD and DAFF representatives, accompanied by 3 technical advisors from the World Health Organisation in Geneva, visited a food-production site in Polokwane and conducted an extensive food product and environmental sampling.\n\n_L. monocytogenes_ was isolated from over 30 percent of the environmental samples collected from this site, which happens to be the Enterprise factory in Polokwane.\n\nTo conclude the investigation, whole genome sequencing analysis was performed from this Enterprise factory and the results became available midnight or last night [3 Mar 2018]. Polony products have tested positive for _L. monocytogenes_, but the sequence types of the isolates are NOT ST6. However, such contamination of ready-to-eat processed meat products constitutes a health risk. Also, over 10 percent of environmental samples collected by EHPs at this facility have tested positive for _L. monocytogenes_. The sequence types of these isolates are not known as yet.\n\n\"With the information at our disposal, we have decided on the following course of action:\n\"1. The National Consumer Commission (NCC) has in terms of Section 60(2) of the Consumer Protection Act this morning [4 Mar 2018] issued the manufacturers concerned with safety recall notices.\n\n\"Section 60(2) of the Consumer Protection Act states that:\nIf the NCC has reasonable grounds to believe that any goods may be unsafe, or that there is a potential risk to the public from the continued use of or exposure to the goods, and the producer or importer of those goods has not taken any steps required by an applicable code contemplated in subsection the Commission, by written notice, may require that producer to:\n(a) conduct an investigation contemplated in subsection (1); or\n(b) carry out a recall programme on any terms required by the Commission.\n\n\"The NCC will prepare a recall strategy in conjunction with the manufacturers and make further announcements to the public in due course.\nThe safety recall will affect the manufacturers' entire distribution networks, both domestic and international.\n\n\"2. Compliance notices will be issued to facilities in terms of the National Health Act.\nEnvironmental Health Practitioners appointed in terms of section 80(1) of the Act and duly registered as such in terms of section 83(5) of the National Health Amendment Act, 2013 (Act No. 12 of 2013) should upon finding that there are in terms of section 83 (1) and (2), existing conditions which:\n(a) constitutes a violation of the right contained in section 24(a) of the Constitution;\n(b) constitutes pollution detrimental to health;\n(c) is likely to cause a health nuisance; or\n(d) constitutes a health nuisance,\n\n\"3. In terms of registration for exports by the Department of Agriculture, Forestry and Fisheries (DAFF), the respective processing or manufacturing establishments namely RCL Foods with an export registration number ZA32 and Enterprise Foods with an export registration number ZA 33 have been temporarily suspected [suspended?] till further notice.\n\n\"4. We advise members of the public to avoid all processed meat products that are sold as ready-to-eat. While we know that polony is definitely implicated, there is a risk of cross-contamination of other ready-to-eat processed meat products, either at production, distribution or retail. This is because _Listeria_ on the exterior casing (packaging) of polony can be transferred to other products it comes into contact with, including viennas, russians, frankfurters, other sausages, and other 'cold meat' products that are typically not cooked before eating.\n\n\"Just a reminder that people at high risk for listeriosis include:\n- pregnant women;\n- neonates (1st 28 days of life);\n- very young infants;\n- elderly persons, older than 65 years of age, and\n- anyone with a weakened immune system (due to HIV infection, cancer, diabetes, kidney disease, liver disease, people with transplants and those on immunosuppressive therapy such as oral corticosteroids, chemotherapy, or anti-TNF therapy for auto-immune disease).\n\n\"The recall of these products does not mean that members of the public must now relax and stop the 5 food-safety rules, which we have recited many times, that is, washing your hands before handling food or when coming back from the bathroom; making sure that food is well cooked; isolating raw food from cooked food; making sure that food is at an appropriate temperature; and washing non-cooked food with clean running water; as well as using only pasteurised or boiled milk products.\n\n\"It means that the general status of hygiene of the population must still be a matter of priority to society as a whole, and must remain like that forever.\"\n\n\"For media enquiries, please contact:\nMr Popo Maja\nHead of Communications\nNational Department of Health\nCell: 0725853219/012 395 9591\nFoster Mohale\nDirector: Media Relations\nNational Department of Health\nCell: 0724323792/012 395 8180\n<Foster.mohale@health.gov.za>\"\n\n--\nCharlene Jacobs\n<charlenea.jacobs@westerncape.gov.za>\n\n[ProMED-mail thanks Charlene Jacobs for the official press conference media statement from Dr Aaron Motsoaledi, South Africa Minister of Health on the listeriosis outbreak in South Africa. - South Africa (08): fatal, more cases, source found, polony", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5665592", "date": "2018-01-22 20:54:48", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS - SOUTH AFRICA (03): FATAL, INCREASING INCIDENCE, ST6\n*****************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 22 Jan 2018\nSource: Poultry World [edited]\nhttp://www.poultryworld.net/Meat/Articles/2018/1/Poultry-under-suspicion-in-worst-listeriosis-outbreak-238226E/\n\n\nCooked chicken and other deli meats such as ham and Bologna sausage are high on the list of suspects for causing the world's worst ever recorded listeriosis outbreak.\n\nAt least 81 people have died in the ongoing outbreak in South Africa, according to the country's National Institute of Communicable Diseases (NICD), with the number of recorded cases now 767 spread across all 9 provinces. It is massively larger than the 2nd biggest outbreak, which took place in the United States in 2011, when 147 cases were reported.\n\nThe disease -- contracted from eating food contaminated with the foodborne pathogen _Listeria_ -- normally has a mortality rate of between 20-25%. However, the NICD has said \"outcome data\" from the 235 cases that it has studied has put the death rate at 34%.\n\nIt said that so far no food sources contaminated with the outbreak strain had been found, including among poultry and poultry products. Earlier this month [January 2018], there had been speculation that one of South Africa's major poultry producers, Sovereign Foods, based at Hartbeespoort in the Eastern Cape, could be involved in the outbreak. Environmental health officers visited Sovereign Foods' abattoirs to collect food samples, but these samples did not pick up the ST6 strain, although the tests found other strains with the potential to cause disease.\n\nSouth Africa's Health Minister Aaron Motsoaledi said that as the abattoir had _Listeria_, the abattoir was prohibited from further preparing food pending a deep clean. The abattoir was closed on 22 Dec 2017 but reopened on 9 Jan [2018]. Blaine van Rensberg, Sovereign Foods' head of production, said the company was further strengthening steps to render products safer than \"they already are.\"\n\nFood safety experts Dr Lucia Anelich said the \"culprit\" was most likely a product consumed \"extremely often\" across the country. \"Deli meats are obviously consumed by a wide variety of people in the population, whether it's a cheaper cut or a more expensive one,\" she said.\n\n[Byline: Tony McDougal]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[When last reported by ProMED-mail (Listeriosis - South Africa (02): fatal, increasing incidence, ST6 20180117.5566300), there were a total of 748 laboratory-confirmed listeriosis cases, including 67 deaths. Now there are 767 nationally, including 81 deaths.\n\nPrevious ProMED-mail posts said that molecular typing identified ST6 in over 90 percent of clinical isolates from all 9 provinces, which supports the current working hypothesis of a single source of food contamination causing the outbreak, i.e. a single widely consumed food product, or multiple food products produced at a single facility. However, no ST6 food/environmental isolates have been identified to date, and the source of this outbreak remains unknown. - Mod.ML\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map:\nSouth Africa: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/179]\nSee Also\nListeriosis - South Africa (03): fatal, increasing incidence, genotyping 20171206.5487695\nListeriosis - South Africa (02): fatal, increasing incidence, RFI 20171205.5484927\nListeriosis - South Africa: increasing incidence 20171025.5402225\n.................................................sb/ml/msp/mpp", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "other", "listeriosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2018-01-22 00:00:00", "2011-03-16 00:00:00", "2018-01-16 00:00:00", "2017-12-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2017-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "South Africa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Hartbeespoort", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "South Africa 's", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5659577", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis - It is massively larger than the 2nd biggest outbreak, which took place in the United States in 2011, when 147 cases were reported.\n\nThe disease -- contracted from eating food contaminated with the foodborne pathogen _Listeria_ -- normally has a mortality rate of between 20-25%. However, the NICD has said \"outcome data\" from the 235 cases that it has studied has put the death rate at 34%.\n\nIt said that so far no food sources contaminated with the outbreak strain had been found, including among poultry and poultry products. Earlier this month [January 2018], there had been speculation that one of South Africa's major poultry producers, Sovereign Foods, based at Hartbeespoort in the Eastern Cape, could be involved in the outbreak. Environmental health officers visited Sovereign Foods' abattoirs to collect food samples, but these samples did not pick up the ST6 strain, although the tests found other strains with the potential to cause disease.\n\nSouth Africa's Health Minister Aaron Motsoaledi said that as the abattoir had _Listeria_, the abattoir was prohibited from further preparing food pending a deep clean. The abattoir was closed on 22 Dec 2017 but reopened on 9 Jan [2018]. Blaine van Rensberg, Sovereign Foods' head of production, said the company was further strengthening steps to render products safer than \"they already are.\"\n\nFood safety experts Dr Lucia Anelich said the \"culprit\" was most likely a product consumed \"extremely often\" across the country. \"Deli meats are obviously consumed by a wide variety of people in the population, whether it's a cheaper cut or a more expensive one,\" she said.\n\n[Byline: Tony McDougal]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[When last reported by ProMED-mail (Listeriosis - South Africa (02): fatal, increasing incidence, ST6 20180117.5566300), there were a total of 748 laboratory-confirmed listeriosis cases, including 67 deaths. Now there are 767 nationally, including 81 deaths.\n\nPrevious ProMED-mail posts said that molecular typing identified ST6 in over 90 percent of clinical isolates from all 9 provinces, which supports the current working hypothesis of a single source of food contamination causing the outbreak, i.e. a single widely consumed food product, or multiple food products produced at a single facility. However, no ST6 food/environmental isolates have been identified to date, and the source of this outbreak remains unknown. - Mod.ML\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map:\nSouth Africa: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/179]\nSee Also\nListeriosis - South Africa (02): fatal, increasing incidence, ST6 20180117.5566300\nListeriosis - South Africa: fatal, increasing incidence, ST6 20180108.5545556\n2017\n----\nListeriosis - South Africa (04): fatal, increasing incidence 20171217.5508986\nListeriosis - South Africa (03): fatal, increasing incidence, genotyping 20171206.5487695\nListeriosis - South Africa (02): fatal, increasing incidence, RFI 20171205.5484927\nListeriosis - South Africa: increasing incidence 20171025.5402225\n.................................................sb/ml/msp/mpp", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "other", "listeriosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2018-01-22 00:00:00", "2011-03-16 00:00:00", "2018-01-16 00:00:00", "2017-12-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2017-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "South Africa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Hartbeespoort", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "South Africa 's", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5586393", "headline": "PRO/AH> Listeriosis - South Africa (04): comment", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5586393", "date": "2018-01-22 20:54:48", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS - SOUTH AFRICA (03): FATAL, INCREASING INCIDENCE, ST6\n*****************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 22 Jan 2018\nSource: Poultry World [edited]\nhttp://www.poultryworld.net/Meat/Articles/2018/1/Poultry-under-suspicion-in-worst-listeriosis-outbreak-238226E/\n\n\nCooked chicken and other deli meats such as ham and Bologna sausage are high on the list of suspects for causing the world's worst ever recorded listeriosis outbreak.\n\nAt least 81 people have died in the ongoing outbreak in South Africa, according to the country's National Institute of Communicable Diseases (NICD), with the number of recorded cases now 767 spread across all 9 provinces. It is massively larger than the 2nd biggest outbreak, which took place in the United States in 2011, when 147 cases were reported.\n\nThe disease -- contracted from eating food contaminated with the foodborne pathogen _Listeria_ -- normally has a mortality rate of between 20-25%. However, the NICD has said \"outcome data\" from the 235 cases that it has studied has put the death rate at 34%.\n\nIt said that so far no food sources contaminated with the outbreak strain had been found, including among poultry and poultry products. Earlier this month [January 2018], there had been speculation that one of South Africa's major poultry producers, Sovereign Foods, based at Hartbeespoort in the Eastern Cape, could be involved in the outbreak. Environmental health officers visited Sovereign Foods' abattoirs to collect food samples, but these samples did not pick up the ST6 strain, although the tests found other strains with the potential to cause disease.\n\nSouth Africa's Health Minister Aaron Motsoaledi said that as the abattoir had _Listeria_, the abattoir was prohibited from further preparing food pending a deep clean. The abattoir was closed on 22 Dec 2017 but reopened on 9 Jan [2018]. Blaine van Rensberg, Sovereign Foods' head of production, said the company was further strengthening steps to render products safer than \"they already are.\"\n\nFood safety experts Dr Lucia Anelich said the \"culprit\" was most likely a product consumed \"extremely often\" across the country. \"Deli meats are obviously consumed by a wide variety of people in the population, whether it's a cheaper cut or a more expensive one,\" she said.\n\n[Byline: Tony McDougal]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[When last reported by ProMED-mail (Listeriosis - South Africa (02): fatal, increasing incidence, ST6 20180117.5566300), there were a total of 748 laboratory-confirmed listeriosis cases, including 67 deaths. Now there are 767 nationally, including 81 deaths.\n\nPrevious ProMED-mail posts said that molecular typing identified ST6 in over 90 percent of clinical isolates from all 9 provinces, which supports the current working hypothesis of a single source of food contamination causing the outbreak, i.e. a single widely consumed food product, or multiple food products produced at a single facility. However, no ST6 food/environmental isolates have been identified to date, and the source of this outbreak remains unknown. - Mod.ML\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map:\nSouth Africa: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/179]\nSee Also\nListeriosis - However, the NICD has said \"outcome data\" from the 235 cases that it has studied has put the death rate at 34%.\n\nIt said that so far no food sources contaminated with the outbreak strain had been found, including among poultry and poultry products. Now there are 767 nationally, including 81 deaths.\n\nPrevious ProMED-mail posts said that molecular typing identified ST6 in over 90 percent of clinical isolates from all 9 provinces, which supports the current working hypothesis of a single source of food contamination causing the outbreak, i.e. a single widely consumed food product, or multiple food products produced at a single facility. South Africa (02): fatal, increasing incidence, ST6", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5566300", "date": "2017-09-02 10:42:15", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS - DENMARK, POLAND: SMOKED SALMON, RECALL\n****************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 31 Aug 2017\nSource: HealthMap [edited]\nhttp://healthmap.org/ln.php?5286790&u8901\n\n\nDansk Supermarket Group issued a recall after F\u00f8devarestyrelsen (Danish Veterinary and Food Administration) detected _Listeria monocytogenes_ in 2 packs of cold-smoked salmon.\n\n[Byline: Joe Withworth]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The original article, available at the source URL (http://www.foodqualitynews.com/Food-Outbreaks/Listeria-outbreak-from-salmon-in-Denmark), is copyrighted and cannot be reproduced. However, it is summarized below:\n\nThe Dansk Supermarket Group (DSG) recalled cold-packed smoked salmon, manufactured in Poland, after _Listeria monocytogenes_ was identified in the product. The isolate from the product was almost identical by whole genome sequencing to isolates from 3 of 4 patients, whose food history in 3 of the patients identified the smoked salmon as the likely source.\n\nThe smoked salmon product was recalled from about 600 stores in Denmark and a limited number in Metro Poland.\n\nUp to 3 of the 4 patients had become ill in the same week in August 2017 and the 4th had become ill in May 2017. One of the 4 patients has died. All 4 patients had severe underlying disease.\n\nDSG consists of chains (fotex, Bilka, Netto, and Salling) with more than 1400 stores in Denmark, Germany, Poland and Sweden.\n\nRefrigerated smoked salmon is a recognized potential source for listeriosis, similar to other cold cut meats and non-heat treated cured smoked meats, being a ready-to-eat product that does not require further cooking before eating. The news report said that more cases related to this outbreak were expected, despite the recall, as the incubation period for listeriosis is up to 3 weeks [actually symptoms can start up to as 70 days after exposure]. - Mod.ML\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/113.]\nSee Also\n2014\n----\nListeriosis - Sweden: deli meat susp. 20140227.2304710\n2012\n----\nListeriosis - USA: (NJ), perinatal 20120316.1072439\n2011\n----\nListeriosis, fatal - The isolate from the product was almost identical by whole genome sequencing to isolates from 3 of 4 patients, whose food history in 3 of the patients identified the smoked salmon as the likely source.\n\nThe smoked salmon product was recalled from about 600 stores in Denmark and a limited number in Metro Poland.\n\nUp to 3 of the 4 patients had become ill in the same week in August 2017 and the 4th had become ill in May 2017. One of the 4 patients has died. All 4 patients had severe underlying disease.\n\nDSG consists of chains (fotex, Bilka, Netto, and Salling) with more than 1400 stores in Denmark, Germany, Poland and Sweden.\n\nRefrigerated smoked salmon is a recognized potential source for listeriosis, similar to other cold cut meats and non-heat treated cured smoked meats, being a ready-to-eat product that does not require further cooking before eating. The news report said that more cases related to this outbreak were expected, despite the recall, as the incubation period for listeriosis is up to 3 weeks [actually symptoms can start up to as 70 days after exposure]. - South Africa (04): fatal, increasing incidence", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5508986", "date": "2017-09-02 10:42:15", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS - DENMARK, POLAND: SMOKED SALMON, RECALL\n****************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 31 Aug 2017\nSource: HealthMap [edited]\nhttp://healthmap.org/ln.php?5286790&u8901\n\n\nDansk Supermarket Group issued a recall after F\u00f8devarestyrelsen (Danish Veterinary and Food Administration) detected _Listeria monocytogenes_ in 2 packs of cold-smoked salmon.\n\n[Byline: Joe Withworth]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The original article, available at the source URL (http://www.foodqualitynews.com/Food-Outbreaks/Listeria-outbreak-from-salmon-in-Denmark), is copyrighted and cannot be reproduced. However, it is summarized below:\n\nThe Dansk Supermarket Group (DSG) recalled cold-packed smoked salmon, manufactured in Poland, after _Listeria monocytogenes_ was identified in the product. The isolate from the product was almost identical by whole genome sequencing to isolates from 3 of 4 patients, whose food history in 3 of the patients identified the smoked salmon as the likely source.\n\nThe smoked salmon product was recalled from about 600 stores in Denmark and a limited number in Metro Poland.\n\nUp to 3 of the 4 patients had become ill in the same week in August 2017 and the 4th had become ill in May 2017. One of the 4 patients has died. All 4 patients had severe underlying disease.\n\nDSG consists of chains (fotex, Bilka, Netto, and Salling) with more than 1400 stores in Denmark, Germany, Poland and Sweden.\n\nRefrigerated smoked salmon is a recognized potential source for listeriosis, similar to other cold cut meats and non-heat treated cured smoked meats, being a ready-to-eat product that does not require further cooking before eating. The news report said that more cases related to this outbreak were expected, despite the recall, as the incubation period for listeriosis is up to 3 weeks [actually symptoms can start up to as 70 days after exposure]. - One of the 4 patients has died. All 4 patients had severe underlying disease.\n\nDSG consists of chains (fotex, Bilka, Netto, and Salling) with more than 1400 stores in Denmark, Germany, Poland and Sweden.\n\nRefrigerated smoked salmon is a recognized potential source for listeriosis, similar to other cold cut meats and non-heat treated cured smoked meats, being a ready-to-eat product that does not require further cooking before eating. The news report said that more cases related to this outbreak were expected, despite the recall, as the incubation period for listeriosis is up to 3 weeks [actually symptoms can start up to as 70 days after exposure]. - Mod.ML\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/113.]\nSee Also\n2014\n----\nListeriosis - Sweden: deli meat susp. 20140227.2304710\n2012\n----\nListeriosis - USA: (NJ), perinatal 20120316.1072439\n2011\n----\nListeriosis, fatal - USA: (CO) 20110605.1719\n2007\n----\nListeriosis - USA: (NC, MA), alert 20071230.4186\nListeriosis, perinatal - Czech Republic (Moravia) 20070108.0079\n2006\n----\nListeriosis, seafood - USA 20060130.0295\n.................................................sb/ml/ec/dk", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "listeriosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2017-08-16 00:00:00", "2017-05-16 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2012-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "NC", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "POLAND", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Netto", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Germany", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Sweden", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Poland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Denmark", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5402225", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis - South Africa: increasing incidence", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5402225", "date": "2017-09-02 10:42:15", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS - DENMARK, POLAND: SMOKED SALMON, RECALL\n****************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 31 Aug 2017\nSource: HealthMap [edited]\nhttp://healthmap.org/ln.php?5286790&u8901\n\n\nDansk Supermarket Group issued a recall after F\u00f8devarestyrelsen (Danish Veterinary and Food Administration) detected _Listeria monocytogenes_ in 2 packs of cold-smoked salmon.\n\n[Byline: Joe Withworth]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The original article, available at the source URL (http://www.foodqualitynews.com/Food-Outbreaks/Listeria-outbreak-from-salmon-in-Denmark), is copyrighted and cannot be reproduced. However, it is summarized below:\n\nThe Dansk Supermarket Group (DSG) recalled cold-packed smoked salmon, manufactured in Poland, after _Listeria monocytogenes_ was identified in the product. The isolate from the product was almost identical by whole genome sequencing to isolates from 3 of 4 patients, whose food history in 3 of the patients identified the smoked salmon as the likely source.\n\nThe smoked salmon product was recalled from about 600 stores in Denmark and a limited number in Metro Poland.\n\nUp to 3 of the 4 patients had become ill in the same week in August 2017 and the 4th had become ill in May 2017. One of the 4 patients has died. All 4 patients had severe underlying disease.\n\nDSG consists of chains (fotex, Bilka, Netto, and Salling) with more than 1400 stores in Denmark, Germany, Poland and Sweden.\n\nRefrigerated smoked salmon is a recognized potential source for listeriosis, similar to other cold cut meats and non-heat treated cured smoked meats, being a ready-to-eat product that does not require further cooking before eating. The news report said that more cases related to this outbreak were expected, despite the recall, as the incubation period for listeriosis is up to 3 weeks [actually symptoms can start up to as 70 days after exposure]. - Mod.ML\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/113.]\nSee Also\n2014\n----\nListeriosis - Sweden: deli meat susp. 20140227.2304710\n2012\n----\nListeriosis - USA: (NJ), perinatal 20120316.1072439\n2011\n----\nListeriosis, fatal - However, it is summarized below:\n\nThe Dansk Supermarket Group (DSG) recalled cold-packed smoked salmon, manufactured in Poland, after _Listeria monocytogenes_ was identified in the product. The isolate from the product was almost identical by whole genome sequencing to isolates from 3 of 4 patients, whose food history in 3 of the patients identified the smoked salmon as the likely source.\n\nThe smoked salmon product was recalled from about 600 stores in Denmark and a limited number in Metro Poland.\n\nUp to 3 of the 4 patients had become ill in the same week in August 2017 and the 4th had become ill in May 2017. One of the 4 patients has died.
