Mod.ML\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/113.]\nSee Also\n2014\n----\nListeriosis - Sweden: deli meat susp. 20140227.2304710\n2012\n----\nListeriosis - USA: (NJ), perinatal 20120316.1072439\n2011\n----\nListeriosis, fatal - USA: (CO) 20110605.1719\n2007\n----\nListeriosis - USA: (NC, MA), alert 20071230.4186\nListeriosis, perinatal - Czech Republic (Moravia) 20070108.0079\n2006\n----\nListeriosis, seafood - USA 20060130.0295\n.................................................sb/ml/ec/dk", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "listeriosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2017-08-16 00:00:00", "2017-05-16 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2012-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "NC", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "POLAND", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Netto", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Germany", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Sweden", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Poland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Denmark", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4896013", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis - USA (02): fatal, unpast soft cheese, aged 60 days, recall", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4896013", "date": "2016-03-20 12:44:09", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS - USA (02): (FLORIDA, CALIFORNIA) FATAL, UNPASTEURIZED MILK, CLUB MEMBERSHIP, 2014\n**********************************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 18 Mar 2016\nSource: CBS News [edited]\nhttp://www.cbsnews.com/news/deadly-listeria-outbreak-linked-to-raw-milk/\n\n\nHealth officials say a deadly outbreak of listeriosis has been linked to raw milk from an organic farm in Pennsylvania. The illnesses happened in 2014, but it took investigators until now to determine the cause. Two patients got sick from the bacteria, one in California and one in Florida, and the patient in Florida died.\n\nThe U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention reported Friday [18 Mar 2016] that the outbreak had been traced to unpasteurized raw milk produced by Miller's Organic Farm in Bird-In-Hand, Pennsylvania.\n\nIn January [2016], the FDA found _Listeria_ in samples of raw chocolate milk produced by the same company and said genetic testing confirmed it was closely related to the strain that sent the 2 patients to the hospital in 2014.\n\nAmos Miller, the owner of Miller's Organic Farm, said the company operates as a private membership club and only supplies milk and other farm-grown products to members. It does not distribute to retail stores or other outlets. Miller told CBS News the company is still selling raw milk and is not aware of any health problems. \"I don't know that it was proved it's on the farm here,\" he said. \"We hope and pray for the best.\"\n\nPublic health officials have long advised people not to drink raw milk or consume other unpasteurized dairy products because of the risk that it may contain dangerous pathogens like _Listeria_, _Salmonella_, _Escherichia coli_ and _Campylobacter_ bacteria. Pasteurized milk has been heated to high enough temperatures to kill the bacteria.\n\nThere have been a number of other widely publicized listeriosis outbreaks in recent years, including one last year traced to Blue Bell Creameries ice cream which killed 3 people and sickened 10. In 2014, 7 people died from listeriosis in caramel apples.\n\nYoung children, older adults, and people with weakened immune systems are at highest risk of severe illness from listeriosis. It's also a serious concern for pregnant women as the bacteria can lead to miscarriage, stillbirth, premature delivery or life-threatening infections in newborns.\n\nThe CDC says symptoms of listeriosis usually develop within a few days of eating contaminated food and may include fever, muscle aches, headache, stiff neck, confusion, loss of balance, and convulsions. Life-threatening complications can develop if the bacteria get into the bloodstream or central nervous system.\n\nAlthough no recall related to this latest outbreak has been announced, the CDC warned consumers to be wary. \"Because _Listeria_ was recently found in raw milk produced by Miller's Organic Farm, CDC is concerned that conditions may exist at the farm that may cause further contamination of raw milk and raw dairy products distributed by this company and make people sick,\" the CDC said in a statement.\n\n[Byline: Paula Cohen]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Unpasteurized milk is an important vehicle for transmission of pathogens, which include _Brucella _ species, _Mycobacterium bovis_, _Salmonella_ species, _Listeria monocytogenes_, _Campylobacter_ species, _Yersinia_ species, _Coxiella burnetii_, and Shiga toxin-producing _E. coli_. In 1987, the United States Food and Drug Administration prohibited distribution of unpasteurized dairy products in interstate commerce for sale to consumers (http://wwwnc.cdc.gov/eid/article/18/3/11-1370_article).\n\nHowever, sale of unpasteurized dairy products within the state where they are produced is regulated by each state, and some states permit sale of these products within these states. To circumvent these regulations for commercial sale of unpasteurized milk, some states allow milk producers to distribute unpasteurized milk through cow-leasing programs, whereby members purchase shares in dairy cows in exchange for a percentage of the milk produced (http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm5125a2.htm).\n\nExactly what the arrangement described as a \"private membership club\" that the unpasteurized milk producer in Pennsylvania had with its \"members\" who developed listeriosis, one in California and one in Florida, is not detailed in the news report above. The clinical isolates from the 2 cases had a genotype that was closely related to the strains isolated from raw chocolate milk produced by the same company. No recall related to this latest outbreak has been announced.\n\nFor a discussion of listeriosis, please see my comments in ProMED-mail post Listeriosis, fatal - USA: (CO) 20110605.1719. - Mod.ML\n\nProMED HealthMaps:\nFlorida http://healthmap.org/promed/p/212\nCalifornia http://healthmap.org/promed/p/204]\nSee Also\nListeriosis - USA (UT) 20070322.1004\nYersiniosis, listeriosis - Canada (ON): unpasteurized milk/cheese 20070319.0968\nE. coli O157, unpasteurized milk, 2005 - USA (WA) 20070302.0741\n.................................................sb/ml/msp/mpp", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "salmonellosis", "yersiniosis", "listeriosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2016-03-16 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-19 00:00:00", "2016-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-01-16 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "1987-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-11 00:00:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-10 00:00:00", "2011-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-10 00:00:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "KS", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "CALIFORNIA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Pennsylvania", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "FLORIDA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Florida", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "California", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4893360", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis - Australia: (VI) fatal, no common source identified", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4717347", "date": "2016-03-20 12:44:09", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS - USA (02): (FLORIDA, CALIFORNIA) FATAL, UNPASTEURIZED MILK, CLUB MEMBERSHIP, 2014\n**********************************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 18 Mar 2016\nSource: CBS News [edited]\nhttp://www.cbsnews.com/news/deadly-listeria-outbreak-linked-to-raw-milk/\n\n\nHealth officials say a deadly outbreak of listeriosis has been linked to raw milk from an organic farm in Pennsylvania. The illnesses happened in 2014, but it took investigators until now to determine the cause. Two patients got sick from the bacteria, one in California and one in Florida, and the patient in Florida died.\n\nThe U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention reported Friday [18 Mar 2016] that the outbreak had been traced to unpasteurized raw milk produced by Miller's Organic Farm in Bird-In-Hand, Pennsylvania.\n\nIn January [2016], the FDA found _Listeria_ in samples of raw chocolate milk produced by the same company and said genetic testing confirmed it was closely related to the strain that sent the 2 patients to the hospital in 2014.\n\nAmos Miller, the owner of Miller's Organic Farm, said the company operates as a private membership club and only supplies milk and other farm-grown products to members. It does not distribute to retail stores or other outlets. Miller told CBS News the company is still selling raw milk and is not aware of any health problems. \"I don't know that it was proved it's on the farm here,\" he said. \"We hope and pray for the best.\"\n\nPublic health officials have long advised people not to drink raw milk or consume other unpasteurized dairy products because of the risk that it may contain dangerous pathogens like _Listeria_, _Salmonella_, _Escherichia coli_ and _Campylobacter_ bacteria. Pasteurized milk has been heated to high enough temperatures to kill the bacteria.\n\nThere have been a number of other widely publicized listeriosis outbreaks in recent years, including one last year traced to Blue Bell Creameries ice cream which killed 3 people and sickened 10. In 2014, 7 people died from listeriosis in caramel apples.\n\nYoung children, older adults, and people with weakened immune systems are at highest risk of severe illness from listeriosis. It's also a serious concern for pregnant women as the bacteria can lead to miscarriage, stillbirth, premature delivery or life-threatening infections in newborns.\n\nThe CDC says symptoms of listeriosis usually develop within a few days of eating contaminated food and may include fever, muscle aches, headache, stiff neck, confusion, loss of balance, and convulsions. Life-threatening complications can develop if the bacteria get into the bloodstream or central nervous system.\n\nAlthough no recall related to this latest outbreak has been announced, the CDC warned consumers to be wary. \"Because _Listeria_ was recently found in raw milk produced by Miller's Organic Farm, CDC is concerned that conditions may exist at the farm that may cause further contamination of raw milk and raw dairy products distributed by this company and make people sick,\" the CDC said in a statement.\n\n[Byline: Paula Cohen]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Unpasteurized milk is an important vehicle for transmission of pathogens, which include _Brucella _ species, _Mycobacterium bovis_, _Salmonella_ species, _Listeria monocytogenes_, _Campylobacter_ species, _Yersinia_ species, _Coxiella burnetii_, and Shiga toxin-producing _E. coli_. In 1987, the United States Food and Drug Administration prohibited distribution of unpasteurized dairy products in interstate commerce for sale to consumers (http://wwwnc.cdc.gov/eid/article/18/3/11-1370_article).\n\nHowever, sale of unpasteurized dairy products within the state where they are produced is regulated by each state, and some states permit sale of these products within these states. To circumvent these regulations for commercial sale of unpasteurized milk, some states allow milk producers to distribute unpasteurized milk through cow-leasing programs, whereby members purchase shares in dairy cows in exchange for a percentage of the milk produced (http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm5125a2.htm).\n\nExactly what the arrangement described as a \"private membership club\" that the unpasteurized milk producer in Pennsylvania had with its \"members\" who developed listeriosis, one in California and one in Florida, is not detailed in the news report above. The clinical isolates from the 2 cases had a genotype that was closely related to the strains isolated from raw chocolate milk produced by the same company. No recall related to this latest outbreak has been announced.\n\nFor a discussion of listeriosis, please see my comments in ProMED-mail post Listeriosis, fatal - USA: (CO) 20110605.1719. - Mod.ML\n\nProMED HealthMaps:\nFlorida http://healthmap.org/promed/p/212\nCalifornia http://healthmap.org/promed/p/204]\nSee Also\nListeriosis - The illnesses happened in 2014, but it took investigators until now to determine the cause. Two patients got sick from the bacteria, one in California and one in Florida, and the patient in Florida died.\n\nThe U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention reported Friday [18 Mar 2016] that the outbreak had been traced to unpasteurized raw milk produced by Miller's Organic Farm in Bird-In-Hand, Pennsylvania.\n\nIn January [2016], the FDA found _Listeria_ in samples of raw chocolate milk produced by the same company and said genetic testing confirmed it was closely related to the strain that sent the 2 patients to the hospital in 2014.\n\nAmos Miller, the owner of Miller's Organic Farm, said the company operates as a private membership club and only supplies milk and other farm-grown products to members. It does not distribute to retail stores or other outlets. Miller told CBS News the company is still selling raw milk and is not aware of any health problems. \"I don't know that it was proved it's on the farm here,\" he said. \"We hope and pray for the best.\"\n\nPublic health officials have long advised people not to drink raw milk or consume other unpasteurized dairy products because of the risk that it may contain dangerous pathogens like _Listeria_, _Salmonella_, _Escherichia coli_ and _Campylobacter_ bacteria. Pasteurized milk has been heated to high enough temperatures to kill the bacteria.\n\nThere have been a number of other widely publicized listeriosis outbreaks in recent years, including one last year traced to Blue Bell Creameries ice cream which killed 3 people and sickened 10. In 2014, 7 people died from listeriosis in caramel apples.\n\nYoung children, older adults, and people with weakened immune systems are at highest risk of severe illness from listeriosis. It's also a serious concern for pregnant women as the bacteria can lead to miscarriage, stillbirth, premature delivery or life-threatening infections in newborns.\n\nThe CDC says symptoms of listeriosis usually develop within a few days of eating contaminated food and may include fever, muscle aches, headache, stiff neck, confusion, loss of balance, and convulsions. Life-threatening complications can develop if the bacteria get into the bloodstream or central nervous system.\n\nAlthough no recall related to this latest outbreak has been announced, the CDC warned consumers to be wary. \"Because _Listeria_ was recently found in raw milk produced by Miller's Organic Farm, CDC is concerned that conditions may exist at the farm that may cause further contamination of raw milk and raw dairy products distributed by this company and make people sick,\" the CDC said in a statement.\n\n[Byline: Paula Cohen]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Unpasteurized milk is an important vehicle for transmission of pathogens, which include _Brucella _ species, _Mycobacterium bovis_, _Salmonella_ species, _Listeria monocytogenes_, _Campylobacter_ species, _Yersinia_ species, _Coxiella burnetii_, and Shiga toxin-producing _E. coli_. In 1987, the United States Food and Drug Administration prohibited distribution of unpasteurized dairy products in interstate commerce for sale to consumers (http://wwwnc.cdc.gov/eid/article/18/3/11-1370_article).\n\nHowever, sale of unpasteurized dairy products within the state where they are produced is regulated by each state, and some states permit sale of these products within these states. To circumvent these regulations for commercial sale of unpasteurized milk, some states allow milk producers to distribute unpasteurized milk through cow-leasing programs, whereby members purchase shares in dairy cows in exchange for a percentage of the milk produced (http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm5125a2.htm).\n\nExactly what the arrangement described as a \"private membership club\" that the unpasteurized milk producer in Pennsylvania had with its \"members\" who developed listeriosis, one in California and one in Florida, is not detailed in the news report above. The clinical isolates from the 2 cases had a genotype that was closely related to the strains isolated from raw chocolate milk produced by the same company. No recall related to this latest outbreak has been announced.\n\nFor a discussion of listeriosis, please see my comments in ProMED-mail post Listeriosis, fatal - USA: (CO) 20110605.1719. - Mod.ML\n\nProMED HealthMaps:\nFlorida http://healthmap.org/promed/p/212\nCalifornia http://healthmap.org/promed/p/204]\nSee Also\nListeriosis - USA (UT) 20070322.1004\nYersiniosis, listeriosis - Canada (ON): unpasteurized milk/cheese 20070319.0968\nE. coli O157, unpasteurized milk, 2005 - USA (WA) 20070302.0741\n.................................................sb/ml/msp/mpp", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "salmonellosis", "yersiniosis", "listeriosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2016-03-16 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-19 00:00:00", "2016-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-01-16 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "1987-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-11 00:00:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-10 00:00:00", "2011-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-10 00:00:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "KS", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "CALIFORNIA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Pennsylvania", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "FLORIDA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Florida", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "California", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4204205", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis - USA, Canada (05): fatal, frozen org & trad fruit/veg, exp recall", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4204205", "date": "2016-03-20 12:44:09", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS - USA (02): (FLORIDA, CALIFORNIA) FATAL, UNPASTEURIZED MILK, CLUB MEMBERSHIP, 2014\n**********************************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 18 Mar 2016\nSource: CBS News [edited]\nhttp://www.cbsnews.com/news/deadly-listeria-outbreak-linked-to-raw-milk/\n\n\nHealth officials say a deadly outbreak of listeriosis has been linked to raw milk from an organic farm in Pennsylvania. The illnesses happened in 2014, but it took investigators until now to determine the cause. Two patients got sick from the bacteria, one in California and one in Florida, and the patient in Florida died.\n\nThe U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention reported Friday [18 Mar 2016] that the outbreak had been traced to unpasteurized raw milk produced by Miller's Organic Farm in Bird-In-Hand, Pennsylvania.\n\nIn January [2016], the FDA found _Listeria_ in samples of raw chocolate milk produced by the same company and said genetic testing confirmed it was closely related to the strain that sent the 2 patients to the hospital in 2014.\n\nAmos Miller, the owner of Miller's Organic Farm, said the company operates as a private membership club and only supplies milk and other farm-grown products to members. It does not distribute to retail stores or other outlets. Miller told CBS News the company is still selling raw milk and is not aware of any health problems. \"I don't know that it was proved it's on the farm here,\" he said. \"We hope and pray for the best.\"\n\nPublic health officials have long advised people not to drink raw milk or consume other unpasteurized dairy products because of the risk that it may contain dangerous pathogens like _Listeria_, _Salmonella_, _Escherichia coli_ and _Campylobacter_ bacteria. Pasteurized milk has been heated to high enough temperatures to kill the bacteria.\n\nThere have been a number of other widely publicized listeriosis outbreaks in recent years, including one last year traced to Blue Bell Creameries ice cream which killed 3 people and sickened 10. In 2014, 7 people died from listeriosis in caramel apples.\n\nYoung children, older adults, and people with weakened immune systems are at highest risk of severe illness from listeriosis. It's also a serious concern for pregnant women as the bacteria can lead to miscarriage, stillbirth, premature delivery or life-threatening infections in newborns.\n\nThe CDC says symptoms of listeriosis usually develop within a few days of eating contaminated food and may include fever, muscle aches, headache, stiff neck, confusion, loss of balance, and convulsions. Life-threatening complications can develop if the bacteria get into the bloodstream or central nervous system.\n\nAlthough no recall related to this latest outbreak has been announced, the CDC warned consumers to be wary. \"Because _Listeria_ was recently found in raw milk produced by Miller's Organic Farm, CDC is concerned that conditions may exist at the farm that may cause further contamination of raw milk and raw dairy products distributed by this company and make people sick,\" the CDC said in a statement.\n\n[Byline: Paula Cohen]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Unpasteurized milk is an important vehicle for transmission of pathogens, which include _Brucella _ species, _Mycobacterium bovis_, _Salmonella_ species, _Listeria monocytogenes_, _Campylobacter_ species, _Yersinia_ species, _Coxiella burnetii_, and Shiga toxin-producing _E. coli_. In 1987, the United States Food and Drug Administration prohibited distribution of unpasteurized dairy products in interstate commerce for sale to consumers (http://wwwnc.cdc.gov/eid/article/18/3/11-1370_article).\n\nHowever, sale of unpasteurized dairy products within the state where they are produced is regulated by each state, and some states permit sale of these products within these states. To circumvent these regulations for commercial sale of unpasteurized milk, some states allow milk producers to distribute unpasteurized milk through cow-leasing programs, whereby members purchase shares in dairy cows in exchange for a percentage of the milk produced (http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm5125a2.htm).\n\nExactly what the arrangement described as a \"private membership club\" that the unpasteurized milk producer in Pennsylvania had with its \"members\" who developed listeriosis, one in California and one in Florida, is not detailed in the news report above. The clinical isolates from the 2 cases had a genotype that was closely related to the strains isolated from raw chocolate milk produced by the same company. No recall related to this latest outbreak has been announced.\n\nFor a discussion of listeriosis, please see my comments in ProMED-mail post Listeriosis, fatal - USA: (CO) 20110605.1719. - Mod.ML\n\nProMED HealthMaps:\nFlorida http://healthmap.org/promed/p/212\nCalifornia http://healthmap.org/promed/p/204]\nSee Also\nListeriosis - USA (UT) 20070322.1004\nYersiniosis, listeriosis - Canada (ON): unpasteurized milk/cheese 20070319.0968\nE. coli O157, unpasteurized milk, 2005 - USA (WA) 20070302.0741\n.................................................sb/ml/msp/mpp", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "salmonellosis", "yersiniosis", "listeriosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2016-03-16 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-19 00:00:00", "2016-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-01-16 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "1987-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-11 00:00:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-10 00:00:00", "2011-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-10 00:00:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "KS", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "CALIFORNIA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Pennsylvania", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "FLORIDA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Florida", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "California", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4107103", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis - USA (02): (FL, CA) fatal, unpasteurized milk, club membership, 2014", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4107103", "date": "2016-03-20 12:44:09", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS - USA (02): (FLORIDA, CALIFORNIA) FATAL, UNPASTEURIZED MILK, CLUB MEMBERSHIP, 2014\n**********************************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 18 Mar 2016\nSource: CBS News [edited]\nhttp://www.cbsnews.com/news/deadly-listeria-outbreak-linked-to-raw-milk/\n\n\nHealth officials say a deadly outbreak of listeriosis has been linked to raw milk from an organic farm in Pennsylvania. The illnesses happened in 2014, but it took investigators until now to determine the cause. Two patients got sick from the bacteria, one in California and one in Florida, and the patient in Florida died.\n\nThe U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention reported Friday [18 Mar 2016] that the outbreak had been traced to unpasteurized raw milk produced by Miller's Organic Farm in Bird-In-Hand, Pennsylvania.\n\nIn January [2016], the FDA found _Listeria_ in samples of raw chocolate milk produced by the same company and said genetic testing confirmed it was closely related to the strain that sent the 2 patients to the hospital in 2014.\n\nAmos Miller, the owner of Miller's Organic Farm, said the company operates as a private membership club and only supplies milk and other farm-grown products to members. It does not distribute to retail stores or other outlets. Miller told CBS News the company is still selling raw milk and is not aware of any health problems. \"I don't know that it was proved it's on the farm here,\" he said. \"We hope and pray for the best.\"\n\nPublic health officials have long advised people not to drink raw milk or consume other unpasteurized dairy products because of the risk that it may contain dangerous pathogens like _Listeria_, _Salmonella_, _Escherichia coli_ and _Campylobacter_ bacteria. Pasteurized milk has been heated to high enough temperatures to kill the bacteria.\n\nThere have been a number of other widely publicized listeriosis outbreaks in recent years, including one last year traced to Blue Bell Creameries ice cream which killed 3 people and sickened 10. In 2014, 7 people died from listeriosis in caramel apples.\n\nYoung children, older adults, and people with weakened immune systems are at highest risk of severe illness from listeriosis. It's also a serious concern for pregnant women as the bacteria can lead to miscarriage, stillbirth, premature delivery or life-threatening infections in newborns.\n\nThe CDC says symptoms of listeriosis usually develop within a few days of eating contaminated food and may include fever, muscle aches, headache, stiff neck, confusion, loss of balance, and convulsions. Life-threatening complications can develop if the bacteria get into the bloodstream or central nervous system.\n\nAlthough no recall related to this latest outbreak has been announced, the CDC warned consumers to be wary. \"Because _Listeria_ was recently found in raw milk produced by Miller's Organic Farm, CDC is concerned that conditions may exist at the farm that may cause further contamination of raw milk and raw dairy products distributed by this company and make people sick,\" the CDC said in a statement.\n\n[Byline: Paula Cohen]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Unpasteurized milk is an important vehicle for transmission of pathogens, which include _Brucella _ species, _Mycobacterium bovis_, _Salmonella_ species, _Listeria monocytogenes_, _Campylobacter_ species, _Yersinia_ species, _Coxiella burnetii_, and Shiga toxin-producing _E. coli_. In 1987, the United States Food and Drug Administration prohibited distribution of unpasteurized dairy products in interstate commerce for sale to consumers (http://wwwnc.cdc.gov/eid/article/18/3/11-1370_article).\n\nHowever, sale of unpasteurized dairy products within the state where they are produced is regulated by each state, and some states permit sale of these products within these states. To circumvent these regulations for commercial sale of unpasteurized milk, some states allow milk producers to distribute unpasteurized milk through cow-leasing programs, whereby members purchase shares in dairy cows in exchange for a percentage of the milk produced (http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm5125a2.htm).\n\nExactly what the arrangement described as a \"private membership club\" that the unpasteurized milk producer in Pennsylvania had with its \"members\" who developed listeriosis, one in California and one in Florida, is not detailed in the news report above. The clinical isolates from the 2 cases had a genotype that was closely related to the strains isolated from raw chocolate milk produced by the same company. No recall related to this latest outbreak has been announced.\n\nFor a discussion of listeriosis, please see my comments in ProMED-mail post Listeriosis, fatal - USA: (CO) 20110605.1719. - Mod.ML\n\nProMED HealthMaps:\nFlorida http://healthmap.org/promed/p/212\nCalifornia http://healthmap.org/promed/p/204]\nSee Also\nListeriosis - USA (UT) 20070322.1004\nYersiniosis, listeriosis - Canada (ON): unpasteurized milk/cheese 20070319.0968\nE. coli O157, unpasteurized milk, 2005 - USA (WA) 20070302.0741\n.................................................sb/ml/msp/mpp", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "salmonellosis", "yersiniosis", "listeriosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2016-03-16 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-19 00:00:00", "2016-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-01-16 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "1987-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-11 00:00:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-10 00:00:00", "2011-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-10 00:00:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "KS", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "CALIFORNIA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Pennsylvania", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "FLORIDA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Florida", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "California", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4062396", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis - USA, Canada (04): fatal, pre-packed salads, same genotype", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4062396", "date": "2015-10-25 10:32:25", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS - USA (11): FATAL, SOFT CHEESES, UPDATE, INVESTIGATION CLOSED\n*************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sat 23 Oct 2015\nSource: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) [edited]\nhttp://www.cdc.gov/listeria/outbreaks/soft-cheeses-09-15/\n\n\nCDC collaborated with public health officials in several states and the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) to investigate a multistate outbreak of _Listeria monocytogenes_ infections (listeriosis). _Listeria_ can cause a serious, life-threatening illness.\n\nPublic health investigators used the PulseNet system to identify illnesses that were part of the outbreak. PulseNet is the national subtyping network of public health and food regulatory agency laboratories coordinated by CDC. DNA \"fingerprinting\" is performed on _Listeria_ bacteria isolated from ill people by using techniques called pulsed-field gel electrophoresis (PFGE) and whole genome sequencing (WGS). PulseNet manages a national database of these DNA fingerprints to identify possible outbreaks. WGS gives a more detailed DNA fingerprint than PFGE. This additional detail was important because 5 rare PFGE fingerprints of _Listeria_ were included in this investigation. The sequencing showed that the _Listeria_ strains with the 5 rare PFGE fingerprints were closely related genetically.\n\n30 people infected with one of the closely related _Listeria_ strains were reported from 10 states since 16 Jun 2010. The number of ill people reported from each state was as follows: California (18), Colorado (1), Illinois (2), Massachusetts (2), Michigan (1), New York (2), Ohio (1), Tennessee (1), Virginia (1), and Washington (1).\n\nDates of _Listeria_ specimen collection ranged from 16 Jun 2010 to 24 Aug 2015. The cluster was 1st identified in August 2015 after investigators saw an increase in one of the 5 rare PFGE fingerprints reported to PulseNet. WGS found that the 4 other PFGE fingerprints were closely related genetically to the 1st PFGE fingerprint. Illnesses associated with those PFGE fingerprints were added to the investigation, including illnesses that occurred over 5 years ago.\n\nIll people ranged in age from less than one year to 92, and the median age was 73. 70 percent of ill people were female. 28 (93 percent) of 30 ill people for whom information was available reported being hospitalized. Six of the illnesses were pregnancy-related, and one illness resulted in a fetal loss. Three deaths were reported from California (2) and Ohio (1).\n\nEpidemiologic and laboratory information indicated that soft cheeses distributed by Karoun Dairies were the likely source of this outbreak.\n\nState and local health departments interviewed ill people about the foods they may have eaten or other exposures in the month before their illness began. 20 (67 percent) of 30 people with available information were of Middle Eastern or Eastern European descent or shopped at Middle Eastern or Eastern European-style markets. Of 28 ill people for whom information was available, 21 (75 percent) consumed soft cheese, and all of those 21 (100 percent) reported eating Middle Eastern, Eastern European, Mediterranean, or Mexican-style cheeses, including ani, feta (e.g., Bulgarian feta), Middle Eastern-style string cheese, nabulsi, and village cheese. Three of 7 ill people who specified the brand of cheese eaten reported brands distributed by Karoun Dairies. An additional ill person was unable to name the brand of cheese eaten but described the packaging and label of a Karoun product. No other brand of soft cheese was reported more than once. One other ill person reported eating Karoun brand kefir cheese. This person was previously included in the number of people reporting a Karoun brand soft cheese, but has now been excluded, since kefir is typically classified as a yogurt product rather than a cheese.\n\nFDA isolated _Listeria monocytogenes_ from 2 environmental samples collected in September 2015 from the Central Valley Cheese, Inc. manufacturing facility in Turlock, California. Central Valley Cheese, Inc. manufactures cheese for Karoun Dairies. Whole genome sequencing showed that these isolates were closely related genetically to isolates from ill people. In addition, whole genome sequencing showed that 5 _Listeria_ isolates collected in 2010 from the same facility were also closely related genetically to isolates from ill people.\n\nOn 16 Sep 2015, Karoun Dairies, Inc. voluntarily recalled certain cheeses that the company distributes due to possible contamination with _Listeria_. The recall includes several brands and types of cheeses that were distributed to retail outlets in the United States. Products were sold under the following brands: Karoun, Arz, Gopi, Queso Del Valle, Central Valley Creamery, and Yanni. Products were vacuum packed in jars or in pails. Weights vary from 5 ounces to 30 pounds. A full list of cheeses is available on the Advice to Consumers, Restaurants, and Retailers page.\n\nThis outbreak investigation is over. However, people could continue to get sick because recalled cheeses may still be in homes, restaurants, or retail locations. Consumers, restaurants, and retailers unaware of the recall could eat, serve, or sell them.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[For discussions of listeriosis, please see my comments in prior ProMED-mail posts listed below. - Mod.ML\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/106.]\nSee Also\nListeriosis - USA (10): fatal, soft cheeses, recall, alert 20150919.3657295\nListeriosis - USA (09): PulseNet, data collection, problems 20150721.3525757\nListeriosis - USA (08): fatal, nosocomial, ice cream, risk remains 20150615.3437487\nListeriosis - USA (07): ice cream, whole gene sequencing detection 20150506.3344944\nListeriosis - Canada: apple products, alert, recall 20150503.3336094\nListeriosis - Denmark: multiple genotypes 20150429.3331222\nListeriosis - USA (06): (KS,TX) fatal, nosocomial, ice cream, recall, update 20150411.3291517\nListeriosis - USA (05): stone fruit 2014 20150321.3244417\nListeriosis - USA (04): (KS) fatal, nosocomial, ice cream 20150315.3231917\nListeriosis - USA (03): (IL,MI) fatal, sprouts, investigation closed 20150129.3129444\nListeriosis - USA (02): fatal, caramel-coated, prepackaged apples, update, alert 20150112.3085796\nListeriosis - USA: fatal, caramel-coated and pre-packaged apples, update, alert 20150103.3068902\n.................................................sb/ml/msp/dk", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "listeriosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-11 00:00:00", "2015-03-16 00:00:00", "2010-06-16 00:00:00", "2010-06-16 00:00:00", "2015-08-24 00:00:00", "2021-03-01 00:00:00", "2015-08-16 00:00:00", "1973-03-16 00:00:00", "2015-09-16 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2015-09-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tennessee", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "FATAL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Michigan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Virginia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "update", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New York", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "soft cheese", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Massachusetts", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Colorado", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Turlock", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Washington", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ohio", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Illinois", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "California", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4030635", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis - USA, Canada (03): fatal, pre-packed salad, same genotype", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4030635", "date": "2015-10-25 10:32:25", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS - USA (11): FATAL, SOFT CHEESES, UPDATE, INVESTIGATION CLOSED\n*************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sat 23 Oct 2015\nSource: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) [edited]\nhttp://www.cdc.gov/listeria/outbreaks/soft-cheeses-09-15/\n\n\nCDC collaborated with public health officials in several states and the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) to investigate a multistate outbreak of _Listeria monocytogenes_ infections (listeriosis). _Listeria_ can cause a serious, life-threatening illness.\n\nPublic health investigators used the PulseNet system to identify illnesses that were part of the outbreak. PulseNet is the national subtyping network of public health and food regulatory agency laboratories coordinated by CDC. DNA \"fingerprinting\" is performed on _Listeria_ bacteria isolated from ill people by using techniques called pulsed-field gel electrophoresis (PFGE) and whole genome sequencing (WGS). PulseNet manages a national database of these DNA fingerprints to identify possible outbreaks. WGS gives a more detailed DNA fingerprint than PFGE. This additional detail was important because 5 rare PFGE fingerprints of _Listeria_ were included in this investigation. The sequencing showed that the _Listeria_ strains with the 5 rare PFGE fingerprints were closely related genetically.\n\n30 people infected with one of the closely related _Listeria_ strains were reported from 10 states since 16 Jun 2010. The number of ill people reported from each state was as follows: California (18), Colorado (1), Illinois (2), Massachusetts (2), Michigan (1), New York (2), Ohio (1), Tennessee (1), Virginia (1), and Washington (1).\n\nDates of _Listeria_ specimen collection ranged from 16 Jun 2010 to 24 Aug 2015. The cluster was 1st identified in August 2015 after investigators saw an increase in one of the 5 rare PFGE fingerprints reported to PulseNet. WGS found that the 4 other PFGE fingerprints were closely related genetically to the 1st PFGE fingerprint. Illnesses associated with those PFGE fingerprints were added to the investigation, including illnesses that occurred over 5 years ago.\n\nIll people ranged in age from less than one year to 92, and the median age was 73. 70 percent of ill people were female. 28 (93 percent) of 30 ill people for whom information was available reported being hospitalized. Six of the illnesses were pregnancy-related, and one illness resulted in a fetal loss. Three deaths were reported from California (2) and Ohio (1).\n\nEpidemiologic and laboratory information indicated that soft cheeses distributed by Karoun Dairies were the likely source of this outbreak.\n\nState and local health departments interviewed ill people about the foods they may have eaten or other exposures in the month before their illness began. 20 (67 percent) of 30 people with available information were of Middle Eastern or Eastern European descent or shopped at Middle Eastern or Eastern European-style markets. Of 28 ill people for whom information was available, 21 (75 percent) consumed soft cheese, and all of those 21 (100 percent) reported eating Middle Eastern, Eastern European, Mediterranean, or Mexican-style cheeses, including ani, feta (e.g., Bulgarian feta), Middle Eastern-style string cheese, nabulsi, and village cheese. Three of 7 ill people who specified the brand of cheese eaten reported brands distributed by Karoun Dairies. An additional ill person was unable to name the brand of cheese eaten but described the packaging and label of a Karoun product. No other brand of soft cheese was reported more than once. One other ill person reported eating Karoun brand kefir cheese. This person was previously included in the number of people reporting a Karoun brand soft cheese, but has now been excluded, since kefir is typically classified as a yogurt product rather than a cheese.\n\nFDA isolated _Listeria monocytogenes_ from 2 environmental samples collected in September 2015 from the Central Valley Cheese, Inc. manufacturing facility in Turlock, California. Central Valley Cheese, Inc. manufactures cheese for Karoun Dairies. Whole genome sequencing showed that these isolates were closely related genetically to isolates from ill people. In addition, whole genome sequencing showed that 5 _Listeria_ isolates collected in 2010 from the same facility were also closely related genetically to isolates from ill people.\n\nOn 16 Sep 2015, Karoun Dairies, Inc. voluntarily recalled certain cheeses that the company distributes due to possible contamination with _Listeria_. The recall includes several brands and types of cheeses that were distributed to retail outlets in the United States. Products were sold under the following brands: Karoun, Arz, Gopi, Queso Del Valle, Central Valley Creamery, and Yanni. Products were vacuum packed in jars or in pails. Weights vary from 5 ounces to 30 pounds. A full list of cheeses is available on the Advice to Consumers, Restaurants, and Retailers page.\n\nThis outbreak investigation is over. However, people could continue to get sick because recalled cheeses may still be in homes, restaurants, or retail locations. Consumers, restaurants, and retailers unaware of the recall could eat, serve, or sell them.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[For discussions of listeriosis, please see my comments in prior ProMED-mail posts listed below. - Denmark: multiple genotypes 20150429.3331222\nListeriosis - USA (06): (KS,TX) fatal, nosocomial, ice cream, recall, update 20150411.3291517\nListeriosis - USA (05): stone fruit 2014 20150321.3244417\nListeriosis - USA (04): (KS) fatal, nosocomial, ice cream 20150315.3231917\nListeriosis - USA (03): (IL,MI) fatal, sprouts, investigation closed 20150129.3129444\nListeriosis - USA (02): fatal, caramel-coated, prepackaged apples, update, alert 20150112.3085796\nListeriosis - USA: fatal, caramel-coated and pre-packaged apples, update, alert 20150103.3068902\n.................................................sb/ml/msp/dk", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "listeriosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-11 00:00:00", "2015-03-16 00:00:00", "2010-06-16 00:00:00", "2010-06-16 00:00:00", "2015-08-24 00:00:00", "2021-03-01 00:00:00", "2015-08-16 00:00:00", "1973-03-16 00:00:00", "2015-09-16 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2015-09-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tennessee", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "FATAL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Michigan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Virginia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "update", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New York", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "soft cheese", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Massachusetts", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Colorado", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Turlock", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Washington", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ohio", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Illinois", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "California", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3980669", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis - USA, Canada (02): fatal, recall, pre-packed salads, same genotype", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3980669", "date": "2015-10-25 10:32:25", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS - USA (11): FATAL, SOFT CHEESES, UPDATE, INVESTIGATION CLOSED\n*************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sat 23 Oct 2015\nSource: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) [edited]\nhttp://www.cdc.gov/listeria/outbreaks/soft-cheeses-09-15/\n\n\nCDC collaborated with public health officials in several states and the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) to investigate a multistate outbreak of _Listeria monocytogenes_ infections (listeriosis). _Listeria_ can cause a serious, life-threatening illness.\n\nPublic health investigators used the PulseNet system to identify illnesses that were part of the outbreak. PulseNet is the national subtyping network of public health and food regulatory agency laboratories coordinated by CDC. DNA \"fingerprinting\" is performed on _Listeria_ bacteria isolated from ill people by using techniques called pulsed-field gel electrophoresis (PFGE) and whole genome sequencing (WGS). PulseNet manages a national database of these DNA fingerprints to identify possible outbreaks. WGS gives a more detailed DNA fingerprint than PFGE. This additional detail was important because 5 rare PFGE fingerprints of _Listeria_ were included in this investigation. The sequencing showed that the _Listeria_ strains with the 5 rare PFGE fingerprints were closely related genetically.\n\n30 people infected with one of the closely related _Listeria_ strains were reported from 10 states since 16 Jun 2010. The number of ill people reported from each state was as follows: California (18), Colorado (1), Illinois (2), Massachusetts (2), Michigan (1), New York (2), Ohio (1), Tennessee (1), Virginia (1), and Washington (1).\n\nDates of _Listeria_ specimen collection ranged from 16 Jun 2010 to 24 Aug 2015. The cluster was 1st identified in August 2015 after investigators saw an increase in one of the 5 rare PFGE fingerprints reported to PulseNet. WGS found that the 4 other PFGE fingerprints were closely related genetically to the 1st PFGE fingerprint. Illnesses associated with those PFGE fingerprints were added to the investigation, including illnesses that occurred over 5 years ago.\n\nIll people ranged in age from less than one year to 92, and the median age was 73. 70 percent of ill people were female. 28 (93 percent) of 30 ill people for whom information was available reported being hospitalized. Six of the illnesses were pregnancy-related, and one illness resulted in a fetal loss. Three deaths were reported from California (2) and Ohio (1).\n\nEpidemiologic and laboratory information indicated that soft cheeses distributed by Karoun Dairies were the likely source of this outbreak.\n\nState and local health departments interviewed ill people about the foods they may have eaten or other exposures in the month before their illness began. 20 (67 percent) of 30 people with available information were of Middle Eastern or Eastern European descent or shopped at Middle Eastern or Eastern European-style markets. Of 28 ill people for whom information was available, 21 (75 percent) consumed soft cheese, and all of those 21 (100 percent) reported eating Middle Eastern, Eastern European, Mediterranean, or Mexican-style cheeses, including ani, feta (e.g., Bulgarian feta), Middle Eastern-style string cheese, nabulsi, and village cheese. Three of 7 ill people who specified the brand of cheese eaten reported brands distributed by Karoun Dairies. An additional ill person was unable to name the brand of cheese eaten but described the packaging and label of a Karoun product. No other brand of soft cheese was reported more than once. One other ill person reported eating Karoun brand kefir cheese. This person was previously included in the number of people reporting a Karoun brand soft cheese, but has now been excluded, since kefir is typically classified as a yogurt product rather than a cheese.\n\nFDA isolated _Listeria monocytogenes_ from 2 environmental samples collected in September 2015 from the Central Valley Cheese, Inc. manufacturing facility in Turlock, California. Central Valley Cheese, Inc. manufactures cheese for Karoun Dairies. Whole genome sequencing showed that these isolates were closely related genetically to isolates from ill people. In addition, whole genome sequencing showed that 5 _Listeria_ isolates collected in 2010 from the same facility were also closely related genetically to isolates from ill people.\n\nOn 16 Sep 2015, Karoun Dairies, Inc. voluntarily recalled certain cheeses that the company distributes due to possible contamination with _Listeria_. The recall includes several brands and types of cheeses that were distributed to retail outlets in the United States. Products were sold under the following brands: Karoun, Arz, Gopi, Queso Del Valle, Central Valley Creamery, and Yanni. Products were vacuum packed in jars or in pails. Weights vary from 5 ounces to 30 pounds. A full list of cheeses is available on the Advice to Consumers, Restaurants, and Retailers page.\n\nThis outbreak investigation is over. However, people could continue to get sick because recalled cheeses may still be in homes, restaurants, or retail locations. Consumers, restaurants, and retailers unaware of the recall could eat, serve, or sell them.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[For discussions of listeriosis, please see my comments in prior ProMED-mail posts listed below. - Mod.ML\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/106.]\nSee Also\nListeriosis - USA (10): fatal, soft cheeses, recall, alert 20150919.3657295\nListeriosis - USA (09): PulseNet, data collection, problems 20150721.3525757\nListeriosis - USA (08): fatal, nosocomial, ice cream, risk remains 20150615.3437487\nListeriosis - USA (07): ice cream, whole gene sequencing detection 20150506.3344944\nListeriosis - Canada: apple products, alert, recall 20150503.3336094\nListeriosis - Denmark: multiple genotypes 20150429.3331222\nListeriosis - USA (06): (KS,TX) fatal, nosocomial, ice cream, recall, update 20150411.3291517\nListeriosis - USA (05): stone fruit 2014 20150321.3244417\nListeriosis - USA (04): (KS) fatal, nosocomial, ice cream 20150315.3231917\nListeriosis - USA (03): (IL,MI) fatal, sprouts, investigation closed 20150129.3129444\nListeriosis - USA (02): fatal, caramel-coated, prepackaged apples, update, alert 20150112.3085796\nListeriosis - USA: fatal, caramel-coated and pre-packaged apples, update, alert 20150103.3068902\n.................................................sb/ml/msp/dk", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "listeriosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-11 00:00:00", "2015-03-16 00:00:00", "2010-06-16 00:00:00", "2010-06-16 00:00:00", "2015-08-24 00:00:00", "2021-03-01 00:00:00", "2015-08-16 00:00:00", "1973-03-16 00:00:00", "2015-09-16 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2015-09-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tennessee", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "FATAL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Michigan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Virginia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "update", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New York", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "soft cheese", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Massachusetts", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Colorado", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Turlock", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Washington", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ohio", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Illinois", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "California", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3960428", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis - USA, Canada: fatal, recall, pre-packed salads, RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3960428", "date": "2015-10-25 10:32:25", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS - USA (11): FATAL, SOFT CHEESES, UPDATE, INVESTIGATION CLOSED\n*************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sat 23 Oct 2015\nSource: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) [edited]\nhttp://www.cdc.gov/listeria/outbreaks/soft-cheeses-09-15/\n\n\nCDC collaborated with public health officials in several states and the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) to investigate a multistate outbreak of _Listeria monocytogenes_ infections (listeriosis). _Listeria_ can cause a serious, life-threatening illness.\n\nPublic health investigators used the PulseNet system to identify illnesses that were part of the outbreak. PulseNet is the national subtyping network of public health and food regulatory agency laboratories coordinated by CDC. DNA \"fingerprinting\" is performed on _Listeria_ bacteria isolated from ill people by using techniques called pulsed-field gel electrophoresis (PFGE) and whole genome sequencing (WGS). PulseNet manages a national database of these DNA fingerprints to identify possible outbreaks. WGS gives a more detailed DNA fingerprint than PFGE. This additional detail was important because 5 rare PFGE fingerprints of _Listeria_ were included in this investigation. The sequencing showed that the _Listeria_ strains with the 5 rare PFGE fingerprints were closely related genetically.\n\n30 people infected with one of the closely related _Listeria_ strains were reported from 10 states since 16 Jun 2010. The number of ill people reported from each state was as follows: California (18), Colorado (1), Illinois (2), Massachusetts (2), Michigan (1), New York (2), Ohio (1), Tennessee (1), Virginia (1), and Washington (1).\n\nDates of _Listeria_ specimen collection ranged from 16 Jun 2010 to 24 Aug 2015. The cluster was 1st identified in August 2015 after investigators saw an increase in one of the 5 rare PFGE fingerprints reported to PulseNet. WGS found that the 4 other PFGE fingerprints were closely related genetically to the 1st PFGE fingerprint. Illnesses associated with those PFGE fingerprints were added to the investigation, including illnesses that occurred over 5 years ago.\n\nIll people ranged in age from less than one year to 92, and the median age was 73. 70 percent of ill people were female. 28 (93 percent) of 30 ill people for whom information was available reported being hospitalized. Six of the illnesses were pregnancy-related, and one illness resulted in a fetal loss. Three deaths were reported from California (2) and Ohio (1).\n\nEpidemiologic and laboratory information indicated that soft cheeses distributed by Karoun Dairies were the likely source of this outbreak.\n\nState and local health departments interviewed ill people about the foods they may have eaten or other exposures in the month before their illness began. 20 (67 percent) of 30 people with available information were of Middle Eastern or Eastern European descent or shopped at Middle Eastern or Eastern European-style markets. Of 28 ill people for whom information was available, 21 (75 percent) consumed soft cheese, and all of those 21 (100 percent) reported eating Middle Eastern, Eastern European, Mediterranean, or Mexican-style cheeses, including ani, feta (e.g., Bulgarian feta), Middle Eastern-style string cheese, nabulsi, and village cheese. Three of 7 ill people who specified the brand of cheese eaten reported brands distributed by Karoun Dairies. An additional ill person was unable to name the brand of cheese eaten but described the packaging and label of a Karoun product. No other brand of soft cheese was reported more than once. One other ill person reported eating Karoun brand kefir cheese. This person was previously included in the number of people reporting a Karoun brand soft cheese, but has now been excluded, since kefir is typically classified as a yogurt product rather than a cheese.\n\nFDA isolated _Listeria monocytogenes_ from 2 environmental samples collected in September 2015 from the Central Valley Cheese, Inc. manufacturing facility in Turlock, California. Central Valley Cheese, Inc. manufactures cheese for Karoun Dairies. Whole genome sequencing showed that these isolates were closely related genetically to isolates from ill people. In addition, whole genome sequencing showed that 5 _Listeria_ isolates collected in 2010 from the same facility were also closely related genetically to isolates from ill people.\n\nOn 16 Sep 2015, Karoun Dairies, Inc. voluntarily recalled certain cheeses that the company distributes due to possible contamination with _Listeria_. The recall includes several brands and types of cheeses that were distributed to retail outlets in the United States. Products were sold under the following brands: Karoun, Arz, Gopi, Queso Del Valle, Central Valley Creamery, and Yanni. Products were vacuum packed in jars or in pails. Weights vary from 5 ounces to 30 pounds. A full list of cheeses is available on the Advice to Consumers, Restaurants, and Retailers page.\n\nThis outbreak investigation is over. However, people could continue to get sick because recalled cheeses may still be in homes, restaurants, or retail locations. Consumers, restaurants, and retailers unaware of the recall could eat, serve, or sell them.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[For discussions of listeriosis, please see my comments in prior ProMED-mail posts listed below. - Illnesses associated with those PFGE fingerprints were added to the investigation, including illnesses that occurred over 5 years ago.\n\nIll people ranged in age from less than one year to 92, and the median age was 73. 70 percent of ill people were female. 28 (93 percent) of 30 ill people for whom information was available reported being hospitalized. Six of the illnesses were pregnancy-related, and one illness resulted in a fetal loss. Three deaths were reported from California (2) and Ohio (1).\n\nEpidemiologic and laboratory information indicated that soft cheeses distributed by Karoun Dairies were the likely source of this outbreak.\n\nState and local health departments interviewed ill people about the foods they may have eaten or other exposures in the month before their illness began. 20 (67 percent) of 30 people with available information were of Middle Eastern or Eastern European descent or shopped at Middle Eastern or Eastern European-style markets. Of 28 ill people for whom information was available, 21 (75 percent) consumed soft cheese, and all of those 21 (100 percent) reported eating Middle Eastern, Eastern European, Mediterranean, or Mexican-style cheeses, including ani, feta (e.g., Bulgarian feta), Middle Eastern-style string cheese, nabulsi, and village cheese. Three of 7 ill people who specified the brand of cheese eaten reported brands distributed by Karoun Dairies. An additional ill person was unable to name the brand of cheese eaten but described the packaging and label of a Karoun product. No other brand of soft cheese was reported more than once. One other ill person reported eating Karoun brand kefir cheese. This person was previously included in the number of people reporting a Karoun brand soft cheese, but has now been excluded, since kefir is typically classified as a yogurt product rather than a cheese.\n\nFDA isolated _Listeria monocytogenes_ from 2 environmental samples collected in September 2015 from the Central Valley Cheese, Inc. manufacturing facility in Turlock, California. Central Valley Cheese, Inc. manufactures cheese for Karoun Dairies. Whole genome sequencing showed that these isolates were closely related genetically to isolates from ill people. In addition, whole genome sequencing showed that 5 _Listeria_ isolates collected in 2010 from the same facility were also closely related genetically to isolates from ill people.\n\nOn 16 Sep 2015, Karoun Dairies, Inc. voluntarily recalled certain cheeses that the company distributes due to possible contamination with _Listeria_. The recall includes several brands and types of cheeses that were distributed to retail outlets in the United States. Products were sold under the following brands: Karoun, Arz, Gopi, Queso Del Valle, Central Valley Creamery, and Yanni. Products were vacuum packed in jars or in pails. Weights vary from 5 ounces to 30 pounds. A full list of cheeses is available on the Advice to Consumers, Restaurants, and Retailers page.\n\nThis outbreak investigation is over. However, people could continue to get sick because recalled cheeses may still be in homes, restaurants, or retail locations. Consumers, restaurants, and retailers unaware of the recall could eat, serve, or sell them.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[For discussions of listeriosis, please see my comments in prior ProMED-mail posts listed below. - Denmark: multiple genotypes 20150429.3331222\nListeriosis - USA (06): (KS,TX) fatal, nosocomial, ice cream, recall, update 20150411.3291517\nListeriosis - USA (05): stone fruit 2014 20150321.3244417\nListeriosis - USA: fatal, caramel-coated and pre-packaged apples, update, alert 20150103.3068902\n.................................................sb/ml/msp/dk", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "listeriosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-11 00:00:00", "2015-03-16 00:00:00", "2010-06-16 00:00:00", "2010-06-16 00:00:00", "2015-08-24 00:00:00", "2021-03-01 00:00:00", "2015-08-16 00:00:00", "1973-03-16 00:00:00", "2015-09-16 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2015-09-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tennessee", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "FATAL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Michigan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Virginia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "update", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New York", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "soft cheese", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Massachusetts", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Colorado", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Turlock", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Washington", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ohio", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Illinois", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "California", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3873909", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis - Germany: (southern states) fatal, unique cluster type, 2012-2015", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3873909", "date": "2015-10-25 10:32:25", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS - USA (11): FATAL, SOFT CHEESES, UPDATE, INVESTIGATION CLOSED\n*************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sat 23 Oct 2015\nSource: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) [edited]\nhttp://www.cdc.gov/listeria/outbreaks/soft-cheeses-09-15/\n\n\nCDC collaborated with public health officials in several states and the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) to investigate a multistate outbreak of _Listeria monocytogenes_ infections (listeriosis). _Listeria_ can cause a serious, life-threatening illness.\n\nPublic health investigators used the PulseNet system to identify illnesses that were part of the outbreak. PulseNet is the national subtyping network of public health and food regulatory agency laboratories coordinated by CDC. DNA \"fingerprinting\" is performed on _Listeria_ bacteria isolated from ill people by using techniques called pulsed-field gel electrophoresis (PFGE) and whole genome sequencing (WGS). PulseNet manages a national database of these DNA fingerprints to identify possible outbreaks. WGS gives a more detailed DNA fingerprint than PFGE. This additional detail was important because 5 rare PFGE fingerprints of _Listeria_ were included in this investigation. The sequencing showed that the _Listeria_ strains with the 5 rare PFGE fingerprints were closely related genetically.\n\n30 people infected with one of the closely related _Listeria_ strains were reported from 10 states since 16 Jun 2010. The number of ill people reported from each state was as follows: California (18), Colorado (1), Illinois (2), Massachusetts (2), Michigan (1), New York (2), Ohio (1), Tennessee (1), Virginia (1), and Washington (1).\n\nDates of _Listeria_ specimen collection ranged from 16 Jun 2010 to 24 Aug 2015. The cluster was 1st identified in August 2015 after investigators saw an increase in one of the 5 rare PFGE fingerprints reported to PulseNet. WGS found that the 4 other PFGE fingerprints were closely related genetically to the 1st PFGE fingerprint. Illnesses associated with those PFGE fingerprints were added to the investigation, including illnesses that occurred over 5 years ago.\n\nIll people ranged in age from less than one year to 92, and the median age was 73. 70 percent of ill people were female. 28 (93 percent) of 30 ill people for whom information was available reported being hospitalized. Six of the illnesses were pregnancy-related, and one illness resulted in a fetal loss. Three deaths were reported from California (2) and Ohio (1).\n\nEpidemiologic and laboratory information indicated that soft cheeses distributed by Karoun Dairies were the likely source of this outbreak.\n\nState and local health departments interviewed ill people about the foods they may have eaten or other exposures in the month before their illness began. 20 (67 percent) of 30 people with available information were of Middle Eastern or Eastern European descent or shopped at Middle Eastern or Eastern European-style markets. Of 28 ill people for whom information was available, 21 (75 percent) consumed soft cheese, and all of those 21 (100 percent) reported eating Middle Eastern, Eastern European, Mediterranean, or Mexican-style cheeses, including ani, feta (e.g., Bulgarian feta), Middle Eastern-style string cheese, nabulsi, and village cheese. Three of 7 ill people who specified the brand of cheese eaten reported brands distributed by Karoun Dairies. An additional ill person was unable to name the brand of cheese eaten but described the packaging and label of a Karoun product. No other brand of soft cheese was reported more than once. One other ill person reported eating Karoun brand kefir cheese. This person was previously included in the number of people reporting a Karoun brand soft cheese, but has now been excluded, since kefir is typically classified as a yogurt product rather than a cheese.\n\nFDA isolated _Listeria monocytogenes_ from 2 environmental samples collected in September 2015 from the Central Valley Cheese, Inc. manufacturing facility in Turlock, California. Central Valley Cheese, Inc. manufactures cheese for Karoun Dairies. Whole genome sequencing showed that these isolates were closely related genetically to isolates from ill people. In addition, whole genome sequencing showed that 5 _Listeria_ isolates collected in 2010 from the same facility were also closely related genetically to isolates from ill people.\n\nOn 16 Sep 2015, Karoun Dairies, Inc. voluntarily recalled certain cheeses that the company distributes due to possible contamination with _Listeria_. The recall includes several brands and types of cheeses that were distributed to retail outlets in the United States. Products were sold under the following brands: Karoun, Arz, Gopi, Queso Del Valle, Central Valley Creamery, and Yanni. Products were vacuum packed in jars or in pails. Weights vary from 5 ounces to 30 pounds. A full list of cheeses is available on the Advice to Consumers, Restaurants, and Retailers page.\n\nThis outbreak investigation is over. However, people could continue to get sick because recalled cheeses may still be in homes, restaurants, or retail locations. Consumers, restaurants, and retailers unaware of the recall could eat, serve, or sell them.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[For discussions of listeriosis, please see my comments in prior ProMED-mail posts listed below. - PulseNet is the national subtyping network of public health and food regulatory agency laboratories coordinated by CDC. DNA \"fingerprinting\" is performed on _Listeria_ bacteria isolated from ill people by using techniques called pulsed-field gel electrophoresis (PFGE) and whole genome sequencing (WGS). An additional ill person was unable to name the brand of cheese eaten but described the packaging and label of a Karoun product. No other brand of soft cheese was reported more than once. One other ill person reported eating Karoun brand kefir cheese. This person was previously included in the number of people reporting a Karoun brand soft cheese, but has now been excluded, since kefir is typically classified as a yogurt product rather than a cheese.\n\nFDA isolated _Listeria monocytogenes_ from 2 environmental samples collected in September 2015 from the Central Valley Cheese, Inc. manufacturing facility in Turlock, California. In addition, whole genome sequencing showed that 5 _Listeria_ isolates collected in 2010 from the same facility were also closely related genetically to isolates from ill people.\n\nOn 16 Sep 2015, Karoun Dairies, Inc. voluntarily recalled certain cheeses that the company distributes due to possible contamination with _Listeria_. Products were sold under the following brands: Karoun, Arz, Gopi, Queso Del Valle, Central Valley Creamery, and Yanni. Products were vacuum packed in jars or in pails. Weights vary from 5 ounces to 30 pounds. A full list of cheeses is available on the Advice to Consumers, Restaurants, and Retailers page.\n\nThis outbreak investigation is over.
