USA: fatal, caramel-coated and pre-packaged apples, update, alert 20150103.3068902\n.................................................sb/ml/msp/dk", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "listeriosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-11 00:00:00", "2015-03-16 00:00:00", "2010-06-16 00:00:00", "2010-06-16 00:00:00", "2015-08-24 00:00:00", "2021-03-01 00:00:00", "2015-08-16 00:00:00", "1973-03-16 00:00:00", "2015-09-16 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2015-09-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tennessee", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "FATAL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Michigan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Virginia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "update", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New York", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "soft cheese", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Massachusetts", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Colorado", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Turlock", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Washington", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ohio", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Illinois", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "California", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3657295", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis - USA (10): fatal, soft cheeses, recall, alert", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3657295", "date": "2015-03-21 22:23:27", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS - USA (05): STONE FRUIT 2014\n*****************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 20 Mar 2015\nSource: CDC. MMWR Morb Mortal Wkly Rep 2015; 64(10): 282-3 [edited]\nhttp://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm6410a6.htm?s_cid=mm6410a6_w\n\n\nListeriosis associated with stone fruit -- United States, 2014\n----------------------------------------------------------------------\n[Authors: Jackson BR, Salter M, Tarr C, et al]\n\nOn 19 Jul 2014, a packing company in California (company A) voluntarily recalled certain lots of stone fruits, including whole peaches, nectarines, plums, and pluots, because of concern about contamination with _Listeria monocytogenes_ based on internal company testing (1). On 31 Jul 2014, the recall was expanded to cover all fruit packed at their facility during 1 Jun 2014-17 Jul 2014 (2). After the initial recall, clinicians, state and local health departments, CDC, and the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) received many inquiries about listeriosis from concerned consumers, many of whom had received automated telephone calls informing them that they had purchased recalled fruit. During 19-31 Jul 2014, the CDC _Listeria_ website received more than 500 000 page views, more than 7 times the views received during the previous 52 weeks. However, no molecular information from _L. monocytogenes_ isolates was available to assess whether human illnesses might be linked to these products.\n\nIn early August 2014, a 2-enzyme pulsed-field gel electrophoresis (PFGE) pattern shared by 3 _L. monocytogenes_ isolates from stone fruit associated with the recall was uploaded to PulseNet, the national molecular subtyping network for foodborne disease surveillance. 4 human isolates with isolation dates during the period 8 May 2014-8 Jul 2014 (Illinois, Massachusetts, and South Carolina) and 28 Aug 2014 (Minnesota) were identified that had PFGE patterns indistinguishable from isolates from company A stone fruit. Samples of stone fruits from company A collected after the recall yielded an additional 31 _L. monocytogenes_ isolates, 22 of which were indistinguishable from the initial isolates by PFGE; 3 other PFGE patterns were identified that did not match any isolates from clinical specimens collected during 1 May-31 Aug 2014. Whole-genome sequencing (WGS) analysis by whole-genome multilocus sequence typing showed that isolates from the Massachusetts and Minnesota patients were highly related (less than 10 allele differences and less than 10 high-quality single nucleotide polymorphism differences) to the isolates from recalled stone fruits, whereas the Illinois and South Carolina isolates were not.\n\nA review of the standardized _Listeria_ Initiative exposure questionnaire (3) for the Massachusetts patient showed that organic nectarine consumption was recorded, although the form does not specifically ask about stone fruit consumption. A subsequent interview using a questionnaire with questions about stone fruits indicated that the patient consumed nectarines and peaches purchased from stores that sold company A stone fruit. Traceback using receipts and shopper card data indicated the patient's family purchased recalled fruit. An interview with a family member of the Minnesota patient revealed that the patient consumed peaches from a store that received company A stone fruit; however, dates from receipts indicated that the peaches were purchased after the recalled fruit was reported to have been removed from the shelves. After removal of recalled fruit, the store received company A peaches that were not part of the recall as well as peaches from another California supplier. The South Carolina patient reportedly did not eat stone fruit before becoming ill. Family of the Illinois patient could not be reached for interview.\n\nStrong evidence linked the Massachusetts case to recalled stone fruit, including food exposure interviews, receipt and shopper card data, and WGS results showing very high genetic relatedness between the patient's isolate and isolates from nectarines. Consumption data and WGS results suggest that stone fruit was also the likely source of _L. monocytogenes_ infection in the Minnesota case; however, the later dates of illness onset and fruit purchase suggest that the patient consumed stone fruit that was not included in the recall.\n\nThis is the 1st reported link between human listeriosis and stone fruit. WGS results provided a basis for focusing resources for extended case interviews and follow-up. Specifically, among cases that matched the recalled stone fruit by PFGE, WGS allowed differentiation between sporadic cases and cases associated with stone fruit consumption.\n\nReported listeriosis is much more common in pregnant women than in the general population and can cause major fetal and perinatal complications. Because of this higher risk, and partially in response to public concern stemming from these recalls, the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists issued guidelines for management of pregnant women with possible _L. monocytogenes_ exposure (4). Although exposure to this recalled product was likely widespread, disease was very rare. Therefore, this recall and associated illness does not provide sufficient evidence to recommend that persons at higher risk for listeriosis (such as, pregnant women, persons aged 65 years or older, and immunocompromised persons) avoid fresh stone fruits. However, it does support the need to understand risks associated with contaminated, ready-to-eat fresh fruit so that prevention strategies can be strengthened.\n\nReferences\n----------\n1. FDA. Recall -- firm press release: Wawona Packing Co. takes precautionary step of voluntarily recalling fresh, whole peaches, plums, nectarines, and pluots because of possible health risk. Available at http://www.fda.gov/Safety/Recalls/ucm405943.htm.\n2. FDA. Recall -- firm press release: Wawona Packing Co. expands its voluntary recall of fresh, whole peaches, plums, nectarines, and pluots because of possible health risk. Available at http://www.fda.gov/Safety/Recalls/ucm407600.htm\n3. CDC. _Listeria_ (Listeriosis) surveillance. Available at http://www.cdc.gov/listeria/surveillance.html\n4. American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists. Ob-Gyns address management of Listeria during pregnancy. Available at http://www.acog.org/About-ACOG/News-Room/News-Releases/2014/Ob-Gyns-Address-Management-of-Listeria-During-Pregnancy\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[As stated in the post, this is the 1st link between stone fruit and human listeriosis.\n\nThe name pluot was not known to me. The strangely named \"pluot(R)\" (http://www.wisegeek.org/what-are-pluots.htm) is a hybrid plant grown from a plum and an apricot. They are extremely sweet, due to very high sugar levels, and are available in a wide range of varieties. The actual ratio works out to around 70 percent plum and 30 apricot and they mainly look like plums. They have a great deal of nutritious value and are low in fat, making them ideal for snacking or sweetening up other dishes.\n\nPluots are sometimes also referred to as \"dinosaur eggs(R)\" due to the strange dappled coloring on some types of the fruit. The name has actually been trademarked by a California pluot grower, though there are still a wide range of available types with other strange-sounding names. Varieties such as the \"flavor grenade,\" \"dapple dandy,\" and \"flavorglo\" are fairly common, as are the \"hand grenade\" and the \"last chance.\" The \"flavor heart\" is one of the largest types of pluot, heart shaped with black coloring and yellow flesh, while the \"candy stripe\" has pink and yellow stripes with spotted red skin (see varieties at http://ww2.hdnux.com/photos/31/31/21/6657137/3/622x350.jpg. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/106.]\nSee Also\nListeriosis - USA (04): (KS) fatal, nosocomial, ice cream 20150315.3231917\nListeriosis - USA (03): (IL,MI) fatal, sprouts, investigation closed 20150129.3129444\nListeriosis - USA (02): fatal, caramel-coated, prepackaged apples, update, alert 20150112.3085796\nListeriosis - USA: fatal, caramel-coated and pre-packaged apples, update, alert 20150103.3068902\n2014\n----\nListeriosis - USA (05): (WA) ice cream, gelato, custard, sorbet, alert 20141229.3060474\nListeriosis - Canada: (ON,MB) ex USA, susp, same genotype 20141226.3055407\nListeriosis - USA (04): fatal, caramel-coated and pre-packaged apples, alert 20141219.3044758\nListeriosis - USA (03): (IL, MI) fatal, sprouts, recall 20141109.2941351\nListeriosis - USA (02): 2013, fatal, cheese 20140410.2394195\nListeriosis - USA: (CA, MD) fatal, Hispanic-style soft cheese, recall 20140222.2294169\n.................................................ll/mj/jw", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "listeriosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Minnesota", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Illinois , Massachusetts", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "South Carolina", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Massachusetts", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "MD", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Illinois", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "California", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3525757", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis - USA (09): PulseNet, data collection, problems", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3525757", "date": "2015-03-21 22:23:27", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS - USA (05): STONE FRUIT 2014\n*****************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 20 Mar 2015\nSource: CDC. MMWR Morb Mortal Wkly Rep 2015; 64(10): 282-3 [edited]\nhttp://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm6410a6.htm?s_cid=mm6410a6_w\n\n\nListeriosis associated with stone fruit -- United States, 2014\n----------------------------------------------------------------------\n[Authors: Jackson BR, Salter M, Tarr C, et al]\n\nOn 19 Jul 2014, a packing company in California (company A) voluntarily recalled certain lots of stone fruits, including whole peaches, nectarines, plums, and pluots, because of concern about contamination with _Listeria monocytogenes_ based on internal company testing (1). On 31 Jul 2014, the recall was expanded to cover all fruit packed at their facility during 1 Jun 2014-17 Jul 2014 (2). After the initial recall, clinicians, state and local health departments, CDC, and the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) received many inquiries about listeriosis from concerned consumers, many of whom had received automated telephone calls informing them that they had purchased recalled fruit. During 19-31 Jul 2014, the CDC _Listeria_ website received more than 500 000 page views, more than 7 times the views received during the previous 52 weeks. However, no molecular information from _L. monocytogenes_ isolates was available to assess whether human illnesses might be linked to these products.\n\nIn early August 2014, a 2-enzyme pulsed-field gel electrophoresis (PFGE) pattern shared by 3 _L. monocytogenes_ isolates from stone fruit associated with the recall was uploaded to PulseNet, the national molecular subtyping network for foodborne disease surveillance. 4 human isolates with isolation dates during the period 8 May 2014-8 Jul 2014 (Illinois, Massachusetts, and South Carolina) and 28 Aug 2014 (Minnesota) were identified that had PFGE patterns indistinguishable from isolates from company A stone fruit. Samples of stone fruits from company A collected after the recall yielded an additional 31 _L. monocytogenes_ isolates, 22 of which were indistinguishable from the initial isolates by PFGE; 3 other PFGE patterns were identified that did not match any isolates from clinical specimens collected during 1 May-31 Aug 2014. Whole-genome sequencing (WGS) analysis by whole-genome multilocus sequence typing showed that isolates from the Massachusetts and Minnesota patients were highly related (less than 10 allele differences and less than 10 high-quality single nucleotide polymorphism differences) to the isolates from recalled stone fruits, whereas the Illinois and South Carolina isolates were not.\n\nA review of the standardized _Listeria_ Initiative exposure questionnaire (3) for the Massachusetts patient showed that organic nectarine consumption was recorded, although the form does not specifically ask about stone fruit consumption. A subsequent interview using a questionnaire with questions about stone fruits indicated that the patient consumed nectarines and peaches purchased from stores that sold company A stone fruit. Traceback using receipts and shopper card data indicated the patient's family purchased recalled fruit. An interview with a family member of the Minnesota patient revealed that the patient consumed peaches from a store that received company A stone fruit; however, dates from receipts indicated that the peaches were purchased after the recalled fruit was reported to have been removed from the shelves. After removal of recalled fruit, the store received company A peaches that were not part of the recall as well as peaches from another California supplier. The South Carolina patient reportedly did not eat stone fruit before becoming ill. Family of the Illinois patient could not be reached for interview.\n\nStrong evidence linked the Massachusetts case to recalled stone fruit, including food exposure interviews, receipt and shopper card data, and WGS results showing very high genetic relatedness between the patient's isolate and isolates from nectarines. Consumption data and WGS results suggest that stone fruit was also the likely source of _L. monocytogenes_ infection in the Minnesota case; however, the later dates of illness onset and fruit purchase suggest that the patient consumed stone fruit that was not included in the recall.\n\nThis is the 1st reported link between human listeriosis and stone fruit. WGS results provided a basis for focusing resources for extended case interviews and follow-up. Specifically, among cases that matched the recalled stone fruit by PFGE, WGS allowed differentiation between sporadic cases and cases associated with stone fruit consumption.\n\nReported listeriosis is much more common in pregnant women than in the general population and can cause major fetal and perinatal complications. Because of this higher risk, and partially in response to public concern stemming from these recalls, the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists issued guidelines for management of pregnant women with possible _L. monocytogenes_ exposure (4). Although exposure to this recalled product was likely widespread, disease was very rare. Therefore, this recall and associated illness does not provide sufficient evidence to recommend that persons at higher risk for listeriosis (such as, pregnant women, persons aged 65 years or older, and immunocompromised persons) avoid fresh stone fruits. However, it does support the need to understand risks associated with contaminated, ready-to-eat fresh fruit so that prevention strategies can be strengthened.\n\nReferences\n----------\n1. FDA. Recall -- firm press release: Wawona Packing Co. takes precautionary step of voluntarily recalling fresh, whole peaches, plums, nectarines, and pluots because of possible health risk. Available at http://www.fda.gov/Safety/Recalls/ucm405943.htm.\n2. FDA. Recall -- firm press release: Wawona Packing Co. expands its voluntary recall of fresh, whole peaches, plums, nectarines, and pluots because of possible health risk. Available at http://www.fda.gov/Safety/Recalls/ucm407600.htm\n3. CDC. _Listeria_ (Listeriosis) surveillance. Available at http://www.cdc.gov/listeria/surveillance.html\n4. American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists. Ob-Gyns address management of Listeria during pregnancy. Available at http://www.acog.org/About-ACOG/News-Room/News-Releases/2014/Ob-Gyns-Address-Management-of-Listeria-During-Pregnancy\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[As stated in the post, this is the 1st link between stone fruit and human listeriosis.\n\nThe name pluot was not known to me. The strangely named \"pluot(R)\" (http://www.wisegeek.org/what-are-pluots.htm) is a hybrid plant grown from a plum and an apricot. They are extremely sweet, due to very high sugar levels, and are available in a wide range of varieties. The actual ratio works out to around 70 percent plum and 30 apricot and they mainly look like plums. They have a great deal of nutritious value and are low in fat, making them ideal for snacking or sweetening up other dishes.\n\nPluots are sometimes also referred to as \"dinosaur eggs(R)\" due to the strange dappled coloring on some types of the fruit. The name has actually been trademarked by a California pluot grower, though there are still a wide range of available types with other strange-sounding names. Varieties such as the \"flavor grenade,\" \"dapple dandy,\" and \"flavorglo\" are fairly common, as are the \"hand grenade\" and the \"last chance.\" The \"flavor heart\" is one of the largest types of pluot, heart shaped with black coloring and yellow flesh, while the \"candy stripe\" has pink and yellow stripes with spotted red skin (see varieties at http://ww2.hdnux.com/photos/31/31/21/6657137/3/622x350.jpg. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/106.]\nSee Also\nListeriosis - USA (04): (KS) fatal, nosocomial, ice cream 20150315.3231917\nListeriosis - USA (03): (IL,MI) fatal, sprouts, investigation closed 20150129.3129444\nListeriosis - USA (02): fatal, caramel-coated, prepackaged apples, update, alert 20150112.3085796\nListeriosis - USA: fatal, caramel-coated and pre-packaged apples, update, alert 20150103.3068902\n2014\n----\nListeriosis - USA (03): (IL, MI) fatal, sprouts, recall 20141109.2941351\nListeriosis - USA (02): 2013, fatal, cheese 20140410.2394195\nListeriosis - USA: (CA, MD) fatal, Hispanic-style soft cheese, recall 20140222.2294169\n.................................................ll/mj/jw", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "listeriosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Minnesota", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Illinois , Massachusetts", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "South Carolina", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Massachusetts", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "MD", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Illinois", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "California", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3437487", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis - USA (07): ice cream, whole gene sequencing detection", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3344944", "date": "2015-03-21 22:23:27", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS - USA (05): STONE FRUIT 2014\n*****************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 20 Mar 2015\nSource: CDC. MMWR Morb Mortal Wkly Rep 2015; 64(10): 282-3 [edited]\nhttp://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm6410a6.htm?s_cid=mm6410a6_w\n\n\nListeriosis associated with stone fruit -- United States, 2014\n----------------------------------------------------------------------\n[Authors: Jackson BR, Salter M, Tarr C, et al]\n\nOn 19 Jul 2014, a packing company in California (company A) voluntarily recalled certain lots of stone fruits, including whole peaches, nectarines, plums, and pluots, because of concern about contamination with _Listeria monocytogenes_ based on internal company testing (1). On 31 Jul 2014, the recall was expanded to cover all fruit packed at their facility during 1 Jun 2014-17 Jul 2014 (2). After the initial recall, clinicians, state and local health departments, CDC, and the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) received many inquiries about listeriosis from concerned consumers, many of whom had received automated telephone calls informing them that they had purchased recalled fruit. During 19-31 Jul 2014, the CDC _Listeria_ website received more than 500 000 page views, more than 7 times the views received during the previous 52 weeks. However, no molecular information from _L. monocytogenes_ isolates was available to assess whether human illnesses might be linked to these products.\n\nIn early August 2014, a 2-enzyme pulsed-field gel electrophoresis (PFGE) pattern shared by 3 _L. monocytogenes_ isolates from stone fruit associated with the recall was uploaded to PulseNet, the national molecular subtyping network for foodborne disease surveillance. 4 human isolates with isolation dates during the period 8 May 2014-8 Jul 2014 (Illinois, Massachusetts, and South Carolina) and 28 Aug 2014 (Minnesota) were identified that had PFGE patterns indistinguishable from isolates from company A stone fruit. Samples of stone fruits from company A collected after the recall yielded an additional 31 _L. monocytogenes_ isolates, 22 of which were indistinguishable from the initial isolates by PFGE; 3 other PFGE patterns were identified that did not match any isolates from clinical specimens collected during 1 May-31 Aug 2014. Whole-genome sequencing (WGS) analysis by whole-genome multilocus sequence typing showed that isolates from the Massachusetts and Minnesota patients were highly related (less than 10 allele differences and less than 10 high-quality single nucleotide polymorphism differences) to the isolates from recalled stone fruits, whereas the Illinois and South Carolina isolates were not.\n\nA review of the standardized _Listeria_ Initiative exposure questionnaire (3) for the Massachusetts patient showed that organic nectarine consumption was recorded, although the form does not specifically ask about stone fruit consumption. A subsequent interview using a questionnaire with questions about stone fruits indicated that the patient consumed nectarines and peaches purchased from stores that sold company A stone fruit. Traceback using receipts and shopper card data indicated the patient's family purchased recalled fruit. An interview with a family member of the Minnesota patient revealed that the patient consumed peaches from a store that received company A stone fruit; however, dates from receipts indicated that the peaches were purchased after the recalled fruit was reported to have been removed from the shelves. After removal of recalled fruit, the store received company A peaches that were not part of the recall as well as peaches from another California supplier. The South Carolina patient reportedly did not eat stone fruit before becoming ill. Family of the Illinois patient could not be reached for interview.\n\nStrong evidence linked the Massachusetts case to recalled stone fruit, including food exposure interviews, receipt and shopper card data, and WGS results showing very high genetic relatedness between the patient's isolate and isolates from nectarines. Consumption data and WGS results suggest that stone fruit was also the likely source of _L. monocytogenes_ infection in the Minnesota case; however, the later dates of illness onset and fruit purchase suggest that the patient consumed stone fruit that was not included in the recall.\n\nThis is the 1st reported link between human listeriosis and stone fruit. WGS results provided a basis for focusing resources for extended case interviews and follow-up. Specifically, among cases that matched the recalled stone fruit by PFGE, WGS allowed differentiation between sporadic cases and cases associated with stone fruit consumption.\n\nReported listeriosis is much more common in pregnant women than in the general population and can cause major fetal and perinatal complications. Because of this higher risk, and partially in response to public concern stemming from these recalls, the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists issued guidelines for management of pregnant women with possible _L. monocytogenes_ exposure (4). Although exposure to this recalled product was likely widespread, disease was very rare. Therefore, this recall and associated illness does not provide sufficient evidence to recommend that persons at higher risk for listeriosis (such as, pregnant women, persons aged 65 years or older, and immunocompromised persons) avoid fresh stone fruits. However, it does support the need to understand risks associated with contaminated, ready-to-eat fresh fruit so that prevention strategies can be strengthened.\n\nReferences\n----------\n1. FDA. The strangely named \"pluot(R)\" (http://www.wisegeek.org/what-are-pluots.htm) is a hybrid plant grown from a plum and an apricot. They are extremely sweet, due to very high sugar levels, and are available in a wide range of varieties. The actual ratio works out to around 70 percent plum and 30 apricot and they mainly look like plums. They have a great deal of nutritious value and are low in fat, making them ideal for snacking or sweetening up other dishes.\n\nPluots are sometimes also referred to as \"dinosaur eggs(R)\" due to the strange dappled coloring on some types of the fruit. The name has actually been trademarked by a California pluot grower, though there are still a wide range of available types with other strange-sounding names. Varieties such as the \"flavor grenade,\" \"dapple dandy,\" and \"flavorglo\" are fairly common, as are the \"hand grenade\" and the \"last chance.\" The \"flavor heart\" is one of the largest types of pluot, heart shaped with black coloring and yellow flesh, while the \"candy stripe\" has pink and yellow stripes with spotted red skin (see varieties at http://ww2.hdnux.com/photos/31/31/21/6657137/3/622x350.jpg. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/106.]\nSee Also\nListeriosis - USA (04): (KS) fatal, nosocomial, ice cream 20150315.3231917\nListeriosis - USA (03): (IL,MI) fatal, sprouts, investigation closed 20150129.3129444\nListeriosis - USA (02): fatal, caramel-coated, prepackaged apples, update, alert 20150112.3085796\nListeriosis - USA: fatal, caramel-coated and pre-packaged apples, update, alert 20150103.3068902\n2014\n----\nListeriosis - USA (05): (WA) ice cream, gelato, custard, sorbet, alert 20141229.3060474\nListeriosis - Canada: (ON,MB) ex USA, susp, same genotype 20141226.3055407\nListeriosis - USA (04): fatal, caramel-coated and pre-packaged apples, alert 20141219.3044758\nListeriosis - USA (03): (IL, MI) fatal, sprouts, recall 20141109.2941351\nListeriosis - USA (02): 2013, fatal, cheese 20140410.2394195\nListeriosis - USA: (CA, MD) fatal, Hispanic-style soft cheese, recall 20140222.2294169\n.................................................ll/mj/jw", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "listeriosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Minnesota", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Illinois , Massachusetts", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "South Carolina", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Massachusetts", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "MD", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Illinois", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "California", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3336094", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis - Canada: apple products, alert, recall", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3336094", "date": "2015-03-21 22:23:27", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS - USA (05): STONE FRUIT 2014\n*****************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 20 Mar 2015\nSource: CDC. MMWR Morb Mortal Wkly Rep 2015; 64(10): 282-3 [edited]\nhttp://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm6410a6.htm?s_cid=mm6410a6_w\n\n\nListeriosis associated with stone fruit -- United States, 2014\n----------------------------------------------------------------------\n[Authors: Jackson BR, Salter M, Tarr C, et al]\n\nOn 19 Jul 2014, a packing company in California (company A) voluntarily recalled certain lots of stone fruits, including whole peaches, nectarines, plums, and pluots, because of concern about contamination with _Listeria monocytogenes_ based on internal company testing (1). On 31 Jul 2014, the recall was expanded to cover all fruit packed at their facility during 1 Jun 2014-17 Jul 2014 (2). After the initial recall, clinicians, state and local health departments, CDC, and the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) received many inquiries about listeriosis from concerned consumers, many of whom had received automated telephone calls informing them that they had purchased recalled fruit. During 19-31 Jul 2014, the CDC _Listeria_ website received more than 500 000 page views, more than 7 times the views received during the previous 52 weeks. However, no molecular information from _L. monocytogenes_ isolates was available to assess whether human illnesses might be linked to these products.\n\nIn early August 2014, a 2-enzyme pulsed-field gel electrophoresis (PFGE) pattern shared by 3 _L. monocytogenes_ isolates from stone fruit associated with the recall was uploaded to PulseNet, the national molecular subtyping network for foodborne disease surveillance. 4 human isolates with isolation dates during the period 8 May 2014-8 Jul 2014 (Illinois, Massachusetts, and South Carolina) and 28 Aug 2014 (Minnesota) were identified that had PFGE patterns indistinguishable from isolates from company A stone fruit. Samples of stone fruits from company A collected after the recall yielded an additional 31 _L. monocytogenes_ isolates, 22 of which were indistinguishable from the initial isolates by PFGE; 3 other PFGE patterns were identified that did not match any isolates from clinical specimens collected during 1 May-31 Aug 2014. Whole-genome sequencing (WGS) analysis by whole-genome multilocus sequence typing showed that isolates from the Massachusetts and Minnesota patients were highly related (less than 10 allele differences and less than 10 high-quality single nucleotide polymorphism differences) to the isolates from recalled stone fruits, whereas the Illinois and South Carolina isolates were not.\n\nA review of the standardized _Listeria_ Initiative exposure questionnaire (3) for the Massachusetts patient showed that organic nectarine consumption was recorded, although the form does not specifically ask about stone fruit consumption. A subsequent interview using a questionnaire with questions about stone fruits indicated that the patient consumed nectarines and peaches purchased from stores that sold company A stone fruit. Traceback using receipts and shopper card data indicated the patient's family purchased recalled fruit. An interview with a family member of the Minnesota patient revealed that the patient consumed peaches from a store that received company A stone fruit; however, dates from receipts indicated that the peaches were purchased after the recalled fruit was reported to have been removed from the shelves. After removal of recalled fruit, the store received company A peaches that were not part of the recall as well as peaches from another California supplier. The South Carolina patient reportedly did not eat stone fruit before becoming ill. Family of the Illinois patient could not be reached for interview.\n\nStrong evidence linked the Massachusetts case to recalled stone fruit, including food exposure interviews, receipt and shopper card data, and WGS results showing very high genetic relatedness between the patient's isolate and isolates from nectarines. Consumption data and WGS results suggest that stone fruit was also the likely source of _L. monocytogenes_ infection in the Minnesota case; however, the later dates of illness onset and fruit purchase suggest that the patient consumed stone fruit that was not included in the recall.\n\nThis is the 1st reported link between human listeriosis and stone fruit. WGS results provided a basis for focusing resources for extended case interviews and follow-up. Specifically, among cases that matched the recalled stone fruit by PFGE, WGS allowed differentiation between sporadic cases and cases associated with stone fruit consumption.\n\nReported listeriosis is much more common in pregnant women than in the general population and can cause major fetal and perinatal complications. Because of this higher risk, and partially in response to public concern stemming from these recalls, the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists issued guidelines for management of pregnant women with possible _L. monocytogenes_ exposure (4). Although exposure to this recalled product was likely widespread, disease was very rare. Therefore, this recall and associated illness does not provide sufficient evidence to recommend that persons at higher risk for listeriosis (such as, pregnant women, persons aged 65 years or older, and immunocompromised persons) avoid fresh stone fruits. However, it does support the need to understand risks associated with contaminated, ready-to-eat fresh fruit so that prevention strategies can be strengthened.\n\nReferences\n----------\n1. FDA. Recall -- firm press release: Wawona Packing Co. takes precautionary step of voluntarily recalling fresh, whole peaches, plums, nectarines, and pluots because of possible health risk. Available at http://www.fda.gov/Safety/Recalls/ucm405943.htm.\n2. FDA. Recall -- firm press release: Wawona Packing Co. expands its voluntary recall of fresh, whole peaches, plums, nectarines, and pluots because of possible health risk. Available at http://www.fda.gov/Safety/Recalls/ucm407600.htm\n3. CDC. _Listeria_ (Listeriosis) surveillance. Available at http://www.cdc.gov/listeria/surveillance.html\n4. American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists. Ob-Gyns address management of Listeria during pregnancy. Available at http://www.acog.org/About-ACOG/News-Room/News-Releases/2014/Ob-Gyns-Address-Management-of-Listeria-During-Pregnancy\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[As stated in the post, this is the 1st link between stone fruit and human listeriosis.\n\nThe name pluot was not known to me. The strangely named \"pluot(R)\" (http://www.wisegeek.org/what-are-pluots.htm) is a hybrid plant grown from a plum and an apricot. They are extremely sweet, due to very high sugar levels, and are available in a wide range of varieties. The actual ratio works out to around 70 percent plum and 30 apricot and they mainly look like plums. They have a great deal of nutritious value and are low in fat, making them ideal for snacking or sweetening up other dishes.\n\nPluots are sometimes also referred to as \"dinosaur eggs(R)\" due to the strange dappled coloring on some types of the fruit. The name has actually been trademarked by a California pluot grower, though there are still a wide range of available types with other strange-sounding names. Varieties such as the \"flavor grenade,\" \"dapple dandy,\" and \"flavorglo\" are fairly common, as are the \"hand grenade\" and the \"last chance.\" The \"flavor heart\" is one of the largest types of pluot, heart shaped with black coloring and yellow flesh, while the \"candy stripe\" has pink and yellow stripes with spotted red skin (see varieties at http://ww2.hdnux.com/photos/31/31/21/6657137/3/622x350.jpg. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/106.]\nSee Also\nListeriosis - USA (04): (KS) fatal, nosocomial, ice cream 20150315.3231917\nListeriosis - USA (03): (IL,MI) fatal, sprouts, investigation closed 20150129.3129444\nListeriosis - USA (02): fatal, caramel-coated, prepackaged apples, update, alert 20150112.3085796\nListeriosis - USA: fatal, caramel-coated and pre-packaged apples, update, alert 20150103.3068902\n2014\n----\nListeriosis - USA (03): (IL, MI) fatal, sprouts, recall 20141109.2941351\nListeriosis - USA (02): 2013, fatal, cheese 20140410.2394195\nListeriosis - USA: (CA, MD) fatal, Hispanic-style soft cheese, recall 20140222.2294169\n.................................................ll/mj/jw", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "listeriosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Minnesota", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Illinois , Massachusetts", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "South Carolina", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Massachusetts", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "MD", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Illinois", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "California", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3331222", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis - USA (06): (KS,TX) fatal, nosocomial, ice cream, recall, update", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3291517", "date": "2015-03-21 22:23:27", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS - USA (05): STONE FRUIT 2014\n*****************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 20 Mar 2015\nSource: CDC. MMWR Morb Mortal Wkly Rep 2015; 64(10): 282-3 [edited]\nhttp://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm6410a6.htm?s_cid=mm6410a6_w\n\n\nListeriosis associated with stone fruit -- United States, 2014\n----------------------------------------------------------------------\n[Authors: Jackson BR, Salter M, Tarr C, et al]\n\nOn 19 Jul 2014, a packing company in California (company A) voluntarily recalled certain lots of stone fruits, including whole peaches, nectarines, plums, and pluots, because of concern about contamination with _Listeria monocytogenes_ based on internal company testing (1). On 31 Jul 2014, the recall was expanded to cover all fruit packed at their facility during 1 Jun 2014-17 Jul 2014 (2). After the initial recall, clinicians, state and local health departments, CDC, and the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) received many inquiries about listeriosis from concerned consumers, many of whom had received automated telephone calls informing them that they had purchased recalled fruit. During 19-31 Jul 2014, the CDC _Listeria_ website received more than 500 000 page views, more than 7 times the views received during the previous 52 weeks. However, no molecular information from _L. monocytogenes_ isolates was available to assess whether human illnesses might be linked to these products.\n\nIn early August 2014, a 2-enzyme pulsed-field gel electrophoresis (PFGE) pattern shared by 3 _L. monocytogenes_ isolates from stone fruit associated with the recall was uploaded to PulseNet, the national molecular subtyping network for foodborne disease surveillance. 4 human isolates with isolation dates during the period 8 May 2014-8 Jul 2014 (Illinois, Massachusetts, and South Carolina) and 28 Aug 2014 (Minnesota) were identified that had PFGE patterns indistinguishable from isolates from company A stone fruit. Whole-genome sequencing (WGS) analysis by whole-genome multilocus sequence typing showed that isolates from the Massachusetts and Minnesota patients were highly related (less than 10 allele differences and less than 10 high-quality single nucleotide polymorphism differences) to the isolates from recalled stone fruits, whereas the Illinois and South Carolina isolates were not.\n\nA review of the standardized _Listeria_ Initiative exposure questionnaire (3) for the Massachusetts patient showed that organic nectarine consumption was recorded, although the form does not specifically ask about stone fruit consumption. A subsequent interview using a questionnaire with questions about stone fruits indicated that the patient consumed nectarines and peaches purchased from stores that sold company A stone fruit. Traceback using receipts and shopper card data indicated the patient's family purchased recalled fruit. An interview with a family member of the Minnesota patient revealed that the patient consumed peaches from a store that received company A stone fruit; however, dates from receipts indicated that the peaches were purchased after the recalled fruit was reported to have been removed from the shelves. After removal of recalled fruit, the store received company A peaches that were not part of the recall as well as peaches from another California supplier. The South Carolina patient reportedly did not eat stone fruit before becoming ill. Family of the Illinois patient could not be reached for interview.\n\nStrong evidence linked the Massachusetts case to recalled stone fruit, including food exposure interviews, receipt and shopper card data, and WGS results showing very high genetic relatedness between the patient's isolate and isolates from nectarines. Consumption data and WGS results suggest that stone fruit was also the likely source of _L. monocytogenes_ infection in the Minnesota case; however, the later dates of illness onset and fruit purchase suggest that the patient consumed stone fruit that was not included in the recall.\n\nThis is the 1st reported link between human listeriosis and stone fruit. WGS results provided a basis for focusing resources for extended case interviews and follow-up. Specifically, among cases that matched the recalled stone fruit by PFGE, WGS allowed differentiation between sporadic cases and cases associated with stone fruit consumption.\n\nReported listeriosis is much more common in pregnant women than in the general population and can cause major fetal and perinatal complications. Because of this higher risk, and partially in response to public concern stemming from these recalls, the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists issued guidelines for management of pregnant women with possible _L. monocytogenes_ exposure (4). Although exposure to this recalled product was likely widespread, disease was very rare. Therefore, this recall and associated illness does not provide sufficient evidence to recommend that persons at higher risk for listeriosis (such as, pregnant women, persons aged 65 years or older, and immunocompromised persons) avoid fresh stone fruits. However, it does support the need to understand risks associated with contaminated, ready-to-eat fresh fruit so that prevention strategies can be strengthened.\n\nReferences\n----------\n1. FDA. The strangely named \"pluot(R)\" (http://www.wisegeek.org/what-are-pluots.htm) is a hybrid plant grown from a plum and an apricot. They are extremely sweet, due to very high sugar levels, and are available in a wide range of varieties. The actual ratio works out to around 70 percent plum and 30 apricot and they mainly look like plums. They have a great deal of nutritious value and are low in fat, making them ideal for snacking or sweetening up other dishes.\n\nPluots are sometimes also referred to as \"dinosaur eggs(R)\" due to the strange dappled coloring on some types of the fruit. The name has actually been trademarked by a California pluot grower, though there are still a wide range of available types with other strange-sounding names. Varieties such as the \"flavor grenade,\" \"dapple dandy,\" and \"flavorglo\" are fairly common, as are the \"hand grenade\" and the \"last chance.\" The \"flavor heart\" is one of the largest types of pluot, heart shaped with black coloring and yellow flesh, while the \"candy stripe\" has pink and yellow stripes with spotted red skin (see varieties at http://ww2.hdnux.com/photos/31/31/21/6657137/3/622x350.jpg. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/106.]\nSee Also\nListeriosis - USA (04): (KS) fatal, nosocomial, ice cream 20150315.3231917\nListeriosis - USA (03): (IL,MI) fatal, sprouts, investigation closed 20150129.3129444\nListeriosis - USA (02): fatal, caramel-coated, prepackaged apples, update, alert 20150112.3085796\nListeriosis - USA: fatal, caramel-coated and pre-packaged apples, update, alert 20150103.3068902\n2014\n----\nListeriosis - USA (05): (WA) ice cream, gelato, custard, sorbet, alert 20141229.3060474\nListeriosis - Canada: (ON,MB) ex USA, susp, same genotype 20141226.3055407\nListeriosis - USA (04): fatal, caramel-coated and pre-packaged apples, alert 20141219.3044758\nListeriosis - USA (03): (IL, MI) fatal, sprouts, recall 20141109.2941351\nListeriosis - USA (02): 2013, fatal, cheese 20140410.2394195\nListeriosis - USA: (CA, MD) fatal, Hispanic-style soft cheese, recall 20140222.2294169\n.................................................ll/mj/jw", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "listeriosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Minnesota", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Illinois , Massachusetts", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "South Carolina", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Massachusetts", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "MD", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Illinois", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "California", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3244417", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Listeriosis - USA (05): stone fruit 2014", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3244417", "date": "2015-03-21 22:23:27", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS - USA (05): STONE FRUIT 2014\n*****************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 20 Mar 2015\nSource: CDC. MMWR Morb Mortal Wkly Rep 2015; 64(10): 282-3 [edited]\nhttp://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm6410a6.htm?s_cid=mm6410a6_w\n\n\nListeriosis associated with stone fruit -- United States, 2014\n----------------------------------------------------------------------\n[Authors: Jackson BR, Salter M, Tarr C, et al]\n\nOn 19 Jul 2014, a packing company in California (company A) voluntarily recalled certain lots of stone fruits, including whole peaches, nectarines, plums, and pluots, because of concern about contamination with _Listeria monocytogenes_ based on internal company testing (1). On 31 Jul 2014, the recall was expanded to cover all fruit packed at their facility during 1 Jun 2014-17 Jul 2014 (2). After the initial recall, clinicians, state and local health departments, CDC, and the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) received many inquiries about listeriosis from concerned consumers, many of whom had received automated telephone calls informing them that they had purchased recalled fruit. During 19-31 Jul 2014, the CDC _Listeria_ website received more than 500 000 page views, more than 7 times the views received during the previous 52 weeks. However, no molecular information from _L. monocytogenes_ isolates was available to assess whether human illnesses might be linked to these products.\n\nIn early August 2014, a 2-enzyme pulsed-field gel electrophoresis (PFGE) pattern shared by 3 _L. monocytogenes_ isolates from stone fruit associated with the recall was uploaded to PulseNet, the national molecular subtyping network for foodborne disease surveillance. 4 human isolates with isolation dates during the period 8 May 2014-8 Jul 2014 (Illinois, Massachusetts, and South Carolina) and 28 Aug 2014 (Minnesota) were identified that had PFGE patterns indistinguishable from isolates from company A stone fruit. Samples of stone fruits from company A collected after the recall yielded an additional 31 _L. monocytogenes_ isolates, 22 of which were indistinguishable from the initial isolates by PFGE; 3 other PFGE patterns were identified that did not match any isolates from clinical specimens collected during 1 May-31 Aug 2014. Whole-genome sequencing (WGS) analysis by whole-genome multilocus sequence typing showed that isolates from the Massachusetts and Minnesota patients were highly related (less than 10 allele differences and less than 10 high-quality single nucleotide polymorphism differences) to the isolates from recalled stone fruits, whereas the Illinois and South Carolina isolates were not.\n\nA review of the standardized _Listeria_ Initiative exposure questionnaire (3) for the Massachusetts patient showed that organic nectarine consumption was recorded, although the form does not specifically ask about stone fruit consumption. A subsequent interview using a questionnaire with questions about stone fruits indicated that the patient consumed nectarines and peaches purchased from stores that sold company A stone fruit. Traceback using receipts and shopper card data indicated the patient's family purchased recalled fruit. An interview with a family member of the Minnesota patient revealed that the patient consumed peaches from a store that received company A stone fruit; however, dates from receipts indicated that the peaches were purchased after the recalled fruit was reported to have been removed from the shelves. After removal of recalled fruit, the store received company A peaches that were not part of the recall as well as peaches from another California supplier. The South Carolina patient reportedly did not eat stone fruit before becoming ill. Family of the Illinois patient could not be reached for interview.\n\nStrong evidence linked the Massachusetts case to recalled stone fruit, including food exposure interviews, receipt and shopper card data, and WGS results showing very high genetic relatedness between the patient's isolate and isolates from nectarines. Consumption data and WGS results suggest that stone fruit was also the likely source of _L. monocytogenes_ infection in the Minnesota case; however, the later dates of illness onset and fruit purchase suggest that the patient consumed stone fruit that was not included in the recall.\n\nThis is the 1st reported link between human listeriosis and stone fruit. WGS results provided a basis for focusing resources for extended case interviews and follow-up. Specifically, among cases that matched the recalled stone fruit by PFGE, WGS allowed differentiation between sporadic cases and cases associated with stone fruit consumption.\n\nReported listeriosis is much more common in pregnant women than in the general population and can cause major fetal and perinatal complications. Because of this higher risk, and partially in response to public concern stemming from these recalls, the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists issued guidelines for management of pregnant women with possible _L. monocytogenes_ exposure (4). Although exposure to this recalled product was likely widespread, disease was very rare. Therefore, this recall and associated illness does not provide sufficient evidence to recommend that persons at higher risk for listeriosis (such as, pregnant women, persons aged 65 years or older, and immunocompromised persons) avoid fresh stone fruits. However, it does support the need to understand risks associated with contaminated, ready-to-eat fresh fruit so that prevention strategies can be strengthened.\n\nReferences\n----------\n1. FDA. Recall -- firm press release: Wawona Packing Co. takes precautionary step of voluntarily recalling fresh, whole peaches, plums, nectarines, and pluots because of possible health risk. Available at http://www.fda.gov/Safety/Recalls/ucm405943.htm.\n2. FDA. Recall -- firm press release: Wawona Packing Co. expands its voluntary recall of fresh, whole peaches, plums, nectarines, and pluots because of possible health risk. Available at http://www.fda.gov/Safety/Recalls/ucm407600.htm\n3. CDC. _Listeria_ (Listeriosis) surveillance. Available at http://www.cdc.gov/listeria/surveillance.html\n4. American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists. Ob-Gyns address management of Listeria during pregnancy. Available at http://www.acog.org/About-ACOG/News-Room/News-Releases/2014/Ob-Gyns-Address-Management-of-Listeria-During-Pregnancy\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[As stated in the post, this is the 1st link between stone fruit and human listeriosis.\n\nThe name pluot was not known to me. The strangely named \"pluot(R)\" (http://www.wisegeek.org/what-are-pluots.htm) is a hybrid plant grown from a plum and an apricot. They are extremely sweet, due to very high sugar levels, and are available in a wide range of varieties. The actual ratio works out to around 70 percent plum and 30 apricot and they mainly look like plums. They have a great deal of nutritious value and are low in fat, making them ideal for snacking or sweetening up other dishes.\n\nPluots are sometimes also referred to as \"dinosaur eggs(R)\" due to the strange dappled coloring on some types of the fruit. The name has actually been trademarked by a California pluot grower, though there are still a wide range of available types with other strange-sounding names. Varieties such as the \"flavor grenade,\" \"dapple dandy,\" and \"flavorglo\" are fairly common, as are the \"hand grenade\" and the \"last chance.\" The \"flavor heart\" is one of the largest types of pluot, heart shaped with black coloring and yellow flesh, while the \"candy stripe\" has pink and yellow stripes with spotted red skin (see varieties at http://ww2.hdnux.com/photos/31/31/21/6657137/3/622x350.jpg. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/106.]\nSee Also\nListeriosis - USA (04): (KS) fatal, nosocomial, ice cream 20150315.3231917\nListeriosis - USA (03): (IL,MI) fatal, sprouts, investigation closed 20150129.3129444\nListeriosis - USA (02): fatal, caramel-coated, prepackaged apples, update, alert 20150112.3085796\nListeriosis - USA: fatal, caramel-coated and pre-packaged apples, update, alert 20150103.3068902\n2014\n----\nListeriosis - USA (05): (WA) ice cream, gelato, custard, sorbet, alert 20141229.3060474\nListeriosis - Canada: (ON,MB) ex USA, susp, same genotype 20141226.3055407\nListeriosis - USA (04): fatal, caramel-coated and pre-packaged apples, alert 20141219.3044758\nListeriosis - USA (03): (IL, MI) fatal, sprouts, recall 20141109.2941351\nListeriosis - USA (02): 2013, fatal, cheese 20140410.2394195\nListeriosis - USA: (CA, MD) fatal, Hispanic-style soft cheese, recall 20140222.2294169\n.................................................ll/mj/jw", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "listeriosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Minnesota", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Illinois , Massachusetts", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "South Carolina", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Massachusetts", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "MD", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Illinois", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "California", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3231917", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis - USA (04): (KS) fatal, nosocomial, ice cream", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3231917", "date": "2014-12-19 20:16:27", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS - USA (04): FATAL, CARAMEL-COATED AND PRE-PACKAGED APPLES, ALERT\n****************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\nDate: Thu 18 Dec 2014\nSource: Food Poison Journal [edited]\nhttp://www.foodpoisonjournal.com/foodborne-illness-outbreaks/minnesota-health-agriculture-officials-investigate-listeria-outbreak-linked-to-caramel-apples/\n\n\nThe Minnesota Departments of Health and Agriculture are working with the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) and the US Food and Drug Administration on a multi-state outbreak of listeriosis linked to eating caramel apples.\n\nFour people in Minnesota have become ill as part of this outbreak. All were adults, ages 59 to 90 years. They became ill in late October and November [2014]. All were hospitalized and 2 died.\n\nHealth officials are warning consumers who may have purchased any pre-packaged, commercially-produced caramel apples, including caramel apples with other toppings such as nuts, chocolate, and sprinkles, to not eat them until more information from the investigation becomes available.\n\nMinnesota cases purchased caramel apples from Cub Foods, Kwik Trip, and Mike's Discount Foods, which carried Carnival brand and Kitchen Cravings brand caramel apples. These 2 brands are no longer available for purchase at retail locations; however, health officials are concerned that persons who purchased them may still have them in their homes. The investigation is evolving, and other caramel apple brands and locations may also be impacted. Minnesota officials are working with national partners to determine the scope of products impacted. Consumers should not eat any brands of commercially-produced pre-packaged caramel apples until additional information is available. At this time, no illnesses related to this outbreak have been linked to apples that are not caramel-coated and not pre-packaged.\n\nListeriosis is a serious infection caused by eating food contaminated with the bacterium _Listeria monocytogenes_. The disease affects primarily older adults, pregnant women, newborns, and persons with weakened immune systems. On average, 7 cases of listeriosis are reported in Minnesota each year. Symptoms of listeriosis include fever, muscle aches, headache, stiff neck, confusion, loss of balance, and convulsions. Infected pregnant women may experience only a mild, flu-like illness; however, infections during pregnancy can lead to miscarriage or stillbirth, premature delivery, or infection of the newborn. Symptoms begin from 3 to 70 days after consuming the bacteria.\n\nAnyone who believes they may have become ill with listeriosis should contact their health care provider.\n\n[Byline: Bruce Clark]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n& Dr Tony Ellam\nRetired Consultant in Communicable Disease Control\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: Fri 19 Dec 2014\nSource: Chicago Tribune [edited]\nhttp://www.chicagotribune.com/lifestyles/health/chi-listeria-caramel-apples-20141219-story.html\n\n\nFive people have died and 21 others have been hospitalized in a [listeriosis] outbreak linked to caramel apples, federal health officials said today [19 Dec 2014].\n\nA total of 28 people infected with _Listeria_ have been reported from 10 states, according to a statement from the US Centers for Disease Control. 11 of the cases are in the Midwest: 5 in Missouri, 4 in Minnesota and 2 in Wisconsin.\n\n[A map of the USA showing states with cases of listeriosis linked to caramel apples is available at the source URL.]\n\nThe CDC warned consumers not to eat any pre-packaged, commercially-produced caramel apples, including those with other toppings such as nuts, chocolate or sprinkles, until more information is available. A recall, however, has not been issued as of Friday afternoon [19 Dec 2014].\n\nOf the 28 victims, 26 were hospitalized and 5 of those people died, the CDC said, adding that listeriosis contributed to at least 4 of the deaths. 9 of the cases involved a pregnant woman or her newborn infant and 3 were among otherwise healthy children aged 5 to 15 years, the CDC said. According to the studies, 83 percent of the ill people interviewed reported eating commercially produced prepackaged caramel apples.\n\nThose affected became ill between [17 Oct and 27 Nov 2014], the CDC said, adding that cases after [3 Dec 2014] might not yet be reported.\n\nListeriosis is an infection that primarily affects older adults, pregnant women, newborns and people with weakened immune symptoms. Symptoms, which begin anywhere from 3 to 70 days after consuming the bacteria, include fever, muscle aches, headache, confusion and convulsions.\n\nNo illnesses related to the outbreak have been linked to apples that are not caramel-coated and are not prepackaged, or to caramel candy, the CDC said.\n\nThe states include Missouri and New Mexico, which each had 5 cases; Minnesota, Texas and Arizona, with 4 cases each; Wisconsin, with 2 cases; and Washington, California, Utah and North Carolina, with 1 case each.\n\nIn Minnesota, those who fell ill bought caramel apples from Supervalu Inc's Cub Foods, Kwik Trip and Mike's Discount Foods, which carried Carnival brand and Kitchen Cravings brand apples, state health officials said. These 2 brands are no longer being sold there, but health officials are concerned that people who bought them may still have them in their homes.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[3]\nDate: Fri 19 Dec 2014\nSource: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) [edited]\nhttp://www.cdc.gov/listeria/outbreaks/caramel-apples-12-14/\n\n\nCDC is collaborating with public health officials in several states and with the US Food and Drug Administration (FDA) to investigate an outbreak of _Listeria monocytogenes_ infections (listeriosis) linked to commercially produced, prepackaged caramel apples. _Listeria_ can cause a serious, life-threatening illness.\n\nThe information CDC has at this time indicates that commercially produced, prepackaged caramel apples may be contaminated with _Listeria_ and may be causing this outbreak.\n\nOut of an abundance of caution, CDC recommends that US consumers do not eat any commercially produced, prepackaged caramel apples, including plain caramel apples as well as those containing nuts, sprinkles, chocolate, or other toppings, until more specific guidance can be provided. Although caramel apples are often a fall seasonal product, contaminated commercially produced, prepackaged caramel apples may still be for sale at grocery stores and other retailers nationwide or may be in consumers' homes.\n\nAs of [18 Dec 2014], a total of 28 people infected with the outbreak strains of _Listeria monocytogenes_ have been reported from 10 states. 26 ill people have been hospitalized. Among the 26 people hospitalized, 5 deaths have been reported. Listeriosis contributed to at least 4 of these deaths. 9 illnesses were pregnancy-related (occurred in a pregnant woman or her newborn infant). 3 invasive illnesses (meningitis) were among otherwise healthy children aged 5-15 years.\n\n[No miscarriages or fetal losses have been reported. Among people whose illnesses were not associated with a pregnancy, ages ranged from 7 to 92 years, with a median age of 64 years, and 32 percent were female.]\n\nTo date, 15 (83 percent) of the 18 ill people interviewed reported eating commercially produced, prepackaged caramel apples before becoming ill. At this time, no illnesses related to this outbreak have been linked to apples that are not caramel-coated and not prepackaged or to caramel candy. Investigators are working quickly to determine specific brands or types of commercially produced, prepackaged caramel apples that may be linked to illnesses and to identify the source of contamination.\n\nThis investigation is rapidly evolving, and new information will be provided as it becomes available.\n\nDNA \"fingerprinting\" is performed on _Listeria_ bacteria isolated from ill persons using techniques called pulsed-field gel electrophoresis (PFGE) and whole genome sequencing (WGS). WGS gives a more detailed DNA fingerprint than PFGE. Two outbreak clusters were identified by the PFGE technique, and _Listeria_ isolates within each cluster were found to be highly related by the WGS technique but distinct between the 2 clusters. CDC is investigating the 2 clusters together because one person was infected with both _Listeria_ strains simultaneously and also because illnesses in the 2 clusters have occurred during a similar time period and in similar regions of the country.\n\n[An Epi Curve (a chart showing the number of persons who were diagnosed each week) of the multistate outbreak of listeriosis linked to commercially produced, prepackaged caramel apples is available at http://www.cdc.gov/listeria/outbreaks/caramel-apples-12-14/epi.html.]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The US CDC has reported that to date a total of 28 people have developed listeriosis linked to eating commercially produced, prepackaged caramel apples, including those with other toppings such as nuts, chocolate or sprinkles (15 [83 percent] of the 18 ill people interviewed reported eating caramel apples before becoming ill). Genotyping by pulsed-field gel electrophoresis (EFGE) of clinical isolates identified 2 outbreak clusters, and _Listeria_ isolates within each cluster were found to be highly related by the whole genome sequencing technique. CDC considers the 2 clusters epidemiologically related because one person was infected with both _Listeria_ strains simultaneously and because illnesses in the 2 clusters have occurred during same time period and in similar regions of the country.\n\nThe outbreak so far has been reported from 10 states. 5 deaths have been reported and 9 illnesses were pregnancy-related. 3 invasive illnesses (meningitis) were among otherwise healthy children aged 5-15 years.\n\nMinnesota cases purchased 2 brands of caramel apples (Carnival brand and Kitchen Cravings brand), which are no longer available for purchase; however, health officials are concerned that persons who purchased them may still have them in their homes -- they could have a shelf life of more than one month, or perhaps other brands are involved. CDC advises that US consumers not eat any commercially produced, prepackaged caramel apples, including plain caramel apples as well as those containing nuts, sprinkles, chocolate, or other toppings, until more information becomes available.\n\nFor a discussion of listeriosis, please see my comments in ProMED-mail post Listeriosis, fatal - USA: (CO) 20110605.1719. - Mod.ML\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/106.]\nSee Also\nListeriosis - USA (03): (IL, MI) fatal, sprouts, recall 20141109.2941351\nListeriosis -
