USA (03): (IL,MI) fatal, sprouts, investigation closed", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3129444", "date": "2014-12-19 20:16:27", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS - USA (04): FATAL, CARAMEL-COATED AND PRE-PACKAGED APPLES, ALERT\n****************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\nDate: Thu 18 Dec 2014\nSource: Food Poison Journal [edited]\nhttp://www.foodpoisonjournal.com/foodborne-illness-outbreaks/minnesota-health-agriculture-officials-investigate-listeria-outbreak-linked-to-caramel-apples/\n\n\nThe Minnesota Departments of Health and Agriculture are working with the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) and the US Food and Drug Administration on a multi-state outbreak of listeriosis linked to eating caramel apples.\n\nFour people in Minnesota have become ill as part of this outbreak. All were adults, ages 59 to 90 years. They became ill in late October and November [2014]. All were hospitalized and 2 died.\n\nHealth officials are warning consumers who may have purchased any pre-packaged, commercially-produced caramel apples, including caramel apples with other toppings such as nuts, chocolate, and sprinkles, to not eat them until more information from the investigation becomes available.\n\nMinnesota cases purchased caramel apples from Cub Foods, Kwik Trip, and Mike's Discount Foods, which carried Carnival brand and Kitchen Cravings brand caramel apples. These 2 brands are no longer available for purchase at retail locations; however, health officials are concerned that persons who purchased them may still have them in their homes. The investigation is evolving, and other caramel apple brands and locations may also be impacted. Minnesota officials are working with national partners to determine the scope of products impacted. Consumers should not eat any brands of commercially-produced pre-packaged caramel apples until additional information is available. At this time, no illnesses related to this outbreak have been linked to apples that are not caramel-coated and not pre-packaged.\n\nListeriosis is a serious infection caused by eating food contaminated with the bacterium _Listeria monocytogenes_. The disease affects primarily older adults, pregnant women, newborns, and persons with weakened immune systems. On average, 7 cases of listeriosis are reported in Minnesota each year. Symptoms of listeriosis include fever, muscle aches, headache, stiff neck, confusion, loss of balance, and convulsions. Infected pregnant women may experience only a mild, flu-like illness; however, infections during pregnancy can lead to miscarriage or stillbirth, premature delivery, or infection of the newborn. Symptoms begin from 3 to 70 days after consuming the bacteria.\n\nAnyone who believes they may have become ill with listeriosis should contact their health care provider.\n\n[Byline: Bruce Clark]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n& Dr Tony Ellam\nRetired Consultant in Communicable Disease Control\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: Fri 19 Dec 2014\nSource: Chicago Tribune [edited]\nhttp://www.chicagotribune.com/lifestyles/health/chi-listeria-caramel-apples-20141219-story.html\n\n\nFive people have died and 21 others have been hospitalized in a [listeriosis] outbreak linked to caramel apples, federal health officials said today [19 Dec 2014].\n\nA total of 28 people infected with _Listeria_ have been reported from 10 states, according to a statement from the US Centers for Disease Control. 11 of the cases are in the Midwest: 5 in Missouri, 4 in Minnesota and 2 in Wisconsin.\n\n[A map of the USA showing states with cases of listeriosis linked to caramel apples is available at the source URL.]\n\nThe CDC warned consumers not to eat any pre-packaged, commercially-produced caramel apples, including those with other toppings such as nuts, chocolate or sprinkles, until more information is available. A recall, however, has not been issued as of Friday afternoon [19 Dec 2014].\n\nOf the 28 victims, 26 were hospitalized and 5 of those people died, the CDC said, adding that listeriosis contributed to at least 4 of the deaths. 9 of the cases involved a pregnant woman or her newborn infant and 3 were among otherwise healthy children aged 5 to 15 years, the CDC said. According to the studies, 83 percent of the ill people interviewed reported eating commercially produced prepackaged caramel apples.\n\nThose affected became ill between [17 Oct and 27 Nov 2014], the CDC said, adding that cases after [3 Dec 2014] might not yet be reported.\n\nListeriosis is an infection that primarily affects older adults, pregnant women, newborns and people with weakened immune symptoms. Symptoms, which begin anywhere from 3 to 70 days after consuming the bacteria, include fever, muscle aches, headache, confusion and convulsions.\n\nNo illnesses related to the outbreak have been linked to apples that are not caramel-coated and are not prepackaged, or to caramel candy, the CDC said.\n\nThe states include Missouri and New Mexico, which each had 5 cases; Minnesota, Texas and Arizona, with 4 cases each; Wisconsin, with 2 cases; and Washington, California, Utah and North Carolina, with 1 case each.\n\nIn Minnesota, those who fell ill bought caramel apples from Supervalu Inc's Cub Foods, Kwik Trip and Mike's Discount Foods, which carried Carnival brand and Kitchen Cravings brand apples, state health officials said. These 2 brands are no longer being sold there, but health officials are concerned that people who bought them may still have them in their homes.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[3]\nDate: Fri 19 Dec 2014\nSource: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) [edited]\nhttp://www.cdc.gov/listeria/outbreaks/caramel-apples-12-14/\n\n\nCDC is collaborating with public health officials in several states and with the US Food and Drug Administration (FDA) to investigate an outbreak of _Listeria monocytogenes_ infections (listeriosis) linked to commercially produced, prepackaged caramel apples. _Listeria_ can cause a serious, life-threatening illness.\n\nThe information CDC has at this time indicates that commercially produced, prepackaged caramel apples may be contaminated with _Listeria_ and may be causing this outbreak.\n\nOut of an abundance of caution, CDC recommends that US consumers do not eat any commercially produced, prepackaged caramel apples, including plain caramel apples as well as those containing nuts, sprinkles, chocolate, or other toppings, until more specific guidance can be provided. Although caramel apples are often a fall seasonal product, contaminated commercially produced, prepackaged caramel apples may still be for sale at grocery stores and other retailers nationwide or may be in consumers' homes.\n\nAs of [18 Dec 2014], a total of 28 people infected with the outbreak strains of _Listeria monocytogenes_ have been reported from 10 states. 26 ill people have been hospitalized. Among the 26 people hospitalized, 5 deaths have been reported. Listeriosis contributed to at least 4 of these deaths. 9 illnesses were pregnancy-related (occurred in a pregnant woman or her newborn infant). 3 invasive illnesses (meningitis) were among otherwise healthy children aged 5-15 years.\n\n[No miscarriages or fetal losses have been reported. Among people whose illnesses were not associated with a pregnancy, ages ranged from 7 to 92 years, with a median age of 64 years, and 32 percent were female.]\n\nTo date, 15 (83 percent) of the 18 ill people interviewed reported eating commercially produced, prepackaged caramel apples before becoming ill. At this time, no illnesses related to this outbreak have been linked to apples that are not caramel-coated and not prepackaged or to caramel candy. Investigators are working quickly to determine specific brands or types of commercially produced, prepackaged caramel apples that may be linked to illnesses and to identify the source of contamination.\n\nThis investigation is rapidly evolving, and new information will be provided as it becomes available.\n\nDNA \"fingerprinting\" is performed on _Listeria_ bacteria isolated from ill persons using techniques called pulsed-field gel electrophoresis (PFGE) and whole genome sequencing (WGS). WGS gives a more detailed DNA fingerprint than PFGE. Two outbreak clusters were identified by the PFGE technique, and _Listeria_ isolates within each cluster were found to be highly related by the WGS technique but distinct between the 2 clusters. CDC is investigating the 2 clusters together because one person was infected with both _Listeria_ strains simultaneously and also because illnesses in the 2 clusters have occurred during a similar time period and in similar regions of the country.\n\n[An Epi Curve (a chart showing the number of persons who were diagnosed each week) of the multistate outbreak of listeriosis linked to commercially produced, prepackaged caramel apples is available at http://www.cdc.gov/listeria/outbreaks/caramel-apples-12-14/epi.html.]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The US CDC has reported that to date a total of 28 people have developed listeriosis linked to eating commercially produced, prepackaged caramel apples, including those with other toppings such as nuts, chocolate or sprinkles (15 [83 percent] of the 18 ill people interviewed reported eating caramel apples before becoming ill). Genotyping by pulsed-field gel electrophoresis (EFGE) of clinical isolates identified 2 outbreak clusters, and _Listeria_ isolates within each cluster were found to be highly related by the whole genome sequencing technique. CDC considers the 2 clusters epidemiologically related because one person was infected with both _Listeria_ strains simultaneously and because illnesses in the 2 clusters have occurred during same time period and in similar regions of the country.\n\nThe outbreak so far has been reported from 10 states. 5 deaths have been reported and 9 illnesses were pregnancy-related. 3 invasive illnesses (meningitis) were among otherwise healthy children aged 5-15 years.\n\nMinnesota cases purchased 2 brands of caramel apples (Carnival brand and Kitchen Cravings brand), which are no longer available for purchase; however, health officials are concerned that persons who purchased them may still have them in their homes -- they could have a shelf life of more than one month, or perhaps other brands are involved. CDC advises that US consumers not eat any commercially produced, prepackaged caramel apples, including plain caramel apples as well as those containing nuts, sprinkles, chocolate, or other toppings, until more information becomes available.\n\nFor a discussion of listeriosis, please see my comments in ProMED-mail post Listeriosis, fatal - USA: (CO) 20110605.1719. - Mod.ML\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/106.]\nSee Also\nListeriosis - USA (03): (IL, MI) fatal, sprouts, recall 20141109.2941351\nListeriosis - USA (03) 20110914.2800\nListeriosis, fatal - USA (02): (CO) 20110909.2746\nListeriosis, fatal - USA: (CO) 20110605.1719\n.................................................sb/ml/je/ml", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "listeriosis", "meningitis"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2014-12-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-19 00:00:00", "2014-12-16 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-14 00:00:00", "2021-03-11 00:00:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Minnesota", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Texas", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Utah", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Arizona", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "North Carolina", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Bosnia & Herzegovina", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Mexico", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Washington", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Missouri", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "MD", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "California", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Wisconsin", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3107945", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Undiagnosed deaths, ovine, caprine - FYR Macedonia (02): listeriosis conf", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3107945", "date": "2014-12-19 20:16:27", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS - USA (04): FATAL, CARAMEL-COATED AND PRE-PACKAGED APPLES, ALERT\n****************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\nDate: Thu 18 Dec 2014\nSource: Food Poison Journal [edited]\nhttp://www.foodpoisonjournal.com/foodborne-illness-outbreaks/minnesota-health-agriculture-officials-investigate-listeria-outbreak-linked-to-caramel-apples/\n\n\nThe Minnesota Departments of Health and Agriculture are working with the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) and the US Food and Drug Administration on a multi-state outbreak of listeriosis linked to eating caramel apples.\n\nFour people in Minnesota have become ill as part of this outbreak. All were adults, ages 59 to 90 years. They became ill in late October and November [2014]. All were hospitalized and 2 died.\n\nHealth officials are warning consumers who may have purchased any pre-packaged, commercially-produced caramel apples, including caramel apples with other toppings such as nuts, chocolate, and sprinkles, to not eat them until more information from the investigation becomes available.\n\nMinnesota cases purchased caramel apples from Cub Foods, Kwik Trip, and Mike's Discount Foods, which carried Carnival brand and Kitchen Cravings brand caramel apples. These 2 brands are no longer available for purchase at retail locations; however, health officials are concerned that persons who purchased them may still have them in their homes. The investigation is evolving, and other caramel apple brands and locations may also be impacted. Minnesota officials are working with national partners to determine the scope of products impacted. Consumers should not eat any brands of commercially-produced pre-packaged caramel apples until additional information is available. At this time, no illnesses related to this outbreak have been linked to apples that are not caramel-coated and not pre-packaged.\n\nListeriosis is a serious infection caused by eating food contaminated with the bacterium _Listeria monocytogenes_. The disease affects primarily older adults, pregnant women, newborns, and persons with weakened immune systems. On average, 7 cases of listeriosis are reported in Minnesota each year. Symptoms of listeriosis include fever, muscle aches, headache, stiff neck, confusion, loss of balance, and convulsions. Infected pregnant women may experience only a mild, flu-like illness; however, infections during pregnancy can lead to miscarriage or stillbirth, premature delivery, or infection of the newborn. Symptoms begin from 3 to 70 days after consuming the bacteria.\n\nAnyone who believes they may have become ill with listeriosis should contact their health care provider.\n\n[Byline: Bruce Clark]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n& Dr Tony Ellam\nRetired Consultant in Communicable Disease Control\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: Fri 19 Dec 2014\nSource: Chicago Tribune [edited]\nhttp://www.chicagotribune.com/lifestyles/health/chi-listeria-caramel-apples-20141219-story.html\n\n\nFive people have died and 21 others have been hospitalized in a [listeriosis] outbreak linked to caramel apples, federal health officials said today [19 Dec 2014].\n\nA total of 28 people infected with _Listeria_ have been reported from 10 states, according to a statement from the US Centers for Disease Control. 11 of the cases are in the Midwest: 5 in Missouri, 4 in Minnesota and 2 in Wisconsin.\n\n[A map of the USA showing states with cases of listeriosis linked to caramel apples is available at the source URL.]\n\nThe CDC warned consumers not to eat any pre-packaged, commercially-produced caramel apples, including those with other toppings such as nuts, chocolate or sprinkles, until more information is available. A recall, however, has not been issued as of Friday afternoon [19 Dec 2014].\n\nOf the 28 victims, 26 were hospitalized and 5 of those people died, the CDC said, adding that listeriosis contributed to at least 4 of the deaths. 9 of the cases involved a pregnant woman or her newborn infant and 3 were among otherwise healthy children aged 5 to 15 years, the CDC said. According to the studies, 83 percent of the ill people interviewed reported eating commercially produced prepackaged caramel apples.\n\nThose affected became ill between [17 Oct and 27 Nov 2014], the CDC said, adding that cases after [3 Dec 2014] might not yet be reported.\n\nListeriosis is an infection that primarily affects older adults, pregnant women, newborns and people with weakened immune symptoms. These 2 brands are no longer being sold there, but health officials are concerned that people who bought them may still have them in their homes.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[3]\nDate: Fri 19 Dec 2014\nSource: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) [edited]\nhttp://www.cdc.gov/listeria/outbreaks/caramel-apples-12-14/\n\n\nCDC is collaborating with public health officials in several states and with the US Food and Drug Administration (FDA) to investigate an outbreak of _Listeria monocytogenes_ infections (listeriosis) linked to commercially produced, prepackaged caramel apples. _Listeria_ can cause a serious, life-threatening illness.\n\nThe information CDC has at this time indicates that commercially produced, prepackaged caramel apples may be contaminated with _Listeria_ and may be causing this outbreak.\n\nOut of an abundance of caution, CDC recommends that US consumers do not eat any commercially produced, prepackaged caramel apples, including plain caramel apples as well as those containing nuts, sprinkles, chocolate, or other toppings, until more specific guidance can be provided. Among the 26 people hospitalized, 5 deaths have been reported. A recall, however, has not been issued as of Friday afternoon [19 Dec 2014].\n\nOf the 28 victims, 26 were hospitalized and 5 of those people died, the CDC said, adding that listeriosis contributed to at least 4 of the deaths. 9 of the cases involved a pregnant woman or her newborn infant and 3 were among otherwise healthy children aged 5 to 15 years, the CDC said. According to the studies, 83 percent of the ill people interviewed reported eating commercially produced prepackaged caramel apples.\n\nThose affected became ill between [17 Oct and 27 Nov 2014], the CDC said, adding that cases after [3 Dec 2014] might not yet be reported.\n\nListeriosis is an infection that primarily affects older adults, pregnant women, newborns and people with weakened immune symptoms. Symptoms, which begin anywhere from 3 to 70 days after consuming the bacteria, include fever, muscle aches, headache, confusion and convulsions.\n\nNo illnesses related to the outbreak have been linked to apples that are not caramel-coated and are not prepackaged, or to caramel candy, the CDC said.\n\nThe states include Missouri and New Mexico, which each had 5 cases; Minnesota, Texas and Arizona, with 4 cases each; Wisconsin, with 2 cases; and Washington, California, Utah and North Carolina, with 1 case each.\n\nIn Minnesota, those who fell ill bought caramel apples from Supervalu Inc's Cub Foods, Kwik Trip and Mike's Discount Foods, which carried Carnival brand and Kitchen Cravings brand apples, state health officials said. These 2 brands are no longer being sold there, but health officials are concerned that people who bought them may still have them in their homes.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[3]\nDate: Fri 19 Dec 2014\nSource: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) [edited]\nhttp://www.cdc.gov/listeria/outbreaks/caramel-apples-12-14/\n\n\nCDC is collaborating with public health officials in several states and with the US Food and Drug Administration (FDA) to investigate an outbreak of _Listeria monocytogenes_ infections (listeriosis) linked to commercially produced, prepackaged caramel apples. _Listeria_ can cause a serious, life-threatening illness.\n\nThe information CDC has at this time indicates that commercially produced, prepackaged caramel apples may be contaminated with _Listeria_ and may be causing this outbreak.\n\nOut of an abundance of caution, CDC recommends that US consumers do not eat any commercially produced, prepackaged caramel apples, including plain caramel apples as well as those containing nuts, sprinkles, chocolate, or other toppings, until more specific guidance can be provided. Although caramel apples are often a fall seasonal product, contaminated commercially produced, prepackaged caramel apples may still be for sale at grocery stores and other retailers nationwide or may be in consumers' homes.\n\nAs of [18 Dec 2014], a total of 28 people infected with the outbreak strains of _Listeria monocytogenes_ have been reported from 10 states. 26 ill people have been hospitalized. Among the 26 people hospitalized, 5 deaths have been reported. Listeriosis contributed to at least 4 of these deaths. 9 illnesses were pregnancy-related (occurred in a pregnant woman or her newborn infant). 3 invasive illnesses (meningitis) were among otherwise healthy children aged 5-15 years.\n\n[No miscarriages or fetal losses have been reported. Among people whose illnesses were not associated with a pregnancy, ages ranged from 7 to 92 years, with a median age of 64 years, and 32 percent were female.]\n\nTo date, 15 (83 percent) of the 18 ill people interviewed reported eating commercially produced, prepackaged caramel apples before becoming ill. At this time, no illnesses related to this outbreak have been linked to apples that are not caramel-coated and not prepackaged or to caramel candy. Investigators are working quickly to determine specific brands or types of commercially produced, prepackaged caramel apples that may be linked to illnesses and to identify the source of contamination.\n\nThis investigation is rapidly evolving, and new information will be provided as it becomes available.\n\nDNA \"fingerprinting\" is performed on _Listeria_ bacteria isolated from ill persons using techniques called pulsed-field gel electrophoresis (PFGE) and whole genome sequencing (WGS). WGS gives a more detailed DNA fingerprint than PFGE. Two outbreak clusters were identified by the PFGE technique, and _Listeria_ isolates within each cluster were found to be highly related by the WGS technique but distinct between the 2 clusters. CDC is investigating the 2 clusters together because one person was infected with both _Listeria_ strains simultaneously and also because illnesses in the 2 clusters have occurred during a similar time period and in similar regions of the country.\n\n[An Epi Curve (a chart showing the number of persons who were diagnosed each week) of the multistate outbreak of listeriosis linked to commercially produced, prepackaged caramel apples is available at http://www.cdc.gov/listeria/outbreaks/caramel-apples-12-14/epi.html.]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The US CDC has reported that to date a total of 28 people have developed listeriosis linked to eating commercially produced, prepackaged caramel apples, including those with other toppings such as nuts, chocolate or sprinkles (15 [83 percent] of the 18 ill people interviewed reported eating caramel apples before becoming ill). Genotyping by pulsed-field gel electrophoresis (EFGE) of clinical isolates identified 2 outbreak clusters, and _Listeria_ isolates within each cluster were found to be highly related by the whole genome sequencing technique. CDC considers the 2 clusters epidemiologically related because one person was infected with both _Listeria_ strains simultaneously and because illnesses in the 2 clusters have occurred during same time period and in similar regions of the country.\n\nThe outbreak so far has been reported from 10 states. 5 deaths have been reported and 9 illnesses were pregnancy-related. 3 invasive illnesses (meningitis) were among otherwise healthy children aged 5-15 years.\n\nMinnesota cases purchased 2 brands of caramel apples (Carnival brand and Kitchen Cravings brand), which are no longer available for purchase; however, health officials are concerned that persons who purchased them may still have them in their homes -- they could have a shelf life of more than one month, or perhaps other brands are involved. CDC advises that US consumers not eat any commercially produced, prepackaged caramel apples, including plain caramel apples as well as those containing nuts, sprinkles, chocolate, or other toppings, until more information becomes available.\n\nFor a discussion of listeriosis, please see my comments in ProMED-mail post Listeriosis, fatal - USA: (CO) 20110605.1719. - Mod.ML\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/106.]\nSee Also\nListeriosis - USA (03): (IL, MI) fatal, sprouts, recall 20141109.2941351\nListeriosis - USA (02): (CT) ex Bosnia & Herzegovina, cheese 20130719.1832515\nListeriosis - USA: fatal, cheese, recall 20130710.1816187\n2012\n----\nListeriosis - USA (04): fatal, cheese, update 20121014.1341613\nListeriosis - USA (14): cantaloupe, more cases & deaths 20111105.3290\nListeriosis, fatal - USA (13): cantaloupe, more cases & deaths 20111026.3188\nListeriosis, fatal - USA (12): cantaloupe 20111022.3144\nListeriosis, fatal - USA (11): cantaloupe, farm factors 20111020.3130\nListeriosis, fatal - USA (10): cantaloupe, more cases & deaths 20111008.3022\nListeriosis, fatal - USA (09): cantaloupe, more cases & deaths 20111005.2993\nListeriosis - USA: romaine lettuce, recall 20111001.2959\nListeriosis, fatal - USA (08): background 20111001.2958\nListeriosis, fatal - USA (07): cantaloupe, more cases & deaths 20110930.2950\nListeriosis, fatal - USA (06): cantaloupe, more cases & deaths 20110923.2876\nListeriosis, fatal - USA (05): cantaloupe, more cases & deaths 20110922.2871\nListeriosis, fatal - USA (04): cantaloupe, alert 20110921.2866\nListeriosis, fatal - USA (03) 20110914.2800\nListeriosis, fatal - USA (02): (CO) 20110909.2746\nListeriosis, fatal - USA: (CO) 20110605.1719\n.................................................sb/ml/je/ml", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "listeriosis", "meningitis"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2014-12-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-19 00:00:00", "2014-12-16 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-14 00:00:00", "2021-03-11 00:00:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Minnesota", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Texas", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Utah", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Arizona", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "North Carolina", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Bosnia & Herzegovina", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Mexico", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Washington", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Missouri", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "MD", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "California", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Wisconsin", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3068902", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis - USA: fatal, caramel-coated and pre-packaged apples, update, alert", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3068902", "date": "2014-12-19 20:16:27", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS - USA (04): FATAL, CARAMEL-COATED AND PRE-PACKAGED APPLES, ALERT\n****************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\nDate: Thu 18 Dec 2014\nSource: Food Poison Journal [edited]\nhttp://www.foodpoisonjournal.com/foodborne-illness-outbreaks/minnesota-health-agriculture-officials-investigate-listeria-outbreak-linked-to-caramel-apples/\n\n\nThe Minnesota Departments of Health and Agriculture are working with the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) and the US Food and Drug Administration on a multi-state outbreak of listeriosis linked to eating caramel apples.\n\nFour people in Minnesota have become ill as part of this outbreak. All were adults, ages 59 to 90 years. They became ill in late October and November [2014]. All were hospitalized and 2 died.\n\nHealth officials are warning consumers who may have purchased any pre-packaged, commercially-produced caramel apples, including caramel apples with other toppings such as nuts, chocolate, and sprinkles, to not eat them until more information from the investigation becomes available.\n\nMinnesota cases purchased caramel apples from Cub Foods, Kwik Trip, and Mike's Discount Foods, which carried Carnival brand and Kitchen Cravings brand caramel apples. These 2 brands are no longer available for purchase at retail locations; however, health officials are concerned that persons who purchased them may still have them in their homes. The investigation is evolving, and other caramel apple brands and locations may also be impacted. Minnesota officials are working with national partners to determine the scope of products impacted. Consumers should not eat any brands of commercially-produced pre-packaged caramel apples until additional information is available. At this time, no illnesses related to this outbreak have been linked to apples that are not caramel-coated and not pre-packaged.\n\nListeriosis is a serious infection caused by eating food contaminated with the bacterium _Listeria monocytogenes_. The disease affects primarily older adults, pregnant women, newborns, and persons with weakened immune systems. On average, 7 cases of listeriosis are reported in Minnesota each year. Symptoms of listeriosis include fever, muscle aches, headache, stiff neck, confusion, loss of balance, and convulsions. Infected pregnant women may experience only a mild, flu-like illness; however, infections during pregnancy can lead to miscarriage or stillbirth, premature delivery, or infection of the newborn. Symptoms begin from 3 to 70 days after consuming the bacteria.\n\nAnyone who believes they may have become ill with listeriosis should contact their health care provider.\n\n[Byline: Bruce Clark]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n& Dr Tony Ellam\nRetired Consultant in Communicable Disease Control\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: Fri 19 Dec 2014\nSource: Chicago Tribune [edited]\nhttp://www.chicagotribune.com/lifestyles/health/chi-listeria-caramel-apples-20141219-story.html\n\n\nFive people have died and 21 others have been hospitalized in a [listeriosis] outbreak linked to caramel apples, federal health officials said today [19 Dec 2014].\n\nA total of 28 people infected with _Listeria_ have been reported from 10 states, according to a statement from the US Centers for Disease Control. 11 of the cases are in the Midwest: 5 in Missouri, 4 in Minnesota and 2 in Wisconsin.\n\n[A map of the USA showing states with cases of listeriosis linked to caramel apples is available at the source URL.]\n\nThe CDC warned consumers not to eat any pre-packaged, commercially-produced caramel apples, including those with other toppings such as nuts, chocolate or sprinkles, until more information is available. A recall, however, has not been issued as of Friday afternoon [19 Dec 2014].\n\nOf the 28 victims, 26 were hospitalized and 5 of those people died, the CDC said, adding that listeriosis contributed to at least 4 of the deaths. 9 of the cases involved a pregnant woman or her newborn infant and 3 were among otherwise healthy children aged 5 to 15 years, the CDC said. According to the studies, 83 percent of the ill people interviewed reported eating commercially produced prepackaged caramel apples.\n\nThose affected became ill between [17 Oct and 27 Nov 2014], the CDC said, adding that cases after [3 Dec 2014] might not yet be reported.\n\nListeriosis is an infection that primarily affects older adults, pregnant women, newborns and people with weakened immune symptoms. Symptoms, which begin anywhere from 3 to 70 days after consuming the bacteria, include fever, muscle aches, headache, confusion and convulsions.\n\nNo illnesses related to the outbreak have been linked to apples that are not caramel-coated and are not prepackaged, or to caramel candy, the CDC said.\n\nThe states include Missouri and New Mexico, which each had 5 cases; Minnesota, Texas and Arizona, with 4 cases each; Wisconsin, with 2 cases; and Washington, California, Utah and North Carolina, with 1 case each.\n\nIn Minnesota, those who fell ill bought caramel apples from Supervalu Inc's Cub Foods, Kwik Trip and Mike's Discount Foods, which carried Carnival brand and Kitchen Cravings brand apples, state health officials said. These 2 brands are no longer being sold there, but health officials are concerned that people who bought them may still have them in their homes.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[3]\nDate: Fri 19 Dec 2014\nSource: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) [edited]\nhttp://www.cdc.gov/listeria/outbreaks/caramel-apples-12-14/\n\n\nCDC is collaborating with public health officials in several states and with the US Food and Drug Administration (FDA) to investigate an outbreak of _Listeria monocytogenes_ infections (listeriosis) linked to commercially produced, prepackaged caramel apples. _Listeria_ can cause a serious, life-threatening illness.\n\nThe information CDC has at this time indicates that commercially produced, prepackaged caramel apples may be contaminated with _Listeria_ and may be causing this outbreak.\n\nOut of an abundance of caution, CDC recommends that US consumers do not eat any commercially produced, prepackaged caramel apples, including plain caramel apples as well as those containing nuts, sprinkles, chocolate, or other toppings, until more specific guidance can be provided. Although caramel apples are often a fall seasonal product, contaminated commercially produced, prepackaged caramel apples may still be for sale at grocery stores and other retailers nationwide or may be in consumers' homes.\n\nAs of [18 Dec 2014], a total of 28 people infected with the outbreak strains of _Listeria monocytogenes_ have been reported from 10 states. 26 ill people have been hospitalized. Among the 26 people hospitalized, 5 deaths have been reported. Listeriosis contributed to at least 4 of these deaths. 9 illnesses were pregnancy-related (occurred in a pregnant woman or her newborn infant). 3 invasive illnesses (meningitis) were among otherwise healthy children aged 5-15 years.\n\n[No miscarriages or fetal losses have been reported. Among people whose illnesses were not associated with a pregnancy, ages ranged from 7 to 92 years, with a median age of 64 years, and 32 percent were female.]\n\nTo date, 15 (83 percent) of the 18 ill people interviewed reported eating commercially produced, prepackaged caramel apples before becoming ill. At this time, no illnesses related to this outbreak have been linked to apples that are not caramel-coated and not prepackaged or to caramel candy. Investigators are working quickly to determine specific brands or types of commercially produced, prepackaged caramel apples that may be linked to illnesses and to identify the source of contamination.\n\nThis investigation is rapidly evolving, and new information will be provided as it becomes available.\n\nDNA \"fingerprinting\" is performed on _Listeria_ bacteria isolated from ill persons using techniques called pulsed-field gel electrophoresis (PFGE) and whole genome sequencing (WGS). WGS gives a more detailed DNA fingerprint than PFGE. Two outbreak clusters were identified by the PFGE technique, and _Listeria_ isolates within each cluster were found to be highly related by the WGS technique but distinct between the 2 clusters. CDC is investigating the 2 clusters together because one person was infected with both _Listeria_ strains simultaneously and also because illnesses in the 2 clusters have occurred during a similar time period and in similar regions of the country.\n\n[An Epi Curve (a chart showing the number of persons who were diagnosed each week) of the multistate outbreak of listeriosis linked to commercially produced, prepackaged caramel apples is available at http://www.cdc.gov/listeria/outbreaks/caramel-apples-12-14/epi.html.]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The US CDC has reported that to date a total of 28 people have developed listeriosis linked to eating commercially produced, prepackaged caramel apples, including those with other toppings such as nuts, chocolate or sprinkles (15 [83 percent] of the 18 ill people interviewed reported eating caramel apples before becoming ill). Genotyping by pulsed-field gel electrophoresis (EFGE) of clinical isolates identified 2 outbreak clusters, and _Listeria_ isolates within each cluster were found to be highly related by the whole genome sequencing technique. CDC considers the 2 clusters epidemiologically related because one person was infected with both _Listeria_ strains simultaneously and because illnesses in the 2 clusters have occurred during same time period and in similar regions of the country.\n\nThe outbreak so far has been reported from 10 states. 5 deaths have been reported and 9 illnesses were pregnancy-related. 3 invasive illnesses (meningitis) were among otherwise healthy children aged 5-15 years.\n\nMinnesota cases purchased 2 brands of caramel apples (Carnival brand and Kitchen Cravings brand), which are no longer available for purchase; however, health officials are concerned that persons who purchased them may still have them in their homes -- they could have a shelf life of more than one month, or perhaps other brands are involved. A recall, however, has not been issued as of Friday afternoon [19 Dec 2014].\n\nOf the 28 victims, 26 were hospitalized and 5 of those people died, the CDC said, adding that listeriosis contributed to at least 4 of the deaths. 9 of the cases involved a pregnant woman or her newborn infant and 3 were among otherwise healthy children aged 5 to 15 years, the CDC said. Symptoms, which begin anywhere from 3 to 70 days after consuming the bacteria, include fever, muscle aches, headache, confusion and convulsions.\n\nNo illnesses related to the outbreak have been linked to apples that are not caramel-coated and are not prepackaged, or to caramel candy, the CDC said.\n\nThe states include Missouri and New Mexico, which each had 5 cases; Minnesota, Texas and Arizona, with 4 cases each; Wisconsin, with 2 cases; and Washington, California, Utah and North Carolina, with 1 case each.\n\nIn Minnesota, those who fell ill bought caramel apples from Supervalu Inc's Cub Foods, Kwik Trip and Mike's Discount Foods, which carried Carnival brand and Kitchen Cravings brand apples, state health officials said. These 2 brands are no longer being sold there, but health officials are concerned that people who bought them may still have them in their homes.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[3]\nDate: Fri 19 Dec 2014\nSource: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) [edited]\nhttp://www.cdc.gov/listeria/outbreaks/caramel-apples-12-14/\n\n\nCDC is collaborating with public health officials in several states and with the US Food and Drug Administration (FDA) to investigate an outbreak of _Listeria monocytogenes_ infections (listeriosis) linked to commercially produced, prepackaged caramel apples. _Listeria_ can cause a serious, life-threatening illness.\n\nThe information CDC has at this time indicates that commercially produced, prepackaged caramel apples may be contaminated with _Listeria_ and may be causing this outbreak.\n\nOut of an abundance of caution, CDC recommends that US consumers do not eat any commercially produced, prepackaged caramel apples, including plain caramel apples as well as those containing nuts, sprinkles, chocolate, or other toppings, until more specific guidance can be provided. Although caramel apples are often a fall seasonal product, contaminated commercially produced, prepackaged caramel apples may still be for sale at grocery stores and other retailers nationwide or may be in consumers' homes.\n\nAs of [18 Dec 2014], a total of 28 people infected with the outbreak strains of _Listeria monocytogenes_ have been reported from 10 states. 26 ill people have been hospitalized. Among the 26 people hospitalized, 5 deaths have been reported. Listeriosis contributed to at least 4 of these deaths. 9 illnesses were pregnancy-related (occurred in a pregnant woman or her newborn infant). 3 invasive illnesses (meningitis) were among otherwise healthy children aged 5-15 years.\n\n[No miscarriages or fetal losses have been reported. Among people whose illnesses were not associated with a pregnancy, ages ranged from 7 to 92 years, with a median age of 64 years, and 32 percent were female.]\n\nTo date, 15 (83 percent) of the 18 ill people interviewed reported eating commercially produced, prepackaged caramel apples before becoming ill. At this time, no illnesses related to this outbreak have been linked to apples that are not caramel-coated and not prepackaged or to caramel candy. Investigators are working quickly to determine specific brands or types of commercially produced, prepackaged caramel apples that may be linked to illnesses and to identify the source of contamination.\n\nThis investigation is rapidly evolving, and new information will be provided as it becomes available.\n\nDNA \"fingerprinting\" is performed on _Listeria_ bacteria isolated from ill persons using techniques called pulsed-field gel electrophoresis (PFGE) and whole genome sequencing (WGS). WGS gives a more detailed DNA fingerprint than PFGE. Two outbreak clusters were identified by the PFGE technique, and _Listeria_ isolates within each cluster were found to be highly related by the WGS technique but distinct between the 2 clusters. CDC is investigating the 2 clusters together because one person was infected with both _Listeria_ strains simultaneously and also because illnesses in the 2 clusters have occurred during a similar time period and in similar regions of the country.\n\n[An Epi Curve (a chart showing the number of persons who were diagnosed each week) of the multistate outbreak of listeriosis linked to commercially produced, prepackaged caramel apples is available at http://www.cdc.gov/listeria/outbreaks/caramel-apples-12-14/epi.html.]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The US CDC has reported that to date a total of 28 people have developed listeriosis linked to eating commercially produced, prepackaged caramel apples, including those with other toppings such as nuts, chocolate or sprinkles (15 [83 percent] of the 18 ill people interviewed reported eating caramel apples before becoming ill). Genotyping by pulsed-field gel electrophoresis (EFGE) of clinical isolates identified 2 outbreak clusters, and _Listeria_ isolates within each cluster were found to be highly related by the whole genome sequencing technique. CDC considers the 2 clusters epidemiologically related because one person was infected with both _Listeria_ strains simultaneously and because illnesses in the 2 clusters have occurred during same time period and in similar regions of the country.\n\nThe outbreak so far has been reported from 10 states. 5 deaths have been reported and 9 illnesses were pregnancy-related. 3 invasive illnesses (meningitis) were among otherwise healthy children aged 5-15 years.\n\nMinnesota cases purchased 2 brands of caramel apples (Carnival brand and Kitchen Cravings brand), which are no longer available for purchase; however, health officials are concerned that persons who purchased them may still have them in their homes -- they could have a shelf life of more than one month, or perhaps other brands are involved. CDC advises that US consumers not eat any commercially produced, prepackaged caramel apples, including plain caramel apples as well as those containing nuts, sprinkles, chocolate, or other toppings, until more information becomes available.\n\nFor a discussion of listeriosis, please see my comments in ProMED-mail post Listeriosis, fatal - USA: (CO) 20110605.1719. - Mod.ML\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/106.]\nSee Also\nListeriosis - USA (03): (IL, MI) fatal, sprouts, recall 20141109.2941351\nListeriosis - USA (11): cantaloupe, farm factors 20111020.3130\nListeriosis, fatal - USA (10): cantaloupe, more cases & deaths 20111008.3022\nListeriosis, fatal - USA (09): cantaloupe, more cases & deaths 20111005.2993\nListeriosis - USA: romaine lettuce, recall 20111001.2959\nListeriosis, fatal - USA (08): background 20111001.2958\nListeriosis, fatal - USA (07): cantaloupe, more cases & deaths 20110930.2950\nListeriosis, fatal - USA (06): cantaloupe, more cases & deaths 20110923.2876\nListeriosis, fatal - USA (05): cantaloupe, more cases & deaths 20110922.2871\nListeriosis, fatal - USA (04): cantaloupe, alert 20110921.2866\nListeriosis, fatal - USA (03) 20110914.2800\nListeriosis, fatal - USA (02): (CO) 20110909.2746\nListeriosis, fatal - USA: (CO) 20110605.1719\n.................................................sb/ml/je/ml", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "listeriosis", "meningitis"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2014-12-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-19 00:00:00", "2014-12-16 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-14 00:00:00", "2021-03-11 00:00:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Minnesota", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Texas", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Utah", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Arizona", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "North Carolina", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Bosnia & Herzegovina", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Mexico", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Washington", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Missouri", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "MD", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "California", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Wisconsin", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3055407", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis - Canada: (ON,MB) ex USA, susp, same genotype", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3055407", "date": "2014-12-19 20:16:27", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS - USA (04): FATAL, CARAMEL-COATED AND PRE-PACKAGED APPLES, ALERT\n****************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\nDate: Thu 18 Dec 2014\nSource: Food Poison Journal [edited]\nhttp://www.foodpoisonjournal.com/foodborne-illness-outbreaks/minnesota-health-agriculture-officials-investigate-listeria-outbreak-linked-to-caramel-apples/\n\n\nThe Minnesota Departments of Health and Agriculture are working with the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) and the US Food and Drug Administration on a multi-state outbreak of listeriosis linked to eating caramel apples.\n\nFour people in Minnesota have become ill as part of this outbreak. All were adults, ages 59 to 90 years. They became ill in late October and November [2014]. All were hospitalized and 2 died.\n\nHealth officials are warning consumers who may have purchased any pre-packaged, commercially-produced caramel apples, including caramel apples with other toppings such as nuts, chocolate, and sprinkles, to not eat them until more information from the investigation becomes available.\n\nMinnesota cases purchased caramel apples from Cub Foods, Kwik Trip, and Mike's Discount Foods, which carried Carnival brand and Kitchen Cravings brand caramel apples. These 2 brands are no longer available for purchase at retail locations; however, health officials are concerned that persons who purchased them may still have them in their homes. The investigation is evolving, and other caramel apple brands and locations may also be impacted. Minnesota officials are working with national partners to determine the scope of products impacted. Consumers should not eat any brands of commercially-produced pre-packaged caramel apples until additional information is available. At this time, no illnesses related to this outbreak have been linked to apples that are not caramel-coated and not pre-packaged.\n\nListeriosis is a serious infection caused by eating food contaminated with the bacterium _Listeria monocytogenes_. The disease affects primarily older adults, pregnant women, newborns, and persons with weakened immune systems. On average, 7 cases of listeriosis are reported in Minnesota each year. Symptoms of listeriosis include fever, muscle aches, headache, stiff neck, confusion, loss of balance, and convulsions. Infected pregnant women may experience only a mild, flu-like illness; however, infections during pregnancy can lead to miscarriage or stillbirth, premature delivery, or infection of the newborn. Symptoms begin from 3 to 70 days after consuming the bacteria.\n\nAnyone who believes they may have become ill with listeriosis should contact their health care provider.\n\n[Byline: Bruce Clark]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n& Dr Tony Ellam\nRetired Consultant in Communicable Disease Control\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: Fri 19 Dec 2014\nSource: Chicago Tribune [edited]\nhttp://www.chicagotribune.com/lifestyles/health/chi-listeria-caramel-apples-20141219-story.html\n\n\nFive people have died and 21 others have been hospitalized in a [listeriosis] outbreak linked to caramel apples, federal health officials said today [19 Dec 2014].\n\nA total of 28 people infected with _Listeria_ have been reported from 10 states, according to a statement from the US Centers for Disease Control. 11 of the cases are in the Midwest: 5 in Missouri, 4 in Minnesota and 2 in Wisconsin.\n\n[A map of the USA showing states with cases of listeriosis linked to caramel apples is available at the source URL.]\n\nThe CDC warned consumers not to eat any pre-packaged, commercially-produced caramel apples, including those with other toppings such as nuts, chocolate or sprinkles, until more information is available. A recall, however, has not been issued as of Friday afternoon [19 Dec 2014].\n\nOf the 28 victims, 26 were hospitalized and 5 of those people died, the CDC said, adding that listeriosis contributed to at least 4 of the deaths. 9 of the cases involved a pregnant woman or her newborn infant and 3 were among otherwise healthy children aged 5 to 15 years, the CDC said. According to the studies, 83 percent of the ill people interviewed reported eating commercially produced prepackaged caramel apples.\n\nThose affected became ill between [17 Oct and 27 Nov 2014], the CDC said, adding that cases after [3 Dec 2014] might not yet be reported.\n\nListeriosis is an infection that primarily affects older adults, pregnant women, newborns and people with weakened immune symptoms. Symptoms, which begin anywhere from 3 to 70 days after consuming the bacteria, include fever, muscle aches, headache, confusion and convulsions.\n\nNo illnesses related to the outbreak have been linked to apples that are not caramel-coated and are not prepackaged, or to caramel candy, the CDC said.\n\nThe states include Missouri and New Mexico, which each had 5 cases; Minnesota, Texas and Arizona, with 4 cases each; Wisconsin, with 2 cases; and Washington, California, Utah and North Carolina, with 1 case each.\n\nIn Minnesota, those who fell ill bought caramel apples from Supervalu Inc's Cub Foods, Kwik Trip and Mike's Discount Foods, which carried Carnival brand and Kitchen Cravings brand apples, state health officials said. These 2 brands are no longer being sold there, but health officials are concerned that people who bought them may still have them in their homes.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[3]\nDate: Fri 19 Dec 2014\nSource: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) [edited]\nhttp://www.cdc.gov/listeria/outbreaks/caramel-apples-12-14/\n\n\nCDC is collaborating with public health officials in several states and with the US Food and Drug Administration (FDA) to investigate an outbreak of _Listeria monocytogenes_ infections (listeriosis) linked to commercially produced, prepackaged caramel apples. _Listeria_ can cause a serious, life-threatening illness.\n\nThe information CDC has at this time indicates that commercially produced, prepackaged caramel apples may be contaminated with _Listeria_ and may be causing this outbreak.\n\nOut of an abundance of caution, CDC recommends that US consumers do not eat any commercially produced, prepackaged caramel apples, including plain caramel apples as well as those containing nuts, sprinkles, chocolate, or other toppings, until more specific guidance can be provided. Although caramel apples are often a fall seasonal product, contaminated commercially produced, prepackaged caramel apples may still be for sale at grocery stores and other retailers nationwide or may be in consumers' homes.\n\nAs of [18 Dec 2014], a total of 28 people infected with the outbreak strains of _Listeria monocytogenes_ have been reported from 10 states. 26 ill people have been hospitalized. Among the 26 people hospitalized, 5 deaths have been reported. Listeriosis contributed to at least 4 of these deaths. 9 illnesses were pregnancy-related (occurred in a pregnant woman or her newborn infant). 3 invasive illnesses (meningitis) were among otherwise healthy children aged 5-15 years.\n\n[No miscarriages or fetal losses have been reported. Among people whose illnesses were not associated with a pregnancy, ages ranged from 7 to 92 years, with a median age of 64 years, and 32 percent were female.]\n\nTo date, 15 (83 percent) of the 18 ill people interviewed reported eating commercially produced, prepackaged caramel apples before becoming ill. At this time, no illnesses related to this outbreak have been linked to apples that are not caramel-coated and not prepackaged or to caramel candy. Investigators are working quickly to determine specific brands or types of commercially produced, prepackaged caramel apples that may be linked to illnesses and to identify the source of contamination.\n\nThis investigation is rapidly evolving, and new information will be provided as it becomes available.\n\nDNA \"fingerprinting\" is performed on _Listeria_ bacteria isolated from ill persons using techniques called pulsed-field gel electrophoresis (PFGE) and whole genome sequencing (WGS). WGS gives a more detailed DNA fingerprint than PFGE. Two outbreak clusters were identified by the PFGE technique, and _Listeria_ isolates within each cluster were found to be highly related by the WGS technique but distinct between the 2 clusters. CDC is investigating the 2 clusters together because one person was infected with both _Listeria_ strains simultaneously and also because illnesses in the 2 clusters have occurred during a similar time period and in similar regions of the country.\n\n[An Epi Curve (a chart showing the number of persons who were diagnosed each week) of the multistate outbreak of listeriosis linked to commercially produced, prepackaged caramel apples is available at http://www.cdc.gov/listeria/outbreaks/caramel-apples-12-14/epi.html.]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The US CDC has reported that to date a total of 28 people have developed listeriosis linked to eating commercially produced, prepackaged caramel apples, including those with other toppings such as nuts, chocolate or sprinkles (15 [83 percent] of the 18 ill people interviewed reported eating caramel apples before becoming ill). Genotyping by pulsed-field gel electrophoresis (EFGE) of clinical isolates identified 2 outbreak clusters, and _Listeria_ isolates within each cluster were found to be highly related by the whole genome sequencing technique. CDC considers the 2 clusters epidemiologically related because one person was infected with both _Listeria_ strains simultaneously and because illnesses in the 2 clusters have occurred during same time period and in similar regions of the country.\n\nThe outbreak so far has been reported from 10 states. 5 deaths have been reported and 9 illnesses were pregnancy-related. 3 invasive illnesses (meningitis) were among otherwise healthy children aged 5-15 years.\n\nMinnesota cases purchased 2 brands of caramel apples (Carnival brand and Kitchen Cravings brand), which are no longer available for purchase; however, health officials are concerned that persons who purchased them may still have them in their homes -- they could have a shelf life of more than one month, or perhaps other brands are involved. Among the 26 people hospitalized, 5 deaths have been reported. Listeriosis contributed to at least 4 of these deaths. 9 illnesses were pregnancy-related (occurred in a pregnant woman or her newborn infant). 3 invasive illnesses (meningitis) were among otherwise healthy children aged 5-15 years.\n\n[No miscarriages or fetal losses have been reported. Among people whose illnesses were not associated with a pregnancy, ages ranged from 7 to 92 years, with a median age of 64 years, and 32 percent were female.]\n\nTo date, 15 (83 percent) of the 18 ill people interviewed reported eating commercially produced, prepackaged caramel apples before becoming ill. At this time, no illnesses related to this outbreak have been linked to apples that are not caramel-coated and not prepackaged or to caramel candy. Investigators are working quickly to determine specific brands or types of commercially produced, prepackaged caramel apples that may be linked to illnesses and to identify the source of contamination.\n\nThis investigation is rapidly evolving, and new information will be provided as it becomes available.\n\nDNA \"fingerprinting\" is performed on _Listeria_ bacteria isolated from ill persons using techniques called pulsed-field gel electrophoresis (PFGE) and whole genome sequencing (WGS). WGS gives a more detailed DNA fingerprint than PFGE. Two outbreak clusters were identified by the PFGE technique, and _Listeria_ isolates within each cluster were found to be highly related by the WGS technique but distinct between the 2 clusters. CDC is investigating the 2 clusters together because one person was infected with both _Listeria_ strains simultaneously and also because illnesses in the 2 clusters have occurred during a similar time period and in similar regions of the country.\n\n[An Epi Curve (a chart showing the number of persons who were diagnosed each week) of the multistate outbreak of listeriosis linked to commercially produced, prepackaged caramel apples is available at http://www.cdc.gov/listeria/outbreaks/caramel-apples-12-14/epi.html.]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The US CDC has reported that to date a total of 28 people have developed listeriosis linked to eating commercially produced, prepackaged caramel apples, including those with other toppings such as nuts, chocolate or sprinkles (15 [83 percent] of the 18 ill people interviewed reported eating caramel apples before becoming ill). Genotyping by pulsed-field gel electrophoresis (EFGE) of clinical isolates identified 2 outbreak clusters, and _Listeria_ isolates within each cluster were found to be highly related by the whole genome sequencing technique. CDC considers the 2 clusters epidemiologically related because one person was infected with both _Listeria_ strains simultaneously and because illnesses in the 2 clusters have occurred during same time period and in similar regions of the country.\n\nThe outbreak so far has been reported from 10 states. 5 deaths have been reported and 9 illnesses were pregnancy-related. 3 invasive illnesses (meningitis) were among otherwise healthy children aged 5-15 years.\n\nMinnesota cases purchased 2 brands of caramel apples (Carnival brand and Kitchen Cravings brand), which are no longer available for purchase; however, health officials are concerned that persons who purchased them may still have them in their homes -- they could have a shelf life of more than one month, or perhaps other brands are involved. CDC advises that US consumers not eat any commercially produced, prepackaged caramel apples, including plain caramel apples as well as those containing nuts, sprinkles, chocolate, or other toppings, until more information becomes available.\n\nFor a discussion of listeriosis, please see my comments in ProMED-mail post Listeriosis, fatal - USA: (CO) 20110605.1719. - Mod.ML\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/106.]\nSee Also\nListeriosis - USA (03): (IL, MI) fatal, sprouts, recall 20141109.2941351\nListeriosis - USA (02): 2013, fatal, cheese 20140410.2394195\nListeriosis - USA: (CA, MD) fatal, Hispanic-style soft cheese, recall 20140222.2294169\n2013\n----\nListeriosis - USA (03): multistate, fatal, cheese, recall 20130828.1909350\nListeriosis - USA (02): (CT) ex Bosnia & Herzegovina, cheese 20130719.1832515\nListeriosis - USA: fatal, cheese, recall 20130710.1816187\n2012\n----\nListeriosis - USA (04): fatal, cheese, update 20121014.1341613\nListeriosis - USA (03): fatal, cheese, recall, update 20120923.1305794\nListeriosis - USA (02): (multistate) fatal, cheese, recall 20120912.1292100\nListeriosis - USA: (NJ), perinatal 20120316.1072439\n2011\n----\nListeriosis, fatal - USA (14): cantaloupe, more cases & deaths 20111105.3290\nListeriosis, fatal - USA (13): cantaloupe, more cases & deaths 20111026.3188\nListeriosis, fatal - USA (12): cantaloupe 20111022.3144\nListeriosis, fatal - USA (11): cantaloupe, farm factors 20111020.3130\nListeriosis, fatal - USA (10): cantaloupe, more cases & deaths 20111008.3022\nListeriosis, fatal - USA (09): cantaloupe, more cases & deaths 20111005.2993\nListeriosis - USA: romaine lettuce, recall 20111001.2959\nListeriosis, fatal - USA (08): background 20111001.2958\nListeriosis, fatal - USA (07): cantaloupe, more cases & deaths 20110930.2950\nListeriosis, fatal - USA (06): cantaloupe, more cases & deaths 20110923.2876\nListeriosis, fatal - USA (05): cantaloupe, more cases & deaths 20110922.2871\nListeriosis, fatal - USA (04): cantaloupe, alert 20110921.2866\nListeriosis, fatal - USA (03) 20110914.2800\nListeriosis, fatal - USA (02): (CO) 20110909.2746\nListeriosis, fatal - USA: (CO) 20110605.1719\n.................................................sb/ml/je/ml", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "listeriosis", "meningitis"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2014-12-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-19 00:00:00", "2014-12-16 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-14 00:00:00", "2021-03-11 00:00:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Minnesota", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Texas", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Utah", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Arizona", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "North Carolina", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Bosnia & Herzegovina", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Mexico", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Washington", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Missouri", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "MD", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "California", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Wisconsin", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2941351", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis - USA (03): (IL, MI) fatal, sprouts, recall", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2941351", "date": "2014-04-10 14:36:12", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS - USA (02): 2013, FATAL, CHEESE\n*******************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 8 Apr 2014\nSource: fdlreporter.com, Associated Press (AP) report [edited]\nhttp://www.fdlreporter.com/viewart/20140408/FON03/140408008/Dodge-County-cheese-plant-cited-illness-outbreak\n\n\nAn illness outbreak from a Wisconsin cheesemaker that was linked to one death and a miscarriage likely was caused by substantial sanitation deficiencies in the cheese-making process, a new report from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) says.\n\nThe listeriosis outbreak occurred last summer [2013] and was linked to contaminated soft cheeses from Crave Brothers Farmstead Cheese Co. of Waterloo. The death was in Minnesota, while illnesses from _Listeria monocytogenes_ were reported in Minnesota, Illinois, Indiana, and Ohio, according to the US Food and Drug Administration (FDA), according to the Milwaukee Journal Sentinel.\n\n3 Crave Brothers pasteurized soft cheeses were the subject of a nationwide recall as a result of the outbreak: Les Freres, Petit Frere, and Petit Frere with truffles. All 3 had previously captured national and international awards for Crave, one of Wisconsin's most well-known cheesemakers.\n\n\"Inspection of the cheesemaking facility revealed that substantial sanitation deficiencies during the cheesemaking process itself, after the milk was pasteurized, likely led to contamination,\" CDC's Morbidity and Mortality Weekly Report noted.\n\nPasteurization, a process in which milk is heated to a high temperature to destroy pathogens, eliminates listeria in milk. But contamination can occur after pasteurization, according to government regulators. \"Cheese-making facilities should use strict sanitation and microbiologic monitoring, regardless of whether they use pasteurized milk,\" the CDC report said. Details of the contamination were not in the report, and Crave Brothers declined to comment.\n\nThe 5 people sickened told health department officials they had definitely or probably eaten 1 of 3 varieties of Crave soft-ripened cheese. 3 of the people had purchased the cheese at 3 different restaurants, and 2 had purchased it at 2 different grocery stores. The cheeses were shipped as intact wheels to the restaurants and stores, where they had been cut and served or cut and repackaged and sold to customers, according to the CDC report.\n\nLaboratory tests conducted by the Minnesota Department of Agriculture on samples of the cheeses from 2 retail stores indicated the presence of the outbreak strain [of] _Listeria monocytogenes_.\n\nListeria infections are among the 3 most deadly foodborne bacteria after toxoplasmosis and salmonellosis.\n\nCrave Brothers issued voluntary product recalls 2 days after it halted production of the 3 cheeses. On [11 Jul 2013], the company voluntarily halted production of all cheese products made in the plant, the report noted.\n\nAll 5 people sickened in the outbreak were hospitalized, including the pregnant woman who suffered a miscarriage. They ranged in age from 31 to 67 years old, according to the Food and Drug Administration.\n\nThe company has not been fined, and checks of court records haven't revealed lawsuits. Cheesemakers could face criminal charges for shipping contaminated cheese into the marketplace, according to Bill Marler, a Seattle attorney who specializes in food safety cases. \"But it's very rare that the FDA does anything with respect to fines or sanctions whatsoever in these cases,\" he said.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The news report above refers to the CDC publication, which is abridged and edited below: Choi MJ, Jackson KA, Medus C, et al. Notes from the field: multistate outbreak of listeriosis linked to soft-ripened cheese -- United States, 2013. MMWR Morb Mortal Wkly Rep 4 Apr 2014; 63(13): 294-5; available at http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm6313a5.htm:\n\nOn [27 Jun 2013], the Minnesota Department of Health notified CDC of 2 patients with invasive _Listeria monocytogenes_ infections (listeriosis) whose clinical isolates had indistinguishable pulsed-field gel electrophoresis (PFGE) patterns. A query of PulseNet, the national molecular subtyping network for foodborne disease surveillance, identified clinical and environmental isolates from other states. On [28 Jun 2013], CDC learned from the Food and Drug Administration's Coordinated Outbreak Response and Evaluation Network that environmental isolates indistinguishable from those of the 2 patients had been collected from Crave Brothers Farmstead Cheese during 2010-2011.\n\nAs of [28 Jun 2014], 5 cases [who had isolation of _L. monocytogenes_ with the outbreak PFGE pattern from an anatomic site that is normally sterile (such as, blood or cerebrospinal fluid), or from a product of conception] were identified in 4 states (Minnesota, 2 cases; Illinois, Indiana, and Ohio, one case each). Median age of the 5 patients was 58 years (range: 31-67 years). 4 patients were female, including one who was pregnant at the time of infection. All 5 were hospitalized. 1 death and 1 miscarriage were reported.\n\nAll 5 patients had definitely or probably eaten one of 3 varieties of Crave Brothers soft-ripened cheese (Les Freres, Petit Frere, or Petit Frere with truffles). 3 patients had purchased the cheese at 3 different restaurants, and 2 had purchased the cheese at 2 different grocery stores. The cheeses were shipped as intact wheels to the 3 restaurants and 2 grocery stores, where they had been cut and served or repackaged and sold to customers.\n\nTesting at the Minnesota Department of Agriculture identified the outbreak pattern of _L. monocytogenes_ in 2 cheese wedges (Les Freres and Petit Frere with truffles) collected from 2 different grocery stores in Minnesota. Inspection of the cheese-making facility revealed that substantial sanitation deficiencies during the cheese-making process itself, after the milk was pasteurized, likely led to contamination. On [1 Jul 2013], Crave Brothers halted production of Les Freres, Petit Frere, and Petit Frere with truffles. On [3 Jul 2013], Crave Brothers issued a voluntary recall of these products with a production date of [1 Jul 2013], or earlier. On [11 Jul 2013], the company voluntarily halted production of all cheese products manufactured at the facility. After product recall, one additional case was identified in Texas through whole genome sequencing, bringing the total case count for the outbreak to 6.\n\nThis outbreak was linked to soft cheeses that were likely contaminated during the cheese-making process (2,3). Pasteurization eliminates _Listeria_ in milk. However, contamination can occur after pasteurization. Cheesemaking facilities should use strict sanitation and microbiologic monitoring, regardless of whether they use pasteurized milk.+\n\nPersons at greater risk for listeriosis, including older adults, pregnant women, and those with immunocompromising conditions, should be aware that certain soft cheeses made with unpasteurized milk, or made under unsanitary conditions, regardless of whether the milk was pasteurized, have been shown to cause severe illness. These soft cheeses include fresh (unripened) cheeses, such as queso fresco (4), and soft-ripened cheeses, such as the cheeses implicated in this outbreak.\n\n[Footnotes and references are available at the CDC URL above.]\n\nReports of this outbreak of listeriosis were posted by ProMED-mail in 2013 (see postings listed below). - Mod.ML\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/106.]\nSee Also\n2013\n---\nListeriosis - USA (03): multistate, fatal, cheese, recall 20130828.1909350\nListeriosis - USA: fatal, cheese, recall 20130710.1816187\n.................................................sb/ml/mj/sh", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "salmonellosis", "listeriosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Minnesota", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Texas", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Indiana", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Wisconsin", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Jackson KA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ohio", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Seattle", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Illinois", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2922167", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis - Notes from the field: multistate outbreak of listeriosis linked to soft-ripened cheese -- United States, 2013. MMWR Morb Mortal Wkly Rep 4 Apr 2014; 63(13): 294-5; available at http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm6313a5.htm:\n\nOn [27 Jun 2013], the Minnesota Department of Health notified CDC of 2 patients with invasive _Listeria monocytogenes_ infections (listeriosis) whose clinical isolates had indistinguishable pulsed-field gel electrophoresis (PFGE) patterns. All 5 were hospitalized. 1 death and 1 miscarriage were reported.\n\nAll 5 patients had definitely or probably eaten one of 3 varieties of Crave Brothers soft-ripened cheese (Les Freres, Petit Frere, or Petit Frere with truffles). 3 patients had purchased the cheese at 3 different restaurants, and 2 had purchased the cheese at 2 different grocery stores.
