Inspection of the cheese-making facility revealed that substantial sanitation deficiencies during the cheese-making process itself, after the milk was pasteurized, likely led to contamination. On [1 Jul 2013], Crave Brothers halted production of Les Freres, Petit Frere, and Petit Frere with truffles. On [3 Jul 2013], Crave Brothers issued a voluntary recall of these products with a production date of [1 Jul 2013], or earlier. On [11 Jul 2013], the company voluntarily halted production of all cheese products manufactured at the facility. After product recall, one additional case was identified in Texas through whole genome sequencing, bringing the total case count for the outbreak to 6.\n\nThis outbreak was linked to soft cheeses that were likely contaminated during the cheese-making process (2,3). Pasteurization eliminates _Listeria_ in milk. However, contamination can occur after pasteurization. Cheesemaking facilities should use strict sanitation and microbiologic monitoring, regardless of whether they use pasteurized milk.+\n\nPersons at greater risk for listeriosis, including older adults, pregnant women, and those with immunocompromising conditions, should be aware that certain soft cheeses made with unpasteurized milk, or made under unsanitary conditions, regardless of whether the milk was pasteurized, have been shown to cause severe illness. These soft cheeses include fresh (unripened) cheeses, such as queso fresco (4), and soft-ripened cheeses, such as the cheeses implicated in this outbreak.\n\n[Footnotes and references are available at the CDC URL above.]\n\nReports of this outbreak of listeriosis were posted by ProMED-mail in 2013 (see postings listed below). - Mod.ML\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/106.]\nSee Also\n2013\n---\nListeriosis - USA (03): multistate, fatal, cheese, recall 20130828.1909350\nListeriosis - USA: fatal, cheese, recall 20130710.1816187\n.................................................sb/ml/mj/sh", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "salmonellosis", "listeriosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Minnesota", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Texas", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Indiana", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Wisconsin", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Jackson KA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ohio", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Seattle", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Illinois", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2764685", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis - Denmark (03): (Copenhagen) fatal, deli meat susp, more cases", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2764685", "date": "2014-04-10 14:36:12", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS - USA (02): 2013, FATAL, CHEESE\n*******************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 8 Apr 2014\nSource: fdlreporter.com, Associated Press (AP) report [edited]\nhttp://www.fdlreporter.com/viewart/20140408/FON03/140408008/Dodge-County-cheese-plant-cited-illness-outbreak\n\n\nAn illness outbreak from a Wisconsin cheesemaker that was linked to one death and a miscarriage likely was caused by substantial sanitation deficiencies in the cheese-making process, a new report from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) says.\n\nThe listeriosis outbreak occurred last summer [2013] and was linked to contaminated soft cheeses from Crave Brothers Farmstead Cheese Co. of Waterloo. The death was in Minnesota, while illnesses from _Listeria monocytogenes_ were reported in Minnesota, Illinois, Indiana, and Ohio, according to the US Food and Drug Administration (FDA), according to the Milwaukee Journal Sentinel.\n\n3 Crave Brothers pasteurized soft cheeses were the subject of a nationwide recall as a result of the outbreak: Les Freres, Petit Frere, and Petit Frere with truffles. All 3 had previously captured national and international awards for Crave, one of Wisconsin's most well-known cheesemakers.\n\n\"Inspection of the cheesemaking facility revealed that substantial sanitation deficiencies during the cheesemaking process itself, after the milk was pasteurized, likely led to contamination,\" CDC's Morbidity and Mortality Weekly Report noted.\n\nPasteurization, a process in which milk is heated to a high temperature to destroy pathogens, eliminates listeria in milk. But contamination can occur after pasteurization, according to government regulators. \"Cheese-making facilities should use strict sanitation and microbiologic monitoring, regardless of whether they use pasteurized milk,\" the CDC report said. Details of the contamination were not in the report, and Crave Brothers declined to comment.\n\nThe 5 people sickened told health department officials they had definitely or probably eaten 1 of 3 varieties of Crave soft-ripened cheese. 3 of the people had purchased the cheese at 3 different restaurants, and 2 had purchased it at 2 different grocery stores. The cheeses were shipped as intact wheels to the restaurants and stores, where they had been cut and served or cut and repackaged and sold to customers, according to the CDC report.\n\nLaboratory tests conducted by the Minnesota Department of Agriculture on samples of the cheeses from 2 retail stores indicated the presence of the outbreak strain [of] _Listeria monocytogenes_.\n\nListeria infections are among the 3 most deadly foodborne bacteria after toxoplasmosis and salmonellosis.\n\nCrave Brothers issued voluntary product recalls 2 days after it halted production of the 3 cheeses. On [11 Jul 2013], the company voluntarily halted production of all cheese products made in the plant, the report noted.\n\nAll 5 people sickened in the outbreak were hospitalized, including the pregnant woman who suffered a miscarriage. They ranged in age from 31 to 67 years old, according to the Food and Drug Administration.\n\nThe company has not been fined, and checks of court records haven't revealed lawsuits. Cheesemakers could face criminal charges for shipping contaminated cheese into the marketplace, according to Bill Marler, a Seattle attorney who specializes in food safety cases. \"But it's very rare that the FDA does anything with respect to fines or sanctions whatsoever in these cases,\" he said.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The news report above refers to the CDC publication, which is abridged and edited below: Choi MJ, Jackson KA, Medus C, et al. Notes from the field: multistate outbreak of listeriosis linked to soft-ripened cheese -- United States, 2013. MMWR Morb Mortal Wkly Rep 4 Apr 2014; 63(13): 294-5; available at http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm6313a5.htm:\n\nOn [27 Jun 2013], the Minnesota Department of Health notified CDC of 2 patients with invasive _Listeria monocytogenes_ infections (listeriosis) whose clinical isolates had indistinguishable pulsed-field gel electrophoresis (PFGE) patterns. A query of PulseNet, the national molecular subtyping network for foodborne disease surveillance, identified clinical and environmental isolates from other states. On [28 Jun 2013], CDC learned from the Food and Drug Administration's Coordinated Outbreak Response and Evaluation Network that environmental isolates indistinguishable from those of the 2 patients had been collected from Crave Brothers Farmstead Cheese during 2010-2011.\n\nAs of [28 Jun 2014], 5 cases [who had isolation of _L. monocytogenes_ with the outbreak PFGE pattern from an anatomic site that is normally sterile (such as, blood or cerebrospinal fluid), or from a product of conception] were identified in 4 states (Minnesota, 2 cases; Illinois, Indiana, and Ohio, one case each). Median age of the 5 patients was 58 years (range: 31-67 years). 4 patients were female, including one who was pregnant at the time of infection. All 5 were hospitalized. 1 death and 1 miscarriage were reported.\n\nAll 5 patients had definitely or probably eaten one of 3 varieties of Crave Brothers soft-ripened cheese (Les Freres, Petit Frere, or Petit Frere with truffles). 3 patients had purchased the cheese at 3 different restaurants, and 2 had purchased the cheese at 2 different grocery stores. The cheeses were shipped as intact wheels to the 3 restaurants and 2 grocery stores, where they had been cut and served or repackaged and sold to customers.\n\nTesting at the Minnesota Department of Agriculture identified the outbreak pattern of _L. monocytogenes_ in 2 cheese wedges (Les Freres and Petit Frere with truffles) collected from 2 different grocery stores in Minnesota. Inspection of the cheese-making facility revealed that substantial sanitation deficiencies during the cheese-making process itself, after the milk was pasteurized, likely led to contamination. On [1 Jul 2013], Crave Brothers halted production of Les Freres, Petit Frere, and Petit Frere with truffles. On [3 Jul 2013], Crave Brothers issued a voluntary recall of these products with a production date of [1 Jul 2013], or earlier. On [11 Jul 2013], the company voluntarily halted production of all cheese products manufactured at the facility. After product recall, one additional case was identified in Texas through whole genome sequencing, bringing the total case count for the outbreak to 6.\n\nThis outbreak was linked to soft cheeses that were likely contaminated during the cheese-making process (2,3). Pasteurization eliminates _Listeria_ in milk. However, contamination can occur after pasteurization. Cheesemaking facilities should use strict sanitation and microbiologic monitoring, regardless of whether they use pasteurized milk.+\n\nPersons at greater risk for listeriosis, including older adults, pregnant women, and those with immunocompromising conditions, should be aware that certain soft cheeses made with unpasteurized milk, or made under unsanitary conditions, regardless of whether the milk was pasteurized, have been shown to cause severe illness. These soft cheeses include fresh (unripened) cheeses, such as queso fresco (4), and soft-ripened cheeses, such as the cheeses implicated in this outbreak.\n\n[Footnotes and references are available at the CDC URL above.]\n\nReports of this outbreak of listeriosis were posted by ProMED-mail in 2013 (see postings listed below). - Mod.ML\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/106.]\nSee Also\n2013\n---\nListeriosis - USA (03): multistate, fatal, cheese, recall 20130828.1909350\nListeriosis - Denmark (02): (KO) fatal, deli meat susp. more cases", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2708272", "date": "2014-04-10 14:36:12", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS - USA (02): 2013, FATAL, CHEESE\n*******************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 8 Apr 2014\nSource: fdlreporter.com, Associated Press (AP) report [edited]\nhttp://www.fdlreporter.com/viewart/20140408/FON03/140408008/Dodge-County-cheese-plant-cited-illness-outbreak\n\n\nAn illness outbreak from a Wisconsin cheesemaker that was linked to one death and a miscarriage likely was caused by substantial sanitation deficiencies in the cheese-making process, a new report from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) says.\n\nThe listeriosis outbreak occurred last summer [2013] and was linked to contaminated soft cheeses from Crave Brothers Farmstead Cheese Co. of Waterloo. The death was in Minnesota, while illnesses from _Listeria monocytogenes_ were reported in Minnesota, Illinois, Indiana, and Ohio, according to the US Food and Drug Administration (FDA), according to the Milwaukee Journal Sentinel.\n\n3 Crave Brothers pasteurized soft cheeses were the subject of a nationwide recall as a result of the outbreak: Les Freres, Petit Frere, and Petit Frere with truffles. All 3 had previously captured national and international awards for Crave, one of Wisconsin's most well-known cheesemakers.\n\n\"Inspection of the cheesemaking facility revealed that substantial sanitation deficiencies during the cheesemaking process itself, after the milk was pasteurized, likely led to contamination,\" CDC's Morbidity and Mortality Weekly Report noted.\n\nPasteurization, a process in which milk is heated to a high temperature to destroy pathogens, eliminates listeria in milk. But contamination can occur after pasteurization, according to government regulators. \"Cheese-making facilities should use strict sanitation and microbiologic monitoring, regardless of whether they use pasteurized milk,\" the CDC report said. Details of the contamination were not in the report, and Crave Brothers declined to comment.\n\nThe 5 people sickened told health department officials they had definitely or probably eaten 1 of 3 varieties of Crave soft-ripened cheese. 3 of the people had purchased the cheese at 3 different restaurants, and 2 had purchased it at 2 different grocery stores. The cheeses were shipped as intact wheels to the restaurants and stores, where they had been cut and served or cut and repackaged and sold to customers, according to the CDC report.\n\nLaboratory tests conducted by the Minnesota Department of Agriculture on samples of the cheeses from 2 retail stores indicated the presence of the outbreak strain [of] _Listeria monocytogenes_.\n\nListeria infections are among the 3 most deadly foodborne bacteria after toxoplasmosis and salmonellosis.\n\nCrave Brothers issued voluntary product recalls 2 days after it halted production of the 3 cheeses. On [11 Jul 2013], the company voluntarily halted production of all cheese products made in the plant, the report noted.\n\nAll 5 people sickened in the outbreak were hospitalized, including the pregnant woman who suffered a miscarriage. They ranged in age from 31 to 67 years old, according to the Food and Drug Administration.\n\nThe company has not been fined, and checks of court records haven't revealed lawsuits. Cheesemakers could face criminal charges for shipping contaminated cheese into the marketplace, according to Bill Marler, a Seattle attorney who specializes in food safety cases. \"But it's very rare that the FDA does anything with respect to fines or sanctions whatsoever in these cases,\" he said.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The news report above refers to the CDC publication, which is abridged and edited below: Choi MJ, Jackson KA, Medus C, et al. Notes from the field: multistate outbreak of listeriosis linked to soft-ripened cheese -- United States, 2013. MMWR Morb Mortal Wkly Rep 4 Apr 2014; 63(13): 294-5; available at http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm6313a5.htm:\n\nOn [27 Jun 2013], the Minnesota Department of Health notified CDC of 2 patients with invasive _Listeria monocytogenes_ infections (listeriosis) whose clinical isolates had indistinguishable pulsed-field gel electrophoresis (PFGE) patterns. A query of PulseNet, the national molecular subtyping network for foodborne disease surveillance, identified clinical and environmental isolates from other states. On [28 Jun 2013], CDC learned from the Food and Drug Administration's Coordinated Outbreak Response and Evaluation Network that environmental isolates indistinguishable from those of the 2 patients had been collected from Crave Brothers Farmstead Cheese during 2010-2011.\n\nAs of [28 Jun 2014], 5 cases [who had isolation of _L. monocytogenes_ with the outbreak PFGE pattern from an anatomic site that is normally sterile (such as, blood or cerebrospinal fluid), or from a product of conception] were identified in 4 states (Minnesota, 2 cases; Illinois, Indiana, and Ohio, one case each). Median age of the 5 patients was 58 years (range: 31-67 years). 4 patients were female, including one who was pregnant at the time of infection. All 5 were hospitalized. 1 death and 1 miscarriage were reported.\n\nAll 5 patients had definitely or probably eaten one of 3 varieties of Crave Brothers soft-ripened cheese (Les Freres, Petit Frere, or Petit Frere with truffles). 3 patients had purchased the cheese at 3 different restaurants, and 2 had purchased the cheese at 2 different grocery stores. The cheeses were shipped as intact wheels to the 3 restaurants and 2 grocery stores, where they had been cut and served or repackaged and sold to customers.\n\nTesting at the Minnesota Department of Agriculture identified the outbreak pattern of _L. monocytogenes_ in 2 cheese wedges (Les Freres and Petit Frere with truffles) collected from 2 different grocery stores in Minnesota. Inspection of the cheese-making facility revealed that substantial sanitation deficiencies during the cheese-making process itself, after the milk was pasteurized, likely led to contamination. On [1 Jul 2013], Crave Brothers halted production of Les Freres, Petit Frere, and Petit Frere with truffles. On [3 Jul 2013], Crave Brothers issued a voluntary recall of these products with a production date of [1 Jul 2013], or earlier. On [11 Jul 2013], the company voluntarily halted production of all cheese products manufactured at the facility. After product recall, one additional case was identified in Texas through whole genome sequencing, bringing the total case count for the outbreak to 6.\n\nThis outbreak was linked to soft cheeses that were likely contaminated during the cheese-making process (2,3). Pasteurization eliminates _Listeria_ in milk. However, contamination can occur after pasteurization. Cheesemaking facilities should use strict sanitation and microbiologic monitoring, regardless of whether they use pasteurized milk.+\n\nPersons at greater risk for listeriosis, including older adults, pregnant women, and those with immunocompromising conditions, should be aware that certain soft cheeses made with unpasteurized milk, or made under unsanitary conditions, regardless of whether the milk was pasteurized, have been shown to cause severe illness. These soft cheeses include fresh (unripened) cheeses, such as queso fresco (4), and soft-ripened cheeses, such as the cheeses implicated in this outbreak.\n\n[Footnotes and references are available at the CDC URL above.]\n\nReports of this outbreak of listeriosis were posted by ProMED-mail in 2013 (see postings listed below). - Cheesemakers could face criminal charges for shipping contaminated cheese into the marketplace, according to Bill Marler, a Seattle attorney who specializes in food safety cases. \"But it's very rare that the FDA does anything with respect to fines or sanctions whatsoever in these cases,\" he said.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The news report above refers to the CDC publication, which is abridged and edited below: Choi MJ, Jackson KA, Medus C, et al. Notes from the field: multistate outbreak of listeriosis linked to soft-ripened cheese -- United States, 2013. MMWR Morb Mortal Wkly Rep 4 Apr 2014; 63(13): 294-5; available at http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm6313a5.htm:\n\nOn [27 Jun 2013], the Minnesota Department of Health notified CDC of 2 patients with invasive _Listeria monocytogenes_ infections (listeriosis) whose clinical isolates had indistinguishable pulsed-field gel electrophoresis (PFGE) patterns. A query of PulseNet, the national molecular subtyping network for foodborne disease surveillance, identified clinical and environmental isolates from other states. On [28 Jun 2013], CDC learned from the Food and Drug Administration's Coordinated Outbreak Response and Evaluation Network that environmental isolates indistinguishable from those of the 2 patients had been collected from Crave Brothers Farmstead Cheese during 2010-2011.\n\nAs of [28 Jun 2014], 5 cases [who had isolation of _L. monocytogenes_ with the outbreak PFGE pattern from an anatomic site that is normally sterile (such as, blood or cerebrospinal fluid), or from a product of conception] were identified in 4 states (Minnesota, 2 cases; Illinois, Indiana, and Ohio, one case each). Median age of the 5 patients was 58 years (range: 31-67 years). 4 patients were female, including one who was pregnant at the time of infection. All 5 were hospitalized. 1 death and 1 miscarriage were reported.\n\nAll 5 patients had definitely or probably eaten one of 3 varieties of Crave Brothers soft-ripened cheese (Les Freres, Petit Frere, or Petit Frere with truffles). 3 patients had purchased the cheese at 3 different restaurants, and 2 had purchased the cheese at 2 different grocery stores. The cheeses were shipped as intact wheels to the 3 restaurants and 2 grocery stores, where they had been cut and served or repackaged and sold to customers.\n\nTesting at the Minnesota Department of Agriculture identified the outbreak pattern of _L. monocytogenes_ in 2 cheese wedges (Les Freres and Petit Frere with truffles) collected from 2 different grocery stores in Minnesota. Inspection of the cheese-making facility revealed that substantial sanitation deficiencies during the cheese-making process itself, after the milk was pasteurized, likely led to contamination. On [1 Jul 2013], Crave Brothers halted production of Les Freres, Petit Frere, and Petit Frere with truffles. On [3 Jul 2013], Crave Brothers issued a voluntary recall of these products with a production date of [1 Jul 2013], or earlier. On [11 Jul 2013], the company voluntarily halted production of all cheese products manufactured at the facility. After product recall, one additional case was identified in Texas through whole genome sequencing, bringing the total case count for the outbreak to 6.\n\nThis outbreak was linked to soft cheeses that were likely contaminated during the cheese-making process (2,3). Pasteurization eliminates _Listeria_ in milk. However, contamination can occur after pasteurization. Cheesemaking facilities should use strict sanitation and microbiologic monitoring, regardless of whether they use pasteurized milk.+\n\nPersons at greater risk for listeriosis, including older adults, pregnant women, and those with immunocompromising conditions, should be aware that certain soft cheeses made with unpasteurized milk, or made under unsanitary conditions, regardless of whether the milk was pasteurized, have been shown to cause severe illness. These soft cheeses include fresh (unripened) cheeses, such as queso fresco (4), and soft-ripened cheeses, such as the cheeses implicated in this outbreak.\n\n[Footnotes and references are available at the CDC URL above.]\n\nReports of this outbreak of listeriosis were posted by ProMED-mail in 2013 (see postings listed below). - Mod.ML\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/106.]\nSee Also\n2013\n---\nListeriosis - USA (03): multistate, fatal, cheese, recall 20130828.1909350\nListeriosis - USA: fatal, cheese, recall 20130710.1816187\n.................................................sb/ml/mj/sh", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "salmonellosis", "listeriosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Minnesota", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Texas", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Indiana", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Wisconsin", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Jackson KA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ohio", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Seattle", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Illinois", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2394195", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis - USA (02): 2013, fatal, cheese", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2394195", "date": "2014-04-10 14:36:12", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS - USA (02): 2013, FATAL, CHEESE\n*******************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 8 Apr 2014\nSource: fdlreporter.com, Associated Press (AP) report [edited]\nhttp://www.fdlreporter.com/viewart/20140408/FON03/140408008/Dodge-County-cheese-plant-cited-illness-outbreak\n\n\nAn illness outbreak from a Wisconsin cheesemaker that was linked to one death and a miscarriage likely was caused by substantial sanitation deficiencies in the cheese-making process, a new report from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) says.\n\nThe listeriosis outbreak occurred last summer [2013] and was linked to contaminated soft cheeses from Crave Brothers Farmstead Cheese Co. of Waterloo. The death was in Minnesota, while illnesses from _Listeria monocytogenes_ were reported in Minnesota, Illinois, Indiana, and Ohio, according to the US Food and Drug Administration (FDA), according to the Milwaukee Journal Sentinel.\n\n3 Crave Brothers pasteurized soft cheeses were the subject of a nationwide recall as a result of the outbreak: Les Freres, Petit Frere, and Petit Frere with truffles. All 3 had previously captured national and international awards for Crave, one of Wisconsin's most well-known cheesemakers.\n\n\"Inspection of the cheesemaking facility revealed that substantial sanitation deficiencies during the cheesemaking process itself, after the milk was pasteurized, likely led to contamination,\" CDC's Morbidity and Mortality Weekly Report noted.\n\nPasteurization, a process in which milk is heated to a high temperature to destroy pathogens, eliminates listeria in milk. But contamination can occur after pasteurization, according to government regulators. \"Cheese-making facilities should use strict sanitation and microbiologic monitoring, regardless of whether they use pasteurized milk,\" the CDC report said. Details of the contamination were not in the report, and Crave Brothers declined to comment.\n\nThe 5 people sickened told health department officials they had definitely or probably eaten 1 of 3 varieties of Crave soft-ripened cheese. 3 of the people had purchased the cheese at 3 different restaurants, and 2 had purchased it at 2 different grocery stores. The cheeses were shipped as intact wheels to the restaurants and stores, where they had been cut and served or cut and repackaged and sold to customers, according to the CDC report.\n\nLaboratory tests conducted by the Minnesota Department of Agriculture on samples of the cheeses from 2 retail stores indicated the presence of the outbreak strain [of] _Listeria monocytogenes_.\n\nListeria infections are among the 3 most deadly foodborne bacteria after toxoplasmosis and salmonellosis.\n\nCrave Brothers issued voluntary product recalls 2 days after it halted production of the 3 cheeses. On [11 Jul 2013], the company voluntarily halted production of all cheese products made in the plant, the report noted.\n\nAll 5 people sickened in the outbreak were hospitalized, including the pregnant woman who suffered a miscarriage. They ranged in age from 31 to 67 years old, according to the Food and Drug Administration.\n\nThe company has not been fined, and checks of court records haven't revealed lawsuits. Cheesemakers could face criminal charges for shipping contaminated cheese into the marketplace, according to Bill Marler, a Seattle attorney who specializes in food safety cases. \"But it's very rare that the FDA does anything with respect to fines or sanctions whatsoever in these cases,\" he said.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The news report above refers to the CDC publication, which is abridged and edited below: Choi MJ, Jackson KA, Medus C, et al. Notes from the field: multistate outbreak of listeriosis linked to soft-ripened cheese -- United States, 2013. MMWR Morb Mortal Wkly Rep 4 Apr 2014; 63(13): 294-5; available at http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm6313a5.htm:\n\nOn [27 Jun 2013], the Minnesota Department of Health notified CDC of 2 patients with invasive _Listeria monocytogenes_ infections (listeriosis) whose clinical isolates had indistinguishable pulsed-field gel electrophoresis (PFGE) patterns. A query of PulseNet, the national molecular subtyping network for foodborne disease surveillance, identified clinical and environmental isolates from other states. On [28 Jun 2013], CDC learned from the Food and Drug Administration's Coordinated Outbreak Response and Evaluation Network that environmental isolates indistinguishable from those of the 2 patients had been collected from Crave Brothers Farmstead Cheese during 2010-2011.\n\nAs of [28 Jun 2014], 5 cases [who had isolation of _L. monocytogenes_ with the outbreak PFGE pattern from an anatomic site that is normally sterile (such as, blood or cerebrospinal fluid), or from a product of conception] were identified in 4 states (Minnesota, 2 cases; Illinois, Indiana, and Ohio, one case each). Median age of the 5 patients was 58 years (range: 31-67 years). 4 patients were female, including one who was pregnant at the time of infection. All 5 were hospitalized. 1 death and 1 miscarriage were reported.\n\nAll 5 patients had definitely or probably eaten one of 3 varieties of Crave Brothers soft-ripened cheese (Les Freres, Petit Frere, or Petit Frere with truffles). 3 patients had purchased the cheese at 3 different restaurants, and 2 had purchased the cheese at 2 different grocery stores. The cheeses were shipped as intact wheels to the 3 restaurants and 2 grocery stores, where they had been cut and served or repackaged and sold to customers.\n\nTesting at the Minnesota Department of Agriculture identified the outbreak pattern of _L. monocytogenes_ in 2 cheese wedges (Les Freres and Petit Frere with truffles) collected from 2 different grocery stores in Minnesota. Inspection of the cheese-making facility revealed that substantial sanitation deficiencies during the cheese-making process itself, after the milk was pasteurized, likely led to contamination. On [1 Jul 2013], Crave Brothers halted production of Les Freres, Petit Frere, and Petit Frere with truffles. On [3 Jul 2013], Crave Brothers issued a voluntary recall of these products with a production date of [1 Jul 2013], or earlier. On [11 Jul 2013], the company voluntarily halted production of all cheese products manufactured at the facility. After product recall, one additional case was identified in Texas through whole genome sequencing, bringing the total case count for the outbreak to 6.\n\nThis outbreak was linked to soft cheeses that were likely contaminated during the cheese-making process (2,3). Pasteurization eliminates _Listeria_ in milk. However, contamination can occur after pasteurization. Cheesemaking facilities should use strict sanitation and microbiologic monitoring, regardless of whether they use pasteurized milk.+\n\nPersons at greater risk for listeriosis, including older adults, pregnant women, and those with immunocompromising conditions, should be aware that certain soft cheeses made with unpasteurized milk, or made under unsanitary conditions, regardless of whether the milk was pasteurized, have been shown to cause severe illness. These soft cheeses include fresh (unripened) cheeses, such as queso fresco (4), and soft-ripened cheeses, such as the cheeses implicated in this outbreak.\n\n[Footnotes and references are available at the CDC URL above.]\n\nReports of this outbreak of listeriosis were posted by ProMED-mail in 2013 (see postings listed below). - Mod.ML\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/106.]\nSee Also\n2013\n---\nListeriosis - USA (03): multistate, fatal, cheese, recall 20130828.1909350\nListeriosis - USA: fatal, cheese, recall 20130710.1816187\n.................................................sb/ml/mj/sh", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "salmonellosis", "listeriosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Minnesota", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Texas", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Indiana", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Wisconsin", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Jackson KA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ohio", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Seattle", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Illinois", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2306847", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis - Sweden (02): background", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2306847", "date": "2013-04-21 11:13:38", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS - AUSTRALIA (03): (SYDNEY) NOSOCOMIAL, PROFITEROLE\n**************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sun 21 Apr 2013\nSource: Yahoo 7 News, ABC News (Australian Broadcasting Corporation) report [edited]\nhttp://au.news.yahoo.com/latest/a/-/latest/16818325/profiteroles-blamed-for-listeria-outbreak/\n\n\nA batch of dodgy profiteroles is being blamed on a listeriosis outbreak that could have spread across 13 public hospitals in Sydney.\n\nThe NSW [New South Wales] Department of Health says that so far 3 patients, including a terminally ill man at Campbelltown Hospital who has since died, have tested positive for listeriosis. The 2 other patients, one from Concord hospital and another from the Royal Prince Alfred are responding well to treatment.\n\nThe profiteroles, which were made by Rich Products Australia, have since been withdrawn from all patient meals.\n\nAn investigation into the outbreak, which is believed to have occurred between mid-March and 16 Apr 2013, is ongoing.\n\nNSW Director of Health Protection Jeremy McAnulty says the risk of further cases is low but if people are concerned they should seek medical advice.\n\n\"If people did eat profiteroles in one of the hospitals in central or southwest Sydney and they get the symptoms of listeriosis then they should see their doctor,\" he said. \"We've withdrawn them from serving to patients.\"\n\n[Symptoms] include fever, muscle aches, and sometimes gastrointestinal symptoms such as nausea and diarrhoea. In the more severe form, symptoms also include collapse and shock.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Listeriosis is a worldwide zoonosis caused by _Listeria monocytogenes_, which is transmitted by ingestion of contaminated food. Infection results in diarrhea and, in some patients, invasive disease that includes bacteremia without an evident focus, meningitis, abscesses in the brain and spinal cord, endocarditis, and intrauterine infection. Infection during pregnancy can lead to premature delivery, infection of the newborn, or stillbirth. Invasive listeriosis is rare (about 2500 cases occur annually in the USA), but the disease has an overall mortality rate of 20 to 30 percent. Newborns, pregnant women, people 60 years of age or older, and those with compromised immune defenses (such as HIV-infected patients) are most susceptible to invasive disease.\n\nFood implicated in outbreaks has included raw milk, soft cheeses such as Latin-American cheeses, feta, brie, and Camembert, ice cream, raw vegetables and fruit, or consumption of ready-to-eat food that has been contaminated during processing of food, such as deli meat and delicatessen salads such as coleslaw, raw and smoked fish, shellfish such as shrimp, and undercooked chicken.\n\nWhen _L. monocytogenes_ get into a food-processing facility (such as, factories processing smoked fish, poultry, meat, and dairy products), they persist there for years and can contaminate food after factory cooking, but before packaging. Particularly problematic is the fact that _L. monocytogenes_ can grow in refrigeration temperatures during storage, which is why even minimal contamination with this bacterium during the processing of subsequently refrigerated ready-to-eat food can cause severe foodborne infections.\n\nNosocomial listeriosis has been described previously related to food service in healthcare facilities. Since listeriosis is more severe in newborns, pregnant women, people 60 years of age or older, and those with compromised immune defenses, food such as refrigerated, packaged ready-to-eat products, such as, cold cut meats, should not be part of a menu in health care settings.\n\nA profiterole or cream puff is a hollow pastry ball filled with whipped cream, pastry cream, or ice cream and the puff garnished with chocolate sauce, caramel, or a dusting of powdered sugar (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Profiterole).\n\nComparison of the molecular characteristics, such as PFGE, of _L. monocytogenes_ strains isolated from the cases with each other and with that of strains isolated from suspected foods help to confirm a common source for an outbreak.\n\nThe incubation period for listeriosis ranges from 3 to 70 days, with the median incubation period being 3 weeks. With such a long incubation period, we may continue to see more cases of listeriosis in this outbreak.\n\nThe HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of Australia is available at http://healthmap.org/r/1*7F. - Mod.ML]\nSee Also\nListeriosis - Australia (02): fatal, soft cheese, more cases 20130211.1538072\nListeriosis - Australia: fatal, soft cheese, recall 20130125.1514992\n2012\n---\nListeriosis - Australia: cheese, recall 20121219.1459159\nListeriosis - New Zealand (03): (HB) nosocomial, fatal 20120724.1212514\nListeriosis - New Zealand (02): (HB) nosocomial, fatal, background 20120721.1210276\nListeriosis - New Zealand: (HB) nosocomial, fatal 20120720.1209143\nListeriosis - UK (04): (N. Ireland) nosocomial, fatal 20120517.1136357\nListeriosis - UK (03): (N. Ireland) nosocomial, fatal, background 20120420.1107753\nListeriosis - UK (02): (N. USA: (CA, MD) fatal, Hispanic-style soft cheese, recall", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2294169", "date": "2013-04-21 11:13:38", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS - AUSTRALIA (03): (SYDNEY) NOSOCOMIAL, PROFITEROLE\n**************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sun 21 Apr 2013\nSource: Yahoo 7 News, ABC News (Australian Broadcasting Corporation) report [edited]\nhttp://au.news.yahoo.com/latest/a/-/latest/16818325/profiteroles-blamed-for-listeria-outbreak/\n\n\nA batch of dodgy profiteroles is being blamed on a listeriosis outbreak that could have spread across 13 public hospitals in Sydney.\n\nThe NSW [New South Wales] Department of Health says that so far 3 patients, including a terminally ill man at Campbelltown Hospital who has since died, have tested positive for listeriosis. The 2 other patients, one from Concord hospital and another from the Royal Prince Alfred are responding well to treatment.\n\nThe profiteroles, which were made by Rich Products Australia, have since been withdrawn from all patient meals.\n\nAn investigation into the outbreak, which is believed to have occurred between mid-March and 16 Apr 2013, is ongoing.\n\nNSW Director of Health Protection Jeremy McAnulty says the risk of further cases is low but if people are concerned they should seek medical advice.\n\n\"If people did eat profiteroles in one of the hospitals in central or southwest Sydney and they get the symptoms of listeriosis then they should see their doctor,\" he said. \"We've withdrawn them from serving to patients.\"\n\n[Symptoms] include fever, muscle aches, and sometimes gastrointestinal symptoms such as nausea and diarrhoea. In the more severe form, symptoms also include collapse and shock.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Listeriosis is a worldwide zoonosis caused by _Listeria monocytogenes_, which is transmitted by ingestion of contaminated food. Infection results in diarrhea and, in some patients, invasive disease that includes bacteremia without an evident focus, meningitis, abscesses in the brain and spinal cord, endocarditis, and intrauterine infection. Infection during pregnancy can lead to premature delivery, infection of the newborn, or stillbirth. Invasive listeriosis is rare (about 2500 cases occur annually in the USA), but the disease has an overall mortality rate of 20 to 30 percent. Newborns, pregnant women, people 60 years of age or older, and those with compromised immune defenses (such as HIV-infected patients) are most susceptible to invasive disease.\n\nFood implicated in outbreaks has included raw milk, soft cheeses such as Latin-American cheeses, feta, brie, and Camembert, ice cream, raw vegetables and fruit, or consumption of ready-to-eat food that has been contaminated during processing of food, such as deli meat and delicatessen salads such as coleslaw, raw and smoked fish, shellfish such as shrimp, and undercooked chicken.\n\nWhen _L. monocytogenes_ get into a food-processing facility (such as, factories processing smoked fish, poultry, meat, and dairy products), they persist there for years and can contaminate food after factory cooking, but before packaging. Particularly problematic is the fact that _L. monocytogenes_ can grow in refrigeration temperatures during storage, which is why even minimal contamination with this bacterium during the processing of subsequently refrigerated ready-to-eat food can cause severe foodborne infections.\n\nNosocomial listeriosis has been described previously related to food service in healthcare facilities. Since listeriosis is more severe in newborns, pregnant women, people 60 years of age or older, and those with compromised immune defenses, food such as refrigerated, packaged ready-to-eat products, such as, cold cut meats, should not be part of a menu in health care settings.\n\nA profiterole or cream puff is a hollow pastry ball filled with whipped cream, pastry cream, or ice cream and the puff garnished with chocolate sauce, caramel, or a dusting of powdered sugar (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Profiterole).\n\nComparison of the molecular characteristics, such as PFGE, of _L. monocytogenes_ strains isolated from the cases with each other and with that of strains isolated from suspected foods help to confirm a common source for an outbreak.\n\nThe incubation period for listeriosis ranges from 3 to 70 days, with the median incubation period being 3 weeks. With such a long incubation period, we may continue to see more cases of listeriosis in this outbreak.\n\nThe HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of Australia is available at http://healthmap.org/r/1*7F. - Mod.ML]\nSee Also\nListeriosis - Australia (02): fatal, soft cheese, more cases 20130211.1538072\nListeriosis - Australia: fatal, soft cheese, recall 20130125.1514992\n2012\n---\nListeriosis - Australia: cheese, recall 20121219.1459159\nListeriosis - New Zealand (03): (HB) nosocomial, fatal 20120724.1212514\nListeriosis - New Zealand (02): (HB) nosocomial, fatal, background 20120721.1210276\nListeriosis - New Zealand: (HB) nosocomial, fatal 20120720.1209143\nListeriosis - UK (04): (N. Ireland) nosocomial, fatal 20120517.1136357\nListeriosis - UK (03): (N. Ireland) nosocomial, fatal, background 20120420.1107753\nListeriosis - UK (02): (N. UK (England): alert, recall 20070326.1049\n2005\n----\nListeriosis, nosocomial - Australia (SA) (02) 20051215.3598\nListeriosis, nosocomial - Australia (SA) 20051213.3587\n.................................................sb/ml/mj/ml", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "listeriosis", "meningitis"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Sydney", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "England", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "SYDNEY", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Australia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Northern Ireland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Concord", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1909350", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis - USA (03): multistate, fatal, cheese, recall", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1909350", "date": "2013-04-21 11:13:38", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS - AUSTRALIA (03): (SYDNEY) NOSOCOMIAL, PROFITEROLE\n**************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sun 21 Apr 2013\nSource: Yahoo 7 News, ABC News (Australian Broadcasting Corporation) report [edited]\nhttp://au.news.yahoo.com/latest/a/-/latest/16818325/profiteroles-blamed-for-listeria-outbreak/\n\n\nA batch of dodgy profiteroles is being blamed on a listeriosis outbreak that could have spread across 13 public hospitals in Sydney.\n\nThe NSW [New South Wales] Department of Health says that so far 3 patients, including a terminally ill man at Campbelltown Hospital who has since died, have tested positive for listeriosis. The 2 other patients, one from Concord hospital and another from the Royal Prince Alfred are responding well to treatment.\n\nThe profiteroles, which were made by Rich Products Australia, have since been withdrawn from all patient meals.\n\nAn investigation into the outbreak, which is believed to have occurred between mid-March and 16 Apr 2013, is ongoing.\n\nNSW Director of Health Protection Jeremy McAnulty says the risk of further cases is low but if people are concerned they should seek medical advice.\n\n\"If people did eat profiteroles in one of the hospitals in central or southwest Sydney and they get the symptoms of listeriosis then they should see their doctor,\" he said. \"We've withdrawn them from serving to patients.\"\n\n[Symptoms] include fever, muscle aches, and sometimes gastrointestinal symptoms such as nausea and diarrhoea. In the more severe form, symptoms also include collapse and shock.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Listeriosis is a worldwide zoonosis caused by _Listeria monocytogenes_, which is transmitted by ingestion of contaminated food. Infection results in diarrhea and, in some patients, invasive disease that includes bacteremia without an evident focus, meningitis, abscesses in the brain and spinal cord, endocarditis, and intrauterine infection. Infection during pregnancy can lead to premature delivery, infection of the newborn, or stillbirth. Invasive listeriosis is rare (about 2500 cases occur annually in the USA), but the disease has an overall mortality rate of 20 to 30 percent. Newborns, pregnant women, people 60 years of age or older, and those with compromised immune defenses (such as HIV-infected patients) are most susceptible to invasive disease.\n\nFood implicated in outbreaks has included raw milk, soft cheeses such as Latin-American cheeses, feta, brie, and Camembert, ice cream, raw vegetables and fruit, or consumption of ready-to-eat food that has been contaminated during processing of food, such as deli meat and delicatessen salads such as coleslaw, raw and smoked fish, shellfish such as shrimp, and undercooked chicken.\n\nWhen _L. monocytogenes_ get into a food-processing facility (such as, factories processing smoked fish, poultry, meat, and dairy products), they persist there for years and can contaminate food after factory cooking, but before packaging. Particularly problematic is the fact that _L. monocytogenes_ can grow in refrigeration temperatures during storage, which is why even minimal contamination with this bacterium during the processing of subsequently refrigerated ready-to-eat food can cause severe foodborne infections.\n\nNosocomial listeriosis has been described previously related to food service in healthcare facilities. Since listeriosis is more severe in newborns, pregnant women, people 60 years of age or older, and those with compromised immune defenses, food such as refrigerated, packaged ready-to-eat products, such as, cold cut meats, should not be part of a menu in health care settings.\n\nA profiterole or cream puff is a hollow pastry ball filled with whipped cream, pastry cream, or ice cream and the puff garnished with chocolate sauce, caramel, or a dusting of powdered sugar (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Profiterole).\n\nComparison of the molecular characteristics, such as PFGE, of _L. monocytogenes_ strains isolated from the cases with each other and with that of strains isolated from suspected foods help to confirm a common source for an outbreak.\n\nThe incubation period for listeriosis ranges from 3 to 70 days, with the median incubation period being 3 weeks. With such a long incubation period, we may continue to see more cases of listeriosis in this outbreak.\n\nThe HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of Australia is available at http://healthmap.org/r/1*7F. - Mod.ML]\nSee Also\nListeriosis - Australia (02): fatal, soft cheese, more cases 20130211.1538072\nListeriosis - Australia: fatal, soft cheese, recall 20130125.1514992\n2012\n---\nListeriosis - Australia: cheese, recall 20121219.1459159\nListeriosis - New Zealand (03): (HB) nosocomial, fatal 20120724.1212514\nListeriosis - New Zealand (02): (HB) nosocomial, fatal, background 20120721.1210276\nListeriosis - New Zealand: (HB) nosocomial, fatal 20120720.1209143\nListeriosis - UK (04): (N. UK (England): alert, recall 20070326.1049\n2005\n----\nListeriosis, nosocomial - Australia (SA) (02) 20051215.3598\nListeriosis, nosocomial - Australia (SA) 20051213.3587\n.................................................sb/ml/mj/ml", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "listeriosis", "meningitis"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Sydney", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "England", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "SYDNEY", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Australia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Northern Ireland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Concord", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1661868", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis - Australia (03): (Sydney) nosocomial, profiterole", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1661868", "date": "2013-04-21 11:13:38", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS - AUSTRALIA (03): (SYDNEY) NOSOCOMIAL, PROFITEROLE\n**************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sun 21 Apr 2013\nSource: Yahoo 7 News, ABC News (Australian Broadcasting Corporation) report [edited]\nhttp://au.news.yahoo.com/latest/a/-/latest/16818325/profiteroles-blamed-for-listeria-outbreak/\n\n\nA batch of dodgy profiteroles is being blamed on a listeriosis outbreak that could have spread across 13 public hospitals in Sydney.\n\nThe NSW [New South Wales] Department of Health says that so far 3 patients, including a terminally ill man at Campbelltown Hospital who has since died, have tested positive for listeriosis. The 2 other patients, one from Concord hospital and another from the Royal Prince Alfred are responding well to treatment.\n\nThe profiteroles, which were made by Rich Products Australia, have since been withdrawn from all patient meals.\n\nAn investigation into the outbreak, which is believed to have occurred between mid-March and 16 Apr 2013, is ongoing.\n\nNSW Director of Health Protection Jeremy McAnulty says the risk of further cases is low but if people are concerned they should seek medical advice.\n\n\"If people did eat profiteroles in one of the hospitals in central or southwest Sydney and they get the symptoms of listeriosis then they should see their doctor,\" he said. \"We've withdrawn them from serving to patients.\"\n\n[Symptoms] include fever, muscle aches, and sometimes gastrointestinal symptoms such as nausea and diarrhoea. In the more severe form, symptoms also include collapse and shock.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Listeriosis is a worldwide zoonosis caused by _Listeria monocytogenes_, which is transmitted by ingestion of contaminated food. Infection results in diarrhea and, in some patients, invasive disease that includes bacteremia without an evident focus, meningitis, abscesses in the brain and spinal cord, endocarditis, and intrauterine infection. Infection during pregnancy can lead to premature delivery, infection of the newborn, or stillbirth. Invasive listeriosis is rare (about 2500 cases occur annually in the USA), but the disease has an overall mortality rate of 20 to 30 percent. Newborns, pregnant women, people 60 years of age or older, and those with compromised immune defenses (such as HIV-infected patients) are most susceptible to invasive disease.\n\nFood implicated in outbreaks has included raw milk, soft cheeses such as Latin-American cheeses, feta, brie, and Camembert, ice cream, raw vegetables and fruit, or consumption of ready-to-eat food that has been contaminated during processing of food, such as deli meat and delicatessen salads such as coleslaw, raw and smoked fish, shellfish such as shrimp, and undercooked chicken.\n\nWhen _L. monocytogenes_ get into a food-processing facility (such as, factories processing smoked fish, poultry, meat, and dairy products), they persist there for years and can contaminate food after factory cooking, but before packaging. Particularly problematic is the fact that _L. monocytogenes_ can grow in refrigeration temperatures during storage, which is why even minimal contamination with this bacterium during the processing of subsequently refrigerated ready-to-eat food can cause severe foodborne infections.\n\nNosocomial listeriosis has been described previously related to food service in healthcare facilities. Since listeriosis is more severe in newborns, pregnant women, people 60 years of age or older, and those with compromised immune defenses, food such as refrigerated, packaged ready-to-eat products, such as, cold cut meats, should not be part of a menu in health care settings.\n\nA profiterole or cream puff is a hollow pastry ball filled with whipped cream, pastry cream, or ice cream and the puff garnished with chocolate sauce, caramel, or a dusting of powdered sugar (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Profiterole).\n\nComparison of the molecular characteristics, such as PFGE, of _L. monocytogenes_ strains isolated from the cases with each other and with that of strains isolated from suspected foods help to confirm a common source for an outbreak.\n\nThe incubation period for listeriosis ranges from 3 to 70 days, with the median incubation period being 3 weeks. With such a long incubation period, we may continue to see more cases of listeriosis in this outbreak.\n\nThe HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of Australia is available at http://healthmap.org/r/1*7F. - Mod.ML]\nSee Also\nListeriosis - Australia (02): fatal, soft cheese, more cases 20130211.1538072\nListeriosis - Australia: fatal, soft cheese, recall 20130125.1514992\n2012\n---\nListeriosis - Australia: cheese, recall 20121219.1459159\nListeriosis - New Zealand (03): (HB) nosocomial, fatal 20120724.1212514\nListeriosis - New Zealand (02): (HB) nosocomial, fatal, background 20120721.1210276\nListeriosis - New Zealand: (HB) nosocomial, fatal 20120720.1209143\nListeriosis - UK (04): (N. Ireland) nosocomial, fatal 20120517.1136357\nListeriosis - UK (03): (N. Ireland) nosocomial, fatal, background 20120420.1107753\nListeriosis - UK (02): (N. New Zealand: (HB) nosocomial, fatal 20120720.1209143\n-----------------------------------\nAmong the major English-speaking countries, New Zealand reports the highest incidence of listeriosis per 100,000 population - approximately twice the rate reported in Australia - see graph at http://www.gideononline.com/wp/wp-content/uploads/Listeriosis-NZ.png (1-3).\n\nGideon http://www.GideonOnline.com records 5 outbreaks of listeriosis in New Zealand during 1969 to 2000, including:\n1980 - An outbreak (22 cases, 5 fetal deaths) of perinatal listeriosis among 3 obstetrics hospitals in Auckland.\n1981 to 1982 - An outbreak (18 cases, 3 abortions and one neonatal death) in Christchurch.\n1992 - An outbreak (2 cases) of perinatal listeriosis related to contaminated smoked mussels.\n\nReferences:\n1. Berger SA. Infectious Diseases of New Zealand, 2012. 413 pages, 136 graphs, 1534 references. Gideon e-books, http://www.gideononline.com/ebooks/country/infectious-diseases-of-new-zealand/\n2. New Zealand: (HB) nosocomial, fatal 20120720.1209143\n-----------------------------------\nAmong the major English-speaking countries, New Zealand reports the highest incidence of listeriosis per 100,000 population - approximately twice the rate reported in Australia - see graph at http://www.gideononline.com/wp/wp-content/uploads/Listeriosis-NZ.png (1-3).\n\nGideon http://www.GideonOnline.com records 5 outbreaks of listeriosis in New Zealand during 1969 to 2000, including:\n1980 - An outbreak (2 cases) of perinatal listeriosis related to contaminated smoked mussels.\n\nReferences:\n1. USA (02): (multistate) fatal, cheese, recall", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1292100", "date": "2012-07-21 20:42:04", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS - NEW ZEALAND (02): (HAWKE'S BAY), NOSOCOMIAL, FATAL, BACKGROUND\n****************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sat 21 Jul 2012\nSource: Dr. Steve Berger <mberger@post.tau.ac.il> [edited]\n\n\nRe: ProMED-mail post Listeriosis - New Zealand: (HB) nosocomial, fatal 20120720.1209143\n-----------------------------------\nAmong the major English-speaking countries, New Zealand reports the highest incidence of listeriosis per 100,000 population - approximately twice the rate reported in Australia - see graph at http://www.gideononline.com/wp/wp-content/uploads/Listeriosis-NZ.png (1-3).\n\nGideon http://www.GideonOnline.com records 5 outbreaks of listeriosis in New Zealand during 1969 to 2000, including:\n1980 - An outbreak (22 cases, 5 fetal deaths) of perinatal listeriosis among 3 obstetrics hospitals in Auckland.\n1981 to 1982 - An outbreak (18 cases, 3 abortions and one neonatal death) in Christchurch.\n1992 - An outbreak (2 cases) of perinatal listeriosis related to contaminated smoked mussels.\n\nReferences:\n1. Berger SA. Infectious Diseases of New Zealand, 2012. 413 pages, 136 graphs, 1534 references. Gideon e-books, http://www.gideononline.com/ebooks/country/infectious-diseases-of-new-zealand/\n2. Berger SA. Listeriosis: Global Status, 2012. 95 pages, 105 graphs, 557 references. Gideon e-books, http://www.gideononline.com/ebooks/disease/listeriosis-global-status/\n3. Gideon Graph Tool at http://www.GIDEONonline.com/wp/wp-content/uploads/Gideon-Graphs.pps\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nSteve Berger\nGeographic Medicine\nTel Aviv Medical Center\n<mberger@post.tau.ac.il>\n\n[ProMED-mail thanks Steve Berger for this background information.\n\nThe HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of New Zealand can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/r/1VY-. - Mod.ML]\nSee Also\nListeriosis - New Zealand: (HB) nosocomial, fatal 20120720.1209143\nListeriosis - UK (04): (N. Ireland) nosocomial, fatal, comment 20120418.1105643\nListeriosis - UK: (Northern Ireland) nosocomial, fatal 20120415.1101822\n2007\n----\nListeriosis, nosocomial - Norway: (Oslo) 20071024.3452\nListeriosis, sandwiches - New Zealand: (HB) nosocomial, fatal", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1209143", "date": "2011-11-05 16:33:00", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS, FATAL - USA (14): CANTALOUPE, MORE CASES AND DEATHS\n****************************************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 2 Nov 2011\nSource: Reuters [edited]\nhttp://www.reuters.com/article/2011/11/03/us-listeria-cantaloupes-idUSTRE7A20BU20111103\n\n\n\nThe death toll linked to _Listeria_-contaminated cantaloupe in the\nUnited States rose to 29 as another death was reported, the Centers\nfor Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) said on Wednesday [2 Nov\n2011].\n\nWhole or pre-cut Rocky Ford-brand cantaloupe from Colorado-based\nJensen Farms has been traced as the cause of what has become one of\nthe deadliest U.S. food-borne outbreaks in U.S. history. A total of\n139 people in 28 states have fallen ill so far in the outbreak, and\nthe CDC has said that one woman, who was pregnant at the time she fell\nill, had a miscarriage.\n\nThe deadliest known food-borne listeriosis outbreak prior to the\ncurrent spate of illnesses in the United States was in 1985, when\nMexican-style soft cheese contaminated with _Listeria_ was tied to the\ndeaths of 18 adults, and 10 newborns, as well as 20 miscarriages,\naccording to a CDC report.\n\nListeriosis has a long incubation period, with symptoms sometimes not\nshowing up until 2 months after people consume tainted foods.\n\nThe elderly, pregnant women, and people with weakened immune systems\nare most at risk of falling ill from _Listeria_ infection. Symptoms\ninclude fever and muscle aches, sometimes preceded by diarrhea and\nother gastric problems.\n\nIn a warning letter to Jensen Farms last month, the U.S. Food and Drug\nAdministration said testing turned up widespread _Listeria_\ncontamination at its Granada, Colorado, packing plant, which\n\"indicates poor sanitary practices in the facility.\"\n\nListeria outbreaks are most commonly linked to contaminated cheese or\npackaged meats. The current outbreak is the 1st to be associated with\ncantaloupe.\n\n\"What this shows is that these bugs are very opportunistic,\" food\nsafety attorney and advocate Bill Marler said. \"As long as you have a\ncool, wet environment and a product that is ready-to-eat, you're\nalways going to have a risk of _Listeria_ contamination, which is why\nthe sanitation of the plant is so critical,\" said Marler, who is\nrepresenting several families affected by the outbreak.\n\n[Byline: Lisa Baertlein, Cynthia Johnston]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The total number of people who have been sickened after eating whole\nor pre-cut _Listeria moncytogenes_- contaminated cantaloupe from\nColorado-based Jensen Farms has risen from 133 to 139, the number of\nstates where cases have occurred has risen from 26 to 28, and the\nnumber of deaths has risen from 28 to 29 since the last ProMED-mail\npost, Listeriosis, fatal - USA (13): cantaloupe, more cases & deaths\n20111026.3188. A discussion of listeriosis can be found in prior\nProMED-mail posts on this outbreak.\n\nThe long incubation period for listeriosis, with symptoms sometimes\nnot showing up until 2 months after people consumed the tainted food,\nexplains the continuing occurrence of new cases. On 14 Sep 2011, FDA\nissued a press release to announce that Jensen Farms issued a\nvoluntary recall of their brand of Rocky Ford Cantaloupes because of\n_Listeria_ contamination.\n\nInitially cantaloupe from the Rocky Ford region of southeastern\nColorado was the suspected vehicle (ProMED-mail post Listeriosis,\nfatal - USA (03) 20110914.2800). Subsequently, cantaloupe involved in\nthe listeriosis outbreak was traced specifically to cantaloupe from\nJensen Farm, which labeled its cantaloupe with the Rocky Ford name.\nThe FDA identified the recalled whole cantaloupes from Jensen Farm as\nhaving a green and white sticker that reads: \"Product of USA-Frontera\nProduce-Colorado Fresh-Rocky Ford-Cantaloupe,\" or a gray, yellow, and\ngreen sticker that reads \"Jensen Farms-Sweet Rocky Fords\"\n(http://www.fda.gov/Safety/Recalls/ucm271879.htm). Photos of the\nlabeling can be seen at\nhttp://www.fda.gov/Safety/Recalls/ucm271882.htm. Cantaloupe from\nother farms in this region of southeastern Colorado have not been\nimplicated in this outbreak. - Mod.ML]\nSee Also\nListeriosis, fatal - USA (13): cantaloupe, more cases & deaths\n20111026.3188\nListeriosis, fatal - USA (12): cantaloupe 20111022.3144\nListeriosis, fatal - USA (11): cantaloupe, farm factors 20111020.3130\nListeriosis, fatal - USA (10): cantaloupe, more cases & deaths\n20111008.3022\nListeriosis, fatal - USA (09): cantaloupe, more cases & deaths\n20111005.2993\nListeriosis - USA: romaine lettuce, recall 20111001.2959\nListeriosis, fatal - USA (08): background 20111001.2958\nListeriosis, fatal - USA (07): cantaloupe, more cases & deaths\n20110930.2950\nListeriosis, fatal - USA (06): cantaloupe, more cases & deaths\n20110923.2876\nListeriosis, fatal - USA (05): cantaloupe, more cases & deaths\n20110922.2871\nListeriosis, fatal - USA (04): cantaloupe, alert 20110921.2866\nListeriosis, fatal - USA (03): cantaloupe susp. 20110914.2800\nListeriosis, fatal - USA (02): (CO) 20110909.2746\nListeriosis, fatal - USA: (CO) 20110605.1719\n2010\n----\nListeriosis, fatal - USA (03): (TX), recall 20101105.4005\nListeriosis, fatal - USA (02): (TX), recall 20101021.3813\nListeriosis, fatal - USA: (TX) 20100515.1592\nListeriosis, fatal, meat product - Canada: (ON) 20100314.0829\n.................................................sb/ml/ejp/lm", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "listeriosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-14 00:00:00", "2021-03-17 00:00:00", "1985-03-16 00:00:00", "2011-09-14 00:00:00", "2021-03-11 00:00:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Granada", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "U.S.", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Colorado", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "United States", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1136357", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis - UK (04): (N. A total of\n139 people in 28 states have fallen ill so far in the outbreak, and\nthe CDC has said that one woman, who was pregnant at the time she fell\nill, had a miscarriage.\n\nThe deadliest known food-borne listeriosis outbreak prior to the\ncurrent spate of illnesses in the United States was in 1985, when\nMexican-style soft cheese contaminated with _Listeria_ was tied to the\ndeaths of 18 adults, and 10 newborns, as well as 20 miscarriages,\naccording to a CDC report.\n\nListeriosis has a long incubation period, with symptoms sometimes not\nshowing up until 2 months after people consume tainted foods.\n\nThe elderly, pregnant women, and people with weakened immune systems\nare most at risk of falling ill from _Listeria_ infection. Symptoms\ninclude fever and muscle aches, sometimes preceded by diarrhea and\nother gastric problems.\n\nIn a warning letter to Jensen Farms last month, the U.S. Food and Drug\nAdministration said testing turned up widespread _Listeria_\ncontamination at its Granada, Colorado, packing plant, which\n\"indicates poor sanitary practices in the facility.\"\n\nListeria outbreaks are most commonly linked to contaminated cheese or\npackaged meats. The current outbreak is the 1st to be associated with\ncantaloupe.\n\n\"What this shows is that these bugs are very opportunistic,\" food\nsafety attorney and advocate Bill Marler said. \"As long as you have a\ncool, wet environment and a product that is ready-to-eat, you're\nalways going to have a risk of _Listeria_ contamination, which is why\nthe sanitation of the plant is so critical,\" said Marler, who is\nrepresenting several families affected by the outbreak.\n\n[Byline: Lisa Baertlein, Cynthia Johnston]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The total number of people who have been sickened after eating whole\nor pre-cut _Listeria moncytogenes_- contaminated cantaloupe from\nColorado-based Jensen Farms has risen from 133 to 139, the number of\nstates where cases have occurred has risen from 26 to 28, and the\nnumber of deaths has risen from 28 to 29 since the last ProMED-mail\npost, Listeriosis, fatal - USA (13): cantaloupe, more cases & deaths\n20111026.3188. A discussion of listeriosis can be found in prior\nProMED-mail posts on this outbreak.\n\nThe long incubation period for listeriosis, with symptoms sometimes\nnot showing up until 2 months after people consumed the tainted food,\nexplains the continuing occurrence of new cases. On 14 Sep 2011, FDA\nissued a press release to announce that Jensen Farms issued a\nvoluntary recall of their brand of Rocky Ford Cantaloupes because of\n_Listeria_ contamination.\n\nInitially cantaloupe from the Rocky Ford region of southeastern\nColorado was the suspected vehicle (ProMED-mail post Listeriosis,\nfatal - USA (03) 20110914.2800). Subsequently, cantaloupe involved in\nthe listeriosis outbreak was traced specifically to cantaloupe from\nJensen Farm, which labeled its cantaloupe with the Rocky Ford name.\nThe FDA identified the recalled whole cantaloupes from Jensen Farm as\nhaving a green and white sticker that reads: \"Product of USA-Frontera\nProduce-Colorado Fresh-Rocky Ford-Cantaloupe,\" or a gray, yellow, and\ngreen sticker that reads \"Jensen Farms-Sweet Rocky Fords\"\n(http://www.fda.gov/Safety/Recalls/ucm271879.htm). USA (02): (TX), recall 20101021.3813\nListeriosis, fatal - USA: (TX) 20100515.1592\nListeriosis, fatal, meat product - Canada: (ON) 20100314.0829\n.................................................sb/ml/ejp/lm", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "listeriosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-14 00:00:00", "2021-03-17 00:00:00", "1985-03-16 00:00:00", "2011-09-14 00:00:00", "2021-03-11 00:00:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Granada", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "U.S.", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Colorado", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "United States", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1107753", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis - UK (03): (N. Ireland) nosocomial, fatal, background", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1107753", "date": "2011-11-05 16:33:00", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS, FATAL - USA (14): CANTALOUPE, MORE CASES AND DEATHS\n****************************************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 2 Nov 2011\nSource: Reuters [edited]\nhttp://www.reuters.com/article/2011/11/03/us-listeria-cantaloupes-idUSTRE7A20BU20111103\n\n\n\nThe death toll linked to _Listeria_-contaminated cantaloupe in the\nUnited States rose to 29 as another death was reported, the Centers\nfor Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) said on Wednesday [2 Nov\n2011].\n\nWhole or pre-cut Rocky Ford-brand cantaloupe from Colorado-based\nJensen Farms has been traced as the cause of what has become one of\nthe deadliest U.S. food-borne outbreaks in U.S. history. A total of\n139 people in 28 states have fallen ill so far in the outbreak, and\nthe CDC has said that one woman, who was pregnant at the time she fell\nill, had a miscarriage.\n\nThe deadliest known food-borne listeriosis outbreak prior to the\ncurrent spate of illnesses in the United States was in 1985, when\nMexican-style soft cheese contaminated with _Listeria_ was tied to the\ndeaths of 18 adults, and 10 newborns, as well as 20 miscarriages,\naccording to a CDC report.\n\nListeriosis has a long incubation period, with symptoms sometimes not\nshowing up until 2 months after people consume tainted foods.\n\nThe elderly, pregnant women, and people with weakened immune systems\nare most at risk of falling ill from _Listeria_ infection. Symptoms\ninclude fever and muscle aches, sometimes preceded by diarrhea and\nother gastric problems.\n\nIn a warning letter to Jensen Farms last month, the U.S. Food and Drug\nAdministration said testing turned up widespread _Listeria_\ncontamination at its Granada, Colorado, packing plant, which\n\"indicates poor sanitary practices in the facility.\"\n\nListeria outbreaks are most commonly linked to contaminated cheese or\npackaged meats. The current outbreak is the 1st to be associated with\ncantaloupe.\n\n\"What this shows is that these bugs are very opportunistic,\" food\nsafety attorney and advocate Bill Marler said. \"As long as you have a\ncool, wet environment and a product that is ready-to-eat, you're\nalways going to have a risk of _Listeria_ contamination, which is why\nthe sanitation of the plant is so critical,\" said Marler, who is\nrepresenting several families affected by the outbreak.\n\n[Byline: Lisa Baertlein, Cynthia Johnston]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The total number of people who have been sickened after eating whole\nor pre-cut _Listeria moncytogenes_- contaminated cantaloupe from\nColorado-based Jensen Farms has risen from 133 to 139, the number of\nstates where cases have occurred has risen from 26 to 28, and the\nnumber of deaths has risen from 28 to 29 since the last ProMED-mail\npost, Listeriosis, fatal - USA (13): cantaloupe, more cases & deaths\n20111026.3188. A discussion of listeriosis can be found in prior\nProMED-mail posts on this outbreak.\n\nThe long incubation period for listeriosis, with symptoms sometimes\nnot showing up until 2 months after people consumed the tainted food,\nexplains the continuing occurrence of new cases. On 14 Sep 2011, FDA\nissued a press release to announce that Jensen Farms issued a\nvoluntary recall of their brand of Rocky Ford Cantaloupes because of\n_Listeria_ contamination.\n\nInitially cantaloupe from the Rocky Ford region of southeastern\nColorado was the suspected vehicle (ProMED-mail post Listeriosis,\nfatal - USA (03) 20110914.2800). Subsequently, cantaloupe involved in\nthe listeriosis outbreak was traced specifically to cantaloupe from\nJensen Farm, which labeled its cantaloupe with the Rocky Ford name.\nThe FDA identified the recalled whole cantaloupes from Jensen Farm as\nhaving a green and white sticker that reads: \"Product of USA-Frontera\nProduce-Colorado Fresh-Rocky Ford-Cantaloupe,\" or a gray, yellow, and\ngreen sticker that reads \"Jensen Farms-Sweet Rocky Fords\"\n(http://www.fda.gov/Safety/Recalls/ucm271879.htm). Photos of the\nlabeling can be seen at\nhttp://www.fda.gov/Safety/Recalls/ucm271882.htm. Cantaloupe from\nother farms in this region of southeastern Colorado have not been\nimplicated in this outbreak. - Mod.ML]\nSee Also\nListeriosis, fatal - USA (13): cantaloupe, more cases & deaths\n20111026.3188\nListeriosis, fatal - USA (12): cantaloupe 20111022.3144\nListeriosis, fatal - USA (11): cantaloupe, farm factors 20111020.3130\nListeriosis, fatal - USA (10): cantaloupe, more cases & deaths\n20111008.3022\nListeriosis, fatal - USA (09): cantaloupe, more cases & deaths\n20111005.2993\nListeriosis - USA: romaine lettuce, recall 20111001.2959\nListeriosis, fatal - USA (08): background 20111001.2958\nListeriosis, fatal - USA (07): cantaloupe, more cases & deaths\n20110930.2950\nListeriosis, fatal -
