UK (02): (N. Ireland) nosocomial, fatal, comment", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1105643", "date": "2011-11-05 16:33:00", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS, FATAL - USA (14): CANTALOUPE, MORE CASES AND DEATHS\n****************************************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 2 Nov 2011\nSource: Reuters [edited]\nhttp://www.reuters.com/article/2011/11/03/us-listeria-cantaloupes-idUSTRE7A20BU20111103\n\n\n\nThe death toll linked to _Listeria_-contaminated cantaloupe in the\nUnited States rose to 29 as another death was reported, the Centers\nfor Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) said on Wednesday [2 Nov\n2011].\n\nWhole or pre-cut Rocky Ford-brand cantaloupe from Colorado-based\nJensen Farms has been traced as the cause of what has become one of\nthe deadliest U.S. food-borne outbreaks in U.S. history. A total of\n139 people in 28 states have fallen ill so far in the outbreak, and\nthe CDC has said that one woman, who was pregnant at the time she fell\nill, had a miscarriage.\n\nThe deadliest known food-borne listeriosis outbreak prior to the\ncurrent spate of illnesses in the United States was in 1985, when\nMexican-style soft cheese contaminated with _Listeria_ was tied to the\ndeaths of 18 adults, and 10 newborns, as well as 20 miscarriages,\naccording to a CDC report.\n\nListeriosis has a long incubation period, with symptoms sometimes not\nshowing up until 2 months after people consume tainted foods.\n\nThe elderly, pregnant women, and people with weakened immune systems\nare most at risk of falling ill from _Listeria_ infection. Symptoms\ninclude fever and muscle aches, sometimes preceded by diarrhea and\nother gastric problems.\n\nIn a warning letter to Jensen Farms last month, the U.S. Food and Drug\nAdministration said testing turned up widespread _Listeria_\ncontamination at its Granada, Colorado, packing plant, which\n\"indicates poor sanitary practices in the facility.\"\n\nListeria outbreaks are most commonly linked to contaminated cheese or\npackaged meats. The current outbreak is the 1st to be associated with\ncantaloupe.\n\n\"What this shows is that these bugs are very opportunistic,\" food\nsafety attorney and advocate Bill Marler said. \"As long as you have a\ncool, wet environment and a product that is ready-to-eat, you're\nalways going to have a risk of _Listeria_ contamination, which is why\nthe sanitation of the plant is so critical,\" said Marler, who is\nrepresenting several families affected by the outbreak.\n\n[Byline: Lisa Baertlein, Cynthia Johnston]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The total number of people who have been sickened after eating whole\nor pre-cut _Listeria moncytogenes_- contaminated cantaloupe from\nColorado-based Jensen Farms has risen from 133 to 139, the number of\nstates where cases have occurred has risen from 26 to 28, and the\nnumber of deaths has risen from 28 to 29 since the last ProMED-mail\npost, Listeriosis, fatal - USA (13): cantaloupe, more cases & deaths\n20111026.3188. A discussion of listeriosis can be found in prior\nProMED-mail posts on this outbreak.\n\nThe long incubation period for listeriosis, with symptoms sometimes\nnot showing up until 2 months after people consumed the tainted food,\nexplains the continuing occurrence of new cases. On 14 Sep 2011, FDA\nissued a press release to announce that Jensen Farms issued a\nvoluntary recall of their brand of Rocky Ford Cantaloupes because of\n_Listeria_ contamination.\n\nInitially cantaloupe from the Rocky Ford region of southeastern\nColorado was the suspected vehicle (ProMED-mail post Listeriosis,\nfatal - USA (03) 20110914.2800). Subsequently, cantaloupe involved in\nthe listeriosis outbreak was traced specifically to cantaloupe from\nJensen Farm, which labeled its cantaloupe with the Rocky Ford name.\nThe FDA identified the recalled whole cantaloupes from Jensen Farm as\nhaving a green and white sticker that reads: \"Product of USA-Frontera\nProduce-Colorado Fresh-Rocky Ford-Cantaloupe,\" or a gray, yellow, and\ngreen sticker that reads \"Jensen Farms-Sweet Rocky Fords\"\n(http://www.fda.gov/Safety/Recalls/ucm271879.htm). Photos of the\nlabeling can be seen at\nhttp://www.fda.gov/Safety/Recalls/ucm271882.htm. Cantaloupe from\nother farms in this region of southeastern Colorado have not been\nimplicated in this outbreak. - Mod.ML]\nSee Also\nListeriosis, fatal - USA (13): cantaloupe, more cases & deaths\n20111026.3188\nListeriosis, fatal - USA (06): cantaloupe, more cases & deaths\n20110923.2876\nListeriosis, fatal - USA (05): cantaloupe, more cases & deaths\n20110922.2871\nListeriosis, fatal - USA (04): cantaloupe, alert 20110921.2866\nListeriosis, fatal - USA (03): cantaloupe susp. 20110914.2800\nListeriosis, fatal - USA (02): (CO) 20110909.2746\nListeriosis, fatal - USA: (CO) 20110605.1719\n2010\n----\nListeriosis, fatal - USA (03): (TX), recall 20101105.4005\nListeriosis, fatal - USA (02): (TX), recall 20101021.3813\nListeriosis, fatal - USA: (TX) 20100515.1592\nListeriosis, fatal, meat product - Canada: (ON) 20100314.0829\n.................................................sb/ml/ejp/lm", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "listeriosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-14 00:00:00", "2021-03-17 00:00:00", "1985-03-16 00:00:00", "2011-09-14 00:00:00", "2021-03-11 00:00:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Granada", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "U.S.", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Colorado", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "United States", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "992860", "headline": "PRO/ALL> Listeriosis; early reporting on ProMED", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=992860", "date": "2011-11-05 16:33:00", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS, FATAL - USA (14): CANTALOUPE, MORE CASES AND DEATHS\n****************************************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 2 Nov 2011\nSource: Reuters [edited]\nhttp://www.reuters.com/article/2011/11/03/us-listeria-cantaloupes-idUSTRE7A20BU20111103\n\n\n\nThe death toll linked to _Listeria_-contaminated cantaloupe in the\nUnited States rose to 29 as another death was reported, the Centers\nfor Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) said on Wednesday [2 Nov\n2011].\n\nWhole or pre-cut Rocky Ford-brand cantaloupe from Colorado-based\nJensen Farms has been traced as the cause of what has become one of\nthe deadliest U.S. food-borne outbreaks in U.S. history. A total of\n139 people in 28 states have fallen ill so far in the outbreak, and\nthe CDC has said that one woman, who was pregnant at the time she fell\nill, had a miscarriage.\n\nThe deadliest known food-borne listeriosis outbreak prior to the\ncurrent spate of illnesses in the United States was in 1985, when\nMexican-style soft cheese contaminated with _Listeria_ was tied to the\ndeaths of 18 adults, and 10 newborns, as well as 20 miscarriages,\naccording to a CDC report.\n\nListeriosis has a long incubation period, with symptoms sometimes not\nshowing up until 2 months after people consume tainted foods.\n\nThe elderly, pregnant women, and people with weakened immune systems\nare most at risk of falling ill from _Listeria_ infection. Symptoms\ninclude fever and muscle aches, sometimes preceded by diarrhea and\nother gastric problems.\n\nIn a warning letter to Jensen Farms last month, the U.S. Food and Drug\nAdministration said testing turned up widespread _Listeria_\ncontamination at its Granada, Colorado, packing plant, which\n\"indicates poor sanitary practices in the facility.\"\n\nListeria outbreaks are most commonly linked to contaminated cheese or\npackaged meats. The current outbreak is the 1st to be associated with\ncantaloupe.\n\n\"What this shows is that these bugs are very opportunistic,\" food\nsafety attorney and advocate Bill Marler said. \"As long as you have a\ncool, wet environment and a product that is ready-to-eat, you're\nalways going to have a risk of _Listeria_ contamination, which is why\nthe sanitation of the plant is so critical,\" said Marler, who is\nrepresenting several families affected by the outbreak.\n\n[Byline: Lisa Baertlein, Cynthia Johnston]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The total number of people who have been sickened after eating whole\nor pre-cut _Listeria moncytogenes_- contaminated cantaloupe from\nColorado-based Jensen Farms has risen from 133 to 139, the number of\nstates where cases have occurred has risen from 26 to 28, and the\nnumber of deaths has risen from 28 to 29 since the last ProMED-mail\npost, Listeriosis, fatal - USA (13): cantaloupe, more cases & deaths\n20111026.3188. A discussion of listeriosis can be found in prior\nProMED-mail posts on this outbreak.\n\nThe long incubation period for listeriosis, with symptoms sometimes\nnot showing up until 2 months after people consumed the tainted food,\nexplains the continuing occurrence of new cases. On 14 Sep 2011, FDA\nissued a press release to announce that Jensen Farms issued a\nvoluntary recall of their brand of Rocky Ford Cantaloupes because of\n_Listeria_ contamination.\n\nInitially cantaloupe from the Rocky Ford region of southeastern\nColorado was the suspected vehicle (ProMED-mail post Listeriosis,\nfatal - USA (03) 20110914.2800). Subsequently, cantaloupe involved in\nthe listeriosis outbreak was traced specifically to cantaloupe from\nJensen Farm, which labeled its cantaloupe with the Rocky Ford name.\nThe FDA identified the recalled whole cantaloupes from Jensen Farm as\nhaving a green and white sticker that reads: \"Product of USA-Frontera\nProduce-Colorado Fresh-Rocky Ford-Cantaloupe,\" or a gray, yellow, and\ngreen sticker that reads \"Jensen Farms-Sweet Rocky Fords\"\n(http://www.fda.gov/Safety/Recalls/ucm271879.htm). Photos of the\nlabeling can be seen at\nhttp://www.fda.gov/Safety/Recalls/ucm271882.htm. Cantaloupe from\nother farms in this region of southeastern Colorado have not been\nimplicated in this outbreak. - Mod.ML]\nSee Also\nListeriosis, fatal - USA (13): cantaloupe, more cases & deaths\n20111026.3188\nListeriosis, fatal - USA (12): cantaloupe 20111022.3144\nListeriosis, fatal - USA (11): cantaloupe, farm factors 20111020.3130\nListeriosis, fatal - USA (10): cantaloupe, more cases & deaths\n20111008.3022\nListeriosis, fatal - USA (09): cantaloupe, more cases & deaths\n20111005.2993\nListeriosis - USA: romaine lettuce, recall 20111001.2959\nListeriosis, fatal - USA (08): background 20111001.2958\nListeriosis, fatal - USA (07): cantaloupe, more cases & deaths\n20110930.2950\nListeriosis, fatal - USA (03): cantaloupe susp. 20110914.2800\nListeriosis, fatal - USA (02): (CO) 20110909.2746\nListeriosis, fatal - USA: (CO) 20110605.1719\n2010\n----\nListeriosis, fatal - USA (03): (TX), recall 20101105.4005\nListeriosis, fatal - USA (02): (TX), recall 20101021.3813\nListeriosis, fatal - USA: (TX) 20100515.1592\nListeriosis, fatal, meat product - Canada: (ON) 20100314.0829\n.................................................sb/ml/ejp/lm", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "listeriosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-14 00:00:00", "2021-03-17 00:00:00", "1985-03-16 00:00:00", "2011-09-14 00:00:00", "2021-03-11 00:00:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Granada", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "U.S.", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Colorado", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "United States", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "938581", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis, fatal - USA (02): (TX), recall 20101021.3813\nListeriosis, fatal - USA: (TX) 20100515.1592\nListeriosis, fatal, meat product - Canada: (ON) 20100314.0829\n.................................................sb/ml/ejp/lm", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "listeriosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-14 00:00:00", "2021-03-17 00:00:00", "1985-03-16 00:00:00", "2011-09-14 00:00:00", "2021-03-11 00:00:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Granada", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "U.S.", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Colorado", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "United States", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "924461", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis, fatal - USA (13): cantaloupe, more cases & deaths", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=924461", "date": "2011-09-30 11:35:10", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS, FATAL - USA (07): CANTALOUPE, MORE CASES AND DEATHS\n****************************************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\nDate: Tue 27 Sep 2011\nSource: New York Times [edited]\nhttp://www.nytimes.com/2011/09/28/business/deaths-from-cantaloupe-listeria-rises.html\n\n\nAt least 13 people in 8 states have died after eating cantaloupe\ncontaminated with _Listeria_ [_monocytogenes_], in the deadliest\noutbreak of foodborne illness in the United States in more than a\ndecade, public health officials said on Tuesday [27 Sep 2011]. Many of\nthe deaths involved elderly people, who are especially susceptible to\nthe aggressive pathogen.\n\nThe cantaloupes were grown by a Colorado company, Jensen Farms, which\nissued a recall earlier this month [September 2011]. The melons, a\ntype marketed as Rocky Ford cantaloupes, named after a region in\nColorado, were sold around the country.\n\nThe federal Centers for Disease Control and Prevention reported that\nsince the outbreak began in late July [2011] at least 72 people had\nfallen ill in 18 states. The agency said that 4 people had died in New\nMexico, 2 in Colorado, 2 in Texas, and one each in Kansas, Maryland,\nMissouri, Nebraska, and Oklahoma. The toll could grow as state health\nofficials wait for test results on other deaths suspected of being\npart of the outbreak.\n\nOfficials said that most of those who died were over age 60. At least\n2 were in their 90s. _Listeria_ is a common but dangerous bacterium\nthat can cause severe illness, especially among the elderly, the very\nyoung, and people with compromised immune systems. The pathogen can\nalso cause pregnant women to have miscarriages. Federal officials have\nso far provided no information about the number of miscarriages or\nstillbirths associated with the outbreak. Pregnant women are 20 times\nas likely as other healthy adults to come down with a severe\ninfection, according to the CDC.\n\nJohn N Sofos, a professor of food safety at Colorado State University,\nsaid that many people who were infected might have only mild symptoms,\nlike diarrhea. But in others, especially those in the most vulnerable\ncategories, the bacteria can aggressively move out of the\ngastrointestinal tract and attack muscle tissue or the spinal cord,\nleading to much more severe illnesses like meningitis. For that\nreason, the death rate in listeriosis outbreaks is often much higher\nthan with other forms of foodborne bacteria.\n\nWilliam Marler, a Seattle lawyer who represents victims of foodborne\nillness, said this outbreak might turn out to be especially deadly\nsimply because cantaloupe is a food eaten by many older people.\nSometimes in outbreaks, it's the population that's consuming the food\nthat drives the numbers, Mr Marler said. In this instance, you've got\na lot of people 60 and older who are consuming cantaloupe.\n\nThe outbreak appeared to be the 3rd worst in the United States\nattributed to any form of foodborne illness, in terms of the number of\ndeaths, since the CDC began regularly tracking such outbreaks in the\nearly 1970s. The deadliest outbreak in the United States since then\noccurred in 1985, when a wave of listeriosis, linked to Mexican-style\nfresh cheese, swept through California. A federal database says 52\ndeaths were attributed to the outbreak, but news reports at the time\nput the number as high as 84.\n\nThe 2nd deadliest outbreak was in 1998 and 1999, when there were at\nleast 14 deaths and 4 miscarriages or stillbirths in a listeriosis\noutbreak linked to hot dogs and delicatessen meats. Some sources put\nthe death toll in that outbreak as high as 21.\n\nWith the updated death toll on Tuesday [27 Sep 2011], the Rocky Ford\ncantaloupe outbreak surpassed the 2008 deaths associated with\nsalmonella-tainted peanuts and peanut butter produced by a Georgia\ncompany, the Peanut Corporation of America. That outbreak, which drew\na large amount of news coverage, killed 9 people and sickened more\nthan 700.\n\nThe huge outbreak this year [2011] in Europe of a rare form of _E.\ncoli_ bacteria attributed to fenugreek sprouts killed at least 50\npeople.\n\n_Listeria_ is a common bacterium that can be found in soil, water,\ndecaying plant matter, and manure. A strain of the organism, called\n_Listeria monocytogenes_, was first found to cause illness linked to\nfood in the early 1980s. Since then, only a handful of listeriosis\noutbreaks have been associated with fresh fruits and vegetables. The\nmajority was caused by tainted meat or dairy products.\n\nIt can take more than 2 months for a person exposed to the bacteria to\nfall ill, which means that it is often difficult to identify a food\nthat carried the pathogen. Unlike some other bacteria, _Listeria_ also\ngrows well at low temperatures, meaning it can be difficult to\neliminate from refrigerated areas used to process or store foods.\n\nThe Food and Drug Administration said it had found the strain of the\nbacterium on melons and on equipment in the Colorado farm's\npackinghouse. It also found the bacteria on melons in a Denver-area\nstore. Investigators have not said how they believe the contamination\noccurred.\n\nThe FDA recommends that consumers rinse all raw produce, including\ncantaloupes, under running water. Firm produce, like melons, should be\nscrubbed with a produce brush. The washed produce should be dried with\na clean cloth or unused paper towel, the agency said.\n\n[Byline: William Neuman]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: Wed 28 Sep 2011\nSource: KKTV [edited]\nhttp://www.kktv.com/home/headlines/D70_Takes_Cantaloupe_Off_Menu_Due_To_Listeria_Scare_129834148.html\n\n\nDr Thomas Frieden, director of the Centers for Disease Control and\nPrevention, said Wednesday [28 Sep 2011] during a conference call with\nmedia that 2 pregnant women were among the 72 confirmed cases of\n_Listeria_ infection linked to cantaloupes grown in Colorado. He also\nconfirmed that this was the deadliest outbreak in more than a decade.\n\nBoth of the pregnant women and their fetuses are expected to be fine,\nbut 13 people have died from the infection. 3 more deaths are also\nsuspected to be connected, but are not yet confirmed by laboratory\ntests.\n\nThe CDC says _Listeria_ infection during pregnancy could lead to\npremature delivery, miscarriage, stillbirth, and other serious health\nproblems.\n\nThe CDC also said that the number of cases and deaths are likely to\nincrease, because symptoms of _Listeria_ infections can develop up to\n2 months after consumption of the contaminated food.\n\nThe _Listeria_ infections were reported in 18 states.\n\nIn this case, laboratory tests have connected the strains of\n_Listeria_ to melons of the \"Rocky Ford\" variety grown by Jensen Farms\nin Holly, Colorado. That particular variety is prized for having a\nhigher sugar contact, and was developed in the Rocky Ford region of\nColorado during the late 1800's.\n\nThe state of Colorado says it has tested melon samples from the\nrefrigerator of a listeriosis patient's home, as well as samples\nobtained from various retail outlets. They were also traced to Jensen\nFarms.\n\nJensen Farms has voluntarily recalled the melons in question, which it\nsays were shipped between 29 Jul and 10 Sep 2011. They were sent to\nIllinois, Wyoming, Tennessee, Utah, Texas, Colorado, Minnesota,\nKansas, New Mexico, North Carolina, Missouri, Nebraska, Oklahoma,\nArizona, New Jersey, New York, and Pennsylvania.\n\nThey carry stickers that say either, \"Product of USA - Frontera\nProduce - Colorado Fresh - Rocky Ford\" or \"Jensen Farms - Sweet Rocky\nFords.\"\n\nAnyone who has, or may have had cantaloupes from Jensen Farms is\nadvised to throw them away. Do not try to clean the melons.\n\nAdditionally, the CDC warned that _Listeria_ can continue to grow --\neven inside a refrigerator. Caution is advised for everyone who may\nhave had one of the recalled melons, but specifically for people who\nare at high risk.\n\nThe FDA, also represented during Wednesday's [28 Sep 2011] conference\ncall, said this is the 1st known outbreak of listeriosis related to\ncantaloupe. The 10 cantaloupe-related outbreaks in the past decade\nwere connected to salmonella or a virus.\n\nThe worst outbreak of listeriosis on record was in 1985 and traced\nback to Mexican-style cheese.\n\nThe FDA says it has a team working with a team from Colorado to do an\nenvironmental assessment at Jensen Farm's facilities. As part of that\nwork, they're looking at potential contamination from animals, water,\nand the processing facility. So far, they've not reached any\nconclusions.\n\nA couple from Colorado Springs is suing the farm and Walmart because\nof the tainted fruit. According to the lawsuit, obtained by 11 News,\nthey are alleging that a cantaloupe distributed by Jensen Farms and\nsold at a Walmart on Razorback Road in the Springs caused [the man] to\nfall ill with listeriosis. [He] has been hospitalized since 31 Aug\n2011.\n\nIn the lawsuit, the couple claims that the cantaloupe was contaminated\nwith _Listeria_ at the time it was sold, and is directly responsible\nfor [his] illness. They say Jensen Farms and Walmart are both liable\nfor having sold \"food which was defective and not reasonably safe.\"\n\nIf you have questions about listeriosis, call the Colorado Department\nof Public Health and Environment at 1-877-462-2911.\n\nAnyone with questions about the recall can contact Jensen Farms at\n1-800-267-4561 or recall@rfordcantaloupe.com.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[3]\nDate: Wed 28 Sep 2011\nSource: Los Angeles Times [edited]\nhttp://latimesblogs.latimes.com/nationnow/2011/09/listeria-outbreak-linked-to-cantaloupes-could-worsen.html\n\n\nIf in doubt, throw it out. Unless you can be sure of the source of\nthat cantaloupe in your kitchen, it's best to toss it. That's the word\nfrom the US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, which is\ntrying to put a lid on one of the worst listeriosis outbreaks in US\nhistory.\n\nSo far, there are 72 reported cases of listeriosis linked to tainted\ncantaloupes, and 13 deaths. State and local officials say they are\ninvestigating 3 additional deaths that may be connected and the toll\ncould rise, according to the Associated Press.\n\nThe tainted melons that triggered the multi-state listeriosis outbreak\nhave been traced to Jensen Farms in Granada, Colorado.\n\n\"If it's not Jensen farms, it's okay to eat,\" Dr Thomas Frieden, CDC\ndirector, said in a media conference call today [28 Sep 2011]. \"But if\nyou can't confirm that it's not Jensen farms, then it's best to throw\nit out.\"\n\nSome of the cantaloupes were exported out of the country, and the CDC\nhas been issuing recalls both inside and outside the US for all the\naffected melons.\n\nThis outbreak is the largest in a decade and could grow worse, said\nthe CDC's foodborne illness specialist, Dr Barbara Mahon, who also\nparticipated in the media alert. \"To date there's 72 cases and 13\ndeaths... We do expect that the number of cases will increase.\"\n\nThe single largest listeriosis outbreak occurred in 1985, and was\ntraced to soft Mexican-style cheese manufactured by Jalisco Mexican\nProducts Inc. of Artesia. It killed at least 40 people, and also ranks\nas one of the biggest food-contamination cases in California history.\n\nCantaloupes can rot within 2 weeks or so, and go bad even faster once\nthey've been sliced open. The cantaloupes at the center of this\noutbreak -- first flagged on 12 Sep 2011 -- are nearing the outer edge\nof their shelf life, making it less likely they will be eaten with\neach passing day.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Cantaloupes are said to have a shelf life of 2 weeks or so. Since\nJensen Farms, the source of the contaminated melons, voluntarily\nrecalled these melons, which it says were shipped between 29 Jul and\n10 Sep 2011, there should not be many more of these melons being\neaten. However, because the incubation period of listeriosis can be up\nto a month or more, there may be more cases, deaths, miscarriages, or\nstillbirths reported in the future due to consumption of these\n_Listeria_-contaminated melons. - Mod.ML]\nSee Also\nListeriosis, fatal - USA (06): cantaloupe, more cases & deaths\n20110923.2876\nListeriosis, fatal - USA (05): cantaloupe, more cases & deaths\n20110922.2871\nListeriosis, fatal - USA (04): cantaloupe, alert 20110921.2866\nListeriosis, fatal - USA (03): cantaloupe susp. 20110914.2800\nListeriosis, fatal - USA (02): (CO) 20110909.2746\nListeriosis, fatal - USA: (CO) 20110605.1719\n2010\n----\nListeriosis, fatal - USA (03): (TX), recall 20101105.4005\nListeriosis, fatal - USA (02): (TX), recall 20101021.3813\nListeriosis, fatal - USA: (TX) 20100515.1592\nListeriosis, fatal, meat product - Canada: (ON) 20100314.0829\n2009\n----\nListeriosis - Australia (02): airline food, chicken wrap susp\n20090820.2947\nListeriosis - Australia: airline food, chicken wrap susp\n20090807.2793\nListeriosis, fatal - Chile: (Santiago) meat susp, RFI 20090411.1391\nListeriosis, Mexican-style cheeses - USA: risk, recall 20090401.1261\nListeriosis, fatal, meat product - Canada: unconf. 20090307.0957\n2008\n----\nListeriosis, fatal - Chile: (Santiago) cheese susp. RFI 20081128.3754\nListeriosis, fatal, meat product - Canada (04) 20081005.3147\nListeriosis, fatal, meat product - Canada: alert, recall\n20080821.2605\nListeriosis - USA: (MA), update 20080118.0223\n2007\n----\nListeriosis - USA: (NC, MA), alert 20071230.4186\nListeriosis, nosocomial - Norway: (Oslo) 20071024.3452\nListeriosis, unpasteurized cheese - USA (IN) 20070425.1351\nListeriosis, sandwiches - UK (England): alert, recall 20070326.1049\n2006\n----\nListeriosis, seafood - USA 20060130.0295\n2005\n----\nListeriosis - USA (TX) 20050824.2491\nListeriosis - USA (NY) (05) 20050819.2431\nListeriosis - USA (NY) 20050707.1925\n2004\n----\nListeriosis, cluster - USA (VA) (02): background 20040723.2013\n.................................................sb/ml/mj/lm", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "listeriosis", "meningitis"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2011-09-27 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2011-09-27 00:00:00", "2011-09-16 00:00:00", "1985-03-16 00:00:00", "1998-03-16 00:00:00", "1999-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2011-09-27 00:00:00", "2008-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-17 00:00:00", "2011-09-28 00:00:00", "2011-09-10 00:00:00", "2021-03-17 00:00:00", "1985-03-16 00:00:00", "2011-03-16 00:00:00", "1985-03-16 00:00:00", "2011-09-12 00:00:00", "2011-09-10 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Minnesota", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "NC", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Pennsylvania", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Mexico", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Wyoming", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "California", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New York", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Illinois", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Jersey", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Texas", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Artesia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Denver", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Colorado Springs", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Holly", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Utah", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Colorado", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Maryland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Nebraska", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Seattle", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "England", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Granada", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Arizona", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Missouri", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kansas", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Oklahoma", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "North Carolina", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tennessee", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "918653", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis, fatal - USA (12): cantaloupe", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=918653", "date": "2011-09-30 11:35:10", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS, FATAL - USA (07): CANTALOUPE, MORE CASES AND DEATHS\n****************************************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\nDate: Tue 27 Sep 2011\nSource: New York Times [edited]\nhttp://www.nytimes.com/2011/09/28/business/deaths-from-cantaloupe-listeria-rises.html\n\n\nAt least 13 people in 8 states have died after eating cantaloupe\ncontaminated with _Listeria_ [_monocytogenes_], in the deadliest\noutbreak of foodborne illness in the United States in more than a\ndecade, public health officials said on Tuesday [27 Sep 2011]. Many of\nthe deaths involved elderly people, who are especially susceptible to\nthe aggressive pathogen.\n\nThe cantaloupes were grown by a Colorado company, Jensen Farms, which\nissued a recall earlier this month [September 2011]. The melons, a\ntype marketed as Rocky Ford cantaloupes, named after a region in\nColorado, were sold around the country.\n\nThe federal Centers for Disease Control and Prevention reported that\nsince the outbreak began in late July [2011] at least 72 people had\nfallen ill in 18 states. The agency said that 4 people had died in New\nMexico, 2 in Colorado, 2 in Texas, and one each in Kansas, Maryland,\nMissouri, Nebraska, and Oklahoma. The toll could grow as state health\nofficials wait for test results on other deaths suspected of being\npart of the outbreak.\n\nOfficials said that most of those who died were over age 60. At least\n2 were in their 90s. _Listeria_ is a common but dangerous bacterium\nthat can cause severe illness, especially among the elderly, the very\nyoung, and people with compromised immune systems. The pathogen can\nalso cause pregnant women to have miscarriages. Federal officials have\nso far provided no information about the number of miscarriages or\nstillbirths associated with the outbreak. Pregnant women are 20 times\nas likely as other healthy adults to come down with a severe\ninfection, according to the CDC.\n\nJohn N Sofos, a professor of food safety at Colorado State University,\nsaid that many people who were infected might have only mild symptoms,\nlike diarrhea. But in others, especially those in the most vulnerable\ncategories, the bacteria can aggressively move out of the\ngastrointestinal tract and attack muscle tissue or the spinal cord,\nleading to much more severe illnesses like meningitis. For that\nreason, the death rate in listeriosis outbreaks is often much higher\nthan with other forms of foodborne bacteria.\n\nWilliam Marler, a Seattle lawyer who represents victims of foodborne\nillness, said this outbreak might turn out to be especially deadly\nsimply because cantaloupe is a food eaten by many older people.\nSometimes in outbreaks, it's the population that's consuming the food\nthat drives the numbers, Mr Marler said. In this instance, you've got\na lot of people 60 and older who are consuming cantaloupe.\n\nThe outbreak appeared to be the 3rd worst in the United States\nattributed to any form of foodborne illness, in terms of the number of\ndeaths, since the CDC began regularly tracking such outbreaks in the\nearly 1970s. The deadliest outbreak in the United States since then\noccurred in 1985, when a wave of listeriosis, linked to Mexican-style\nfresh cheese, swept through California. A federal database says 52\ndeaths were attributed to the outbreak, but news reports at the time\nput the number as high as 84.\n\nThe 2nd deadliest outbreak was in 1998 and 1999, when there were at\nleast 14 deaths and 4 miscarriages or stillbirths in a listeriosis\noutbreak linked to hot dogs and delicatessen meats. Some sources put\nthe death toll in that outbreak as high as 21.\n\nWith the updated death toll on Tuesday [27 Sep 2011], the Rocky Ford\ncantaloupe outbreak surpassed the 2008 deaths associated with\nsalmonella-tainted peanuts and peanut butter produced by a Georgia\ncompany, the Peanut Corporation of America. That outbreak, which drew\na large amount of news coverage, killed 9 people and sickened more\nthan 700.\n\nThe huge outbreak this year [2011] in Europe of a rare form of _E.\ncoli_ bacteria attributed to fenugreek sprouts killed at least 50\npeople.\n\n_Listeria_ is a common bacterium that can be found in soil, water,\ndecaying plant matter, and manure. A strain of the organism, called\n_Listeria monocytogenes_, was first found to cause illness linked to\nfood in the early 1980s. Since then, only a handful of listeriosis\noutbreaks have been associated with fresh fruits and vegetables. The\nmajority was caused by tainted meat or dairy products.\n\nIt can take more than 2 months for a person exposed to the bacteria to\nfall ill, which means that it is often difficult to identify a food\nthat carried the pathogen. Unlike some other bacteria, _Listeria_ also\ngrows well at low temperatures, meaning it can be difficult to\neliminate from refrigerated areas used to process or store foods.\n\nThe Food and Drug Administration said it had found the strain of the\nbacterium on melons and on equipment in the Colorado farm's\npackinghouse. It also found the bacteria on melons in a Denver-area\nstore. Investigators have not said how they believe the contamination\noccurred.\n\nThe FDA recommends that consumers rinse all raw produce, including\ncantaloupes, under running water. Firm produce, like melons, should be\nscrubbed with a produce brush. The washed produce should be dried with\na clean cloth or unused paper towel, the agency said.\n\n[Byline: William Neuman]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: Wed 28 Sep 2011\nSource: KKTV [edited]\nhttp://www.kktv.com/home/headlines/D70_Takes_Cantaloupe_Off_Menu_Due_To_Listeria_Scare_129834148.html\n\n\nDr Thomas Frieden, director of the Centers for Disease Control and\nPrevention, said Wednesday [28 Sep 2011] during a conference call with\nmedia that 2 pregnant women were among the 72 confirmed cases of\n_Listeria_ infection linked to cantaloupes grown in Colorado. He also\nconfirmed that this was the deadliest outbreak in more than a decade.\n\nBoth of the pregnant women and their fetuses are expected to be fine,\nbut 13 people have died from the infection. 3 more deaths are also\nsuspected to be connected, but are not yet confirmed by laboratory\ntests.\n\nThe CDC says _Listeria_ infection during pregnancy could lead to\npremature delivery, miscarriage, stillbirth, and other serious health\nproblems.\n\nThe CDC also said that the number of cases and deaths are likely to\nincrease, because symptoms of _Listeria_ infections can develop up to\n2 months after consumption of the contaminated food.\n\nThe _Listeria_ infections were reported in 18 states.\n\nIn this case, laboratory tests have connected the strains of\n_Listeria_ to melons of the \"Rocky Ford\" variety grown by Jensen Farms\nin Holly, Colorado. That particular variety is prized for having a\nhigher sugar contact, and was developed in the Rocky Ford region of\nColorado during the late 1800's.\n\nThe state of Colorado says it has tested melon samples from the\nrefrigerator of a listeriosis patient's home, as well as samples\nobtained from various retail outlets. They were also traced to Jensen\nFarms.\n\nJensen Farms has voluntarily recalled the melons in question, which it\nsays were shipped between 29 Jul and 10 Sep 2011. They were sent to\nIllinois, Wyoming, Tennessee, Utah, Texas, Colorado, Minnesota,\nKansas, New Mexico, North Carolina, Missouri, Nebraska, Oklahoma,\nArizona, New Jersey, New York, and Pennsylvania.\n\nThey carry stickers that say either, \"Product of USA - Frontera\nProduce - Colorado Fresh - Rocky Ford\" or \"Jensen Farms - Sweet Rocky\nFords.\"\n\nAnyone who has, or may have had cantaloupes from Jensen Farms is\nadvised to throw them away. Do not try to clean the melons.\n\nAdditionally, the CDC warned that _Listeria_ can continue to grow --\neven inside a refrigerator. Caution is advised for everyone who may\nhave had one of the recalled melons, but specifically for people who\nare at high risk.\n\nThe FDA, also represented during Wednesday's [28 Sep 2011] conference\ncall, said this is the 1st known outbreak of listeriosis related to\ncantaloupe. The 10 cantaloupe-related outbreaks in the past decade\nwere connected to salmonella or a virus.\n\nThe worst outbreak of listeriosis on record was in 1985 and traced\nback to Mexican-style cheese.\n\nThe FDA says it has a team working with a team from Colorado to do an\nenvironmental assessment at Jensen Farm's facilities. As part of that\nwork, they're looking at potential contamination from animals, water,\nand the processing facility. So far, they've not reached any\nconclusions.\n\nA couple from Colorado Springs is suing the farm and Walmart because\nof the tainted fruit. According to the lawsuit, obtained by 11 News,\nthey are alleging that a cantaloupe distributed by Jensen Farms and\nsold at a Walmart on Razorback Road in the Springs caused [the man] to\nfall ill with listeriosis. [He] has been hospitalized since 31 Aug\n2011.\n\nIn the lawsuit, the couple claims that the cantaloupe was contaminated\nwith _Listeria_ at the time it was sold, and is directly responsible\nfor [his] illness. They say Jensen Farms and Walmart are both liable\nfor having sold \"food which was defective and not reasonably safe.\"\n\nIf you have questions about listeriosis, call the Colorado Department\nof Public Health and Environment at 1-877-462-2911.\n\nAnyone with questions about the recall can contact Jensen Farms at\n1-800-267-4561 or recall@rfordcantaloupe.com.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[3]\nDate: Wed 28 Sep 2011\nSource: Los Angeles Times [edited]\nhttp://latimesblogs.latimes.com/nationnow/2011/09/listeria-outbreak-linked-to-cantaloupes-could-worsen.html\n\n\nIf in doubt, throw it out. Unless you can be sure of the source of\nthat cantaloupe in your kitchen, it's best to toss it. That's the word\nfrom the US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, which is\ntrying to put a lid on one of the worst listeriosis outbreaks in US\nhistory.\n\nSo far, there are 72 reported cases of listeriosis linked to tainted\ncantaloupes, and 13 deaths. State and local officials say they are\ninvestigating 3 additional deaths that may be connected and the toll\ncould rise, according to the Associated Press.\n\nThe tainted melons that triggered the multi-state listeriosis outbreak\nhave been traced to Jensen Farms in Granada, Colorado.\n\n\"If it's not Jensen farms, it's okay to eat,\" Dr Thomas Frieden, CDC\ndirector, said in a media conference call today [28 Sep 2011]. \"But if\nyou can't confirm that it's not Jensen farms, then it's best to throw\nit out.\"\n\nSome of the cantaloupes were exported out of the country, and the CDC\nhas been issuing recalls both inside and outside the US for all the\naffected melons.\n\nThis outbreak is the largest in a decade and could grow worse, said\nthe CDC's foodborne illness specialist, Dr Barbara Mahon, who also\nparticipated in the media alert. \"To date there's 72 cases and 13\ndeaths... We do expect that the number of cases will increase.\"\n\nThe single largest listeriosis outbreak occurred in 1985, and was\ntraced to soft Mexican-style cheese manufactured by Jalisco Mexican\nProducts Inc. of Artesia. It killed at least 40 people, and also ranks\nas one of the biggest food-contamination cases in California history.\n\nCantaloupes can rot within 2 weeks or so, and go bad even faster once\nthey've been sliced open. The cantaloupes at the center of this\noutbreak -- first flagged on 12 Sep 2011 -- are nearing the outer edge\nof their shelf life, making it less likely they will be eaten with\neach passing day.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Cantaloupes are said to have a shelf life of 2 weeks or so. Since\nJensen Farms, the source of the contaminated melons, voluntarily\nrecalled these melons, which it says were shipped between 29 Jul and\n10 Sep 2011, there should not be many more of these melons being\neaten. However, because the incubation period of listeriosis can be up\nto a month or more, there may be more cases, deaths, miscarriages, or\nstillbirths reported in the future due to consumption of these\n_Listeria_-contaminated melons. - Mod.ML]\nSee Also\nListeriosis, fatal - USA (06): cantaloupe, more cases & deaths\n20110923.2876\nListeriosis, fatal - USA (05): cantaloupe, more cases & deaths\n20110922.2871\nListeriosis, fatal - USA (04): cantaloupe, alert 20110921.2866\nListeriosis, fatal - USA (03): cantaloupe susp. 20110914.2800\nListeriosis, fatal - USA (02): (CO) 20110909.2746\nListeriosis, fatal - USA: (CO) 20110605.1719\n2010\n----\nListeriosis, fatal - USA (03): (TX), recall 20101105.4005\nListeriosis, fatal - USA (02): (TX), recall 20101021.3813\nListeriosis, fatal - USA: (TX) 20100515.1592\nListeriosis, fatal, meat product - Canada: (ON) 20100314.0829\n2009\n----\nListeriosis - Australia (02): airline food, chicken wrap susp\n20090820.2947\nListeriosis - Australia: airline food, chicken wrap susp\n20090807.2793\nListeriosis, fatal - Chile: (Santiago) meat susp, RFI 20090411.1391\nListeriosis, Mexican-style cheeses - USA: risk, recall 20090401.1261\nListeriosis, fatal, meat product - Canada: unconf. 20090307.0957\n2008\n----\nListeriosis, fatal - Chile: (Santiago) cheese susp. RFI 20081128.3754\nListeriosis, fatal, meat product - Canada (04) 20081005.3147\nListeriosis, fatal, meat product - Canada: alert, recall\n20080821.2605\nListeriosis - USA: (MA), update 20080118.0223\n2007\n----\nListeriosis - USA: (NC, MA), alert 20071230.4186\nListeriosis, nosocomial - Norway: (Oslo) 20071024.3452\nListeriosis, unpasteurized cheese - USA (IN) 20070425.1351\nListeriosis, sandwiches - UK (England): alert, recall 20070326.1049\n2006\n----\nListeriosis, seafood - USA 20060130.0295\n2005\n----\nListeriosis - USA (TX) 20050824.2491\nListeriosis - USA (NY) (05) 20050819.2431\nListeriosis - USA (NY) 20050707.1925\n2004\n----\nListeriosis, cluster - USA (VA) (02): background 20040723.2013\n.................................................sb/ml/mj/lm", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "listeriosis", "meningitis"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-07 {"location": "North Carolina", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tennessee", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "916599", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis, fatal - USA (11): cantaloupe, farm factors", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=916599", "date": "2011-09-30 11:35:10", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS, FATAL - USA (07): CANTALOUPE, MORE CASES AND DEATHS\n****************************************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\nDate: Tue 27 Sep 2011\nSource: New York Times [edited]\nhttp://www.nytimes.com/2011/09/28/business/deaths-from-cantaloupe-listeria-rises.html\n\n\nAt least 13 people in 8 states have died after eating cantaloupe\ncontaminated with _Listeria_ [_monocytogenes_], in the deadliest\noutbreak of foodborne illness in the United States in more than a\ndecade, public health officials said on Tuesday [27 Sep 2011]. Many of\nthe deaths involved elderly people, who are especially susceptible to\nthe aggressive pathogen.\n\nThe cantaloupes were grown by a Colorado company, Jensen Farms, which\nissued a recall earlier this month [September 2011]. The melons, a\ntype marketed as Rocky Ford cantaloupes, named after a region in\nColorado, were sold around the country.\n\nThe federal Centers for Disease Control and Prevention reported that\nsince the outbreak began in late July [2011] at least 72 people had\nfallen ill in 18 states. The agency said that 4 people had died in New\nMexico, 2 in Colorado, 2 in Texas, and one each in Kansas, Maryland,\nMissouri, Nebraska, and Oklahoma. The toll could grow as state health\nofficials wait for test results on other deaths suspected of being\npart of the outbreak.\n\nOfficials said that most of those who died were over age 60. At least\n2 were in their 90s. _Listeria_ is a common but dangerous bacterium\nthat can cause severe illness, especially among the elderly, the very\nyoung, and people with compromised immune systems. The pathogen can\nalso cause pregnant women to have miscarriages. Federal officials have\nso far provided no information about the number of miscarriages or\nstillbirths associated with the outbreak. Pregnant women are 20 times\nas likely as other healthy adults to come down with a severe\ninfection, according to the CDC.\n\nJohn N Sofos, a professor of food safety at Colorado State University,\nsaid that many people who were infected might have only mild symptoms,\nlike diarrhea. But in others, especially those in the most vulnerable\ncategories, the bacteria can aggressively move out of the\ngastrointestinal tract and attack muscle tissue or the spinal cord,\nleading to much more severe illnesses like meningitis. For that\nreason, the death rate in listeriosis outbreaks is often much higher\nthan with other forms of foodborne bacteria.\n\nWilliam Marler, a Seattle lawyer who represents victims of foodborne\nillness, said this outbreak might turn out to be especially deadly\nsimply because cantaloupe is a food eaten by many older people.\nSometimes in outbreaks, it's the population that's consuming the food\nthat drives the numbers, Mr Marler said. In this instance, you've got\na lot of people 60 and older who are consuming cantaloupe.\n\nThe outbreak appeared to be the 3rd worst in the United States\nattributed to any form of foodborne illness, in terms of the number of\ndeaths, since the CDC began regularly tracking such outbreaks in the\nearly 1970s. The deadliest outbreak in the United States since then\noccurred in 1985, when a wave of listeriosis, linked to Mexican-style\nfresh cheese, swept through California. A federal database says 52\ndeaths were attributed to the outbreak, but news reports at the time\nput the number as high as 84.\n\nThe 2nd deadliest outbreak was in 1998 and 1999, when there were at\nleast 14 deaths and 4 miscarriages or stillbirths in a listeriosis\noutbreak linked to hot dogs and delicatessen meats. Some sources put\nthe death toll in that outbreak as high as 21.\n\nWith the updated death toll on Tuesday [27 Sep 2011], the Rocky Ford\ncantaloupe outbreak surpassed the 2008 deaths associated with\nsalmonella-tainted peanuts and peanut butter produced by a Georgia\ncompany, the Peanut Corporation of America. That outbreak, which drew\na large amount of news coverage, killed 9 people and sickened more\nthan 700.\n\nThe huge outbreak this year [2011] in Europe of a rare form of _E.\ncoli_ bacteria attributed to fenugreek sprouts killed at least 50\npeople.\n\n_Listeria_ is a common bacterium that can be found in soil, water,\ndecaying plant matter, and manure. A strain of the organism, called\n_Listeria monocytogenes_, was first found to cause illness linked to\nfood in the early 1980s. Since then, only a handful of listeriosis\noutbreaks have been associated with fresh fruits and vegetables. The\nmajority was caused by tainted meat or dairy products.\n\nIt can take more than 2 months for a person exposed to the bacteria to\nfall ill, which means that it is often difficult to identify a food\nthat carried the pathogen. Unlike some other bacteria, _Listeria_ also\ngrows well at low temperatures, meaning it can be difficult to\neliminate from refrigerated areas used to process or store foods.\n\nThe Food and Drug Administration said it had found the strain of the\nbacterium on melons and on equipment in the Colorado farm's\npackinghouse. It also found the bacteria on melons in a Denver-area\nstore. Investigators have not said how they believe the contamination\noccurred.\n\nThe FDA recommends that consumers rinse all raw produce, including\ncantaloupes, under running water. Firm produce, like melons, should be\nscrubbed with a produce brush. The washed produce should be dried with\na clean cloth or unused paper towel, the agency said.\n\n[Byline: William Neuman]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: Wed 28 Sep 2011\nSource: KKTV [edited]\nhttp://www.kktv.com/home/headlines/D70_Takes_Cantaloupe_Off_Menu_Due_To_Listeria_Scare_129834148.html\n\n\nDr Thomas Frieden, director of the Centers for Disease Control and\nPrevention, said Wednesday [28 Sep 2011] during a conference call with\nmedia that 2 pregnant women were among the 72 confirmed cases of\n_Listeria_ infection linked to cantaloupes grown in Colorado. He also\nconfirmed that this was the deadliest outbreak in more than a decade.\n\nBoth of the pregnant women and their fetuses are expected to be fine,\nbut 13 people have died from the infection. 3 more deaths are also\nsuspected to be connected, but are not yet confirmed by laboratory\ntests.\n\nThe CDC says _Listeria_ infection during pregnancy could lead to\npremature delivery, miscarriage, stillbirth, and other serious health\nproblems.\n\nThe CDC also said that the number of cases and deaths are likely to\nincrease, because symptoms of _Listeria_ infections can develop up to\n2 months after consumption of the contaminated food.\n\nThe _Listeria_ infections were reported in 18 states.\n\nIn this case, laboratory tests have connected the strains of\n_Listeria_ to melons of the \"Rocky Ford\" variety grown by Jensen Farms\nin Holly, Colorado. That particular variety is prized for having a\nhigher sugar contact, and was developed in the Rocky Ford region of\nColorado during the late 1800's.\n\nThe state of Colorado says it has tested melon samples from the\nrefrigerator of a listeriosis patient's home, as well as samples\nobtained from various retail outlets. They were also traced to Jensen\nFarms.\n\nJensen Farms has voluntarily recalled the melons in question, which it\nsays were shipped between 29 Jul and 10 Sep 2011. They were sent to\nIllinois, Wyoming, Tennessee, Utah, Texas, Colorado, Minnesota,\nKansas, New Mexico, North Carolina, Missouri, Nebraska, Oklahoma,\nArizona, New Jersey, New York, and Pennsylvania.\n\nThey carry stickers that say either, \"Product of USA - Frontera\nProduce - Colorado Fresh - Rocky Ford\" or \"Jensen Farms - Sweet Rocky\nFords.\"\n\nAnyone who has, or may have had cantaloupes from Jensen Farms is\nadvised to throw them away. Do not try to clean the melons.\n\nAdditionally, the CDC warned that _Listeria_ can continue to grow --\neven inside a refrigerator. Caution is advised for everyone who may\nhave had one of the recalled melons, but specifically for people who\nare at high risk.\n\nThe FDA, also represented during Wednesday's [28 Sep 2011] conference\ncall, said this is the 1st known outbreak of listeriosis related to\ncantaloupe. The 10 cantaloupe-related outbreaks in the past decade\nwere connected to salmonella or a virus.\n\nThe worst outbreak of listeriosis on record was in 1985 and traced\nback to Mexican-style cheese.\n\nThe FDA says it has a team working with a team from Colorado to do an\nenvironmental assessment at Jensen Farm's facilities. As part of that\nwork, they're looking at potential contamination from animals, water,\nand the processing facility. So far, they've not reached any\nconclusions.\n\nA couple from Colorado Springs is suing the farm and Walmart because\nof the tainted fruit. According to the lawsuit, obtained by 11 News,\nthey are alleging that a cantaloupe distributed by Jensen Farms and\nsold at a Walmart on Razorback Road in the Springs caused [the man] to\nfall ill with listeriosis. [He] has been hospitalized since 31 Aug\n2011.\n\nIn the lawsuit, the couple claims that the cantaloupe was contaminated\nwith _Listeria_ at the time it was sold, and is directly responsible\nfor [his] illness. They say Jensen Farms and Walmart are both liable\nfor having sold \"food which was defective and not reasonably safe.\"\n\nIf you have questions about listeriosis, call the Colorado Department\nof Public Health and Environment at 1-877-462-2911.\n\nAnyone with questions about the recall can contact Jensen Farms at\n1-800-267-4561 or recall@rfordcantaloupe.com.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[3]\nDate: Wed 28 Sep 2011\nSource: Los Angeles Times [edited]\nhttp://latimesblogs.latimes.com/nationnow/2011/09/listeria-outbreak-linked-to-cantaloupes-could-worsen.html\n\n\nIf in doubt, throw it out. Unless you can be sure of the source of\nthat cantaloupe in your kitchen, it's best to toss it. That's the word\nfrom the US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, which is\ntrying to put a lid on one of the worst listeriosis outbreaks in US\nhistory.\n\nSo far, there are 72 reported cases of listeriosis linked to tainted\ncantaloupes, and 13 deaths. State and local officials say they are\ninvestigating 3 additional deaths that may be connected and the toll\ncould rise, according to the Associated Press.\n\nThe tainted melons that triggered the multi-state listeriosis outbreak\nhave been traced to Jensen Farms in Granada, Colorado.\n\n\"If it's not Jensen farms, it's okay to eat,\" Dr Thomas Frieden, CDC\ndirector, said in a media conference call today [28 Sep 2011]. \"But if\nyou can't confirm that it's not Jensen farms, then it's best to throw\nit out.\"\n\nSome of the cantaloupes were exported out of the country, and the CDC\nhas been issuing recalls both inside and outside the US for all the\naffected melons.\n\nThis outbreak is the largest in a decade and could grow worse, said\nthe CDC's foodborne illness specialist, Dr Barbara Mahon, who also\nparticipated in the media alert. \"To date there's 72 cases and 13\ndeaths... We do expect that the number of cases will increase.\"\n\nThe single largest listeriosis outbreak occurred in 1985, and was\ntraced to soft Mexican-style cheese manufactured by Jalisco Mexican\nProducts Inc. of Artesia. It killed at least 40 people, and also ranks\nas one of the biggest food-contamination cases in California history.\n\nCantaloupes can rot within 2 weeks or so, and go bad even faster once\nthey've been sliced open. The cantaloupes at the center of this\noutbreak -- first flagged on 12 Sep 2011 -- are nearing the outer edge\nof their shelf life, making it less likely they will be eaten with\neach passing day.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Cantaloupes are said to have a shelf life of 2 weeks or so. Since\nJensen Farms, the source of the contaminated melons, voluntarily\nrecalled these melons, which it says were shipped between 29 Jul and\n10 Sep 2011, there should not be many more of these melons being\neaten. However, because the incubation period of listeriosis can be up\nto a month or more, there may be more cases, deaths, miscarriages, or\nstillbirths reported in the future due to consumption of these\n_Listeria_-contaminated melons. - Mod.ML]\nSee Also\nListeriosis, fatal - USA (06): cantaloupe, more cases & deaths\n20110923.2876\nListeriosis, fatal - USA (05): cantaloupe, more cases & deaths\n20110922.2871\nListeriosis, fatal - USA (04): cantaloupe, alert 20110921.2866\nListeriosis, fatal - USA (03): cantaloupe susp. 20110914.2800\nListeriosis, fatal - USA (02): (CO) 20110909.2746\nListeriosis, fatal - USA: (CO) 20110605.1719\n2010\n----\nListeriosis, fatal - USA (03): (TX), recall 20101105.4005\nListeriosis, fatal - USA (02): (TX), recall 20101021.3813\nListeriosis, fatal - USA: (TX) 20100515.1592\nListeriosis, fatal, meat product - Canada: (ON) 20100314.0829\n2009\n----\nListeriosis - Australia (02): airline food, chicken wrap susp\n20090820.2947\nListeriosis - Australia: airline food, chicken wrap susp\n20090807.2793\nListeriosis, fatal - Chile: (Santiago) meat susp, RFI 20090411.1391\nListeriosis, Mexican-style cheeses - USA: risk, recall 20090401.1261\nListeriosis, fatal, meat product - Canada: unconf. 20090307.0957\n2008\n----\nListeriosis, fatal - Chile: (Santiago) cheese susp. 20040723.2013\n.................................................sb/ml/mj/lm", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "listeriosis", "meningitis"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2011-09-27 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2011-09-27 00:00:00", "2011-09-16 00:00:00", "1985-03-16 00:00:00", "1998-03-16 00:00:00", "1999-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2011-09-27 00:00:00", "2008-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-17 00:00:00", "2011-09-28 00:00:00", "2011-09-10 00:00:00", "2021-03-17 00:00:00", "1985-03-16 00:00:00", "2011-03-16 00:00:00", "1985-03-16 00:00:00", "2011-09-12 00:00:00", "2011-09-10 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Minnesota", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "NC", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Pennsylvania", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Mexico", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Wyoming", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "California", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New York", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Illinois", "country": {"location": "North Carolina", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tennessee", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "901937", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis, fatal - USA (10): cantaloupe, more cases & deaths", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=901937", "date": "2011-09-30 11:35:10", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS, FATAL - USA (07): CANTALOUPE, MORE CASES AND DEATHS\n****************************************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\nDate: Tue 27 Sep 2011\nSource: New York Times [edited]\nhttp://www.nytimes.com/2011/09/28/business/deaths-from-cantaloupe-listeria-rises.html\n\n\nAt least 13 people in 8 states have died after eating cantaloupe\ncontaminated with _Listeria_ [_monocytogenes_], in the deadliest\noutbreak of foodborne illness in the United States in more than a\ndecade, public health officials said on Tuesday [27 Sep 2011]. Many of\nthe deaths involved elderly people, who are especially susceptible to\nthe aggressive pathogen.\n\nThe cantaloupes were grown by a Colorado company, Jensen Farms, which\nissued a recall earlier this month [September 2011]. The melons, a\ntype marketed as Rocky Ford cantaloupes, named after a region in\nColorado, were sold around the country.\n\nThe federal Centers for Disease Control and Prevention reported that\nsince the outbreak began in late July [2011] at least 72 people had\nfallen ill in 18 states. The agency said that 4 people had died in New\nMexico, 2 in Colorado, 2 in Texas, and one each in Kansas, Maryland,\nMissouri, Nebraska, and Oklahoma. The toll could grow as state health\nofficials wait for test results on other deaths suspected of being\npart of the outbreak.\n\nOfficials said that most of those who died were over age 60. At least\n2 were in their 90s. _Listeria_ is a common but dangerous bacterium\nthat can cause severe illness, especially among the elderly, the very\nyoung, and people with compromised immune systems. The pathogen can\nalso cause pregnant women to have miscarriages. Federal officials have\nso far provided no information about the number of miscarriages or\nstillbirths associated with the outbreak. Pregnant women are 20 times\nas likely as other healthy adults to come down with a severe\ninfection, according to the CDC.\n\nJohn N Sofos, a professor of food safety at Colorado State University,\nsaid that many people who were infected might have only mild symptoms,\nlike diarrhea. But in others, especially those in the most vulnerable\ncategories, the bacteria can aggressively move out of the\ngastrointestinal tract and attack muscle tissue or the spinal cord,\nleading to much more severe illnesses like meningitis. For that\nreason, the death rate in listeriosis outbreaks is often much higher\nthan with other forms of foodborne bacteria.\n\nWilliam Marler, a Seattle lawyer who represents victims of foodborne\nillness, said this outbreak might turn out to be especially deadly\nsimply because cantaloupe is a food eaten by many older people.\nSometimes in outbreaks, it's the population that's consuming the food\nthat drives the numbers, Mr Marler said. In this instance, you've got\na lot of people 60 and older who are consuming cantaloupe.\n\nThe outbreak appeared to be the 3rd worst in the United States\nattributed to any form of foodborne illness, in terms of the number of\ndeaths, since the CDC began regularly tracking such outbreaks in the\nearly 1970s. The deadliest outbreak in the United States since then\noccurred in 1985, when a wave of listeriosis, linked to Mexican-style\nfresh cheese, swept through California. A federal database says 52\ndeaths were attributed to the outbreak, but news reports at the time\nput the number as high as 84.\n\nThe 2nd deadliest outbreak was in 1998 and 1999, when there were at\nleast 14 deaths and 4 miscarriages or stillbirths in a listeriosis\noutbreak linked to hot dogs and delicatessen meats. Some sources put\nthe death toll in that outbreak as high as 21.\n\nWith the updated death toll on Tuesday [27 Sep 2011], the Rocky Ford\ncantaloupe outbreak surpassed the 2008 deaths associated with\nsalmonella-tainted peanuts and peanut butter produced by a Georgia\ncompany, the Peanut Corporation of America. That outbreak, which drew\na large amount of news coverage, killed 9 people and sickened more\nthan 700.\n\nThe huge outbreak this year [2011] in Europe of a rare form of _E.\ncoli_ bacteria attributed to fenugreek sprouts killed at least 50\npeople.\n\n_Listeria_ is a common bacterium that can be found in soil, water,\ndecaying plant matter, and manure. A strain of the organism, called\n_Listeria monocytogenes_, was first found to cause illness linked to\nfood in the early 1980s. Since then, only a handful of listeriosis\noutbreaks have been associated with fresh fruits and vegetables. The\nmajority was caused by tainted meat or dairy products.\n\nIt can take more than 2 months for a person exposed to the bacteria to\nfall ill, which means that it is often difficult to identify a food\nthat carried the pathogen. Unlike some other bacteria, _Listeria_ also\ngrows well at low temperatures, meaning it can be difficult to\neliminate from refrigerated areas used to process or store foods.\n\nThe Food and Drug Administration said it had found the strain of the\nbacterium on melons and on equipment in the Colorado farm's\npackinghouse. It also found the bacteria on melons in a Denver-area\nstore. Investigators have not said how they believe the contamination\noccurred.\n\nThe FDA recommends that consumers rinse all raw produce, including\ncantaloupes, under running water. Firm produce, like melons, should be\nscrubbed with a produce brush. The washed produce should be dried with\na clean cloth or unused paper towel, the agency said.\n\n[Byline: William Neuman]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: Wed 28 Sep 2011\nSource: KKTV [edited]\nhttp://www.kktv.com/home/headlines/D70_Takes_Cantaloupe_Off_Menu_Due_To_Listeria_Scare_129834148.html\n\n\nDr Thomas Frieden, director of the Centers for Disease Control and\nPrevention, said Wednesday [28 Sep 2011] during a conference call with\nmedia that 2 pregnant women were among the 72 confirmed cases of\n_Listeria_ infection linked to cantaloupes grown in Colorado. He also\nconfirmed that this was the deadliest outbreak in more than a decade.\n\nBoth of the pregnant women and their fetuses are expected to be fine,\nbut 13 people have died from the infection. 3 more deaths are also\nsuspected to be connected, but are not yet confirmed by laboratory\ntests.\n\nThe CDC says _Listeria_ infection during pregnancy could lead to\npremature delivery, miscarriage, stillbirth, and other serious health\nproblems.\n\nThe CDC also said that the number of cases and deaths are likely to\nincrease, because symptoms of _Listeria_ infections can develop up to\n2 months after consumption of the contaminated food.\n\nThe _Listeria_ infections were reported in 18 states.\n\nIn this case, laboratory tests have connected the strains of\n_Listeria_ to melons of the \"Rocky Ford\" variety grown by Jensen Farms\nin Holly, Colorado. That particular variety is prized for having a\nhigher sugar contact, and was developed in the Rocky Ford region of\nColorado during the late 1800's.\n\nThe state of Colorado says it has tested melon samples from the\nrefrigerator of a listeriosis patient's home, as well as samples\nobtained from various retail outlets. They were also traced to Jensen\nFarms.\n\nJensen Farms has voluntarily recalled the melons in question, which it\nsays were shipped between 29 Jul and 10 Sep 2011. They were sent to\nIllinois, Wyoming, Tennessee, Utah, Texas, Colorado, Minnesota,\nKansas, New Mexico, North Carolina, Missouri, Nebraska, Oklahoma,\nArizona, New Jersey, New York, and Pennsylvania.\n\nThey carry stickers that say either, \"Product of USA - Frontera\nProduce - Colorado Fresh - Rocky Ford\" or \"Jensen Farms - Sweet Rocky\nFords.\"\n\nAnyone who has, or may have had cantaloupes from Jensen Farms is\nadvised to throw them away. Do not try to clean the melons.\n\nAdditionally, the CDC warned that _Listeria_ can continue to grow --\neven inside a refrigerator. Caution is advised for everyone who may\nhave had one of the recalled melons, but specifically for people who\nare at high risk.\n\nThe FDA, also represented during Wednesday's [28 Sep 2011] conference\ncall, said this is the 1st known outbreak of listeriosis related to\ncantaloupe. The 10 cantaloupe-related outbreaks in the past decade\nwere connected to salmonella or a virus.\n\nThe worst outbreak of listeriosis on record was in 1985 and traced\nback to Mexican-style cheese.\n\nThe FDA says it has a team working with a team from Colorado to do an\nenvironmental assessment at Jensen Farm's facilities. As part of that\nwork, they're looking at potential contamination from animals, water,\nand the processing facility. So far, they've not reached any\nconclusions.\n\nA couple from Colorado Springs is suing the farm and Walmart because\nof the tainted fruit. According to the lawsuit, obtained by 11 News,\nthey are alleging that a cantaloupe distributed by Jensen Farms and\nsold at a Walmart on Razorback Road in the Springs caused [the man] to\nfall ill with listeriosis. [He] has been hospitalized since 31 Aug\n2011.\n\nIn the lawsuit, the couple claims that the cantaloupe was contaminated\nwith _Listeria_ at the time it was sold, and is directly responsible\nfor [his] illness. They say Jensen Farms and Walmart are both liable\nfor having sold \"food which was defective and not reasonably safe.\"\n\nIf you have questions about listeriosis, call the Colorado Department\nof Public Health and Environment at 1-877-462-2911.\n\nAnyone with questions about the recall can contact Jensen Farms at\n1-800-267-4561 or recall@rfordcantaloupe.com.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[3]\nDate: Wed 28 Sep 2011\nSource: Los Angeles Times [edited]\nhttp://latimesblogs.latimes.com/nationnow/2011/09/listeria-outbreak-linked-to-cantaloupes-could-worsen.html\n\n\nIf in doubt, throw it out. Unless you can be sure of the source of\nthat cantaloupe in your kitchen, it's best to toss it. That's the word\nfrom the US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, which is\ntrying to put a lid on one of the worst listeriosis outbreaks in US\nhistory.\n\nSo far, there are 72 reported cases of listeriosis linked to tainted\ncantaloupes, and 13 deaths. State and local officials say they are\ninvestigating 3 additional deaths that may be connected and the toll\ncould rise, according to the Associated Press.\n\nThe tainted melons that triggered the multi-state listeriosis outbreak\nhave been traced to Jensen Farms in Granada, Colorado.\n\n\"If it's not Jensen farms, it's okay to eat,\" Dr Thomas Frieden, CDC\ndirector, said in a media conference call today [28 Sep 2011]. \"But if\nyou can't confirm that it's not Jensen farms, then it's best to throw\nit out.\"\n\nSome of the cantaloupes were exported out of the country, and the CDC\nhas been issuing recalls both inside and outside the US for all the\naffected melons.\n\nThis outbreak is the largest in a decade and could grow worse, said\nthe CDC's foodborne illness specialist, Dr Barbara Mahon, who also\nparticipated in the media alert. \"To date there's 72 cases and 13\ndeaths... We do expect that the number of cases will increase.\"\n\nThe single largest listeriosis outbreak occurred in 1985, and was\ntraced to soft Mexican-style cheese manufactured by Jalisco Mexican\nProducts Inc. of Artesia. It killed at least 40 people, and also ranks\nas one of the biggest food-contamination cases in California history.\n\nCantaloupes can rot within 2 weeks or so, and go bad even faster once\nthey've been sliced open. The cantaloupes at the center of this\noutbreak -- first flagged on 12 Sep 2011 -- are nearing the outer edge\nof their shelf life, making it less likely they will be eaten with\neach passing day.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Cantaloupes are said to have a shelf life of 2 weeks or so. Since\nJensen Farms, the source of the contaminated melons, voluntarily\nrecalled these melons, which it says were shipped between 29 Jul and\n10 Sep 2011, there should not be many more of these melons being\neaten. However, because the incubation period of listeriosis can be up\nto a month or more, there may be more cases, deaths, miscarriages, or\nstillbirths reported in the future due to consumption of these\n_Listeria_-contaminated melons. - Mod.ML]\nSee Also\nListeriosis, fatal - USA (06): cantaloupe, more cases & deaths\n20110923.2876\nListeriosis, fatal - USA (05): cantaloupe, more cases & deaths\n20110922.2871\nListeriosis, fatal - USA (04): cantaloupe, alert 20110921.2866\nListeriosis, fatal - USA (03): cantaloupe susp. 20110914.2800\nListeriosis, fatal - USA (02): (CO) 20110909.2746\nListeriosis, fatal - USA: (CO) 20110605.1719\n2010\n----\nListeriosis, fatal - USA (03): (TX), recall 20101105.4005\nListeriosis, fatal - USA (02): (TX), recall 20101021.3813\nListeriosis, fatal - USA: (TX) 20100515.1592\nListeriosis, fatal, meat product - Canada: (ON) 20100314.0829\n2009\n----\nListeriosis - Australia (02): airline food, chicken wrap susp\n20090820.2947\nListeriosis - Australia: airline food, chicken wrap susp\n20090807.2793\nListeriosis, fatal - Chile: (Santiago) meat susp, RFI 20090411.1391\nListeriosis, Mexican-style cheeses - USA: risk, recall 20090401.1261\nListeriosis, fatal, meat product - Canada: unconf. 20090307.0957\n2008\n----\nListeriosis, fatal - Chile: (Santiago) cheese susp. 20040723.2013\n.................................................sb/ml/mj/lm", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "listeriosis", "meningitis"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2011-09-27 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2011-09-27 00:00:00", "2011-09-16 00:00:00", "1985-03-16 00:00:00", "1998-03-16 00:00:00", "1999-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2011-09-27 00:00:00", "2008-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-17 00:00:00", "2011-09-28 00:00:00", "2011-09-10 00:00:00", "2021-03-17 00:00:00", "1985-03-16 00:00:00", "2011-03-16 00:00:00", "1985-03-16 00:00:00", "2011-09-12 00:00:00", "2011-09-10 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Minnesota", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "NC", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Pennsylvania", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Mexico", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Wyoming", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "California", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New York", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Illinois", "country":
