{"location": "North Carolina", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tennessee", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "897817", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis, fatal - USA (09): cantaloupe, more cases & deaths", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=897817", "date": "2011-09-30 11:35:10", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS, FATAL - USA (07): CANTALOUPE, MORE CASES AND DEATHS\n****************************************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\nDate: Tue 27 Sep 2011\nSource: New York Times [edited]\nhttp://www.nytimes.com/2011/09/28/business/deaths-from-cantaloupe-listeria-rises.html\n\n\nAt least 13 people in 8 states have died after eating cantaloupe\ncontaminated with _Listeria_ [_monocytogenes_], in the deadliest\noutbreak of foodborne illness in the United States in more than a\ndecade, public health officials said on Tuesday [27 Sep 2011]. Many of\nthe deaths involved elderly people, who are especially susceptible to\nthe aggressive pathogen.\n\nThe cantaloupes were grown by a Colorado company, Jensen Farms, which\nissued a recall earlier this month [September 2011]. The melons, a\ntype marketed as Rocky Ford cantaloupes, named after a region in\nColorado, were sold around the country.\n\nThe federal Centers for Disease Control and Prevention reported that\nsince the outbreak began in late July [2011] at least 72 people had\nfallen ill in 18 states. The agency said that 4 people had died in New\nMexico, 2 in Colorado, 2 in Texas, and one each in Kansas, Maryland,\nMissouri, Nebraska, and Oklahoma. The toll could grow as state health\nofficials wait for test results on other deaths suspected of being\npart of the outbreak.\n\nOfficials said that most of those who died were over age 60. At least\n2 were in their 90s. _Listeria_ is a common but dangerous bacterium\nthat can cause severe illness, especially among the elderly, the very\nyoung, and people with compromised immune systems. The pathogen can\nalso cause pregnant women to have miscarriages. Federal officials have\nso far provided no information about the number of miscarriages or\nstillbirths associated with the outbreak. Pregnant women are 20 times\nas likely as other healthy adults to come down with a severe\ninfection, according to the CDC.\n\nJohn N Sofos, a professor of food safety at Colorado State University,\nsaid that many people who were infected might have only mild symptoms,\nlike diarrhea. But in others, especially those in the most vulnerable\ncategories, the bacteria can aggressively move out of the\ngastrointestinal tract and attack muscle tissue or the spinal cord,\nleading to much more severe illnesses like meningitis. For that\nreason, the death rate in listeriosis outbreaks is often much higher\nthan with other forms of foodborne bacteria.\n\nWilliam Marler, a Seattle lawyer who represents victims of foodborne\nillness, said this outbreak might turn out to be especially deadly\nsimply because cantaloupe is a food eaten by many older people.\nSometimes in outbreaks, it's the population that's consuming the food\nthat drives the numbers, Mr Marler said. In this instance, you've got\na lot of people 60 and older who are consuming cantaloupe.\n\nThe outbreak appeared to be the 3rd worst in the United States\nattributed to any form of foodborne illness, in terms of the number of\ndeaths, since the CDC began regularly tracking such outbreaks in the\nearly 1970s. The deadliest outbreak in the United States since then\noccurred in 1985, when a wave of listeriosis, linked to Mexican-style\nfresh cheese, swept through California. A federal database says 52\ndeaths were attributed to the outbreak, but news reports at the time\nput the number as high as 84.\n\nThe 2nd deadliest outbreak was in 1998 and 1999, when there were at\nleast 14 deaths and 4 miscarriages or stillbirths in a listeriosis\noutbreak linked to hot dogs and delicatessen meats. Some sources put\nthe death toll in that outbreak as high as 21.\n\nWith the updated death toll on Tuesday [27 Sep 2011], the Rocky Ford\ncantaloupe outbreak surpassed the 2008 deaths associated with\nsalmonella-tainted peanuts and peanut butter produced by a Georgia\ncompany, the Peanut Corporation of America. That outbreak, which drew\na large amount of news coverage, killed 9 people and sickened more\nthan 700.\n\nThe huge outbreak this year [2011] in Europe of a rare form of _E.\ncoli_ bacteria attributed to fenugreek sprouts killed at least 50\npeople.\n\n_Listeria_ is a common bacterium that can be found in soil, water,\ndecaying plant matter, and manure. A strain of the organism, called\n_Listeria monocytogenes_, was first found to cause illness linked to\nfood in the early 1980s. Since then, only a handful of listeriosis\noutbreaks have been associated with fresh fruits and vegetables. The\nmajority was caused by tainted meat or dairy products.\n\nIt can take more than 2 months for a person exposed to the bacteria to\nfall ill, which means that it is often difficult to identify a food\nthat carried the pathogen. Unlike some other bacteria, _Listeria_ also\ngrows well at low temperatures, meaning it can be difficult to\neliminate from refrigerated areas used to process or store foods.\n\nThe Food and Drug Administration said it had found the strain of the\nbacterium on melons and on equipment in the Colorado farm's\npackinghouse. It also found the bacteria on melons in a Denver-area\nstore. Investigators have not said how they believe the contamination\noccurred.\n\nThe FDA recommends that consumers rinse all raw produce, including\ncantaloupes, under running water. Firm produce, like melons, should be\nscrubbed with a produce brush. The washed produce should be dried with\na clean cloth or unused paper towel, the agency said.\n\n[Byline: William Neuman]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: Wed 28 Sep 2011\nSource: KKTV [edited]\nhttp://www.kktv.com/home/headlines/D70_Takes_Cantaloupe_Off_Menu_Due_To_Listeria_Scare_129834148.html\n\n\nDr Thomas Frieden, director of the Centers for Disease Control and\nPrevention, said Wednesday [28 Sep 2011] during a conference call with\nmedia that 2 pregnant women were among the 72 confirmed cases of\n_Listeria_ infection linked to cantaloupes grown in Colorado. He also\nconfirmed that this was the deadliest outbreak in more than a decade.\n\nBoth of the pregnant women and their fetuses are expected to be fine,\nbut 13 people have died from the infection. 3 more deaths are also\nsuspected to be connected, but are not yet confirmed by laboratory\ntests.\n\nThe CDC says _Listeria_ infection during pregnancy could lead to\npremature delivery, miscarriage, stillbirth, and other serious health\nproblems.\n\nThe CDC also said that the number of cases and deaths are likely to\nincrease, because symptoms of _Listeria_ infections can develop up to\n2 months after consumption of the contaminated food.\n\nThe _Listeria_ infections were reported in 18 states.\n\nIn this case, laboratory tests have connected the strains of\n_Listeria_ to melons of the \"Rocky Ford\" variety grown by Jensen Farms\nin Holly, Colorado. That particular variety is prized for having a\nhigher sugar contact, and was developed in the Rocky Ford region of\nColorado during the late 1800's.\n\nThe state of Colorado says it has tested melon samples from the\nrefrigerator of a listeriosis patient's home, as well as samples\nobtained from various retail outlets. They were also traced to Jensen\nFarms.\n\nJensen Farms has voluntarily recalled the melons in question, which it\nsays were shipped between 29 Jul and 10 Sep 2011. They were sent to\nIllinois, Wyoming, Tennessee, Utah, Texas, Colorado, Minnesota,\nKansas, New Mexico, North Carolina, Missouri, Nebraska, Oklahoma,\nArizona, New Jersey, New York, and Pennsylvania.\n\nThey carry stickers that say either, \"Product of USA - Frontera\nProduce - Colorado Fresh - Rocky Ford\" or \"Jensen Farms - Sweet Rocky\nFords.\"\n\nAnyone who has, or may have had cantaloupes from Jensen Farms is\nadvised to throw them away. Do not try to clean the melons.\n\nAdditionally, the CDC warned that _Listeria_ can continue to grow --\neven inside a refrigerator. Caution is advised for everyone who may\nhave had one of the recalled melons, but specifically for people who\nare at high risk.\n\nThe FDA, also represented during Wednesday's [28 Sep 2011] conference\ncall, said this is the 1st known outbreak of listeriosis related to\ncantaloupe. The 10 cantaloupe-related outbreaks in the past decade\nwere connected to salmonella or a virus.\n\nThe worst outbreak of listeriosis on record was in 1985 and traced\nback to Mexican-style cheese.\n\nThe FDA says it has a team working with a team from Colorado to do an\nenvironmental assessment at Jensen Farm's facilities. As part of that\nwork, they're looking at potential contamination from animals, water,\nand the processing facility. So far, they've not reached any\nconclusions.\n\nA couple from Colorado Springs is suing the farm and Walmart because\nof the tainted fruit. According to the lawsuit, obtained by 11 News,\nthey are alleging that a cantaloupe distributed by Jensen Farms and\nsold at a Walmart on Razorback Road in the Springs caused [the man] to\nfall ill with listeriosis. [He] has been hospitalized since 31 Aug\n2011.\n\nIn the lawsuit, the couple claims that the cantaloupe was contaminated\nwith _Listeria_ at the time it was sold, and is directly responsible\nfor [his] illness. They say Jensen Farms and Walmart are both liable\nfor having sold \"food which was defective and not reasonably safe.\"\n\nIf you have questions about listeriosis, call the Colorado Department\nof Public Health and Environment at 1-877-462-2911.\n\nAnyone with questions about the recall can contact Jensen Farms at\n1-800-267-4561 or recall@rfordcantaloupe.com.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[3]\nDate: Wed 28 Sep 2011\nSource: Los Angeles Times [edited]\nhttp://latimesblogs.latimes.com/nationnow/2011/09/listeria-outbreak-linked-to-cantaloupes-could-worsen.html\n\n\nIf in doubt, throw it out. Unless you can be sure of the source of\nthat cantaloupe in your kitchen, it's best to toss it. That's the word\nfrom the US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, which is\ntrying to put a lid on one of the worst listeriosis outbreaks in US\nhistory.\n\nSo far, there are 72 reported cases of listeriosis linked to tainted\ncantaloupes, and 13 deaths. State and local officials say they are\ninvestigating 3 additional deaths that may be connected and the toll\ncould rise, according to the Associated Press.\n\nThe tainted melons that triggered the multi-state listeriosis outbreak\nhave been traced to Jensen Farms in Granada, Colorado.\n\n\"If it's not Jensen farms, it's okay to eat,\" Dr Thomas Frieden, CDC\ndirector, said in a media conference call today [28 Sep 2011]. \"But if\nyou can't confirm that it's not Jensen farms, then it's best to throw\nit out.\"\n\nSome of the cantaloupes were exported out of the country, and the CDC\nhas been issuing recalls both inside and outside the US for all the\naffected melons.\n\nThis outbreak is the largest in a decade and could grow worse, said\nthe CDC's foodborne illness specialist, Dr Barbara Mahon, who also\nparticipated in the media alert. \"To date there's 72 cases and 13\ndeaths... We do expect that the number of cases will increase.\"\n\nThe single largest listeriosis outbreak occurred in 1985, and was\ntraced to soft Mexican-style cheese manufactured by Jalisco Mexican\nProducts Inc. of Artesia. It killed at least 40 people, and also ranks\nas one of the biggest food-contamination cases in California history.\n\nCantaloupes can rot within 2 weeks or so, and go bad even faster once\nthey've been sliced open. The cantaloupes at the center of this\noutbreak -- first flagged on 12 Sep 2011 -- are nearing the outer edge\nof their shelf life, making it less likely they will be eaten with\neach passing day.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Cantaloupes are said to have a shelf life of 2 weeks or so. Since\nJensen Farms, the source of the contaminated melons, voluntarily\nrecalled these melons, which it says were shipped between 29 Jul and\n10 Sep 2011, there should not be many more of these melons being\neaten. However, because the incubation period of listeriosis can be up\nto a month or more, there may be more cases, deaths, miscarriages, or\nstillbirths reported in the future due to consumption of these\n_Listeria_-contaminated melons. - Mod.ML]\nSee Also\nListeriosis, fatal - USA (06): cantaloupe, more cases & deaths\n20110923.2876\nListeriosis, fatal - USA (05): cantaloupe, more cases & deaths\n20110922.2871\nListeriosis, fatal - USA (04): cantaloupe, alert 20110921.2866\nListeriosis, fatal - USA (03): cantaloupe susp. 20110914.2800\nListeriosis, fatal - USA (02): (CO) 20110909.2746\nListeriosis, fatal - USA: (CO) 20110605.1719\n2010\n----\nListeriosis, fatal - USA (03): (TX), recall 20101105.4005\nListeriosis, fatal - USA (02): (TX), recall 20101021.3813\nListeriosis, fatal - USA: (TX) 20100515.1592\nListeriosis, fatal, meat product - Canada: (ON) 20100314.0829\n2009\n----\nListeriosis - Australia (02): airline food, chicken wrap susp\n20090820.2947\nListeriosis - Australia: airline food, chicken wrap susp\n20090807.2793\nListeriosis, fatal - Chile: (Santiago) meat susp, RFI 20090411.1391\nListeriosis, Mexican-style cheeses - USA: risk, recall 20090401.1261\nListeriosis, fatal, meat product - Canada: unconf. 20090307.0957\n2008\n----\nListeriosis, fatal - Chile: (Santiago) cheese susp. RFI 20081128.3754\nListeriosis, fatal, meat product - Canada (04) 20081005.3147\nListeriosis, fatal, meat product - Canada: alert, recall\n20080821.2605\nListeriosis - USA: (MA), update 20080118.0223\n2007\n----\nListeriosis - USA: (NC, MA), alert 20071230.4186\nListeriosis, nosocomial - Norway: (Oslo) 20071024.3452\nListeriosis, unpasteurized cheese - USA (IN) 20070425.1351\nListeriosis, sandwiches - UK (England): alert, recall 20070326.1049\n2006\n----\nListeriosis, seafood - USA 20060130.0295\n2005\n----\nListeriosis - USA (TX) 20050824.2491\nListeriosis "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=893557", "date": "2011-09-30 11:35:10", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS, FATAL - USA (07): CANTALOUPE, MORE CASES AND DEATHS\n****************************************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\nDate: Tue 27 Sep 2011\nSource: New York Times [edited]\nhttp://www.nytimes.com/2011/09/28/business/deaths-from-cantaloupe-listeria-rises.html\n\n\nAt least 13 people in 8 states have died after eating cantaloupe\ncontaminated with _Listeria_ [_monocytogenes_], in the deadliest\noutbreak of foodborne illness in the United States in more than a\ndecade, public health officials said on Tuesday [27 Sep 2011]. Many of\nthe deaths involved elderly people, who are especially susceptible to\nthe aggressive pathogen.\n\nThe cantaloupes were grown by a Colorado company, Jensen Farms, which\nissued a recall earlier this month [September 2011]. The melons, a\ntype marketed as Rocky Ford cantaloupes, named after a region in\nColorado, were sold around the country.\n\nThe federal Centers for Disease Control and Prevention reported that\nsince the outbreak began in late July [2011] at least 72 people had\nfallen ill in 18 states. The agency said that 4 people had died in New\nMexico, 2 in Colorado, 2 in Texas, and one each in Kansas, Maryland,\nMissouri, Nebraska, and Oklahoma. The toll could grow as state health\nofficials wait for test results on other deaths suspected of being\npart of the outbreak.\n\nOfficials said that most of those who died were over age 60. At least\n2 were in their 90s. _Listeria_ is a common but dangerous bacterium\nthat can cause severe illness, especially among the elderly, the very\nyoung, and people with compromised immune systems. The pathogen can\nalso cause pregnant women to have miscarriages. Federal officials have\nso far provided no information about the number of miscarriages or\nstillbirths associated with the outbreak. Pregnant women are 20 times\nas likely as other healthy adults to come down with a severe\ninfection, according to the CDC.\n\nJohn N Sofos, a professor of food safety at Colorado State University,\nsaid that many people who were infected might have only mild symptoms,\nlike diarrhea. But in others, especially those in the most vulnerable\ncategories, the bacteria can aggressively move out of the\ngastrointestinal tract and attack muscle tissue or the spinal cord,\nleading to much more severe illnesses like meningitis. For that\nreason, the death rate in listeriosis outbreaks is often much higher\nthan with other forms of foodborne bacteria.\n\nWilliam Marler, a Seattle lawyer who represents victims of foodborne\nillness, said this outbreak might turn out to be especially deadly\nsimply because cantaloupe is a food eaten by many older people.\nSometimes in outbreaks, it's the population that's consuming the food\nthat drives the numbers, Mr Marler said. In this instance, you've got\na lot of people 60 and older who are consuming cantaloupe.\n\nThe outbreak appeared to be the 3rd worst in the United States\nattributed to any form of foodborne illness, in terms of the number of\ndeaths, since the CDC began regularly tracking such outbreaks in the\nearly 1970s. The deadliest outbreak in the United States since then\noccurred in 1985, when a wave of listeriosis, linked to Mexican-style\nfresh cheese, swept through California. A federal database says 52\ndeaths were attributed to the outbreak, but news reports at the time\nput the number as high as 84.\n\nThe 2nd deadliest outbreak was in 1998 and 1999, when there were at\nleast 14 deaths and 4 miscarriages or stillbirths in a listeriosis\noutbreak linked to hot dogs and delicatessen meats. Some sources put\nthe death toll in that outbreak as high as 21.\n\nWith the updated death toll on Tuesday [27 Sep 2011], the Rocky Ford\ncantaloupe outbreak surpassed the 2008 deaths associated with\nsalmonella-tainted peanuts and peanut butter produced by a Georgia\ncompany, the Peanut Corporation of America. That outbreak, which drew\na large amount of news coverage, killed 9 people and sickened more\nthan 700.\n\nThe huge outbreak this year [2011] in Europe of a rare form of _E.\ncoli_ bacteria attributed to fenugreek sprouts killed at least 50\npeople.\n\n_Listeria_ is a common bacterium that can be found in soil, water,\ndecaying plant matter, and manure. A strain of the organism, called\n_Listeria monocytogenes_, was first found to cause illness linked to\nfood in the early 1980s. Since then, only a handful of listeriosis\noutbreaks have been associated with fresh fruits and vegetables. The\nmajority was caused by tainted meat or dairy products.\n\nIt can take more than 2 months for a person exposed to the bacteria to\nfall ill, which means that it is often difficult to identify a food\nthat carried the pathogen. Unlike some other bacteria, _Listeria_ also\ngrows well at low temperatures, meaning it can be difficult to\neliminate from refrigerated areas used to process or store foods.\n\nThe Food and Drug Administration said it had found the strain of the\nbacterium on melons and on equipment in the Colorado farm's\npackinghouse. It also found the bacteria on melons in a Denver-area\nstore. Investigators have not said how they believe the contamination\noccurred.\n\nThe FDA recommends that consumers rinse all raw produce, including\ncantaloupes, under running water. Firm produce, like melons, should be\nscrubbed with a produce brush. The washed produce should be dried with\na clean cloth or unused paper towel, the agency said.\n\n[Byline: William Neuman]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: Wed 28 Sep 2011\nSource: KKTV [edited]\nhttp://www.kktv.com/home/headlines/D70_Takes_Cantaloupe_Off_Menu_Due_To_Listeria_Scare_129834148.html\n\n\nDr Thomas Frieden, director of the Centers for Disease Control and\nPrevention, said Wednesday [28 Sep 2011] during a conference call with\nmedia that 2 pregnant women were among the 72 confirmed cases of\n_Listeria_ infection linked to cantaloupes grown in Colorado. He also\nconfirmed that this was the deadliest outbreak in more than a decade.\n\nBoth of the pregnant women and their fetuses are expected to be fine,\nbut 13 people have died from the infection. 3 more deaths are also\nsuspected to be connected, but are not yet confirmed by laboratory\ntests.\n\nThe CDC says _Listeria_ infection during pregnancy could lead to\npremature delivery, miscarriage, stillbirth, and other serious health\nproblems.\n\nThe CDC also said that the number of cases and deaths are likely to\nincrease, because symptoms of _Listeria_ infections can develop up to\n2 months after consumption of the contaminated food.\n\nThe _Listeria_ infections were reported in 18 states.\n\nIn this case, laboratory tests have connected the strains of\n_Listeria_ to melons of the \"Rocky Ford\" variety grown by Jensen Farms\nin Holly, Colorado. That particular variety is prized for having a\nhigher sugar contact, and was developed in the Rocky Ford region of\nColorado during the late 1800's.\n\nThe state of Colorado says it has tested melon samples from the\nrefrigerator of a listeriosis patient's home, as well as samples\nobtained from various retail outlets. They were also traced to Jensen\nFarms.\n\nJensen Farms has voluntarily recalled the melons in question, which it\nsays were shipped between 29 Jul and 10 Sep 2011. They were sent to\nIllinois, Wyoming, Tennessee, Utah, Texas, Colorado, Minnesota,\nKansas, New Mexico, North Carolina, Missouri, Nebraska, Oklahoma,\nArizona, New Jersey, New York, and Pennsylvania.\n\nThey carry stickers that say either, \"Product of USA - Frontera\nProduce - Colorado Fresh - Rocky Ford\" or \"Jensen Farms - Sweet Rocky\nFords.\"\n\nAnyone who has, or may have had cantaloupes from Jensen Farms is\nadvised to throw them away. Do not try to clean the melons.\n\nAdditionally, the CDC warned that _Listeria_ can continue to grow --\neven inside a refrigerator. Caution is advised for everyone who may\nhave had one of the recalled melons, but specifically for people who\nare at high risk.\n\nThe FDA, also represented during Wednesday's [28 Sep 2011] conference\ncall, said this is the 1st known outbreak of listeriosis related to\ncantaloupe. The 10 cantaloupe-related outbreaks in the past decade\nwere connected to salmonella or a virus.\n\nThe worst outbreak of listeriosis on record was in 1985 and traced\nback to Mexican-style cheese.\n\nThe FDA says it has a team working with a team from Colorado to do an\nenvironmental assessment at Jensen Farm's facilities. As part of that\nwork, they're looking at potential contamination from animals, water,\nand the processing facility. So far, they've not reached any\nconclusions.\n\nA couple from Colorado Springs is suing the farm and Walmart because\nof the tainted fruit. According to the lawsuit, obtained by 11 News,\nthey are alleging that a cantaloupe distributed by Jensen Farms and\nsold at a Walmart on Razorback Road in the Springs caused [the man] to\nfall ill with listeriosis. [He] has been hospitalized since 31 Aug\n2011.\n\nIn the lawsuit, the couple claims that the cantaloupe was contaminated\nwith _Listeria_ at the time it was sold, and is directly responsible\nfor [his] illness. They say Jensen Farms and Walmart are both liable\nfor having sold \"food which was defective and not reasonably safe.\"\n\nIf you have questions about listeriosis, call the Colorado Department\nof Public Health and Environment at 1-877-462-2911.\n\nAnyone with questions about the recall can contact Jensen Farms at\n1-800-267-4561 or recall@rfordcantaloupe.com.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[3]\nDate: Wed 28 Sep 2011\nSource: Los Angeles Times [edited]\nhttp://latimesblogs.latimes.com/nationnow/2011/09/listeria-outbreak-linked-to-cantaloupes-could-worsen.html\n\n\nIf in doubt, throw it out. Unless you can be sure of the source of\nthat cantaloupe in your kitchen, it's best to toss it. That's the word\nfrom the US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, which is\ntrying to put a lid on one of the worst listeriosis outbreaks in US\nhistory.\n\nSo far, there are 72 reported cases of listeriosis linked to tainted\ncantaloupes, and 13 deaths. State and local officials say they are\ninvestigating 3 additional deaths that may be connected and the toll\ncould rise, according to the Associated Press.\n\nThe tainted melons that triggered the multi-state listeriosis outbreak\nhave been traced to Jensen Farms in Granada, Colorado.\n\n\"If it's not Jensen farms, it's okay to eat,\" Dr Thomas Frieden, CDC\ndirector, said in a media conference call today [28 Sep 2011]. \"But if\nyou can't confirm that it's not Jensen farms, then it's best to throw\nit out.\"\n\nSome of the cantaloupes were exported out of the country, and the CDC\nhas been issuing recalls both inside and outside the US for all the\naffected melons.\n\nThis outbreak is the largest in a decade and could grow worse, said\nthe CDC's foodborne illness specialist, Dr Barbara Mahon, who also\nparticipated in the media alert. \"To date there's 72 cases and 13\ndeaths... We do expect that the number of cases will increase.\"\n\nThe single largest listeriosis outbreak occurred in 1985, and was\ntraced to soft Mexican-style cheese manufactured by Jalisco Mexican\nProducts Inc. of Artesia. It killed at least 40 people, and also ranks\nas one of the biggest food-contamination cases in California history.\n\nCantaloupes can rot within 2 weeks or so, and go bad even faster once\nthey've been sliced open. The cantaloupes at the center of this\noutbreak -- first flagged on 12 Sep 2011 -- are nearing the outer edge\nof their shelf life, making it less likely they will be eaten with\neach passing day.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Cantaloupes are said to have a shelf life of 2 weeks or so. Since\nJensen Farms, the source of the contaminated melons, voluntarily\nrecalled these melons, which it says were shipped between 29 Jul and\n10 Sep 2011, there should not be many more of these melons being\neaten. However, because the incubation period of listeriosis can be up\nto a month or more, there may be more cases, deaths, miscarriages, or\nstillbirths reported in the future due to consumption of these\n_Listeria_-contaminated melons. - Mod.ML]\nSee Also\nListeriosis, fatal - USA (06): cantaloupe, more cases & deaths\n20110923.2876\nListeriosis, fatal - USA (05): cantaloupe, more cases & deaths\n20110922.2871\nListeriosis, fatal - USA (04): cantaloupe, alert 20110921.2866\nListeriosis, fatal - USA (03): cantaloupe susp. 20110914.2800\nListeriosis, fatal - USA (02): (CO) 20110909.2746\nListeriosis, fatal - USA: (CO) 20110605.1719\n2010\n----\nListeriosis, fatal - USA (03): (TX), recall 20101105.4005\nListeriosis, fatal - USA (02): (TX), recall 20101021.3813\nListeriosis, fatal - USA: (TX) 20100515.1592\nListeriosis, fatal, meat product - Canada: (ON) 20100314.0829\n2009\n----\nListeriosis - Australia (02): airline food, chicken wrap susp\n20090820.2947\nListeriosis - Australia: airline food, chicken wrap susp\n20090807.2793\nListeriosis, fatal - Chile: (Santiago) meat susp, RFI 20090411.1391\nListeriosis, Mexican-style cheeses - USA: risk, recall 20090401.1261\nListeriosis, fatal, meat product - Canada: unconf. 20090307.0957\n2008\n----\nListeriosis, fatal - Chile: (Santiago) cheese susp. 20080118.0223\n2007\n----\nListeriosis - USA: (NC, MA), alert 20071230.4186\nListeriosis, nosocomial - Norway: (Oslo) 20071024.3452\nListeriosis, unpasteurized cheese - USA (IN) 20070425.1351\nListeriosis, sandwiches - UK (England): alert, recall 20070326.1049\n2006\n----\nListeriosis, seafood - USA 20060130.0295\n2005\n----\nListeriosis - USA (TX) 20050824.2491\nListeriosis 20040723.2013\n.................................................sb/ml/mj/lm", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "listeriosis", "meningitis"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2011-09-27 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2011-09-27 00:00:00", "2011-09-16 00:00:00", "1985-03-16 00:00:00", "1998-03-16 00:00:00", "1999-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2011-09-27 00:00:00", "2008-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-17 00:00:00", "2011-09-28 00:00:00", "2011-09-10 00:00:00", "2021-03-17 00:00:00", "1985-03-16 00:00:00", "2011-03-16 00:00:00", "1985-03-16 00:00:00", "2011-09-12 00:00:00", "2011-09-10 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Minnesota", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "NC", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Pennsylvania", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Mexico", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Wyoming", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "California", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New York", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Illinois", "country": {"location": "North Carolina", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tennessee", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "893555", "headline": "PRO/AH> Listeriosis, fatal - USA (08): background", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=893555", "date": "2011-09-30 11:35:10", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS, FATAL - USA (07): CANTALOUPE, MORE CASES AND DEATHS\n****************************************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\nDate: Tue 27 Sep 2011\nSource: New York Times [edited]\nhttp://www.nytimes.com/2011/09/28/business/deaths-from-cantaloupe-listeria-rises.html\n\n\nAt least 13 people in 8 states have died after eating cantaloupe\ncontaminated with _Listeria_ [_monocytogenes_], in the deadliest\noutbreak of foodborne illness in the United States in more than a\ndecade, public health officials said on Tuesday [27 Sep 2011]. Many of\nthe deaths involved elderly people, who are especially susceptible to\nthe aggressive pathogen.\n\nThe cantaloupes were grown by a Colorado company, Jensen Farms, which\nissued a recall earlier this month [September 2011]. The melons, a\ntype marketed as Rocky Ford cantaloupes, named after a region in\nColorado, were sold around the country.\n\nThe federal Centers for Disease Control and Prevention reported that\nsince the outbreak began in late July [2011] at least 72 people had\nfallen ill in 18 states. The agency said that 4 people had died in New\nMexico, 2 in Colorado, 2 in Texas, and one each in Kansas, Maryland,\nMissouri, Nebraska, and Oklahoma. The toll could grow as state health\nofficials wait for test results on other deaths suspected of being\npart of the outbreak.\n\nOfficials said that most of those who died were over age 60. At least\n2 were in their 90s. _Listeria_ is a common but dangerous bacterium\nthat can cause severe illness, especially among the elderly, the very\nyoung, and people with compromised immune systems. The pathogen can\nalso cause pregnant women to have miscarriages. Federal officials have\nso far provided no information about the number of miscarriages or\nstillbirths associated with the outbreak. Pregnant women are 20 times\nas likely as other healthy adults to come down with a severe\ninfection, according to the CDC.\n\nJohn N Sofos, a professor of food safety at Colorado State University,\nsaid that many people who were infected might have only mild symptoms,\nlike diarrhea. But in others, especially those in the most vulnerable\ncategories, the bacteria can aggressively move out of the\ngastrointestinal tract and attack muscle tissue or the spinal cord,\nleading to much more severe illnesses like meningitis. For that\nreason, the death rate in listeriosis outbreaks is often much higher\nthan with other forms of foodborne bacteria.\n\nWilliam Marler, a Seattle lawyer who represents victims of foodborne\nillness, said this outbreak might turn out to be especially deadly\nsimply because cantaloupe is a food eaten by many older people.\nSometimes in outbreaks, it's the population that's consuming the food\nthat drives the numbers, Mr Marler said. In this instance, you've got\na lot of people 60 and older who are consuming cantaloupe.\n\nThe outbreak appeared to be the 3rd worst in the United States\nattributed to any form of foodborne illness, in terms of the number of\ndeaths, since the CDC began regularly tracking such outbreaks in the\nearly 1970s. The deadliest outbreak in the United States since then\noccurred in 1985, when a wave of listeriosis, linked to Mexican-style\nfresh cheese, swept through California. A federal database says 52\ndeaths were attributed to the outbreak, but news reports at the time\nput the number as high as 84.\n\nThe 2nd deadliest outbreak was in 1998 and 1999, when there were at\nleast 14 deaths and 4 miscarriages or stillbirths in a listeriosis\noutbreak linked to hot dogs and delicatessen meats. Some sources put\nthe death toll in that outbreak as high as 21.\n\nWith the updated death toll on Tuesday [27 Sep 2011], the Rocky Ford\ncantaloupe outbreak surpassed the 2008 deaths associated with\nsalmonella-tainted peanuts and peanut butter produced by a Georgia\ncompany, the Peanut Corporation of America. That outbreak, which drew\na large amount of news coverage, killed 9 people and sickened more\nthan 700.\n\nThe huge outbreak this year [2011] in Europe of a rare form of _E.\ncoli_ bacteria attributed to fenugreek sprouts killed at least 50\npeople.\n\n_Listeria_ is a common bacterium that can be found in soil, water,\ndecaying plant matter, and manure. A strain of the organism, called\n_Listeria monocytogenes_, was first found to cause illness linked to\nfood in the early 1980s. Since then, only a handful of listeriosis\noutbreaks have been associated with fresh fruits and vegetables. The\nmajority was caused by tainted meat or dairy products.\n\nIt can take more than 2 months for a person exposed to the bacteria to\nfall ill, which means that it is often difficult to identify a food\nthat carried the pathogen. Unlike some other bacteria, _Listeria_ also\ngrows well at low temperatures, meaning it can be difficult to\neliminate from refrigerated areas used to process or store foods.\n\nThe Food and Drug Administration said it had found the strain of the\nbacterium on melons and on equipment in the Colorado farm's\npackinghouse. It also found the bacteria on melons in a Denver-area\nstore. Investigators have not said how they believe the contamination\noccurred.\n\nThe FDA recommends that consumers rinse all raw produce, including\ncantaloupes, under running water. Firm produce, like melons, should be\nscrubbed with a produce brush. The washed produce should be dried with\na clean cloth or unused paper towel, the agency said.\n\n[Byline: William Neuman]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: Wed 28 Sep 2011\nSource: KKTV [edited]\nhttp://www.kktv.com/home/headlines/D70_Takes_Cantaloupe_Off_Menu_Due_To_Listeria_Scare_129834148.html\n\n\nDr Thomas Frieden, director of the Centers for Disease Control and\nPrevention, said Wednesday [28 Sep 2011] during a conference call with\nmedia that 2 pregnant women were among the 72 confirmed cases of\n_Listeria_ infection linked to cantaloupes grown in Colorado. He also\nconfirmed that this was the deadliest outbreak in more than a decade.\n\nBoth of the pregnant women and their fetuses are expected to be fine,\nbut 13 people have died from the infection. 3 more deaths are also\nsuspected to be connected, but are not yet confirmed by laboratory\ntests.\n\nThe CDC says _Listeria_ infection during pregnancy could lead to\npremature delivery, miscarriage, stillbirth, and other serious health\nproblems.\n\nThe CDC also said that the number of cases and deaths are likely to\nincrease, because symptoms of _Listeria_ infections can develop up to\n2 months after consumption of the contaminated food.\n\nThe _Listeria_ infections were reported in 18 states.\n\nIn this case, laboratory tests have connected the strains of\n_Listeria_ to melons of the \"Rocky Ford\" variety grown by Jensen Farms\nin Holly, Colorado. That particular variety is prized for having a\nhigher sugar contact, and was developed in the Rocky Ford region of\nColorado during the late 1800's.\n\nThe state of Colorado says it has tested melon samples from the\nrefrigerator of a listeriosis patient's home, as well as samples\nobtained from various retail outlets. They were also traced to Jensen\nFarms.\n\nJensen Farms has voluntarily recalled the melons in question, which it\nsays were shipped between 29 Jul and 10 Sep 2011. They were sent to\nIllinois, Wyoming, Tennessee, Utah, Texas, Colorado, Minnesota,\nKansas, New Mexico, North Carolina, Missouri, Nebraska, Oklahoma,\nArizona, New Jersey, New York, and Pennsylvania.\n\nThey carry stickers that say either, \"Product of USA - Frontera\nProduce - Colorado Fresh - Rocky Ford\" or \"Jensen Farms - Sweet Rocky\nFords.\"\n\nAnyone who has, or may have had cantaloupes from Jensen Farms is\nadvised to throw them away. Do not try to clean the melons.\n\nAdditionally, the CDC warned that _Listeria_ can continue to grow --\neven inside a refrigerator. Caution is advised for everyone who may\nhave had one of the recalled melons, but specifically for people who\nare at high risk.\n\nThe FDA, also represented during Wednesday's [28 Sep 2011] conference\ncall, said this is the 1st known outbreak of listeriosis related to\ncantaloupe. The 10 cantaloupe-related outbreaks in the past decade\nwere connected to salmonella or a virus.\n\nThe worst outbreak of listeriosis on record was in 1985 and traced\nback to Mexican-style cheese.\n\nThe FDA says it has a team working with a team from Colorado to do an\nenvironmental assessment at Jensen Farm's facilities. As part of that\nwork, they're looking at potential contamination from animals, water,\nand the processing facility. So far, they've not reached any\nconclusions.\n\nA couple from Colorado Springs is suing the farm and Walmart because\nof the tainted fruit. According to the lawsuit, obtained by 11 News,\nthey are alleging that a cantaloupe distributed by Jensen Farms and\nsold at a Walmart on Razorback Road in the Springs caused [the man] to\nfall ill with listeriosis. [He] has been hospitalized since 31 Aug\n2011.\n\nIn the lawsuit, the couple claims that the cantaloupe was contaminated\nwith _Listeria_ at the time it was sold, and is directly responsible\nfor [his] illness. They say Jensen Farms and Walmart are both liable\nfor having sold \"food which was defective and not reasonably safe.\"\n\nIf you have questions about listeriosis, call the Colorado Department\nof Public Health and Environment at 1-877-462-2911.\n\nAnyone with questions about the recall can contact Jensen Farms at\n1-800-267-4561 or recall@rfordcantaloupe.com.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[3]\nDate: Wed 28 Sep 2011\nSource: Los Angeles Times [edited]\nhttp://latimesblogs.latimes.com/nationnow/2011/09/listeria-outbreak-linked-to-cantaloupes-could-worsen.html\n\n\nIf in doubt, throw it out. Unless you can be sure of the source of\nthat cantaloupe in your kitchen, it's best to toss it. That's the word\nfrom the US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, which is\ntrying to put a lid on one of the worst listeriosis outbreaks in US\nhistory.\n\nSo far, there are 72 reported cases of listeriosis linked to tainted\ncantaloupes, and 13 deaths. State and local officials say they are\ninvestigating 3 additional deaths that may be connected and the toll\ncould rise, according to the Associated Press.\n\nThe tainted melons that triggered the multi-state listeriosis outbreak\nhave been traced to Jensen Farms in Granada, Colorado.\n\n\"If it's not Jensen farms, it's okay to eat,\" Dr Thomas Frieden, CDC\ndirector, said in a media conference call today [28 Sep 2011]. \"But if\nyou can't confirm that it's not Jensen farms, then it's best to throw\nit out.\"\n\nSome of the cantaloupes were exported out of the country, and the CDC\nhas been issuing recalls both inside and outside the US for all the\naffected melons.\n\nThis outbreak is the largest in a decade and could grow worse, said\nthe CDC's foodborne illness specialist, Dr Barbara Mahon, who also\nparticipated in the media alert. \"To date there's 72 cases and 13\ndeaths... We do expect that the number of cases will increase.\"\n\nThe single largest listeriosis outbreak occurred in 1985, and was\ntraced to soft Mexican-style cheese manufactured by Jalisco Mexican\nProducts Inc. of Artesia. It killed at least 40 people, and also ranks\nas one of the biggest food-contamination cases in California history.\n\nCantaloupes can rot within 2 weeks or so, and go bad even faster once\nthey've been sliced open. The cantaloupes at the center of this\noutbreak -- first flagged on 12 Sep 2011 -- are nearing the outer edge\nof their shelf life, making it less likely they will be eaten with\neach passing day.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Cantaloupes are said to have a shelf life of 2 weeks or so. Since\nJensen Farms, the source of the contaminated melons, voluntarily\nrecalled these melons, which it says were shipped between 29 Jul and\n10 Sep 2011, there should not be many more of these melons being\neaten. However, because the incubation period of listeriosis can be up\nto a month or more, there may be more cases, deaths, miscarriages, or\nstillbirths reported in the future due to consumption of these\n_Listeria_-contaminated melons. - Mod.ML]\nSee Also\nListeriosis, fatal - USA (06): cantaloupe, more cases & deaths\n20110923.2876\nListeriosis, fatal - USA (05): cantaloupe, more cases & deaths\n20110922.2871\nListeriosis, fatal - USA (04): cantaloupe, alert 20110921.2866\nListeriosis, fatal - USA (03): cantaloupe susp. 20110914.2800\nListeriosis, fatal - USA (02): (CO) 20110909.2746\nListeriosis, fatal - USA: (CO) 20110605.1719\n2010\n----\nListeriosis, fatal - USA (03): (TX), recall 20101105.4005\nListeriosis, fatal - USA (02): (TX), recall 20101021.3813\nListeriosis, fatal - USA: (TX) 20100515.1592\nListeriosis, fatal, meat product - Canada: (ON) 20100314.0829\n2009\n----\nListeriosis - Australia (02): airline food, chicken wrap susp\n20090820.2947\nListeriosis - Australia: airline food, chicken wrap susp\n20090807.2793\nListeriosis, fatal - Chile: (Santiago) meat susp, RFI 20090411.1391\nListeriosis, Mexican-style cheeses - USA: risk, recall 20090401.1261\nListeriosis, fatal, meat product - Canada: unconf. 20090307.0957\n2008\n----\nListeriosis, fatal - Chile: (Santiago) cheese susp. {"location": "North Carolina", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tennessee", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "892475", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis, fatal - USA (07): cantaloupe, more cases & deaths", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=892475", "date": "2011-09-30 11:35:10", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS, FATAL - USA (07): CANTALOUPE, MORE CASES AND DEATHS\n****************************************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\nDate: Tue 27 Sep 2011\nSource: New York Times [edited]\nhttp://www.nytimes.com/2011/09/28/business/deaths-from-cantaloupe-listeria-rises.html\n\n\nAt least 13 people in 8 states have died after eating cantaloupe\ncontaminated with _Listeria_ [_monocytogenes_], in the deadliest\noutbreak of foodborne illness in the United States in more than a\ndecade, public health officials said on Tuesday [27 Sep 2011]. Many of\nthe deaths involved elderly people, who are especially susceptible to\nthe aggressive pathogen.\n\nThe cantaloupes were grown by a Colorado company, Jensen Farms, which\nissued a recall earlier this month [September 2011]. The melons, a\ntype marketed as Rocky Ford cantaloupes, named after a region in\nColorado, were sold around the country.\n\nThe federal Centers for Disease Control and Prevention reported that\nsince the outbreak began in late July [2011] at least 72 people had\nfallen ill in 18 states. The agency said that 4 people had died in New\nMexico, 2 in Colorado, 2 in Texas, and one each in Kansas, Maryland,\nMissouri, Nebraska, and Oklahoma. The toll could grow as state health\nofficials wait for test results on other deaths suspected of being\npart of the outbreak.\n\nOfficials said that most of those who died were over age 60. At least\n2 were in their 90s. _Listeria_ is a common but dangerous bacterium\nthat can cause severe illness, especially among the elderly, the very\nyoung, and people with compromised immune systems. The pathogen can\nalso cause pregnant women to have miscarriages. Federal officials have\nso far provided no information about the number of miscarriages or\nstillbirths associated with the outbreak. Pregnant women are 20 times\nas likely as other healthy adults to come down with a severe\ninfection, according to the CDC.\n\nJohn N Sofos, a professor of food safety at Colorado State University,\nsaid that many people who were infected might have only mild symptoms,\nlike diarrhea. But in others, especially those in the most vulnerable\ncategories, the bacteria can aggressively move out of the\ngastrointestinal tract and attack muscle tissue or the spinal cord,\nleading to much more severe illnesses like meningitis. For that\nreason, the death rate in listeriosis outbreaks is often much higher\nthan with other forms of foodborne bacteria.\n\nWilliam Marler, a Seattle lawyer who represents victims of foodborne\nillness, said this outbreak might turn out to be especially deadly\nsimply because cantaloupe is a food eaten by many older people.\nSometimes in outbreaks, it's the population that's consuming the food\nthat drives the numbers, Mr Marler said. In this instance, you've got\na lot of people 60 and older who are consuming cantaloupe.\n\nThe outbreak appeared to be the 3rd worst in the United States\nattributed to any form of foodborne illness, in terms of the number of\ndeaths, since the CDC began regularly tracking such outbreaks in the\nearly 1970s. The deadliest outbreak in the United States since then\noccurred in 1985, when a wave of listeriosis, linked to Mexican-style\nfresh cheese, swept through California. A federal database says 52\ndeaths were attributed to the outbreak, but news reports at the time\nput the number as high as 84.\n\nThe 2nd deadliest outbreak was in 1998 and 1999, when there were at\nleast 14 deaths and 4 miscarriages or stillbirths in a listeriosis\noutbreak linked to hot dogs and delicatessen meats. Some sources put\nthe death toll in that outbreak as high as 21.\n\nWith the updated death toll on Tuesday [27 Sep 2011], the Rocky Ford\ncantaloupe outbreak surpassed the 2008 deaths associated with\nsalmonella-tainted peanuts and peanut butter produced by a Georgia\ncompany, the Peanut Corporation of America. That outbreak, which drew\na large amount of news coverage, killed 9 people and sickened more\nthan 700.\n\nThe huge outbreak this year [2011] in Europe of a rare form of _E.\ncoli_ bacteria attributed to fenugreek sprouts killed at least 50\npeople.\n\n_Listeria_ is a common bacterium that can be found in soil, water,\ndecaying plant matter, and manure. A strain of the organism, called\n_Listeria monocytogenes_, was first found to cause illness linked to\nfood in the early 1980s. Since then, only a handful of listeriosis\noutbreaks have been associated with fresh fruits and vegetables. The\nmajority was caused by tainted meat or dairy products.\n\nIt can take more than 2 months for a person exposed to the bacteria to\nfall ill, which means that it is often difficult to identify a food\nthat carried the pathogen. Unlike some other bacteria, _Listeria_ also\ngrows well at low temperatures, meaning it can be difficult to\neliminate from refrigerated areas used to process or store foods.\n\nThe Food and Drug Administration said it had found the strain of the\nbacterium on melons and on equipment in the Colorado farm's\npackinghouse. It also found the bacteria on melons in a Denver-area\nstore. Investigators have not said how they believe the contamination\noccurred.\n\nThe FDA recommends that consumers rinse all raw produce, including\ncantaloupes, under running water. Firm produce, like melons, should be\nscrubbed with a produce brush. The washed produce should be dried with\na clean cloth or unused paper towel, the agency said.\n\n[Byline: William Neuman]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: Wed 28 Sep 2011\nSource: KKTV [edited]\nhttp://www.kktv.com/home/headlines/D70_Takes_Cantaloupe_Off_Menu_Due_To_Listeria_Scare_129834148.html\n\n\nDr Thomas Frieden, director of the Centers for Disease Control and\nPrevention, said Wednesday [28 Sep 2011] during a conference call with\nmedia that 2 pregnant women were among the 72 confirmed cases of\n_Listeria_ infection linked to cantaloupes grown in Colorado. He also\nconfirmed that this was the deadliest outbreak in more than a decade.\n\nBoth of the pregnant women and their fetuses are expected to be fine,\nbut 13 people have died from the infection. 3 more deaths are also\nsuspected to be connected, but are not yet confirmed by laboratory\ntests.\n\nThe CDC says _Listeria_ infection during pregnancy could lead to\npremature delivery, miscarriage, stillbirth, and other serious health\nproblems.\n\nThe CDC also said that the number of cases and deaths are likely to\nincrease, because symptoms of _Listeria_ infections can develop up to\n2 months after consumption of the contaminated food.\n\nThe _Listeria_ infections were reported in 18 states.\n\nIn this case, laboratory tests have connected the strains of\n_Listeria_ to melons of the \"Rocky Ford\" variety grown by Jensen Farms\nin Holly, Colorado. That particular variety is prized for having a\nhigher sugar contact, and was developed in the Rocky Ford region of\nColorado during the late 1800's.\n\nThe state of Colorado says it has tested melon samples from the\nrefrigerator of a listeriosis patient's home, as well as samples\nobtained from various retail outlets. They were also traced to Jensen\nFarms.\n\nJensen Farms has voluntarily recalled the melons in question, which it\nsays were shipped between 29 Jul and 10 Sep 2011. They were sent to\nIllinois, Wyoming, Tennessee, Utah, Texas, Colorado, Minnesota,\nKansas, New Mexico, North Carolina, Missouri, Nebraska, Oklahoma,\nArizona, New Jersey, New York, and Pennsylvania.\n\nThey carry stickers that say either, \"Product of USA - Frontera\nProduce - Colorado Fresh - Rocky Ford\" or \"Jensen Farms - Sweet Rocky\nFords.\"\n\nAnyone who has, or may have had cantaloupes from Jensen Farms is\nadvised to throw them away. Do not try to clean the melons.\n\nAdditionally, the CDC warned that _Listeria_ can continue to grow --\neven inside a refrigerator. Caution is advised for everyone who may\nhave had one of the recalled melons, but specifically for people who\nare at high risk.\n\nThe FDA, also represented during Wednesday's [28 Sep 2011] conference\ncall, said this is the 1st known outbreak of listeriosis related to\ncantaloupe. The 10 cantaloupe-related outbreaks in the past decade\nwere connected to salmonella or a virus.\n\nThe worst outbreak of listeriosis on record was in 1985 and traced\nback to Mexican-style cheese.\n\nThe FDA says it has a team working with a team from Colorado to do an\nenvironmental assessment at Jensen Farm's facilities. As part of that\nwork, they're looking at potential contamination from animals, water,\nand the processing facility. So far, they've not reached any\nconclusions.\n\nA couple from Colorado Springs is suing the farm and Walmart because\nof the tainted fruit. According to the lawsuit, obtained by 11 News,\nthey are alleging that a cantaloupe distributed by Jensen Farms and\nsold at a Walmart on Razorback Road in the Springs caused [the man] to\nfall ill with listeriosis. [He] has been hospitalized since 31 Aug\n2011.\n\nIn the lawsuit, the couple claims that the cantaloupe was contaminated\nwith _Listeria_ at the time it was sold, and is directly responsible\nfor [his] illness. They say Jensen Farms and Walmart are both liable\nfor having sold \"food which was defective and not reasonably safe.\"\n\nIf you have questions about listeriosis, call the Colorado Department\nof Public Health and Environment at 1-877-462-2911.\n\nAnyone with questions about the recall can contact Jensen Farms at\n1-800-267-4561 or recall@rfordcantaloupe.com.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[3]\nDate: Wed 28 Sep 2011\nSource: Los Angeles Times [edited]\nhttp://latimesblogs.latimes.com/nationnow/2011/09/listeria-outbreak-linked-to-cantaloupes-could-worsen.html\n\n\nIf in doubt, throw it out. Unless you can be sure of the source of\nthat cantaloupe in your kitchen, it's best to toss it. That's the word\nfrom the US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, which is\ntrying to put a lid on one of the worst listeriosis outbreaks in US\nhistory.\n\nSo far, there are 72 reported cases of listeriosis linked to tainted\ncantaloupes, and 13 deaths. State and local officials say they are\ninvestigating 3 additional deaths that may be connected and the toll\ncould rise, according to the Associated Press.\n\nThe tainted melons that triggered the multi-state listeriosis outbreak\nhave been traced to Jensen Farms in Granada, Colorado.\n\n\"If it's not Jensen farms, it's okay to eat,\" Dr Thomas Frieden, CDC\ndirector, said in a media conference call today [28 Sep 2011]. \"But if\nyou can't confirm that it's not Jensen farms, then it's best to throw\nit out.\"\n\nSome of the cantaloupes were exported out of the country, and the CDC\nhas been issuing recalls both inside and outside the US for all the\naffected melons.\n\nThis outbreak is the largest in a decade and could grow worse, said\nthe CDC's foodborne illness specialist, Dr Barbara Mahon, who also\nparticipated in the media alert. \"To date there's 72 cases and 13\ndeaths... We do expect that the number of cases will increase.\"\n\nThe single largest listeriosis outbreak occurred in 1985, and was\ntraced to soft Mexican-style cheese manufactured by Jalisco Mexican\nProducts Inc. of Artesia. It killed at least 40 people, and also ranks\nas one of the biggest food-contamination cases in California history.\n\nCantaloupes can rot within 2 weeks or so, and go bad even faster once\nthey've been sliced open. The cantaloupes at the center of this\noutbreak -- first flagged on 12 Sep 2011 -- are nearing the outer edge\nof their shelf life, making it less likely they will be eaten with\neach passing day.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Cantaloupes are said to have a shelf life of 2 weeks or so. Since\nJensen Farms, the source of the contaminated melons, voluntarily\nrecalled these melons, which it says were shipped between 29 Jul and\n10 Sep 2011, there should not be many more of these melons being\neaten. However, because the incubation period of listeriosis can be up\nto a month or more, there may be more cases, deaths, miscarriages, or\nstillbirths reported in the future due to consumption of these\n_Listeria_-contaminated melons. - Mod.ML]\nSee Also\nListeriosis, fatal - USA (06): cantaloupe, more cases & deaths\n20110923.2876\nListeriosis, fatal - USA (05): cantaloupe, more cases & deaths\n20110922.2871\nListeriosis, fatal - USA (04): cantaloupe, alert 20110921.2866\nListeriosis, fatal - USA (03): cantaloupe susp. 20110914.2800\nListeriosis, fatal - USA (02): (CO) 20110909.2746\nListeriosis, fatal - USA: (CO) 20110605.1719\n2010\n----\nListeriosis, fatal - USA (03): (TX), recall 20101105.4005\nListeriosis, fatal - USA (02): (TX), recall 20101021.3813\nListeriosis, fatal - USA: (TX) 20100515.1592\nListeriosis, fatal, meat product - Canada: (ON) 20100314.0829\n2009\n----\nListeriosis - Australia (02): airline food, chicken wrap susp\n20090820.2947\nListeriosis - Australia: airline food, chicken wrap susp\n20090807.2793\nListeriosis, fatal - Chile: (Santiago) meat susp, RFI 20090411.1391\nListeriosis, Mexican-style cheeses - USA: risk, recall 20090401.1261\nListeriosis, fatal, meat product - Canada: unconf. 20090307.0957\n2008\n----\nListeriosis, fatal - Chile: (Santiago) cheese susp. 20040723.2013\n.................................................sb/ml/mj/lm", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "listeriosis", "meningitis"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2011-09-12 00:00:00", "2011-09-10 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Minnesota", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "NC", more cases & deaths", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=883593", "date": "2010-10-21 21:00:04", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS, FATAL - USA (02): (TEXAS), RECALL\n**********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\n[1]\nDate: Wed 20 Oct 2010\nSource: Foodpoisonjournal.com [edited]\n<http://www.foodpoisonjournal.com/2010/10/articles/foodborne-illness-outbreaks/texas-bexar-travis-and-hidalgo-counties-hit-with-listeria-from-sanger-produce/>\n\n\nOn 20 Oct 2010, the Texas Department of State Health Services (DSHS)\nannounced that it had determined chopped celery was the source of a\n_Listeria_ food poisoning outbreak among Texas residents. Texas DSHS\nhad been investigating the source of 10 cases of listeriosis -- the\nillness caused by the ingestion of _Listeria [monocytogenes]_\nbacteria, 5 of which resulted in death -- for 8 months when\ninvestigators determined that the source of the outbreak was chopped\ncelery sold by Sangar Fresh Cut Produce in San Antonio. Six of the 10\ncases have been conclusively linked to consumption of the chopped\ncelery.\n\nAccording to a health department press release, all cases of\n_Listeria_ food poisoning occurred in Bexar, Travis and Hidalgo\ncounties. All of the reported cases were in people with serious\nunderlying health problems.\n\nSeveral segments of the population are at increased risk for\ncontracting listeriosis. Individuals at increased risk include:\nPregnant women, who are about 20 times more likely than other healthy\nadults to get listeriosis (about 1/3rd of listeriosis cases happen\nduring pregnancy); Newborns, who, rather than the pregnant women\nthemselves, suffer the serious effects of infection in pregnancy;\nPersons with weakened immune systems, [such as] persons with cancer,\ndiabetes, kidney disease, or AIDS (who are almost 300 times more\nlikely to get listeriosis than people with normal immune systems);\nPersons who take glucocorticosteroid medications (such as cortisone);\nand the elderly.\n\nTexas DSHS ordered the celery manufacturer, Sangar Fresh Cut Produce\nin San Antonio, to stop processing food and recall all products\nshipped from the plant since January 2010 after lab testing of\nchopped celery from the plant indicated the presence of _Listeria_.\nAccording to a press release issued by Texas DSHS, conditions in the\nfood processing plant posed \"an immediate and serious threat to human\nlife or health.\"\n\nSangar Fresh Cut Produce recalled products include primarily cut\nfresh produce in sealed packages, which were distributed to\nrestaurants and institutional facilities such as hospitals and\nschools. The chopped celery and other products are not believed to\nhave been sold in grocery stores.\n\nTexas DSHS inspectors reported that they found sanitation issues at\nthe plant during the _Listeria_ outbreak investigation and believe\nthe _Listeria_ bacteria found in the chopped celery may have\ncontaminated other food manufactured in the facility. The agency\nstated in a press release that a condensation leak had been found\nabove the food product area during an inspection. Inspectors also\nfound soil on a food preparation table and identified handwashing\nissues. All of these factors could have contributed to the spread of\n_Listeria_ throughout the food manufacturing plant where celery was\nchopped and packaged.\n\nTexas DSHS food safety personnel are continuing their investigation\ninto the possible points within the facility where the celery became\ncontaminated with _Listeria_ and is contacting distributors,\nrestaurants and institutions believed to have received the recalled\nproducts to ensure the celery and other products sold by Sangar Fresh\nCut Produce does not reach consumers.\n\nThe order issued by Texas DSHS prohibits the plant from reopening\nwithout DSHS approval.\n\nThe incubation period (time between ingestion and the onset of\nsymptoms) for listeriosis ranges from 3 to 70 days and averages 21\ndays.\n\nA person with listeriosis may develop fever, muscle aches, and\nsometimes, gastrointestinal symptoms such as nausea or diarrhea. If\ninfection spreads to the nervous system, symptoms such as headache,\nstiff neck, confusion, loss of balance, or convulsions can occur. In\nimmune-deficient individuals, _Listeria_ can invade the central\nnervous system, causing meningitis and/or encephalitis (brain\ninfection). Infected pregnant women ordinarily experience only a\nmild, flu-like illness; however, infection during pregnancy can lead\nto miscarriage, infection of the newborn or even stillbirth.\n\nNewborns may present clinically with early-onset (less than 7 days)\nor late-onset forms of infection (7 or more days). Those with the\nearly-onset form are often diagnosed in the 1st 24 hours of life with\nsepsis (infection in the blood). Early-onset listeriosis is most\noften acquired from the mother through transplacental transmission.\nLate-onset neonatal listeriosis is less common than the early-onset\nform. Clinical symptoms may be subtle and include irritability, fever\nand poor feeding. The mode of acquisition of late-onset listeriosis\nis poorly understood.\n\n[Byline: Bill Marler]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nSara Volk, PhD\nAssistant Professor, Dept of Biology and Kinesiology\nOur Lady of the Lake University, San Antonio, TX\n<sara.m.volk@gmail.com>\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: Thu 21 Oct 2010\nSource: MySanAntonio.com [edited]\n<http://www.mysanantonio.com/news/health_official_says_celery_was_tainted_105446578.html>\n\n\nState health officials discounted claims by the president of Sangar\nProduce & Processing Co. that the company's celery -- linked to the\ndeaths of 5 people from foodborne illness -- is \"absolutely safe.\"\n\n\"When we test produce, we do a rapid screen initially,\" said Texas\nDepartment of State Health Services spokeswoman Carrie Williams. \"But\nthen we follow up with a very extensive, week long test where we grow\nthe organism to be sure of what we have. The celery was tested\nindependently of other ingredients, and our scientists concluded that\nthe illnesses were linked to the celery processed at the Sangar\nplant.\"\n\nState health officials ordered the closing of the produce plant and\nthe recall of all products shipped from there since January 2010\nfollowing the deaths of 5 people in Bexar, Travis and Hidalgo\ncounties from listeriosis. Five other people have become ill after\neating chopped celery processed by the plant at 1500 S. Zarzamora.\nOfficials say there's no indication celery was shipped outside Texas.\n\nIn a statement, company president Kenneth Sanquist Jr. said\nindependent testing done on the produce found it to be safe, adding,\n\"we are aggressively fighting the state's erroneous findings.\" A call\nto the company headquarters Thursday [21 Oct 2010] morning was\nreferred to the Uresti Law Firm, where an employee said a statement\nwould be released later in the day.\n\nHealth services spokeswoman Williams said Sangar products are sold\nprimarily to restaurants, hospitals and elementary schools, although\nshe would not release the names of any facilities were the celery\nmight have been consumed. Also unknown is the volume of produce\nSangar sold in the 10 months covered by the recall. \"Celery is often\nfrozen and, while you wouldn't want to eat it raw after it was\ndefrosted, it's still often used as an ingredient in other dishes,\"\nexplained Williams.\n\nWilliams would not estimate when the Sangar plant would resume\noperations. \"Right now, we're working with the company to collect\ndistribution information and to get the produce back to protect the\nhealth of consumers,\" she said. \"After that, we'll work with them to\nmake sure the facility is clean and safe and ready to re-open.\"\n\nTracking the outbreak was difficult for several reasons. Only a small\nnumber of cases have been reported, and many of the victims were\nelderly, with poor memories, or had already died. Also, _Listeria\nmonocytogenes_, the bacteria that causes listeriosis, has an\nincubation period of up to 70 days.\n\n[Byline: Richard A. Marini]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Since _Listeria monocytogenes_ in raw food would be killed during\ncooking, the risk of listeriosis is usually greatest from\nready-to-eat products; that is, food that will not be further cooked\nbefore eating. DNA fingerprinting of the isolates would help in\nestablishing epidemiologic linkage. It is not stated in the news\nrelease above whether DNA fingerprinting was done, and if so, whether\nthere was a common DNA fingerprint among the strains of _L.\nmonocytogenes_ isolated from patients in the Texas outbreak, which\nwould indicate a common source, and whether the DNA fingerprint of\nclinical isolates matched that of the strains isolated from the\ncelery processed at the Sangar plant. A detailed discussion of\nlisteriosis can be found in ProMED-mail post 20071230.4186.\n\nAll cases of the Texas listeriosis outbreak occurred in Bexar, Travis\nand Hidalgo counties. Travis County is part of the city of Austin\nmetropolitan area. Austin is the capital of the U.S. state of Texas\nand is located in Central Texas. San Antonio, the county seat of\nBexar County, is located 80 miles to the southwest of Austin. Hidalgo\nCounty is located on the Rio Grande River at the border with Mexico.\n\nThe state of Texas can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail\ninteractive map at\n<http://healthmap.org/promed/en?name=Hidalgo%20County,%20Texas,%20United%20States&g=4707196&v=30.7,-98.667,5>.\nHidalgo County can be located on a map at\n<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Map_of_Texas_highlighting_Hidalgo_County.sv>.\n- Mod.ML]\nSee Also\nListeriosis, fatal - USA: (TX) 20100515.1592\nListeriosis, fatal, meat product - Canada: (ON) 20100314.0829\n2009\n----\nListeriosis - Australia (02): airline food, chicken wrap susp 20090820.2947\nListeriosis - Australia: airline food, chicken wrap susp 20090807.2793\nListeriosis, fatal - Chile: (Santiago) meat susp, RFI 20090411.1391\nListeriosis, Mexican-style cheeses - USA: risk, recall 20090401.1261\nListeriosis, fatal, meat product - Canada: unconf. 20090307.0957\n2008\n----\nListeriosis, fatal - Chile: (Santiago) cheese susp. RFI 20081128.3754\nListeriosis, fatal, meat product - Canada (04) 20081005.3147\nListeriosis, fatal, meat product - Canada: alert, recall 20080821.2605\nListeriosis - USA: (MA), update 20080118.0223\n2007\n----\nListeriosis - USA: (NC, MA), alert 20071230.4186\nListeriosis, nosocomial - Norway: (Oslo) 20071024.3452\nListeriosis, unpasteurized cheese - USA (IN) 20070425.1351\nListeriosis, sandwiches - UK (England): alert, recall 20070326.1049\n2006\n----\nListeriosis, seafood - USA 20060130.0295\n2005\n----\nListeriosis - USA (TX) 20050824.2491\nListeriosis - USA (NY) (05) 20050819.2431\nListeriosis - USA (NY) 20050707.1925\n2004\n----\nListeriosis, cluster - USA (VA) (02): background 20040723.2013\nListeriosis, cluster - USA (VA) 20040722.1999\n............................................ml/msp/lm\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed.
