CopyEd.MJ, edited]\n<http://espanol.news.yahoo.com/s/27112008/54/noticias-entretenimiento-autoridades-chilenas-aclaran-cinco.html>\n\n\nThe Chilean Ministry of Health reported today [27 Nov 2008], that the\nnumber of deaths in the capital [Santiago] caused by an outbreak of\nlisteriosis detected in Brie Lescure cheese has reached 5.\n\nThe new report indicates that the 5 deaths occurred in one newborn,\none young boy, 2 adults, and one immunocompromised person (the most\nrecent victim.)\n\nHealth authorities ordered the recall of Brie Lescure cheese after\nthe bacterium [_Listeria monocytogenes_] was detected in a sample\ntaken from the refrigerator of a 60-year-old man who contracted the\ndisease.\n\nAccording to the official report, to date 91 ill persons have been\nregistered, of which 42 percent are pregnant women, the group at\ngreatest risk.\n\nOf the total number of infected patients, 59 percent are residents of\nthe municipalities of Las Condes & Vitacura, in the eastern section of\nSantiago.\n\nBetween 20 and 25 cases of listeriosis are [routinely] reported\nannually in Chile, but so far in 2008 there have been 91 cases. Ingrid\nHeitman, head of the Chilean Public Health Institute reports that\ncurrently between 2 and 3 cases of listeriosis are being reported per\nweek.\n\nThe disease affects mainly immunocompromised patients and pregnant\nwomen and can result in invasion of the nervous system, meningitis,\nor pneumonia, and even be fatal in newborns and the elderly.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2] Date: Tue 25 Nov 2008\nSource: Yahoo Noticias, Associated Press (AP) report [in Spanish,\ntrans. Mod.JG, edited]\n<http://espanol.news.yahoo.com/s/ap/081125/latinoamerica/ams_gen_chile_listeriosis_1>\n\n\nOn Tuesday [25 Nov 2008] Health authorities ordered the withdrawal\nfrom circulation of a certain type of cheese suspected to be the\ncause of a listeriosis outbreak that had killed at least 4 persons.\n\nDr Ingrid Heitman, head of the Chilean Public Health Institute,\nreported that they ordered the withdrawal from circulation of Brie\nLescure cheese, in which _Listeria_ bacteria were detected, the\ncausative agents of listeriosis, a flu-like illness.\n\nHowever, the exact origin of this outbreak has not been determined\nyet. According to Roberto Belmar, regional secretary of the Chilean\nMinistry of Health, once the origin is confirmed, a sanitary alert\nmay be issued. Until now, health authorities in the capital have\nrecorded 91 cases of the disease, and 60 percent of them originated\nin a wealthy area of the capital [Santiago].\n\nListeriosis is a disease caused by the ingestion of food contaminated\nwith _Listeria monocytogenes_, and it affects mainly pregnant women.\nThis condition may be lethal in babies and in the elderly.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-ESP\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The news releases above report a total of 5 deaths out of 91 reported\ncases of listeriosis, 60 percent of whom live in a wealthy section of\nthe capital, Santiago, but do not give many details as to age, sex, or\nco-morbid conditions -- other than 42 percent were pregnant women --\nor diet history.\n\nThe news releases say that authorities withdrew from circulation a\nbrand of brie, a soft cheese often implicated as a source of\nlisteriosis, in which _Listeria monocytogenes_ was detected, but then\ngo on to say that the exact origin of this outbreak has not as yet\nbeen determined, which implies that this cheese perhaps may not have\nbeen eaten by a significant number of the patients or that a DNA\nfingerprint of the strain isolated from patients and the brie did not\nsubstantiate a link.\n\nIn addition to newborns, pregnant women, and the elderly, mentioned\nabove, those with compromised immune defenses (such as, HIV-infected\npatients) are also more susceptible to severe forms of listeriosis.\n\nWe await a more detailed description of this outbreak, and perhaps\nDNA fingerprinting of isolates from the suspected source and from\npatients that would confirm a linkage.\n\nA detailed discussion of listeriosis can be found in ProMED-mail\nposting no. 20071230.4186.\n\nSantiago, in Chile's central valley, can be located on the\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at\n<http://healthmap.org/promed/en?g=3871336&v=-33.45,-70.667,5>. - USA (NY) (05) 20050819.2431\nListeriosis - USA (NY) 20050707.1925\n2004\n----\nListeriosis, cluster - USA (VA)(02): background 20040723.2013\nListeriosis, cluster - USA (VA) 20040722.1999\n2003\n----\nListeriosis, new prevention regulations - For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "listeriosis", "meningitis"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2008-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2008-11-25 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2002-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "NC", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "England", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Pennsylvania", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "FATAL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Chile", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "395682", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis, fatal, meat product - Canada: (ON)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=395682", "date": "2008-11-28 21:00:36", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS, FATAL - CHILE: (SANTIAGO), CHEESE SUSPECTED, REQUEST FOR\nINFORMATION\n***********\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\n[1]\nDate: Thu 27 Nov 2008\nSource: Yahoo Noticias, Agencia EFE report\n[in Spanish, trans. CopyEd.MJ, edited]\n<http://espanol.news.yahoo.com/s/27112008/54/noticias-entretenimiento-autoridades-chilenas-aclaran-cinco.html>\n\n\nThe Chilean Ministry of Health reported today [27 Nov 2008], that the\nnumber of deaths in the capital [Santiago] caused by an outbreak of\nlisteriosis detected in Brie Lescure cheese has reached 5.\n\nThe new report indicates that the 5 deaths occurred in one newborn,\none young boy, 2 adults, and one immunocompromised person (the most\nrecent victim.)\n\nHealth authorities ordered the recall of Brie Lescure cheese after\nthe bacterium [_Listeria monocytogenes_] was detected in a sample\ntaken from the refrigerator of a 60-year-old man who contracted the\ndisease.\n\nAccording to the official report, to date 91 ill persons have been\nregistered, of which 42 percent are pregnant women, the group at\ngreatest risk.\n\nOf the total number of infected patients, 59 percent are residents of\nthe municipalities of Las Condes & Vitacura, in the eastern section of\nSantiago.\n\nBetween 20 and 25 cases of listeriosis are [routinely] reported\nannually in Chile, but so far in 2008 there have been 91 cases. Ingrid\nHeitman, head of the Chilean Public Health Institute reports that\ncurrently between 2 and 3 cases of listeriosis are being reported per\nweek.\n\nThe disease affects mainly immunocompromised patients and pregnant\nwomen and can result in invasion of the nervous system, meningitis,\nor pneumonia, and even be fatal in newborns and the elderly.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2] Date: Tue 25 Nov 2008\nSource: Yahoo Noticias, Associated Press (AP) report [in Spanish,\ntrans. Mod.JG, edited]\n<http://espanol.news.yahoo.com/s/ap/081125/latinoamerica/ams_gen_chile_listeriosis_1>\n\n\nOn Tuesday [25 Nov 2008] Health authorities ordered the withdrawal\nfrom circulation of a certain type of cheese suspected to be the\ncause of a listeriosis outbreak that had killed at least 4 persons.\n\nDr Ingrid Heitman, head of the Chilean Public Health Institute,\nreported that they ordered the withdrawal from circulation of Brie\nLescure cheese, in which _Listeria_ bacteria were detected, the\ncausative agents of listeriosis, a flu-like illness.\n\nHowever, the exact origin of this outbreak has not been determined\nyet. According to Roberto Belmar, regional secretary of the Chilean\nMinistry of Health, once the origin is confirmed, a sanitary alert\nmay be issued. Until now, health authorities in the capital have\nrecorded 91 cases of the disease, and 60 percent of them originated\nin a wealthy area of the capital [Santiago].\n\nListeriosis is a disease caused by the ingestion of food contaminated\nwith _Listeria monocytogenes_, and it affects mainly pregnant women.\nThis condition may be lethal in babies and in the elderly.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-ESP\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The news releases above report a total of 5 deaths out of 91 reported\ncases of listeriosis, 60 percent of whom live in a wealthy section of\nthe capital, Santiago, but do not give many details as to age, sex, or\nco-morbid conditions -- other than 42 percent were pregnant women --\nor diet history.\n\nThe news releases say that authorities withdrew from circulation a\nbrand of brie, a soft cheese often implicated as a source of\nlisteriosis, in which _Listeria monocytogenes_ was detected, but then\ngo on to say that the exact origin of this outbreak has not as yet\nbeen determined, which implies that this cheese perhaps may not have\nbeen eaten by a significant number of the patients or that a DNA\nfingerprint of the strain isolated from patients and the brie did not\nsubstantiate a link.\n\nIn addition to newborns, pregnant women, and the elderly, mentioned\nabove, those with compromised immune defenses (such as, HIV-infected\npatients) are also more susceptible to severe forms of listeriosis.\n\nWe await a more detailed description of this outbreak, and perhaps\nDNA fingerprinting of isolates from the suspected source and from\npatients that would confirm a linkage.\n\nA detailed discussion of listeriosis can be found in ProMED-mail\nposting no. 20071230.4186.\n\nSantiago, in Chile's central valley, can be located on the\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at\n<http://healthmap.org/promed/en?g=3871336&v=-33.45,-70.667,5>. - Mod.ML]\nSee Also\nListeriosis - USA: (MA), update 20080118.0223\nListeriosis, fatal, meat product - Canada (04) 20081005.3147\n2007\n----\nListeriosis - USA: (NC, MA), alert 20071230.4186\nListeriosis, nosocomial - Norway: (Oslo) 20071024.3452\nListeriosis, unpasteurized cheese - USA (IN) 20070425.1351\nListeriosis, sandwiches - UK (England): alert, recall 20070326.1049\n2005\n----\nListeriosis - USA (TX) 20050824.2491\nListeriosis - USA (NY) (05) 20050819.2431\nListeriosis - USA (NY) 20050707.1925\n2004\n----\nListeriosis, cluster - USA (VA)(02): background 20040723.2013\nListeriosis, cluster - USA (VA) 20040722.1999\n2003\n----\nListeriosis, new prevention regulations - For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "listeriosis", "meningitis"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2008-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2008-11-25 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2002-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "NC", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "England", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Pennsylvania", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "FATAL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Chile", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "272652", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis - Australia (02): airline food, chicken wrap susp", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=272652", "date": "2008-11-28 21:00:36", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS, FATAL - CHILE: (SANTIAGO), CHEESE SUSPECTED, REQUEST FOR\nINFORMATION\n***********\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\n[1]\nDate: Thu 27 Nov 2008\nSource: Yahoo Noticias, Agencia EFE report\n[in Spanish, trans. CopyEd.MJ, edited]\n<http://espanol.news.yahoo.com/s/27112008/54/noticias-entretenimiento-autoridades-chilenas-aclaran-cinco.html>\n\n\nThe Chilean Ministry of Health reported today [27 Nov 2008], that the\nnumber of deaths in the capital [Santiago] caused by an outbreak of\nlisteriosis detected in Brie Lescure cheese has reached 5.\n\nThe new report indicates that the 5 deaths occurred in one newborn,\none young boy, 2 adults, and one immunocompromised person (the most\nrecent victim.)\n\nHealth authorities ordered the recall of Brie Lescure cheese after\nthe bacterium [_Listeria monocytogenes_] was detected in a sample\ntaken from the refrigerator of a 60-year-old man who contracted the\ndisease.\n\nAccording to the official report, to date 91 ill persons have been\nregistered, of which 42 percent are pregnant women, the group at\ngreatest risk.\n\nOf the total number of infected patients, 59 percent are residents of\nthe municipalities of Las Condes & Vitacura, in the eastern section of\nSantiago.\n\nBetween 20 and 25 cases of listeriosis are [routinely] reported\nannually in Chile, but so far in 2008 there have been 91 cases. Ingrid\nHeitman, head of the Chilean Public Health Institute reports that\ncurrently between 2 and 3 cases of listeriosis are being reported per\nweek.\n\nThe disease affects mainly immunocompromised patients and pregnant\nwomen and can result in invasion of the nervous system, meningitis,\nor pneumonia, and even be fatal in newborns and the elderly.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2] Date: Tue 25 Nov 2008\nSource: Yahoo Noticias, Associated Press (AP) report [in Spanish,\ntrans. Mod.JG, edited]\n<http://espanol.news.yahoo.com/s/ap/081125/latinoamerica/ams_gen_chile_listeriosis_1>\n\n\nOn Tuesday [25 Nov 2008] Health authorities ordered the withdrawal\nfrom circulation of a certain type of cheese suspected to be the\ncause of a listeriosis outbreak that had killed at least 4 persons.\n\nDr Ingrid Heitman, head of the Chilean Public Health Institute,\nreported that they ordered the withdrawal from circulation of Brie\nLescure cheese, in which _Listeria_ bacteria were detected, the\ncausative agents of listeriosis, a flu-like illness.\n\nHowever, the exact origin of this outbreak has not been determined\nyet. According to Roberto Belmar, regional secretary of the Chilean\nMinistry of Health, once the origin is confirmed, a sanitary alert\nmay be issued. Until now, health authorities in the capital have\nrecorded 91 cases of the disease, and 60 percent of them originated\nin a wealthy area of the capital [Santiago].\n\nListeriosis is a disease caused by the ingestion of food contaminated\nwith _Listeria monocytogenes_, and it affects mainly pregnant women.\nThis condition may be lethal in babies and in the elderly.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-ESP\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The news releases above report a total of 5 deaths out of 91 reported\ncases of listeriosis, 60 percent of whom live in a wealthy section of\nthe capital, Santiago, but do not give many details as to age, sex, or\nco-morbid conditions -- other than 42 percent were pregnant women --\nor diet history.\n\nThe news releases say that authorities withdrew from circulation a\nbrand of brie, a soft cheese often implicated as a source of\nlisteriosis, in which _Listeria monocytogenes_ was detected, but then\ngo on to say that the exact origin of this outbreak has not as yet\nbeen determined, which implies that this cheese perhaps may not have\nbeen eaten by a significant number of the patients or that a DNA\nfingerprint of the strain isolated from patients and the brie did not\nsubstantiate a link.\n\nIn addition to newborns, pregnant women, and the elderly, mentioned\nabove, those with compromised immune defenses (such as, HIV-infected\npatients) are also more susceptible to severe forms of listeriosis.\n\nWe await a more detailed description of this outbreak, and perhaps\nDNA fingerprinting of isolates from the suspected source and from\npatients that would confirm a linkage.\n\nA detailed discussion of listeriosis can be found in ProMED-mail\nposting no. 20071230.4186.\n\nSantiago, in Chile's central valley, can be located on the\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at\n<http://healthmap.org/promed/en?g=3871336&v=-33.45,-70.667,5>. - Mod.ML]\nSee Also\nListeriosis - USA: (MA), update 20080118.0223\nListeriosis, fatal, meat product - Canada (04) 20081005.3147\n2007\n----\nListeriosis - USA: (NC, MA), alert 20071230.4186\nListeriosis, nosocomial - Norway: (Oslo) 20071024.3452\nListeriosis, unpasteurized cheese - USA (IN) 20070425.1351\nListeriosis, sandwiches - UK (England): alert, recall 20070326.1049\n2005\n----\nListeriosis - USA (TX) 20050824.2491\nListeriosis - USA (NY) (05) 20050819.2431\nListeriosis - USA (NY) 20050707.1925\n2004\n----\nListeriosis, cluster - USA (VA)(02): background 20040723.2013\nListeriosis, cluster - USA (VA) 20040722.1999\n2003\n----\nListeriosis, new prevention regulations - USA 20030605.1385\n2002\n----\nListeriosis - USA (multistate) (08) 20021015.5556\nListeriosis - USA (Pennsylvania) 20020901.5205\n2000\n----\nListeriosis - France (05) 20000226.0261\nListeriosis - France 20000219.0224\n........................................ml/jw/mj/jw\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. CopyEd.MJ, edited]\n<http://espanol.news.yahoo.com/s/27112008/54/noticias-entretenimiento-autoridades-chilenas-aclaran-cinco.html>\n\n\nThe Chilean Ministry of Health reported today [27 Nov 2008], that the\nnumber of deaths in the capital [Santiago] caused by an outbreak of\nlisteriosis detected in Brie Lescure cheese has reached 5.\n\nThe new report indicates that the 5 deaths occurred in one newborn,\none young boy, 2 adults, and one immunocompromised person (the most\nrecent victim.)\n\nHealth authorities ordered the recall of Brie Lescure cheese after\nthe bacterium [_Listeria monocytogenes_] was detected in a sample\ntaken from the refrigerator of a 60-year-old man who contracted the\ndisease.\n\nAccording to the official report, to date 91 ill persons have been\nregistered, of which 42 percent are pregnant women, the group at\ngreatest risk.\n\nOf the total number of infected patients, 59 percent are residents of\nthe municipalities of Las Condes & Vitacura, in the eastern section of\nSantiago.\n\nBetween 20 and 25 cases of listeriosis are [routinely] reported\nannually in Chile, but so far in 2008 there have been 91 cases. Ingrid\nHeitman, head of the Chilean Public Health Institute reports that\ncurrently between 2 and 3 cases of listeriosis are being reported per\nweek.\n\nThe disease affects mainly immunocompromised patients and pregnant\nwomen and can result in invasion of the nervous system, meningitis,\nor pneumonia, and even be fatal in newborns and the elderly.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2] Date: Tue 25 Nov 2008\nSource: Yahoo Noticias, Associated Press (AP) report [in Spanish,\ntrans. Mod.JG, edited]\n<http://espanol.news.yahoo.com/s/ap/081125/latinoamerica/ams_gen_chile_listeriosis_1>\n\n\nOn Tuesday [25 Nov 2008] Health authorities ordered the withdrawal\nfrom circulation of a certain type of cheese suspected to be the\ncause of a listeriosis outbreak that had killed at least 4 persons.\n\nDr Ingrid Heitman, head of the Chilean Public Health Institute,\nreported that they ordered the withdrawal from circulation of Brie\nLescure cheese, in which _Listeria_ bacteria were detected, the\ncausative agents of listeriosis, a flu-like illness.\n\nHowever, the exact origin of this outbreak has not been determined\nyet. According to Roberto Belmar, regional secretary of the Chilean\nMinistry of Health, once the origin is confirmed, a sanitary alert\nmay be issued. Until now, health authorities in the capital have\nrecorded 91 cases of the disease, and 60 percent of them originated\nin a wealthy area of the capital [Santiago].\n\nListeriosis is a disease caused by the ingestion of food contaminated\nwith _Listeria monocytogenes_, and it affects mainly pregnant women.\nThis condition may be lethal in babies and in the elderly.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-ESP\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The news releases above report a total of 5 deaths out of 91 reported\ncases of listeriosis, 60 percent of whom live in a wealthy section of\nthe capital, Santiago, but do not give many details as to age, sex, or\nco-morbid conditions -- other than 42 percent were pregnant women --\nor diet history.\n\nThe news releases say that authorities withdrew from circulation a\nbrand of brie, a soft cheese often implicated as a source of\nlisteriosis, in which _Listeria monocytogenes_ was detected, but then\ngo on to say that the exact origin of this outbreak has not as yet\nbeen determined, which implies that this cheese perhaps may not have\nbeen eaten by a significant number of the patients or that a DNA\nfingerprint of the strain isolated from patients and the brie did not\nsubstantiate a link.\n\nIn addition to newborns, pregnant women, and the elderly, mentioned\nabove, those with compromised immune defenses (such as, HIV-infected\npatients) are also more susceptible to severe forms of listeriosis.\n\nWe await a more detailed description of this outbreak, and perhaps\nDNA fingerprinting of isolates from the suspected source and from\npatients that would confirm a linkage.\n\nA detailed discussion of listeriosis can be found in ProMED-mail\nposting no. 20071230.4186.\n\nSantiago, in Chile's central valley, can be located on the\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at\n<http://healthmap.org/promed/en?g=3871336&v=-33.45,-70.667,5>. - Ingrid\nHeitman, head of the Chilean Public Health Institute reports that\ncurrently between 2 and 3 cases of listeriosis are being reported per\nweek.\n\nThe disease affects mainly immunocompromised patients and pregnant\nwomen and can result in invasion of the nervous system, meningitis,\nor pneumonia, and even be fatal in newborns and the elderly.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2] Date: Tue 25 Nov 2008\nSource: Yahoo Noticias, Associated Press (AP) report [in Spanish,\ntrans. Mod.JG, edited]\n<http://espanol.news.yahoo.com/s/ap/081125/latinoamerica/ams_gen_chile_listeriosis_1>\n\n\nOn Tuesday [25 Nov 2008] Health authorities ordered the withdrawal\nfrom circulation of a certain type of cheese suspected to be the\ncause of a listeriosis outbreak that had killed at least 4 persons.\n\nDr Ingrid Heitman, head of the Chilean Public Health Institute,\nreported that they ordered the withdrawal from circulation of Brie\nLescure cheese, in which _Listeria_ bacteria were detected, the\ncausative agents of listeriosis, a flu-like illness.\n\nHowever, the exact origin of this outbreak has not been determined\nyet. According to Roberto Belmar, regional secretary of the Chilean\nMinistry of Health, once the origin is confirmed, a sanitary alert\nmay be issued. Until now, health authorities in the capital have\nrecorded 91 cases of the disease, and 60 percent of them originated\nin a wealthy area of the capital [Santiago].\n\nListeriosis is a disease caused by the ingestion of food contaminated\nwith _Listeria monocytogenes_, and it affects mainly pregnant women.\nThis condition may be lethal in babies and in the elderly.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-ESP\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The news releases above report a total of 5 deaths out of 91 reported\ncases of listeriosis, 60 percent of whom live in a wealthy section of\nthe capital, Santiago, but do not give many details as to age, sex, or\nco-morbid conditions -- other than 42 percent were pregnant women --\nor diet history.\n\nThe news releases say that authorities withdrew from circulation a\nbrand of brie, a soft cheese often implicated as a source of\nlisteriosis, in which _Listeria monocytogenes_ was detected, but then\ngo on to say that the exact origin of this outbreak has not as yet\nbeen determined, which implies that this cheese perhaps may not have\nbeen eaten by a significant number of the patients or that a DNA\nfingerprint of the strain isolated from patients and the brie did not\nsubstantiate a link.\n\nIn addition to newborns, pregnant women, and the elderly, mentioned\nabove, those with compromised immune defenses (such as, HIV-infected\npatients) are also more susceptible to severe forms of listeriosis.\n\nWe await a more detailed description of this outbreak, and perhaps\nDNA fingerprinting of isolates from the suspected source and from\npatients that would confirm a linkage.\n\nA detailed discussion of listeriosis can be found in ProMED-mail\nposting no. 20071230.4186.\n\nSantiago, in Chile's central valley, can be located on the\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at\n<http://healthmap.org/promed/en?g=3871336&v=-33.45,-70.667,5>. - For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "listeriosis", "meningitis"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2008-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2008-11-25 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2002-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "NC", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "England", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Pennsylvania", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "FATAL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Chile", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "170308", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis, Mexican-style cheeses - USA: risk, recall", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=170308", "date": "2008-11-28 21:00:36", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS, FATAL - CHILE: (SANTIAGO), CHEESE SUSPECTED, REQUEST FOR\nINFORMATION\n***********\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\n[1]\nDate: Thu 27 Nov 2008\nSource: Yahoo Noticias, Agencia EFE report\n[in Spanish, trans. CopyEd.MJ, edited]\n<http://espanol.news.yahoo.com/s/27112008/54/noticias-entretenimiento-autoridades-chilenas-aclaran-cinco.html>\n\n\nThe Chilean Ministry of Health reported today [27 Nov 2008], that the\nnumber of deaths in the capital [Santiago] caused by an outbreak of\nlisteriosis detected in Brie Lescure cheese has reached 5.\n\nThe new report indicates that the 5 deaths occurred in one newborn,\none young boy, 2 adults, and one immunocompromised person (the most\nrecent victim.)\n\nHealth authorities ordered the recall of Brie Lescure cheese after\nthe bacterium [_Listeria monocytogenes_] was detected in a sample\ntaken from the refrigerator of a 60-year-old man who contracted the\ndisease.\n\nAccording to the official report, to date 91 ill persons have been\nregistered, of which 42 percent are pregnant women, the group at\ngreatest risk.\n\nOf the total number of infected patients, 59 percent are residents of\nthe municipalities of Las Condes & Vitacura, in the eastern section of\nSantiago.\n\nBetween 20 and 25 cases of listeriosis are [routinely] reported\nannually in Chile, but so far in 2008 there have been 91 cases. Ingrid\nHeitman, head of the Chilean Public Health Institute reports that\ncurrently between 2 and 3 cases of listeriosis are being reported per\nweek.\n\nThe disease affects mainly immunocompromised patients and pregnant\nwomen and can result in invasion of the nervous system, meningitis,\nor pneumonia, and even be fatal in newborns and the elderly.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2] Date: Tue 25 Nov 2008\nSource: Yahoo Noticias, Associated Press (AP) report [in Spanish,\ntrans. Mod.JG, edited]\n<http://espanol.news.yahoo.com/s/ap/081125/latinoamerica/ams_gen_chile_listeriosis_1>\n\n\nOn Tuesday [25 Nov 2008] Health authorities ordered the withdrawal\nfrom circulation of a certain type of cheese suspected to be the\ncause of a listeriosis outbreak that had killed at least 4 persons.\n\nDr Ingrid Heitman, head of the Chilean Public Health Institute,\nreported that they ordered the withdrawal from circulation of Brie\nLescure cheese, in which _Listeria_ bacteria were detected, the\ncausative agents of listeriosis, a flu-like illness.\n\nHowever, the exact origin of this outbreak has not been determined\nyet. According to Roberto Belmar, regional secretary of the Chilean\nMinistry of Health, once the origin is confirmed, a sanitary alert\nmay be issued. Until now, health authorities in the capital have\nrecorded 91 cases of the disease, and 60 percent of them originated\nin a wealthy area of the capital [Santiago].\n\nListeriosis is a disease caused by the ingestion of food contaminated\nwith _Listeria monocytogenes_, and it affects mainly pregnant women.\nThis condition may be lethal in babies and in the elderly.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-ESP\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The news releases above report a total of 5 deaths out of 91 reported\ncases of listeriosis, 60 percent of whom live in a wealthy section of\nthe capital, Santiago, but do not give many details as to age, sex, or\nco-morbid conditions -- other than 42 percent were pregnant women --\nor diet history.\n\nThe news releases say that authorities withdrew from circulation a\nbrand of brie, a soft cheese often implicated as a source of\nlisteriosis, in which _Listeria monocytogenes_ was detected, but then\ngo on to say that the exact origin of this outbreak has not as yet\nbeen determined, which implies that this cheese perhaps may not have\nbeen eaten by a significant number of the patients or that a DNA\nfingerprint of the strain isolated from patients and the brie did not\nsubstantiate a link.\n\nIn addition to newborns, pregnant women, and the elderly, mentioned\nabove, those with compromised immune defenses (such as, HIV-infected\npatients) are also more susceptible to severe forms of listeriosis.\n\nWe await a more detailed description of this outbreak, and perhaps\nDNA fingerprinting of isolates from the suspected source and from\npatients that would confirm a linkage.\n\nA detailed discussion of listeriosis can be found in ProMED-mail\nposting no. 20071230.4186.\n\nSantiago, in Chile's central valley, can be located on the\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at\n<http://healthmap.org/promed/en?g=3871336&v=-33.45,-70.667,5>. - Mod.ML]\nSee Also\nListeriosis - USA: (MA), update 20080118.0223\nListeriosis, fatal, meat product - Canada (04) 20081005.3147\n2007\n----\nListeriosis - USA: (NC, MA), alert 20071230.4186\nListeriosis, nosocomial - Norway: (Oslo) 20071024.3452\nListeriosis, unpasteurized cheese - USA (IN) 20070425.1351\nListeriosis, sandwiches - UK (England): alert, recall 20070326.1049\n2005\n----\nListeriosis - USA (TX) 20050824.2491\nListeriosis - USA (NY) (05) 20050819.2431\nListeriosis - USA (NY) 20050707.1925\n2004\n----\nListeriosis, cluster - USA (VA)(02): background 20040723.2013\nListeriosis, cluster - USA (VA) 20040722.1999\n2003\n----\nListeriosis, new prevention regulations - USA 20030605.1385\n2002\n----\nListeriosis - USA (multistate) (08) 20021015.5556\nListeriosis - USA (Pennsylvania) 20020901.5205\n2000\n----\nListeriosis - France (05) 20000226.0261\nListeriosis - France 20000219.0224\n........................................ml/jw/mj/jw\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "listeriosis", "meningitis"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2008-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2008-11-25 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2002-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "NC", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "England", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Pennsylvania", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "FATAL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Chile", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "163273", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis, fatal, meat product - Canada: unconf.", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=163273", "date": "2008-11-28 21:00:36", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS, FATAL - CHILE: (SANTIAGO), CHEESE SUSPECTED, REQUEST FOR\nINFORMATION\n***********\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\n[1]\nDate: Thu 27 Nov 2008\nSource: Yahoo Noticias, Agencia EFE report\n[in Spanish, trans. CopyEd.MJ, edited]\n<http://espanol.news.yahoo.com/s/27112008/54/noticias-entretenimiento-autoridades-chilenas-aclaran-cinco.html>\n\n\nThe Chilean Ministry of Health reported today [27 Nov 2008], that the\nnumber of deaths in the capital [Santiago] caused by an outbreak of\nlisteriosis detected in Brie Lescure cheese has reached 5.\n\nThe new report indicates that the 5 deaths occurred in one newborn,\none young boy, 2 adults, and one immunocompromised person (the most\nrecent victim.)\n\nHealth authorities ordered the recall of Brie Lescure cheese after\nthe bacterium [_Listeria monocytogenes_] was detected in a sample\ntaken from the refrigerator of a 60-year-old man who contracted the\ndisease.\n\nAccording to the official report, to date 91 ill persons have been\nregistered, of which 42 percent are pregnant women, the group at\ngreatest risk.\n\nOf the total number of infected patients, 59 percent are residents of\nthe municipalities of Las Condes & Vitacura, in the eastern section of\nSantiago.\n\nBetween 20 and 25 cases of listeriosis are [routinely] reported\nannually in Chile, but so far in 2008 there have been 91 cases. Ingrid\nHeitman, head of the Chilean Public Health Institute reports that\ncurrently between 2 and 3 cases of listeriosis are being reported per\nweek.\n\nThe disease affects mainly immunocompromised patients and pregnant\nwomen and can result in invasion of the nervous system, meningitis,\nor pneumonia, and even be fatal in newborns and the elderly.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2] Date: Tue 25 Nov 2008\nSource: Yahoo Noticias, Associated Press (AP) report [in Spanish,\ntrans. Mod.JG, edited]\n<http://espanol.news.yahoo.com/s/ap/081125/latinoamerica/ams_gen_chile_listeriosis_1>\n\n\nOn Tuesday [25 Nov 2008] Health authorities ordered the withdrawal\nfrom circulation of a certain type of cheese suspected to be the\ncause of a listeriosis outbreak that had killed at least 4 persons.\n\nDr Ingrid Heitman, head of the Chilean Public Health Institute,\nreported that they ordered the withdrawal from circulation of Brie\nLescure cheese, in which _Listeria_ bacteria were detected, the\ncausative agents of listeriosis, a flu-like illness.\n\nHowever, the exact origin of this outbreak has not been determined\nyet. According to Roberto Belmar, regional secretary of the Chilean\nMinistry of Health, once the origin is confirmed, a sanitary alert\nmay be issued. Until now, health authorities in the capital have\nrecorded 91 cases of the disease, and 60 percent of them originated\nin a wealthy area of the capital [Santiago].\n\nListeriosis is a disease caused by the ingestion of food contaminated\nwith _Listeria monocytogenes_, and it affects mainly pregnant women.\nThis condition may be lethal in babies and in the elderly.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-ESP\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The news releases above report a total of 5 deaths out of 91 reported\ncases of listeriosis, 60 percent of whom live in a wealthy section of\nthe capital, Santiago, but do not give many details as to age, sex, or\nco-morbid conditions -- other than 42 percent were pregnant women --\nor diet history.\n\nThe news releases say that authorities withdrew from circulation a\nbrand of brie, a soft cheese often implicated as a source of\nlisteriosis, in which _Listeria monocytogenes_ was detected, but then\ngo on to say that the exact origin of this outbreak has not as yet\nbeen determined, which implies that this cheese perhaps may not have\nbeen eaten by a significant number of the patients or that a DNA\nfingerprint of the strain isolated from patients and the brie did not\nsubstantiate a link.\n\nIn addition to newborns, pregnant women, and the elderly, mentioned\nabove, those with compromised immune defenses (such as, HIV-infected\npatients) are also more susceptible to severe forms of listeriosis.\n\nWe await a more detailed description of this outbreak, and perhaps\nDNA fingerprinting of isolates from the suspected source and from\npatients that would confirm a linkage.\n\nA detailed discussion of listeriosis can be found in ProMED-mail\nposting no. 20071230.4186.\n\nSantiago, in Chile's central valley, can be located on the\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at\n<http://healthmap.org/promed/en?g=3871336&v=-33.45,-70.667,5>. - RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=131216", "date": "2008-11-28 21:00:36", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS, FATAL - CHILE: (SANTIAGO), CHEESE SUSPECTED, REQUEST FOR\nINFORMATION\n***********\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\n[1]\nDate: Thu 27 Nov 2008\nSource: Yahoo Noticias, Agencia EFE report\n[in Spanish, trans. CopyEd.MJ, edited]\n<http://espanol.news.yahoo.com/s/27112008/54/noticias-entretenimiento-autoridades-chilenas-aclaran-cinco.html>\n\n\nThe Chilean Ministry of Health reported today [27 Nov 2008], that the\nnumber of deaths in the capital [Santiago] caused by an outbreak of\nlisteriosis detected in Brie Lescure cheese has reached 5.\n\nThe new report indicates that the 5 deaths occurred in one newborn,\none young boy, 2 adults, and one immunocompromised person (the most\nrecent victim.)\n\nHealth authorities ordered the recall of Brie Lescure cheese after\nthe bacterium [_Listeria monocytogenes_] was detected in a sample\ntaken from the refrigerator of a 60-year-old man who contracted the\ndisease.\n\nAccording to the official report, to date 91 ill persons have been\nregistered, of which 42 percent are pregnant women, the group at\ngreatest risk.\n\nOf the total number of infected patients, 59 percent are residents of\nthe municipalities of Las Condes & Vitacura, in the eastern section of\nSantiago.\n\nBetween 20 and 25 cases of listeriosis are [routinely] reported\nannually in Chile, but so far in 2008 there have been 91 cases. Ingrid\nHeitman, head of the Chilean Public Health Institute reports that\ncurrently between 2 and 3 cases of listeriosis are being reported per\nweek.\n\nThe disease affects mainly immunocompromised patients and pregnant\nwomen and can result in invasion of the nervous system, meningitis,\nor pneumonia, and even be fatal in newborns and the elderly.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2] Date: Tue 25 Nov 2008\nSource: Yahoo Noticias, Associated Press (AP) report [in Spanish,\ntrans. Mod.JG, edited]\n<http://espanol.news.yahoo.com/s/ap/081125/latinoamerica/ams_gen_chile_listeriosis_1>\n\n\nOn Tuesday [25 Nov 2008] Health authorities ordered the withdrawal\nfrom circulation of a certain type of cheese suspected to be the\ncause of a listeriosis outbreak that had killed at least 4 persons.\n\nDr Ingrid Heitman, head of the Chilean Public Health Institute,\nreported that they ordered the withdrawal from circulation of Brie\nLescure cheese, in which _Listeria_ bacteria were detected, the\ncausative agents of listeriosis, a flu-like illness.\n\nHowever, the exact origin of this outbreak has not been determined\nyet. According to Roberto Belmar, regional secretary of the Chilean\nMinistry of Health, once the origin is confirmed, a sanitary alert\nmay be issued. Until now, health authorities in the capital have\nrecorded 91 cases of the disease, and 60 percent of them originated\nin a wealthy area of the capital [Santiago].\n\nListeriosis is a disease caused by the ingestion of food contaminated\nwith _Listeria monocytogenes_, and it affects mainly pregnant women.\nThis condition may be lethal in babies and in the elderly.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-ESP\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The news releases above report a total of 5 deaths out of 91 reported\ncases of listeriosis, 60 percent of whom live in a wealthy section of\nthe capital, Santiago, but do not give many details as to age, sex, or\nco-morbid conditions -- other than 42 percent were pregnant women --\nor diet history.\n\nThe news releases say that authorities withdrew from circulation a\nbrand of brie, a soft cheese often implicated as a source of\nlisteriosis, in which _Listeria monocytogenes_ was detected, but then\ngo on to say that the exact origin of this outbreak has not as yet\nbeen determined, which implies that this cheese perhaps may not have\nbeen eaten by a significant number of the patients or that a DNA\nfingerprint of the strain isolated from patients and the brie did not\nsubstantiate a link.\n\nIn addition to newborns, pregnant women, and the elderly, mentioned\nabove, those with compromised immune defenses (such as, HIV-infected\npatients) are also more susceptible to severe forms of listeriosis.\n\nWe await a more detailed description of this outbreak, and perhaps\nDNA fingerprinting of isolates from the suspected source and from\npatients that would confirm a linkage.\n\nA detailed discussion of listeriosis can be found in ProMED-mail\nposting no. 20071230.4186.\n\nSantiago, in Chile's central valley, can be located on the\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at\n<http://healthmap.org/promed/en?g=3871336&v=-33.45,-70.667,5>. - For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "listeriosis", "meningitis"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2008-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2008-11-25 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2002-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "NC", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "England", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Pennsylvania", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "FATAL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Chile", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "116881", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis, fatal, meat product - Canada (04)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=116881", "date": "2007-04-25 17:00:02", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS, UNPASTEURIZED CHEESE - USA (INDIANA)\n*************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Wed 25 Apr 2007\nSource: The Indy Channel [edited]\n<http://www.theindychannel.com/news/13091454/detail.html>\n\nSerious health concerns are emerging from recent door-to-door sales\nin Indianapolis, from which at least one person has become seriously\nill. Someone is selling unpasteurized cheese on the city's west side.\nThe Marion County Health Department said it was made aware of the\nbad, white cheese on Tue 24 Apr 2007. Officials are worried that\nothers might buy the product.\nThe cheese was contaminated with a bacteria called _Listeria_.\nExperts said that it takes at least 3 weeks before someone who eats\nsomething contaminated with _Listeria_ to notice symptoms.\n\"If something tastes bad, if it's spoiled, we tend not to eat it. We\navoid it,\" said Dr. Crystal Jones, medical director of acute diseases\nfor the Marion County Health Department. \"_Listeria_ can be in\nsomething that tastes perfectly good. We just don't know it, and if\nwe're in one of those at-risk populations, it can become a very\nserious thing.\"\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Another posting from the litany of diseases associated with\nunpasteurized dairy products...\n_Listeria monocytogenes_ has been associated with such foods as raw\nmilk, supposedly pasteurized fluid milk, cheeses (particularly\nsoft-ripened varieties), ice cream, raw vegetables, fermented\nraw-meat sausages, cold cuts, raw and cooked poultry, raw meats (all\ntypes), and raw and smoked fish. Its ability to grow at temperatures\nas low as 3 C permits multiplication in refrigerated foods. It is\nparticularly associated with intrauterine infection of pregnant women\nand meningitis in individuals with depression of cellular immunity.\nIndianapolis is located in Marion County in central Indiana and can\nbe found on a map at:\n<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indianapolis,_Indiana>.\n- Mod.LL]\nSee Also\nListeriosis, sandwiches - UK (England): alert, recall 20070326.1049\nCampylobacteriosis, unpasteurized milk - USA (UT) (02) 20070324.1033\nCampylobacteriosis, unpasteurized milk - USA (UT) 20070322.1004\nYersiniosis, listeriosis - Canada (ON): unpasteurized milk/cheese 20070319.0968\nSalmonellosis, serotype Typhimurium, raw milk - USA (PA) 20070303.0748\nE. coli O157, unpasteurized milk, 2005 - USA (WA) 20070302.0741\n2006\n----\nFoodborne illness, unpasteurized milk - USA (OH) 20060929.2794\nE. coli O157, unpasteurized milk - USA (CA) (03) 20060929.2791\nE. coli O157, unpasteurized milk - USA (WA): recall 20060929.2790\nE. coli O157, unpasteurized milk - USA (CA) (02): background 20060927.2761\nE. coli O157, unpasteurized milk - USA (CA) 20060922.2706\nListeriosis, seafood - USA 20060130.0295\nE. coli O157, unpasteurized milk - USA (OR, WA) (04) 20060121.0199\n2005\n----\nE. coli O157, unpasteurized milk - USA (OR, WA) 20051216.3622\nShigellosis, unpasteurized milk curds, 2004 - Lithuania (Vilnius) 20051203.3494\nListeriosis - USA (TX) 20050824.2491\nListeriosis - USA (NY) (05) 20050819.2431\nListeriosis - USA (NY) 20050707.1925\nE. coli O157: H7, unpasteurized milk - Canada (ONT) 20050411.1047\n2004\n----\nListeriosis, cluster - Someone is selling unpasteurized cheese on the city's west side.\nThe Marion County Health Department said it was made aware of the\nbad, white cheese on Tue 24 Apr 2007. Officials are worried that\nothers might buy the product.\nThe cheese was contaminated with a bacteria called _Listeria_.\nExperts said that it takes at least 3 weeks before someone who eats\nsomething contaminated with _Listeria_ to notice symptoms.\n\"If something tastes bad, if it's spoiled, we tend not to eat it. We\navoid it,\" said Dr. Crystal Jones, medical director of acute diseases\nfor the Marion County Health Department. \"_Listeria_ can be in\nsomething that tastes perfectly good. We just don't know it, and if\nwe're in one of those at-risk populations, it can become a very\nserious thing.\"\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Another posting from the litany of diseases associated with\nunpasteurized dairy products...\n_Listeria monocytogenes_ has been associated with such foods as raw\nmilk, supposedly pasteurized fluid milk, cheeses (particularly\nsoft-ripened varieties), ice cream, raw vegetables, fermented\nraw-meat sausages, cold cuts, raw and cooked poultry, raw meats (all\ntypes), and raw and smoked fish. Its ability to grow at temperatures\nas low as 3 C permits multiplication in refrigerated foods. It is\nparticularly associated with intrauterine infection of pregnant women\nand meningitis in individuals with depression of cellular immunity.\nIndianapolis is located in Marion County in central Indiana and can\nbe found on a map at:\n<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indianapolis,_Indiana>.\n- Mod.LL]\nSee Also\nListeriosis, sandwiches - Someone is selling unpasteurized cheese on the city's west side.\nThe Marion County Health Department said it was made aware of the\nbad, white cheese on Tue 24 Apr 2007. Officials are worried that\nothers might buy the product.\nThe cheese was contaminated with a bacteria called _Listeria_.\nExperts said that it takes at least 3 weeks before someone who eats\nsomething contaminated with _Listeria_ to notice symptoms.\n\"If something tastes bad, if it's spoiled, we tend not to eat it. We\navoid it,\" said Dr. Crystal Jones, medical director of acute diseases\nfor the Marion County Health Department. \"_Listeria_ can be in\nsomething that tastes perfectly good. We just don't know it, and if\nwe're in one of those at-risk populations, it can become a very\nserious thing.\"\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Another posting from the litany of diseases associated with\nunpasteurized dairy products...\n_Listeria monocytogenes_ has been associated with such foods as raw\nmilk, supposedly pasteurized fluid milk, cheeses (particularly\nsoft-ripened varieties), ice cream, raw vegetables, fermented\nraw-meat sausages, cold cuts, raw and cooked poultry, raw meats (all\ntypes), and raw and smoked fish. Its ability to grow at temperatures\nas low as 3 C permits multiplication in refrigerated foods. It is\nparticularly associated with intrauterine infection of pregnant women\nand meningitis in individuals with depression of cellular immunity.\nIndianapolis is located in Marion County in central Indiana and can\nbe found on a map at:\n<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indianapolis,_Indiana>.\n- Mod.LL]\nSee Also\nListeriosis, sandwiches - For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "salmonellosis", "shigellosis", "yersiniosis", "listeriosis", "meningitis"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2004-03-16 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "1998-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "England", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Indiana", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Indianapolis", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ohio", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Marion County", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "9247", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Listeriosis, sandwiches - UK (England): alert, recall", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=9247", "date": "2006-01-30 23:50:00", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS, SEAFOOD - USA\n***********************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Thu 26 Jan 2006\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: FDA [edited]\n<http://www.fda.gov/bbs/topics/news/2006/NEW01303.html>\n\nFDA seeks injunction against Pacific Shellfish, Inc.\n-----------------------------------------------\nThe USA FDA is seeking a permanent injunction against Pacific\nShellfish, Inc. An injunction is a court order to stop a firm from\nmanufacturing, distributing, processing, or shipping a product. The\ngovernment's complaint, filed on 24 Jan 2006 by the Department of\nJustice in the District Court for the Southern District of\nCalifornia, charges the defendants with violating the Federal Food,\nDrug, and Cosmetic Act by permitting ready-to-eat fish held and\nprocessed in Pacific Shellfish's facility to become contaminated.\nAccording to the complaint, recent FDA inspections in 2004 and 2005\nrevealed the presence of _Listeria monocytogenes_, a disease-causing\nbacterium, on Pacific Shellfish's processing equipment and fish\nproducts. Inspections since 2001 have also documented persistent\nunsanitary conditions at the facility. FDA issued a letter to the\nfirm on 8 Dec 2004, after an inspection revealed unsanitary\nconditions and contamination with _Listeria_. Although the firm\npromised to correct its deficiencies, a 2005 inspection found that a\npersistent strain of _Listeria_ remained and the firm had not\nimplemented all of the promised corrections.\n_Listeria monocytogenesis_ is the causal agent of listeriosis, a\ndisease that can be very serious, even fatal, for high-risk groups\nsuch as pregnant women, unborn babies, newborns, and those with\nimpaired immune systems. Although proper cooking can eliminate the\norganism in fish products, raw fish products, such as those found in\nsome types of sushi, pose a serious health risk if contaminated with\n_Listeria_. Even if fish is intended to be cooked, however, adequate\nsanitation is needed to prevent the spread of this strain throughout\nthe distribution system and to restaurants and consumer homes, where\nit may contaminate ready-to-eat foods. The strain isolated from the\n2004 and 2005 inspections was identical to a strain that has caused\nhuman illness.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[The greatest threat of listeriosis is from ready-to-eat products\nthat do not require further cooking at home. _L. monocytogenes_ in\nraw food that will be cooked before consumption is less of a concern\nto the food industry, since the bacteria are killed during cooking.\nListeriosis can be acquired from seafood, although most think of the\nrisk from processed deli meats 1st. Yearly, recalls of seafood,\nespecially smoked salmon, are posted on FDA's website. Although not\ngenerally linked to large outbreaks, those at high risk, such as\npregnant women and those individuals with compromised cell-mediated\nimmunity, should avoid the food described below.\n_L. monocytogenes_ has been isolated from raw fish, cooked crabs, raw\nand cooked shrimp, raw lobster, surimi (minced, processed fish used\nin the preparation of imitation seafood, especially imitation\nshellfish) and smoked fish (1). Hazards from _L. monocytogenes_ can\nbe prevented by thoroughly cooking seafood and by preventing\ncross-contamination once the seafood is cooked.\nThe CDC's recommendations regarding the risk of acquiring listeriosis\nfrom seafood (2) include not eating refrigerated smoked seafood\nunless it is contained in a cooked dish, such as a casserole.\nRefrigerated smoked seafood, such as salmon, trout, whitefish, cod,\ntuna or mackerel, is most often labeled as \"nova-style,\" \"lox,\"\n\"kippered,\" \"smoked,\" or \"jerky.\" The fish is found in the\nrefrigerator section or sold at deli counters of grocery stores and\ndelicatessens. Canned or shelf-stable smoked seafood may be eaten.\n1. Ward D, Bernard D, Collette R, et al. (Eds.): Hazards Found in\nSeafoods, Appendix III. In HACCP: Hazard Analysis and Critical\nControl Point Training Curriculum, 2nd ed., p. 173-188. UNC-SG-96-02.\nNorth Carolina Sea Grant, Raleigh, NC, 1997.\n2. <http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/dbmd/diseaseinfo/listeriosis_g.htm>. - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\n2005\n----\nListeriosis, nosocomial - Australia (SA (02) 20051215.3598\nListeriosis, nosocomial - Australia (SA) 20051213.3587\nListeriosis - USA (TX) 20050824.2491\nListeriosis - USA (NY)(05) 20050819.2431\nListeriosis - USA (NY) 20050707.1925\nListeriosis, fatal - Switzerland (Neuenburg) (02) 20050624.1777\nListeriosis, fatal - Switzerland (Neuenburg): alert 20050608.1597\n2004\n----\nListeriosis, cluster - USA (VA)(02): background 20040723.2013\nListeriosis, cluster - USA (VA) 20040722.1999\n2003\n----\nListeriosis, new prevention regulations - USA 20030605.1385\n2002\n----\nListeriosis - USA (multistate) (08) 20021015.5556\nListeriosis, poultry - USA: recall 20021014.5550\nListeriosis - USA (multistate) 20020915.5323\nListeriosis - USA (Pennsylvania) 20020901.5205\n2000\n----\nListeriosis - France (05) 20000226.0261\nListeriosis - France 20000219.0224\n1998\n----\nListeriosis, contaminated fish - Sweden:1994/95(02) 19980115.0106\nListeriosis, contaminated fish - Sweden: 1994/95 19980113.0097\n..............ll/msp/mpp\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The reader assumes all risks in\nusing information posted or archived by ProMED-mail. ISID\nand its associated service providers shall not be held\nresponsible for errors or omissions or held liable for any\ndamages incurred as a result of use or reliance upon posted\nor archived material.\n************************************************************\nPlease support ProMED-mail by donating to the 2005 Internet-\na-thon at <http://www.isid.org/netathon2005.shtml>\n************************************************************\nVisit ProMED-mail's web site at <http://www.promedmail.org>.\nSend all items for posting to: promed@promedmail.org\n(NOT to an individual moderator). If you do not give your\nfull name and affiliation, it may not be posted. Send\ncommands to subscribe/unsubscribe, get archives, help,\netc. to: majordomo@promedmail.org. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["listeriosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2006-01-26 00:00:00", "2006-01-24 00:00:00", "2004-03-16 00:00:00", "2005-03-16 00:00:00", "2001-03-16 00:00:00", "2004-12-08 00:00:00", "2005-03-16 00:00:00", "1997-03-16 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2002-03-16 00:00:00", "2005-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "NC", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "North Carolina Sea Grant", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Neuenburg", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Pennsylvania", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Switzerland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "California", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "8988", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Yersiniosis, listeriosis - Canada (ON): unpasteurized milk/cheese", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=8988", "date": "2006-01-30 23:50:00", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS, SEAFOOD - USA\n***********************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Thu 26 Jan 2006\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: FDA [edited]\n<http://www.fda.gov/bbs/topics/news/2006/NEW01303.html>\n\nFDA seeks injunction against Pacific Shellfish, Inc.\n-----------------------------------------------\nThe USA FDA is seeking a permanent injunction against Pacific\nShellfish, Inc. An injunction is a court order to stop a firm from\nmanufacturing, distributing, processing, or shipping a product. The\ngovernment's complaint, filed on 24 Jan 2006 by the Department of\nJustice in the District Court for the Southern District of\nCalifornia, charges the defendants with violating the Federal Food,\nDrug, and Cosmetic Act by permitting ready-to-eat fish held and\nprocessed in Pacific Shellfish's facility to become contaminated.\nAccording to the complaint, recent FDA inspections in 2004 and 2005\nrevealed the presence of _Listeria monocytogenes_, a disease-causing\nbacterium, on Pacific Shellfish's processing equipment and fish\nproducts. Inspections since 2001 have also documented persistent\nunsanitary conditions at the facility. FDA issued a letter to the\nfirm on 8 Dec 2004, after an inspection revealed unsanitary\nconditions and contamination with _Listeria_. Although the firm\npromised to correct its deficiencies, a 2005 inspection found that a\npersistent strain of _Listeria_ remained and the firm had not\nimplemented all of the promised corrections.\n_Listeria monocytogenesis_ is the causal agent of listeriosis, a\ndisease that can be very serious, even fatal, for high-risk groups\nsuch as pregnant women, unborn babies, newborns, and those with\nimpaired immune systems. Although proper cooking can eliminate the\norganism in fish products, raw fish products, such as those found in\nsome types of sushi, pose a serious health risk if contaminated with\n_Listeria_. Even if fish is intended to be cooked, however, adequate\nsanitation is needed to prevent the spread of this strain throughout\nthe distribution system and to restaurants and consumer homes, where\nit may contaminate ready-to-eat foods. The strain isolated from the\n2004 and 2005 inspections was identical to a strain that has caused\nhuman illness.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[The greatest threat of listeriosis is from ready-to-eat products\nthat do not require further cooking at home. _L. monocytogenes_ in\nraw food that will be cooked before consumption is less of a concern\nto the food industry, since the bacteria are killed during cooking.\nListeriosis can be acquired from seafood, although most think of the\nrisk from processed deli meats 1st. Yearly, recalls of seafood,\nespecially smoked salmon, are posted on FDA's website. Although not\ngenerally linked to large outbreaks, those at high risk, such as\npregnant women and those individuals with compromised cell-mediated\nimmunity, should avoid the food described below.\n_L. monocytogenes_ has been isolated from raw fish, cooked crabs, raw\nand cooked shrimp, raw lobster, surimi (minced, processed fish used\nin the preparation of imitation seafood, especially imitation\nshellfish) and smoked fish (1). Hazards from _L. monocytogenes_ can\nbe prevented by thoroughly cooking seafood and by preventing\ncross-contamination once the seafood is cooked.\nThe CDC's recommendations regarding the risk of acquiring listeriosis\nfrom seafood (2) include not eating refrigerated smoked seafood\nunless it is contained in a cooked dish, such as a casserole.\nRefrigerated smoked seafood, such as salmon, trout, whitefish, cod,\ntuna or mackerel, is most often labeled as \"nova-style,\" \"lox,\"\n\"kippered,\" \"smoked,\" or \"jerky.\" The fish is found in the\nrefrigerator section or sold at deli counters of grocery stores and\ndelicatessens. Canned or shelf-stable smoked seafood may be eaten.\n1. Ward D, Bernard D, Collette R, et al. (Eds.): Hazards Found in\nSeafoods, Appendix III. In HACCP: Hazard Analysis and Critical\nControl Point Training Curriculum, 2nd ed., p. 173-188. UNC-SG-96-02.\nNorth Carolina Sea Grant, Raleigh, NC, 1997.\n2. <http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/dbmd/diseaseinfo/listeriosis_g.htm>. - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\n2005\n----\nListeriosis, nosocomial - Australia (SA (02) 20051215.3598\nListeriosis, nosocomial - Australia (SA) 20051213.3587\nListeriosis - USA (TX) 20050824.2491\nListeriosis - USA (NY)(05) 20050819.2431\nListeriosis - USA (NY) 20050707.1925\nListeriosis, fatal - Switzerland (Neuenburg) (02) 20050624.1777\nListeriosis, fatal - Switzerland (Neuenburg): alert 20050608.1597\n2004\n----\nListeriosis, cluster - USA (VA)(02): background 20040723.2013\nListeriosis, cluster - USA (VA) 20040722.1999\n2003\n----\nListeriosis, new prevention regulations - USA 20030605.1385\n2002\n----\nListeriosis - USA (multistate) (08) 20021015.5556\nListeriosis, poultry - USA: recall 20021014.5550\nListeriosis - USA (multistate) 20020915.5323\nListeriosis - USA (Pennsylvania) 20020901.5205\n2000\n----\nListeriosis - France (05) 20000226.0261\nListeriosis - France 20000219.0224\n1998\n----\nListeriosis, contaminated fish - Sweden:1994/95(02) 19980115.0106\nListeriosis, contaminated fish - Sweden: 1994/95 19980113.0097\n..............ll/msp/mpp\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. An injunction is a court order to stop a firm from\nmanufacturing, distributing, processing, or shipping a product. The\ngovernment's complaint, filed on 24 Jan 2006 by the Department of\nJustice in the District Court for the Southern District of\nCalifornia, charges the defendants with violating the Federal Food,\nDrug, and Cosmetic Act by permitting ready-to-eat fish held and\nprocessed in Pacific Shellfish's facility to become contaminated.\nAccording to the complaint, recent FDA inspections in 2004 and 2005\nrevealed the presence of _Listeria monocytogenes_, a disease-causing\nbacterium, on Pacific Shellfish's processing equipment and fish\nproducts. Inspections since 2001 have also documented persistent\nunsanitary conditions at the facility. FDA issued a letter to the\nfirm on 8 Dec 2004, after an inspection revealed unsanitary\nconditions and contamination with _Listeria_. Although the firm\npromised to correct its deficiencies, a 2005 inspection found that a\npersistent strain of _Listeria_ remained and the firm had not\nimplemented all of the promised corrections.\n_Listeria monocytogenesis_ is the causal agent of listeriosis, a\ndisease that can be very serious, even fatal, for high-risk groups\nsuch as pregnant women, unborn babies, newborns, and those with\nimpaired immune systems. Although proper cooking can eliminate the\norganism in fish products, raw fish products, such as those found in\nsome types of sushi, pose a serious health risk if contaminated with\n_Listeria_. Even if fish is intended to be cooked, however, adequate\nsanitation is needed to prevent the spread of this strain throughout\nthe distribution system and to restaurants and consumer homes, where\nit may contaminate ready-to-eat foods. The strain isolated from the\n2004 and 2005 inspections was identical to a strain that has caused\nhuman illness.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[The greatest threat of listeriosis is from ready-to-eat products\nthat do not require further cooking at home. _L. monocytogenes_ in\nraw food that will be cooked before consumption is less of a concern\nto the food industry, since the bacteria are killed during cooking.\nListeriosis can be acquired from seafood, although most think of the\nrisk from processed deli meats 1st. Yearly, recalls of seafood,\nespecially smoked salmon, are posted on FDA's website. Although not\ngenerally linked to large outbreaks, those at high risk, such as\npregnant women and those individuals with compromised cell-mediated\nimmunity, should avoid the food described below.\n_L. monocytogenes_ has been isolated from raw fish, cooked crabs, raw\nand cooked shrimp, raw lobster, surimi (minced, processed fish used\nin the preparation of imitation seafood, especially imitation\nshellfish) and smoked fish (1). Hazards from _L. monocytogenes_ can\nbe prevented by thoroughly cooking seafood and by preventing\ncross-contamination once the seafood is cooked.\nThe CDC's recommendations regarding the risk of acquiring listeriosis\nfrom seafood (2) include not eating refrigerated smoked seafood\nunless it is contained in a cooked dish, such as a casserole.\nRefrigerated smoked seafood, such as salmon, trout, whitefish, cod,\ntuna or mackerel, is most often labeled as \"nova-style,\" \"lox,\"\n\"kippered,\" \"smoked,\" or \"jerky.\" The fish is found in the\nrefrigerator section or sold at deli counters of grocery stores and\ndelicatessens. Canned or shelf-stable smoked seafood may be eaten.\n1. Ward D, Bernard D, Collette R, et al. (Eds.): Hazards Found in\nSeafoods, Appendix III. Yearly, recalls of seafood,\nespecially smoked salmon, are posted on FDA's website. Although not\ngenerally linked to large outbreaks, those at high risk, such as\npregnant women and those individuals with compromised cell-mediated\nimmunity, should avoid the food described below.\n_L. monocytogenes_ has been isolated from raw fish, cooked crabs, raw\nand cooked shrimp, raw lobster, surimi (minced, processed fish used\nin the preparation of imitation seafood, especially imitation\nshellfish) and smoked fish (1). Canned or shelf-stable smoked seafood may be eaten.\n1. Ward D, Bernard D, Collette R, et al. (Eds.): Hazards Found in\nSeafoods, Appendix III. In HACCP: Hazard Analysis and Critical\nControl Point Training Curriculum, 2nd ed., p. 173-188. UNC-SG-96-02.\nNorth Carolina Sea Grant, Raleigh, NC, 1997.\n2. <http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/dbmd/diseaseinfo/listeriosis_g.htm>. - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\n2005\n----\nListeriosis, nosocomial - Australia (SA (02) 20051215.3598\nListeriosis, nosocomial - Australia (SA) 20051213.3587\nListeriosis - USA (TX) 20050824.2491\nListeriosis - USA (NY)(05) 20050819.2431\nListeriosis - USA (NY) 20050707.1925\nListeriosis, fatal - Switzerland (Neuenburg) (02) 20050624.1777\nListeriosis, fatal - Switzerland (Neuenburg): alert 20050608.1597\n2004\n----\nListeriosis, cluster - USA (VA)(02): background 20040723.2013\nListeriosis, cluster - USA (VA) 20040722.1999\n2003\n----\nListeriosis, new prevention regulations - USA 20030605.1385\n2002\n----\nListeriosis - USA (multistate) (08) 20021015.5556\nListeriosis, poultry - USA: recall 20021014.5550\nListeriosis - USA (multistate) 20020915.5323\nListeriosis - USA (Pennsylvania) 20020901.5205\n2000\n----\nListeriosis - France (05) 20000226.0261\nListeriosis - France 20000219.0224\n1998\n----\nListeriosis, contaminated fish - Sweden:1994/95(02) 19980115.0106\nListeriosis, contaminated fish - Sweden: 1994/95 19980113.0097\n..............ll/msp/mpp\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["listeriosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2006-01-26 00:00:00", "2006-01-24 00:00:00", "2004-03-16 00:00:00", "2005-03-16 00:00:00", "2001-03-16 00:00:00", "2004-12-08 00:00:00", "2005-03-16 00:00:00", "1997-03-16 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2002-03-16 00:00:00", "2005-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "NC", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "North Carolina Sea Grant", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Neuenburg", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Pennsylvania", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Switzerland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "California", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "7336", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis, perinatal - Czech Republic: dairy source", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=7336", "date": "2006-01-30 23:50:00", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS, SEAFOOD - USA\n***********************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Thu 26 Jan 2006\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: FDA [edited]\n<http://www.fda.gov/bbs/topics/news/2006/NEW01303.html>\n\nFDA seeks injunction against Pacific Shellfish, Inc.\n-----------------------------------------------\nThe USA FDA is seeking a permanent injunction against Pacific\nShellfish, Inc. An injunction is a court order to stop a firm from\nmanufacturing, distributing, processing, or shipping a product. The\ngovernment's complaint, filed on 24 Jan 2006 by the Department of\nJustice in the District Court for the Southern District of\nCalifornia, charges the defendants with violating the Federal Food,\nDrug, and Cosmetic Act by permitting ready-to-eat fish held and\nprocessed in Pacific Shellfish's facility to become contaminated.\nAccording to the complaint, recent FDA inspections in 2004 and 2005\nrevealed the presence of _Listeria monocytogenes_, a disease-causing\nbacterium, on Pacific Shellfish's processing equipment and fish\nproducts. Inspections since 2001 have also documented persistent\nunsanitary conditions at the facility. FDA issued a letter to the\nfirm on 8 Dec 2004, after an inspection revealed unsanitary\nconditions and contamination with _Listeria_. Although the firm\npromised to correct its deficiencies, a 2005 inspection found that a\npersistent strain of _Listeria_ remained and the firm had not\nimplemented all of the promised corrections.\n_Listeria monocytogenesis_ is the causal agent of listeriosis, a\ndisease that can be very serious, even fatal, for high-risk groups\nsuch as pregnant women, unborn babies, newborns, and those with\nimpaired immune systems. Although proper cooking can eliminate the\norganism in fish products, raw fish products, such as those found in\nsome types of sushi, pose a serious health risk if contaminated with\n_Listeria_. Even if fish is intended to be cooked, however, adequate\nsanitation is needed to prevent the spread of this strain throughout\nthe distribution system and to restaurants and consumer homes, where\nit may contaminate ready-to-eat foods. The strain isolated from the\n2004 and 2005 inspections was identical to a strain that has caused\nhuman illness.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[The greatest threat of listeriosis is from ready-to-eat products\nthat do not require further cooking at home. _L. monocytogenes_ in\nraw food that will be cooked before consumption is less of a concern\nto the food industry, since the bacteria are killed during cooking.\nListeriosis can be acquired from seafood, although most think of the\nrisk from processed deli meats 1st. Yearly, recalls of seafood,\nespecially smoked salmon, are posted on FDA's website. Although not\ngenerally linked to large outbreaks, those at high risk, such as\npregnant women and those individuals with compromised cell-mediated\nimmunity, should avoid the food described below.\n_L. monocytogenes_ has been isolated from raw fish, cooked crabs, raw\nand cooked shrimp, raw lobster, surimi (minced, processed fish used\nin the preparation of imitation seafood, especially imitation\nshellfish) and smoked fish (1). Hazards from _L. monocytogenes_ can\nbe prevented by thoroughly cooking seafood and by preventing\ncross-contamination once the seafood is cooked.\nThe CDC's recommendations regarding the risk of acquiring listeriosis\nfrom seafood (2) include not eating refrigerated smoked seafood\nunless it is contained in a cooked dish, such as a casserole.\nRefrigerated smoked seafood, such as salmon, trout, whitefish, cod,\ntuna or mackerel, is most often labeled as \"nova-style,\" \"lox,\"\n\"kippered,\" \"smoked,\" or \"jerky.\" The fish is found in the\nrefrigerator section or sold at deli counters of grocery stores and\ndelicatessens. Canned or shelf-stable smoked seafood may be eaten.\n1. Ward D, Bernard D, Collette R, et al. (Eds.): Hazards Found in\nSeafoods, Appendix III. In HACCP: Hazard Analysis and Critical\nControl Point Training Curriculum, 2nd ed., p. 173-188. UNC-SG-96-02.\nNorth Carolina Sea Grant, Raleigh, NC, 1997.\n2. <http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/dbmd/diseaseinfo/listeriosis_g.htm>. - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\n2005\n----\nListeriosis, nosocomial - Australia (SA (02) 20051215.3598\nListeriosis, nosocomial - Australia (SA) 20051213.3587\nListeriosis - USA (TX) 20050824.2491\nListeriosis - USA (NY)(05) 20050819.2431\nListeriosis - USA (NY) 20050707.1925\nListeriosis, fatal - Switzerland (Neuenburg) (02) 20050624.1777\nListeriosis, fatal - Switzerland (Neuenburg): alert 20050608.1597\n2004\n----\nListeriosis, cluster - USA (VA)(02): background 20040723.2013\nListeriosis, cluster - USA (VA) 20040722.1999\n2003\n----\nListeriosis, new prevention regulations - USA 20030605.1385\n2002\n----\nListeriosis - USA (multistate) (08) 20021015.5556\nListeriosis, poultry - USA: recall 20021014.5550\nListeriosis - USA (multistate) 20020915.5323\nListeriosis - USA (Pennsylvania) 20020901.5205\n2000\n----\nListeriosis - France (05) 20000226.0261\nListeriosis - France 20000219.0224\n1998\n----\nListeriosis, contaminated fish - Sweden:1994/95(02) 19980115.0106\nListeriosis, contaminated fish - Sweden: 1994/95 19980113.0097\n..............ll/msp/mpp\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed.
