If you do not give your\nfull name and affiliation, it may not be posted. Send\ncommands to subscribe/unsubscribe, get archives, help,\netc. to: majordomo@promedmail.org. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["listeriosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2006-01-26 00:00:00", "2006-01-24 00:00:00", "2004-03-16 00:00:00", "2005-03-16 00:00:00", "2001-03-16 00:00:00", "2004-12-08 00:00:00", "2005-03-16 00:00:00", "1997-03-16 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2002-03-16 00:00:00", "2005-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "NC", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "North Carolina Sea Grant", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Neuenburg", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Pennsylvania", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Switzerland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "California", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "6409", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Listeriosis, perinatal - Czech Republic (Moravia)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6409", "date": "2006-01-30 23:50:00", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS, SEAFOOD - USA\n***********************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Thu 26 Jan 2006\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: FDA [edited]\n<http://www.fda.gov/bbs/topics/news/2006/NEW01303.html>\n\nFDA seeks injunction against Pacific Shellfish, Inc.\n-----------------------------------------------\nThe USA FDA is seeking a permanent injunction against Pacific\nShellfish, Inc. An injunction is a court order to stop a firm from\nmanufacturing, distributing, processing, or shipping a product. The\ngovernment's complaint, filed on 24 Jan 2006 by the Department of\nJustice in the District Court for the Southern District of\nCalifornia, charges the defendants with violating the Federal Food,\nDrug, and Cosmetic Act by permitting ready-to-eat fish held and\nprocessed in Pacific Shellfish's facility to become contaminated.\nAccording to the complaint, recent FDA inspections in 2004 and 2005\nrevealed the presence of _Listeria monocytogenes_, a disease-causing\nbacterium, on Pacific Shellfish's processing equipment and fish\nproducts. Inspections since 2001 have also documented persistent\nunsanitary conditions at the facility. FDA issued a letter to the\nfirm on 8 Dec 2004, after an inspection revealed unsanitary\nconditions and contamination with _Listeria_. Although the firm\npromised to correct its deficiencies, a 2005 inspection found that a\npersistent strain of _Listeria_ remained and the firm had not\nimplemented all of the promised corrections.\n_Listeria monocytogenesis_ is the causal agent of listeriosis, a\ndisease that can be very serious, even fatal, for high-risk groups\nsuch as pregnant women, unborn babies, newborns, and those with\nimpaired immune systems. Although proper cooking can eliminate the\norganism in fish products, raw fish products, such as those found in\nsome types of sushi, pose a serious health risk if contaminated with\n_Listeria_. Even if fish is intended to be cooked, however, adequate\nsanitation is needed to prevent the spread of this strain throughout\nthe distribution system and to restaurants and consumer homes, where\nit may contaminate ready-to-eat foods. The strain isolated from the\n2004 and 2005 inspections was identical to a strain that has caused\nhuman illness.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[The greatest threat of listeriosis is from ready-to-eat products\nthat do not require further cooking at home. _L. monocytogenes_ in\nraw food that will be cooked before consumption is less of a concern\nto the food industry, since the bacteria are killed during cooking.\nListeriosis can be acquired from seafood, although most think of the\nrisk from processed deli meats 1st. Yearly, recalls of seafood,\nespecially smoked salmon, are posted on FDA's website. Although not\ngenerally linked to large outbreaks, those at high risk, such as\npregnant women and those individuals with compromised cell-mediated\nimmunity, should avoid the food described below.\n_L. monocytogenes_ has been isolated from raw fish, cooked crabs, raw\nand cooked shrimp, raw lobster, surimi (minced, processed fish used\nin the preparation of imitation seafood, especially imitation\nshellfish) and smoked fish (1). Hazards from _L. monocytogenes_ can\nbe prevented by thoroughly cooking seafood and by preventing\ncross-contamination once the seafood is cooked.\nThe CDC's recommendations regarding the risk of acquiring listeriosis\nfrom seafood (2) include not eating refrigerated smoked seafood\nunless it is contained in a cooked dish, such as a casserole.\nRefrigerated smoked seafood, such as salmon, trout, whitefish, cod,\ntuna or mackerel, is most often labeled as \"nova-style,\" \"lox,\"\n\"kippered,\" \"smoked,\" or \"jerky.\" The fish is found in the\nrefrigerator section or sold at deli counters of grocery stores and\ndelicatessens. Canned or shelf-stable smoked seafood may be eaten.\n1. Ward D, Bernard D, Collette R, et al. (Eds.): Hazards Found in\nSeafoods, Appendix III. In HACCP: Hazard Analysis and Critical\nControl Point Training Curriculum, 2nd ed., p. 173-188. UNC-SG-96-02.\nNorth Carolina Sea Grant, Raleigh, NC, 1997.\n2. <http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/dbmd/diseaseinfo/listeriosis_g.htm>. - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\n2005\n----\nListeriosis, nosocomial - Australia (SA (02) 20051215.3598\nListeriosis, nosocomial - Australia (SA) 20051213.3587\nListeriosis - USA (TX) 20050824.2491\nListeriosis - USA (NY)(05) 20050819.2431\nListeriosis - USA (NY) 20050707.1925\nListeriosis, fatal - Switzerland (Neuenburg) (02) 20050624.1777\nListeriosis, fatal - Switzerland (Neuenburg): alert 20050608.1597\n2004\n----\nListeriosis, cluster - USA (VA)(02): background 20040723.2013\nListeriosis, cluster - USA (VA) 20040722.1999\n2003\n----\nListeriosis, new prevention regulations - USA 20030605.1385\n2002\n----\nListeriosis - USA (multistate) (08) 20021015.5556\nListeriosis, poultry - USA: recall 20021014.5550\nListeriosis - USA (multistate) 20020915.5323\nListeriosis - USA (Pennsylvania) 20020901.5205\n2000\n----\nListeriosis - France (05) 20000226.0261\nListeriosis - France 20000219.0224\n1998\n----\nListeriosis, contaminated fish - Sweden:1994/95(02) 19980115.0106\nListeriosis, contaminated fish - Sweden: 1994/95 19980113.0097\n..............ll/msp/mpp\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The\ngovernment's complaint, filed on 24 Jan 2006 by the Department of\nJustice in the District Court for the Southern District of\nCalifornia, charges the defendants with violating the Federal Food,\nDrug, and Cosmetic Act by permitting ready-to-eat fish held and\nprocessed in Pacific Shellfish's facility to become contaminated.\nAccording to the complaint, recent FDA inspections in 2004 and 2005\nrevealed the presence of _Listeria monocytogenes_, a disease-causing\nbacterium, on Pacific Shellfish's processing equipment and fish\nproducts. Inspections since 2001 have also documented persistent\nunsanitary conditions at the facility. FDA issued a letter to the\nfirm on 8 Dec 2004, after an inspection revealed unsanitary\nconditions and contamination with _Listeria_. Although the firm\npromised to correct its deficiencies, a 2005 inspection found that a\npersistent strain of _Listeria_ remained and the firm had not\nimplemented all of the promised corrections.\n_Listeria monocytogenesis_ is the causal agent of listeriosis, a\ndisease that can be very serious, even fatal, for high-risk groups\nsuch as pregnant women, unborn babies, newborns, and those with\nimpaired immune systems. Although proper cooking can eliminate the\norganism in fish products, raw fish products, such as those found in\nsome types of sushi, pose a serious health risk if contaminated with\n_Listeria_. Even if fish is intended to be cooked, however, adequate\nsanitation is needed to prevent the spread of this strain throughout\nthe distribution system and to restaurants and consumer homes, where\nit may contaminate ready-to-eat foods. Yearly, recalls of seafood,\nespecially smoked salmon, are posted on FDA's website. Although not\ngenerally linked to large outbreaks, those at high risk, such as\npregnant women and those individuals with compromised cell-mediated\nimmunity, should avoid the food described below.\n_L. monocytogenes_ has been isolated from raw fish, cooked crabs, raw\nand cooked shrimp, raw lobster, surimi (minced, processed fish used\nin the preparation of imitation seafood, especially imitation\nshellfish) and smoked fish (1). For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["listeriosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2006-01-26 00:00:00", "2006-01-24 00:00:00", "2004-03-16 00:00:00", "2005-03-16 00:00:00", "2001-03-16 00:00:00", "2004-12-08 00:00:00", "2005-03-16 00:00:00", "1997-03-16 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2002-03-16 00:00:00", "2005-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "NC", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "North Carolina Sea Grant", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Neuenburg", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Pennsylvania", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Switzerland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "California", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2209040", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Listeriosis, nosocomial - Australia (SA) (02)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2209040", "date": "2005-07-07 23:50:00", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS - USA (NEW YORK)\n******************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nSponsored in part by Elsevier, publisher of\nThe International Journal of Infectious Diseases\n<http://tinyurl.com/bj3md>\nDate: Thu, 7 Jul 2005\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: WSTM / NBC3 News [edited]\n<http://www.wstm.com/Global/story.asp?S=3564756>\n\nListeriosis outbreak in Syracuse area\n-------------------------------------\n3 Syracuse-area residents have been diagnosed with listeriosis -- a rare\nand potentially fatal bacterial disease caused by eating contaminated food.\nOnondaga County health officials say the 3 -- ages 48, 70, and 77 -- have\nbeen hospitalized and one is \"quite ill.\" Officials have yet to determine\nthe source of the infection.\nListeria is found in soil and water. Unpasteurized milk and cheeses have\nbeen associated with outbreaks in the past. The disease is not contagious\nand can be treated with antibiotics.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[_L. monocytogenes_ has been associated with such foods as raw milk,\nsupposedly pasteurized fluid milk, cheeses (particularly soft-ripened\nvarieties), ice cream, raw vegetables, fermented raw-meat sausages, cold\ncuts, raw and cooked poultry, raw meats (all types), and raw and smoked\nfish. Its ability to grow at temperatures as low as 3 degrees C permits\nmultiplication in refrigerated foods.\nRecalls related to contamination with _L. monocytogenes_ occur\nfrequently. Whether this cluster of cases in upstate New York is related\nto food from a previous recall -- where some of the contaminated food was\nnot recalled from a consumer or from a soon-to-be-discovered food -- is yet\nto be determined. - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\nListeriosis, fatal - Switzerland (Neuenburg) (02) 20050624.1777\nListeriosis, fatal - Switzerland (Neuenburg): alert 20050608.1597\n2004\n----\nListeriosis, cluster - USA (VA)(02): background 20040723.2013\n2003\n----\nListeriosis, new prevention regulations - USA 20030605.1385\n2000\n----\nListeriosis, foodborne, turkey products - USA (02) 20001221.2248\nListeriosis - France (05) 20000226.0261\nListeriosis - France 20000219.0224\n1999\n----\nListeriosis, butter - Finland 19990318.0407\n1998\n----\nListeriosis, contaminated fish - Sweden:1994/95(02) 19980115.0106\nListeriosis, contaminated fish - Sweden: 1994/95 19980113.0097\n...........................mpp/ll/pg/mpp\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Unpasteurized milk and cheeses have\nbeen associated with outbreaks in the past. The disease is not contagious\nand can be treated with antibiotics.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[_L. monocytogenes_ has been associated with such foods as raw milk,\nsupposedly pasteurized fluid milk, cheeses (particularly soft-ripened\nvarieties), ice cream, raw vegetables, fermented raw-meat sausages, cold\ncuts, raw and cooked poultry, raw meats (all types), and raw and smoked\nfish. Its ability to grow at temperatures as low as 3 degrees C permits\nmultiplication in refrigerated foods.\nRecalls related to contamination with _L. monocytogenes_ occur\nfrequently. Whether this cluster of cases in upstate New York is related\nto food from a previous recall -- where some of the contaminated food was\nnot recalled from a consumer or from a soon-to-be-discovered food -- is yet\nto be determined. - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\nListeriosis, fatal - Switzerland (Neuenburg) (02) 20050624.1777\nListeriosis, fatal - Switzerland (Neuenburg): alert 20050608.1597\n2004\n----\nListeriosis, cluster - USA (VA)(02): background 20040723.2013\n2003\n----\nListeriosis, new prevention regulations - USA 20030605.1385\n2000\n----\nListeriosis, foodborne, turkey products - USA (02) 20001221.2248\nListeriosis - France (05) 20000226.0261\nListeriosis - France 20000219.0224\n1999\n----\nListeriosis, butter - Finland 19990318.0407\n1998\n----\nListeriosis, contaminated fish - Sweden:1994/95(02) 19980115.0106\nListeriosis, contaminated fish - Sweden: 1994/95 19980113.0097\n...........................mpp/ll/pg/mpp\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["listeriosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2048-03-16 00:00:00", "2070-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Neuenburg", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "NEW YORK", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Switzerland", "country": "Switzerland"}, {"location": "Onondaga County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New York", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Syracuse", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2208219", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Listeriosis - USA (NY)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2208219", "date": "2005-07-07 23:50:00", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS - USA (NEW YORK)\n******************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nSponsored in part by Elsevier, publisher of\nThe International Journal of Infectious Diseases\n<http://tinyurl.com/bj3md>\nDate: Thu, 7 Jul 2005\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: WSTM / NBC3 News [edited]\n<http://www.wstm.com/Global/story.asp?S=3564756>\n\nListeriosis outbreak in Syracuse area\n-------------------------------------\n3 Syracuse-area residents have been diagnosed with listeriosis -- a rare\nand potentially fatal bacterial disease caused by eating contaminated food.\nOnondaga County health officials say the 3 -- ages 48, 70, and 77 -- have\nbeen hospitalized and one is \"quite ill.\" Officials have yet to determine\nthe source of the infection.\nListeria is found in soil and water. Unpasteurized milk and cheeses have\nbeen associated with outbreaks in the past. The disease is not contagious\nand can be treated with antibiotics.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[_L. monocytogenes_ has been associated with such foods as raw milk,\nsupposedly pasteurized fluid milk, cheeses (particularly soft-ripened\nvarieties), ice cream, raw vegetables, fermented raw-meat sausages, cold\ncuts, raw and cooked poultry, raw meats (all types), and raw and smoked\nfish. Its ability to grow at temperatures as low as 3 degrees C permits\nmultiplication in refrigerated foods.\nRecalls related to contamination with _L. monocytogenes_ occur\nfrequently. Whether this cluster of cases in upstate New York is related\nto food from a previous recall -- where some of the contaminated food was\nnot recalled from a consumer or from a soon-to-be-discovered food -- is yet\nto be determined. - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\nListeriosis, fatal - Switzerland (Neuenburg) (02) 20050624.1777\nListeriosis, fatal - Switzerland (Neuenburg): alert 20050608.1597\n2004\n----\nListeriosis, cluster - USA (VA)(02): background 20040723.2013\n2003\n----\nListeriosis, new prevention regulations - USA 20030605.1385\n2000\n----\nListeriosis, foodborne, turkey products - USA (02) 20001221.2248\nListeriosis - France (05) 20000226.0261\nListeriosis - France 20000219.0224\n1999\n----\nListeriosis, butter - Finland 19990318.0407\n1998\n----\nListeriosis, contaminated fish - Sweden:1994/95(02) 19980115.0106\nListeriosis, contaminated fish - Sweden: 1994/95 19980113.0097\n...........................mpp/ll/pg/mpp\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["listeriosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2048-03-16 00:00:00", "2070-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Neuenburg", "country": "Switzerland"}, {"location": "NEW YORK", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Switzerland", "country": "Switzerland"}, {"location": "Onondaga County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New York", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Syracuse", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2208136", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Listeriosis, fatal - Switzerland (Neuenburg) (02)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2208136", "date": "2002-11-21 23:50:00", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS, POULTRY - USA: RECALL (03)\n*******************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\n[1]\nDate: 21 Nov 2002\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Houston Chronicle / Reuters 21 Nov 2002 (edited)\n<http://www.chron.com/cs/CDA/story.hts/business/1671780>\n\nPoultry recall for Listeria outbreak widens\n-----------------------------\nWASHINGTON - A New Jersey poultry company linked to a _Listeria\nmonocytogenes_ outbreak that sickened 50 people in the Northeast expanded\nits recall of ready-to-eat turkey and chicken to 4.2 million pounds, the US\nAgriculture Department said today, 21 Nov 2002.\nPrivately held Jack Lambersky, which does business as J.L. Foods Co. Inc.,\nlaunched the recall after inspection of a product sample collected on 14\nNov 2002 tested positive for _L. monocytogenes_, a potentially deadly\nbacteria for especially immune suppressed individuals and pregnant women.\n\"The sample is being further analyzed to determine whether or not it\nmatches the outbreak strain,\" the USDA said in a statement.\nThe company said the recalled products were produced between 1 June 2002\nand 6 Nov 2002 and distributed to retail stores and institutions\nnationwide. The product bears establishment code \"P-4340\" inside the USDA\nseal of inspection.\nSpokesman Lynn Kettleson said officials \"assume a goodly portion of the\nproduct was consumed.\"\nOn 2 Nov 2002, the company recalled 200 000 pounds of poultry, after its\nproducts were linked to an outbreak in the Northeast that has killed 7\npeople. USDA said the strain found in both incidents were\n\"indistinguishable.\" Despite the government's findings, the company said\n\"to our knowledge, no one has become ill as a result of consuming these\nproducts.\"\nPilgrim's Pride, the No. 3 poultry producer based in Pittsburg, Texas, was\nalso linked to the listeriosis outbreak. It recalled 27.4 million pounds of\nits Wampler brand turkey and chicken, a record recall. Despite USDA\ntest results finding the listeria outbreak strain at its plant, Pilgrim's\nPride also has said its products were not to blame for the illnesses.\nJack Lambersky's plant in Camden, N.J., was voluntarily closed after the\ninitial recall of 200 000 pounds. USDA said last week it would allow the\nplant to resume operations after inspectors approved the company's new food\nsafety measures.\nDespite the expanded recall, the USDA said the plant remained open because\nthe 14 Nov 2002 sample that tested positive for listeria was actually\nproduced on 30 Aug 2002. \"The plant is still open because all the (USDA)\naction took place at the 2 Nov 2002 recall,\" said Steve Cohen, spokesman\nfor USDA's Food Safetyand Inspection Service. \"The complete plant was\ncleaned up.\"\nThe company said it was working closely with USDA determining the origin of\nthe listeria contamination. \"We are communicating to all of our impacted\ncustomers and are providing instructions on how the should handle the\nproducts covered by the recall,\" the company said in a statement.\nFaced with severe criticism from consumer groups and some Democrats on lax\nenforcement, the USDA said it would increase listeria testing at certain\nplants. About 1 500 meat plants that either do not test for listeria or\nchoose not to share their results with USDA were subject to USDA's\ndirective, the U.S. Department of Agriculture said on 18 Nov. The directive\nwill take effect on 9 Dec 2002.\nThe new directive would not have prevented the listeria recalls at Jack\nLambersky or Pilgrim's Pride because both claim they routinely test their\nplants and products for the bacteria.\n******\n[2]\nDate: 21 Nov 2002\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Food Safety and Inspection Service Recall (edited)\n<http://www.fsis.usda.gov/OA/recalls/rnrfiles/rnr098-2002.htm>\n\nRecall Notification Report 098-2002 Expanded, 21 Nov 2002\n---------------------------------------------------------------\nProduct(s) Recalled: Fresh and Frozen Ready-To-Eat Turkey and Chicken Products\nIn response to an ongoing food safety investigation, FSIS collected\nmicrobiological investigative sample on 14 Nov 2002, that returned positive\nresults for _Listeria monocytogenes_ on 20 Nov 2002. Based on this positive\nthe firm has voluntarily expanded the recall 098-2002 to include turkey and\nchicken products produced between 29 May 2002 and 2 Nov 2002. The sample is\nbeing further analyzed to determine whether or not it matches the outbreak\nstrain.\nProduction Dates/Identifying Codes:\nProduced between 29 May 2002 and 2 Nov 2002. Each product label bears the\nestablishment number \"P-4340\" inside the USDA mark of inspection. [The long\nlist of the products under recall can be found at the above web site. -\nMod. LL]\nProblem/Reason for Recall:\nThe products may be contaminated with _Listeria monocytogenes_.\nHow/When Discovered:\nOn 3 Oct 2002, FSIS collected samples from retail as part of an ongoing\nfood safety investigation of illnesses in the Northeastern United States.\nAn intact sample was reported positive for _L. monocytogenes_ by the FSIS\nOutbreaks Laboratory. The positive results strongly suggest that the\nrecalled products may be linked to the source of the widespread illnesses\nin the Northeastern US. Based on this information firm has voluntarily\ninitiated the recall and suspended its operations.\nIn response to an on-going food safety investigation, FSIS collected\nmicrobiological investigative sample on 14 Nov 2002, that returned positive\nresults for _L. monocytogenes_ on 20 Nov 2002. Based on this positive the\nfirm has voluntarily expanded the recall 098-2002 to include turkey and\nchicken products produced between 29 May 2002 and 2 Nov 2002. The sample is\nbeing further analyzed to determine whether or not it matches the outbreak\nstrain.\nEstablishment: 4340 P\nJack Lambersky Poultry Inc.\nQuantity Recalled: Approximately 4.2 million pounds (This includes the\n200 000 pounds from 2 Nov 2002 recall)\nConsumer Inquiries: 1-800-535-4555\nWeb Site: <http://www.fsis.usda.gov/oa/recalls/rec_intr.htm>\nSee Also\nListeriosis, poultry - USA: recall (02) 20021105.5719\nListeriosis - USA (multistate) (08) 20021015.5556\nListeriosis, poultry - USA: recall 20021014.5550\nListeriosis - USA (multistate) (07) 20021008.5503\nListeriosis - USA (multistate) (06): correction 20021007.5490\nListeriosis - USA (multistate) (06) 20021006.5481\nListeriosis - USA (multistate) (05) 20021004.5470\nListeriosis - USA (multistate) (04) 20020930.5430\nListeriosis - USA (multistate) (03) 20020918.5348\nListeriosis - USA (multistate) (02) 20020917.5334\nListeriosis - USA (multistate) 20020915.5323\nListeriosis - USA (Pennsylvania) 20020901.5205\n2000\n----\nListeriosis, foodborne, turkey products - USA (02) 20001221.2248\nListeria contamination, poultry - USA: recall 20001215.2198\nListeria monocytogenes, food - USA: recall 20000503.0675\nListeria, hot dogs - USA (multistate): recall 20000328.0450\nListeriosis, chicken salad - USA: recall 20020806.4956\nListeria monocytogenes, smoked salmon - USA: recall 20000412.0521\nListeria monocytogenes, fish products - USA: recall 20000313.0343\n....................jw/mpp/ll/mpp\n\n*##########################################################*\n* *\n* Please support the 2002 ProMED-mail Internet-a-thon! *\n* http://www.isid.org/netathon2002.shtml *\n* *\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Inc.,\nlaunched the recall after inspection of a product sample collected on 14\nNov 2002 tested positive for _L. monocytogenes_, a potentially deadly\nbacteria for especially immune suppressed individuals and pregnant women.\n\"The sample is being further analyzed to determine whether or not it\nmatches the outbreak strain,\" the USDA said in a statement.\nThe company said the recalled products were produced between 1 June 2002\nand 6 Nov 2002 and distributed to retail stores and institutions\nnationwide. USDA said last week it would allow the\nplant to resume operations after inspectors approved the company's new food\nsafety measures.\nDespite the expanded recall, the USDA said the plant remained open because\nthe 14 Nov 2002 sample that tested positive for listeria was actually\nproduced on 30 Aug 2002. \"The plant is still open because all the (USDA)\naction took place at the 2 Nov 2002 recall,\" said Steve Cohen, spokesman\nfor USDA's Food Safetyand Inspection Service. \"The complete plant was\ncleaned up.\"\nThe company said it was working closely with USDA determining the origin of\nthe listeria contamination. \"We are communicating to all of our impacted\ncustomers and are providing instructions on how the should handle the\nproducts covered by the recall,\" the company said in a statement.\nFaced with severe criticism from consumer groups and some Democrats on lax\nenforcement, the USDA said it would increase listeria testing at certain\nplants. About 1 500 meat plants that either do not test for listeria or\nchoose not to share their results with USDA were subject to USDA's\ndirective, the U.S. Department of Agriculture said on 18 Nov. The directive\nwill take effect on 9 Dec 2002.\nThe new directive would not have prevented the listeria recalls at Jack\nLambersky or Pilgrim's Pride because both claim they routinely test their\nplants and products for the bacteria.\n******\n[2]\nDate: 21 Nov 2002\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Food Safety and Inspection Service Recall (edited)\n<http://www.fsis.usda.gov/OA/recalls/rnrfiles/rnr098-2002.htm>\n\nRecall Notification Report 098-2002 Expanded, 21 Nov 2002\n---------------------------------------------------------------\nProduct(s) Recalled: Fresh and Frozen Ready-To-Eat Turkey and Chicken Products\nIn response to an ongoing food safety investigation, FSIS collected\nmicrobiological investigative sample on 14 Nov 2002, that returned positive\nresults for _Listeria monocytogenes_ on 20 Nov 2002. Based on this positive\nthe firm has voluntarily expanded the recall 098-2002 to include turkey and\nchicken products produced between 29 May 2002 and 2 Nov 2002. The sample is\nbeing further analyzed to determine whether or not it matches the outbreak\nstrain.\nProduction Dates/Identifying Codes:\nProduced between 29 May 2002 and 2 Nov 2002. Each product label bears the\nestablishment number \"P-4340\" inside the USDA mark of inspection. [The long\nlist of the products under recall can be found at the above web site. -\nMod. LL]\nProblem/Reason for Recall:\nThe products may be contaminated with _Listeria monocytogenes_.\nHow/When Discovered:\nOn 3 Oct 2002, FSIS collected samples from retail as part of an ongoing\nfood safety investigation of illnesses in the Northeastern United States.\nAn intact sample was reported positive for _L. monocytogenes_ by the FSIS\nOutbreaks Laboratory. The positive results strongly suggest that the\nrecalled products may be linked to the source of the widespread illnesses\nin the Northeastern US. Based on this information firm has voluntarily\ninitiated the recall and suspended its operations.\nIn response to an on-going food safety investigation, FSIS collected\nmicrobiological investigative sample on 14 Nov 2002, that returned positive\nresults for _L. monocytogenes_ on 20 Nov 2002. Based on this positive the\nfirm has voluntarily expanded the recall 098-2002 to include turkey and\nchicken products produced between 29 May 2002 and 2 Nov 2002. The sample is\nbeing further analyzed to determine whether or not it matches the outbreak\nstrain.\nEstablishment: 4340 P\nJack Lambersky Poultry Inc.\nQuantity Recalled: Approximately 4.2 million pounds (This includes the\n200 000 pounds from 2 Nov 2002 recall)\nConsumer Inquiries: 1-800-535-4555\nWeb Site: <http://www.fsis.usda.gov/oa/recalls/rec_intr.htm>\nSee Also\nListeriosis, poultry - USA: recall (02) 20021105.5719\nListeriosis - USA (multistate) (08) 20021015.5556\nListeriosis, poultry - USA: recall 20021014.5550\nListeriosis - USA (multistate) (07) 20021008.5503\nListeriosis - USA (multistate) (06): correction 20021007.5490\nListeriosis - USA (multistate) (06) 20021006.5481\nListeriosis - USA (multistate) (05) 20021004.5470\nListeriosis - USA (multistate) (04) 20020930.5430\nListeriosis - USA (multistate) (03) 20020918.5348\nListeriosis - USA (multistate) (02) 20020917.5334\nListeriosis - USA (multistate) 20020915.5323\nListeriosis - USA (Pennsylvania) 20020901.5205\n2000\n----\nListeriosis, foodborne, turkey products - USA (02) 20001221.2248\nListeria contamination, poultry - USA: recall 20001215.2198\nListeria monocytogenes, food - USA: recall 20000503.0675\nListeria, hot dogs - USA (multistate): recall 20000328.0450\nListeriosis, chicken salad - USA: recall 20020806.4956\nListeria monocytogenes, smoked salmon - USA: recall 20000412.0521\nListeria monocytogenes, fish products - USA: recall 20000313.0343\n....................jw/mpp/ll/mpp\n\n*##########################################################*\n* *\n* Please support the 2002 ProMED-mail Internet-a-thon! *\n* http://www.isid.org/netathon2002.shtml *\n* *\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["listeriosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2002-11-21 00:00:00", "2002-03-16 00:00:00", "2002-11-21 00:00:00", "2002-03-16 00:00:00", "2002-11-06 00:00:00", "2002-11-02 00:00:00", "2002-11-14 00:00:00", "2002-08-30 00:00:00", "2002-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-11-18 00:00:00", "2002-12-09 00:00:00", "2002-11-21 00:00:00", "2002-11-21 00:00:00", "2002-11-14 00:00:00", "2002-11-20 00:00:00", "2002-05-29 00:00:00", "2002-11-02 00:00:00", "2002-11-02 00:00:00", "2002-10-03 00:00:00", "2002-11-14 00:00:00", "2002-11-20 00:00:00", "2002-05-29 00:00:00", "2002-11-02 00:00:00", "2002-11-02 00:00:00", "2002-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "New Jersey", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Texas", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Pittsburg", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Pennsylvania", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Camden", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "N.J.", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the Northeastern United States", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2206180", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Listeriosis, cluster - USA (VA)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2206180", "date": "2002-11-21 23:50:00", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS, POULTRY - USA: RECALL (03)\n*******************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\n[1]\nDate: 21 Nov 2002\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Houston Chronicle / Reuters 21 Nov 2002 (edited)\n<http://www.chron.com/cs/CDA/story.hts/business/1671780>\n\nPoultry recall for Listeria outbreak widens\n-----------------------------\nWASHINGTON - A New Jersey poultry company linked to a _Listeria\nmonocytogenes_ outbreak that sickened 50 people in the Northeast expanded\nits recall of ready-to-eat turkey and chicken to 4.2 million pounds, the US\nAgriculture Department said today, 21 Nov 2002.\nPrivately held Jack Lambersky, which does business as J.L. Foods Co. Inc.,\nlaunched the recall after inspection of a product sample collected on 14\nNov 2002 tested positive for _L. monocytogenes_, a potentially deadly\nbacteria for especially immune suppressed individuals and pregnant women.\n\"The sample is being further analyzed to determine whether or not it\nmatches the outbreak strain,\" the USDA said in a statement.\nThe company said the recalled products were produced between 1 June 2002\nand 6 Nov 2002 and distributed to retail stores and institutions\nnationwide. The product bears establishment code \"P-4340\" inside the USDA\nseal of inspection.\nSpokesman Lynn Kettleson said officials \"assume a goodly portion of the\nproduct was consumed.\"\nOn 2 Nov 2002, the company recalled 200 000 pounds of poultry, after its\nproducts were linked to an outbreak in the Northeast that has killed 7\npeople. USDA said the strain found in both incidents were\n\"indistinguishable.\" Despite the government's findings, the company said\n\"to our knowledge, no one has become ill as a result of consuming these\nproducts.\"\nPilgrim's Pride, the No. 3 poultry producer based in Pittsburg, Texas, was\nalso linked to the listeriosis outbreak. It recalled 27.4 million pounds of\nits Wampler brand turkey and chicken, a record recall. Despite USDA\ntest results finding the listeria outbreak strain at its plant, Pilgrim's\nPride also has said its products were not to blame for the illnesses.\nJack Lambersky's plant in Camden, N.J., was voluntarily closed after the\ninitial recall of 200 000 pounds. USDA said last week it would allow the\nplant to resume operations after inspectors approved the company's new food\nsafety measures.\nDespite the expanded recall, the USDA said the plant remained open because\nthe 14 Nov 2002 sample that tested positive for listeria was actually\nproduced on 30 Aug 2002. \"The plant is still open because all the (USDA)\naction took place at the 2 Nov 2002 recall,\" said Steve Cohen, spokesman\nfor USDA's Food Safetyand Inspection Service. \"The complete plant was\ncleaned up.\"\nThe company said it was working closely with USDA determining the origin of\nthe listeria contamination. \"We are communicating to all of our impacted\ncustomers and are providing instructions on how the should handle the\nproducts covered by the recall,\" the company said in a statement.\nFaced with severe criticism from consumer groups and some Democrats on lax\nenforcement, the USDA said it would increase listeria testing at certain\nplants. About 1 500 meat plants that either do not test for listeria or\nchoose not to share their results with USDA were subject to USDA's\ndirective, the U.S. Department of Agriculture said on 18 Nov. The directive\nwill take effect on 9 Dec 2002.\nThe new directive would not have prevented the listeria recalls at Jack\nLambersky or Pilgrim's Pride because both claim they routinely test their\nplants and products for the bacteria.\n******\n[2]\nDate: 21 Nov 2002\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Food Safety and Inspection Service Recall (edited)\n<http://www.fsis.usda.gov/OA/recalls/rnrfiles/rnr098-2002.htm>\n\nRecall Notification Report 098-2002 Expanded, 21 Nov 2002\n---------------------------------------------------------------\nProduct(s) Recalled: Fresh and Frozen Ready-To-Eat Turkey and Chicken Products\nIn response to an ongoing food safety investigation, FSIS collected\nmicrobiological investigative sample on 14 Nov 2002, that returned positive\nresults for _Listeria monocytogenes_ on 20 Nov 2002. USA", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2203926", "date": "2002-11-21 23:50:00", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS, POULTRY - USA: RECALL (03)\n*******************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\n[1]\nDate: 21 Nov 2002\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Houston Chronicle / Reuters 21 Nov 2002 (edited)\n<http://www.chron.com/cs/CDA/story.hts/business/1671780>\n\nPoultry recall for Listeria outbreak widens\n-----------------------------\nWASHINGTON - Foods Co. Inc.,\nlaunched the recall after inspection of a product sample collected on 14\nNov 2002 tested positive for _L. monocytogenes_, a potentially deadly\nbacteria for especially immune suppressed individuals and pregnant women.\n\"The sample is being further analyzed to determine whether or not it\nmatches the outbreak strain,\" the USDA said in a statement.\nThe company said the recalled products were produced between 1 June 2002\nand 6 Nov 2002 and distributed to retail stores and institutions\nnationwide. The product bears establishment code \"P-4340\" inside the USDA\nseal of inspection.\nSpokesman Lynn Kettleson said officials \"assume a goodly portion of the\nproduct was consumed.\"\nOn 2 Nov 2002, the company recalled 200 000 pounds of poultry, after its\nproducts were linked to an outbreak in the Northeast that has killed 7\npeople. USDA said the strain found in both incidents were\n\"indistinguishable.\" Despite the government's findings, the company said\n\"to our knowledge, no one has become ill as a result of consuming these\nproducts.\"\nPilgrim's Pride, the No. 3 poultry producer based in Pittsburg, Texas, was\nalso linked to the listeriosis outbreak. It recalled 27.4 million pounds of\nits Wampler brand turkey and chicken, a record recall. Despite USDA\ntest results finding the listeria outbreak strain at its plant, Pilgrim's\nPride also has said its products were not to blame for the illnesses.\nJack Lambersky's plant in Camden, N.J., was voluntarily closed after the\ninitial recall of 200 000 pounds. USDA said last week it would allow the\nplant to resume operations after inspectors approved the company's new food\nsafety measures.\nDespite the expanded recall, the USDA said the plant remained open because\nthe 14 Nov 2002 sample that tested positive for listeria was actually\nproduced on 30 Aug 2002. \"The plant is still open because all the (USDA)\naction took place at the 2 Nov 2002 recall,\" said Steve Cohen, spokesman\nfor USDA's Food Safetyand Inspection Service. \"The complete plant was\ncleaned up.\"\nThe company said it was working closely with USDA determining the origin of\nthe listeria contamination. \"We are communicating to all of our impacted\ncustomers and are providing instructions on how the should handle the\nproducts covered by the recall,\" the company said in a statement.\nFaced with severe criticism from consumer groups and some Democrats on lax\nenforcement, the USDA said it would increase listeria testing at certain\nplants. About 1 500 meat plants that either do not test for listeria or\nchoose not to share their results with USDA were subject to USDA's\ndirective, the U.S. Department of Agriculture said on 18 Nov. The directive\nwill take effect on 9 Dec 2002.\nThe new directive would not have prevented the listeria recalls at Jack\nLambersky or Pilgrim's Pride because both claim they routinely test their\nplants and products for the bacteria.\n******\n[2]\nDate: 21 Nov 2002\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Food Safety and Inspection Service Recall (edited)\n<http://www.fsis.usda.gov/OA/recalls/rnrfiles/rnr098-2002.htm>\n\nRecall Notification Report 098-2002 Expanded, 21 Nov 2002\n---------------------------------------------------------------\nProduct(s) Recalled: Fresh and Frozen Ready-To-Eat Turkey and Chicken Products\nIn response to an ongoing food safety investigation, FSIS collected\nmicrobiological investigative sample on 14 Nov 2002, that returned positive\nresults for _Listeria monocytogenes_ on 20 Nov 2002. Based on this positive\nthe firm has voluntarily expanded the recall 098-2002 to include turkey and\nchicken products produced between 29 May 2002 and 2 Nov 2002. The sample is\nbeing further analyzed to determine whether or not it matches the outbreak\nstrain.\nProduction Dates/Identifying Codes:\nProduced between 29 May 2002 and 2 Nov 2002. Each product label bears the\nestablishment number \"P-4340\" inside the USDA mark of inspection. [The long\nlist of the products under recall can be found at the above web site. -\nMod. LL]\nProblem/Reason for Recall:\nThe products may be contaminated with _Listeria monocytogenes_.\nHow/When Discovered:\nOn 3 Oct 2002, FSIS collected samples from retail as part of an ongoing\nfood safety investigation of illnesses in the Northeastern United States.\nAn intact sample was reported positive for _L. monocytogenes_ by the FSIS\nOutbreaks Laboratory. The positive results strongly suggest that the\nrecalled products may be linked to the source of the widespread illnesses\nin the Northeastern US. Based on this information firm has voluntarily\ninitiated the recall and suspended its operations.\nIn response to an on-going food safety investigation, FSIS collected\nmicrobiological investigative sample on 14 Nov 2002, that returned positive\nresults for _L. monocytogenes_ on 20 Nov 2002. Based on this positive the\nfirm has voluntarily expanded the recall 098-2002 to include turkey and\nchicken products produced between 29 May 2002 and 2 Nov 2002. The sample is\nbeing further analyzed to determine whether or not it matches the outbreak\nstrain.\nEstablishment: 4340 P\nJack Lambersky Poultry Inc.\nQuantity Recalled: Approximately 4.2 million pounds (This includes the\n200 000 pounds from 2 Nov 2002 recall)\nConsumer Inquiries: 1-800-535-4555\nWeb Site: <http://www.fsis.usda.gov/oa/recalls/rec_intr.htm>\nSee Also\nListeriosis, poultry - USA: recall (02) 20021105.5719\nListeriosis - USA (multistate) (08) 20021015.5556\nListeriosis, poultry - USA: recall 20021014.5550\nListeriosis - USA (multistate) (07) 20021008.5503\nListeriosis - USA (multistate) (06): correction 20021007.5490\nListeriosis - USA (multistate) (06) 20021006.5481\nListeriosis - USA (multistate) (05) 20021004.5470\nListeriosis - USA (multistate) (04) 20020930.5430\nListeriosis - USA (multistate) (03) 20020918.5348\nListeriosis - USA (multistate) (02) 20020917.5334\nListeriosis - USA (multistate) 20020915.5323\nListeriosis - USA (Pennsylvania) 20020901.5205\n2000\n----\nListeriosis, foodborne, turkey products - USA (02) 20001221.2248\nListeria contamination, poultry - USA: recall 20001215.2198\nListeria monocytogenes, food - USA: recall 20000503.0675\nListeria, hot dogs - USA (multistate): recall 20000328.0450\nListeriosis, chicken salad - USA: recall 20020806.4956\nListeria monocytogenes, smoked salmon - USA: recall 20000412.0521\nListeria monocytogenes, fish products - USA: recall 20000313.0343\n....................jw/mpp/ll/mpp\n\n*##########################################################*\n* *\n* Please support the 2002 ProMED-mail Internet-a-thon! *\n* http://www.isid.org/netathon2002.shtml *\n* *\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. USA: Recall (04)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2203027", "date": "2002-11-21 23:50:00", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS, POULTRY - USA: RECALL (03)\n*******************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\n[1]\nDate: 21 Nov 2002\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Houston Chronicle / Reuters 21 Nov 2002 (edited)\n<http://www.chron.com/cs/CDA/story.hts/business/1671780>\n\nPoultry recall for Listeria outbreak widens\n-----------------------------\nWASHINGTON - A New Jersey poultry company linked to a _Listeria\nmonocytogenes_ outbreak that sickened 50 people in the Northeast expanded\nits recall of ready-to-eat turkey and chicken to 4.2 million pounds, the US\nAgriculture Department said today, 21 Nov 2002.\nPrivately held Jack Lambersky, which does business as J.L. Foods Co. Inc.,\nlaunched the recall after inspection of a product sample collected on 14\nNov 2002 tested positive for _L. monocytogenes_, a potentially deadly\nbacteria for especially immune suppressed individuals and pregnant women.\n\"The sample is being further analyzed to determine whether or not it\nmatches the outbreak strain,\" the USDA said in a statement.\nThe company said the recalled products were produced between 1 June 2002\nand 6 Nov 2002 and distributed to retail stores and institutions\nnationwide. The product bears establishment code \"P-4340\" inside the USDA\nseal of inspection.\nSpokesman Lynn Kettleson said officials \"assume a goodly portion of the\nproduct was consumed.\"\nOn 2 Nov 2002, the company recalled 200 000 pounds of poultry, after its\nproducts were linked to an outbreak in the Northeast that has killed 7\npeople. USDA said the strain found in both incidents were\n\"indistinguishable.\" Despite the government's findings, the company said\n\"to our knowledge, no one has become ill as a result of consuming these\nproducts.\"\nPilgrim's Pride, the No. 3 poultry producer based in Pittsburg, Texas, was\nalso linked to the listeriosis outbreak. It recalled 27.4 million pounds of\nits Wampler brand turkey and chicken, a record recall. Despite USDA\ntest results finding the listeria outbreak strain at its plant, Pilgrim's\nPride also has said its products were not to blame for the illnesses.\nJack Lambersky's plant in Camden, N.J., was voluntarily closed after the\ninitial recall of 200 000 pounds. USDA said last week it would allow the\nplant to resume operations after inspectors approved the company's new food\nsafety measures.\nDespite the expanded recall, the USDA said the plant remained open because\nthe 14 Nov 2002 sample that tested positive for listeria was actually\nproduced on 30 Aug 2002. \"The plant is still open because all the (USDA)\naction took place at the 2 Nov 2002 recall,\" said Steve Cohen, spokesman\nfor USDA's Food Safetyand Inspection Service. \"The complete plant was\ncleaned up.\"\nThe company said it was working closely with USDA determining the origin of\nthe listeria contamination. \"We are communicating to all of our impacted\ncustomers and are providing instructions on how the should handle the\nproducts covered by the recall,\" the company said in a statement.\nFaced with severe criticism from consumer groups and some Democrats on lax\nenforcement, the USDA said it would increase listeria testing at certain\nplants. About 1 500 meat plants that either do not test for listeria or\nchoose not to share their results with USDA were subject to USDA's\ndirective, the U.S. Department of Agriculture said on 18 Nov. The directive\nwill take effect on 9 Dec 2002.\nThe new directive would not have prevented the listeria recalls at Jack\nLambersky or Pilgrim's Pride because both claim they routinely test their\nplants and products for the bacteria.\n******\n[2]\nDate: 21 Nov 2002\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Food Safety and Inspection Service Recall (edited)\n<http://www.fsis.usda.gov/OA/recalls/rnrfiles/rnr098-2002.htm>\n\nRecall Notification Report 098-2002 Expanded, 21 Nov 2002\n---------------------------------------------------------------\nProduct(s) Recalled: Fresh and Frozen Ready-To-Eat Turkey and Chicken Products\nIn response to an ongoing food safety investigation, FSIS collected\nmicrobiological investigative sample on 14 Nov 2002, that returned positive\nresults for _Listeria monocytogenes_ on 20 Nov 2002. USA: recall (02)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2202814", "date": "2002-10-04 23:50:00", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS - USA (MULTISTATE) (05)\n***********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail, a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Thu, 3 Oct 2002 13:14:35 GMT-3\nFrom: Luz Alba Fornells <luzalba@bioqmed.ufrj.br>\nSource: Reuters.com [edited]\n<http://www.reuters.com/news_article.jhtml?type=search&StoryID=1531036>\n\nUS investigates food outbreaks linked to 20 deaths\n--------------------------------------------------\nUS health and food officials said on Thursday, 3 Oct 2002, that they are\ninvestigating the source of a foodborne listeria outbreak blamed for at\nleast 20 deaths and 120 illnesses in north eastern states.\nIn this outbreak, the United States Department of Agriculture said its Food\nSafety and Inspection Service began \"vigorous sampling\" of lunch meats and\ndeli products after illnesses were reported in early September 2002. Most\nillnesses were in New York, Pennsylvania, and New Jersey, but Michigan,\nMaryland, Ohio, Connecticut, and Delaware also were affected. Federal\nofficials have not yet been able to pinpoint whether the listeria\ncontaminated ready-to-eat meats or other foods such as seafood, soft\ncheeses, and unpasteurized milk.\n\"Working with state health officials, Food Safety and Inspection Service\n(FSIS) investigators have been probing every possible lead in an attempt to\nnarrow the list of possible sources of contamination,\" FSIS administrator\nGarry McKee said in a statement. \"Multiple samples have been collected and\nanalyzed, but as of yet, all have tested negative.\"\nOf the 120 listeria illnesses reported to health officials, 36 were linked\nthrough laboratory tests, said FSIS spokesman Steve Cohen. The 36 illnesses\nresulted in 6 deaths. Officials said they have not yet determined the\nstrain of listeria that caused the other 14 deaths.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\nSee Also\nListeriosis - USA (multistate) (04) 20020930.5430\nListeriosis - USA (multistate) (03) 20020918.5348\nListeriosis - USA (multistate) (02) 20020917.5334\nListeriosis - USA (multistate) 20020915.5323\nListeriosis - USA (Pennsylvania) 20020901.5205\nListeriosis, chicken salad - USA: recall 20020806.4956\n2000\n---\nListeriosis, foodborne, turkey products - USA (02) 20001221.2248\nListeria contamination, poultry - USA: recall 20001215.2198\nListeria monocytogenes, food - USA: recall 20000503.0675\nListeria monocytogenes, smoked salmon - USA: recall 20000412.0521\nListeria, hot dogs - USA (multistate): recall 20000328.0450\nListeria monocytogenes, fish products - USA: recall 20000313.0343\n.......................ll/pg/sh\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. USA (multistate) (06)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2202657", "date": "2002-10-04 23:50:00", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS - USA (MULTISTATE) (05)\n***********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail, a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Thu, 3 Oct 2002 13:14:35 GMT-3\nFrom: Luz Alba Fornells <luzalba@bioqmed.ufrj.br>\nSource: Reuters.com [edited]\n<http://www.reuters.com/news_article.jhtml?type=search&StoryID=1531036>\n\nUS investigates food outbreaks linked to 20 deaths\n--------------------------------------------------\nUS health and food officials said on Thursday, 3 Oct 2002, that they are\ninvestigating the source of a foodborne listeria outbreak blamed for at\nleast 20 deaths and 120 illnesses in north eastern states.\nIn this outbreak, the United States Department of Agriculture said its Food\nSafety and Inspection Service began \"vigorous sampling\" of lunch meats and\ndeli products after illnesses were reported in early September 2002. Most\nillnesses were in New York, Pennsylvania, and New Jersey, but Michigan,\nMaryland, Ohio, Connecticut, and Delaware also were affected. Federal\nofficials have not yet been able to pinpoint whether the listeria\ncontaminated ready-to-eat meats or other foods such as seafood, soft\ncheeses, and unpasteurized milk.\n\"Working with state health officials, Food Safety and Inspection Service\n(FSIS) investigators have been probing every possible lead in an attempt to\nnarrow the list of possible sources of contamination,\" FSIS administrator\nGarry McKee said in a statement. \"Multiple samples have been collected and\nanalyzed, but as of yet, all have tested negative.\"\nOf the 120 listeria illnesses reported to health officials, 36 were linked\nthrough laboratory tests, said FSIS spokesman Steve Cohen. The 36 illnesses\nresulted in 6 deaths. Officials said they have not yet determined the\nstrain of listeria that caused the other 14 deaths.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\nSee Also\nListeriosis - USA (multistate) (04) 20020930.5430\nListeriosis - USA (multistate) (03) 20020918.5348\nListeriosis - USA (multistate) (02) 20020917.5334\nListeriosis - USA (multistate) 20020915.5323\nListeriosis - USA (Pennsylvania) 20020901.5205\nListeriosis, chicken salad - USA: recall 20020806.4956\n2000\n---\nListeriosis, foodborne, turkey products - USA (02) 20001221.2248\nListeria contamination, poultry - USA: recall 20001215.2198\nListeria monocytogenes, food - USA: recall 20000503.0675\nListeria monocytogenes, smoked salmon - USA: recall 20000412.0521\nListeria, hot dogs - USA (multistate): recall 20000328.0450\nListeria monocytogenes, fish products - USA: recall 20000313.0343\n.......................ll/pg/sh\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Larry Penning <hlpenning@yahoo.com>\nSource: The Associated Press, 15 Dec 2000 6:10 p.m. EST [edited\n<http://www.nandotimes.com>\n\nGovernment health officials say 4 deaths have been linked to\nbacteria-contaminated turkey products that were recalled this week.\nMinnesota-based Cargill Inc. announced this week that it is recalling 16.7\nmillion pounds of its cooked products, including sliced turkey breast,\nCajun-fried turkey and smoked turkey, because of [contamination with\n_Listeria monocytogenes_ bacteria.\nSonja Olsen, a epidemiologist with the US Centers for Disease Control and\nPrevention, said Friday there have been 28 cases of listeriosis involving\nCargill products since July. She said the outbreak has caused 4 deaths as\nwell as three miscarriages or stillbirths.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[As noted in the prior posting announcing the recall of Cargill poultry\nproducts, they are distributed nationwide. There is no information as to\nthe geographic location of the cases noted in this report. - Mod.ES\n......................................ds/es\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Larry Penning <hlpenning@yahoo.com>\nSource: The Associated Press, 15 Dec 2000 6:10 p.m. EST [edited\n<http://www.nandotimes.com>\n\nGovernment health officials say 4 deaths have been linked to\nbacteria-contaminated turkey products that were recalled this week.\nMinnesota-based Cargill Inc. announced this week that it is recalling 16.7\nmillion pounds of its cooked products, including sliced turkey breast,\nCajun-fried turkey and smoked turkey, because of [contamination with\n_Listeria monocytogenes_ bacteria.\nSonja Olsen, a epidemiologist with the US Centers for Disease Control and\nPrevention, said Friday there have been 28 cases of listeriosis involving\nCargill products since July. She said the outbreak has caused 4 deaths as\nwell as three miscarriages or stillbirths.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[As noted in the prior posting announcing the recall of Cargill poultry\nproducts, they are distributed nationwide. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["listeriosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-19 00:00:00", "2021-07-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Minnesota", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2197339", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis - France (05)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2197339", "date": "1999-02-04 23:50:00", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS, MEAT RECALLS - USA: EXPANDED\n****************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.healthnet.org/programs/promed.html>\n<http://www.fas.org/ahead>\nSee Also\nListeriosis, meat recall - USA (Missouri) 990117112746\nListeriosis, meat recall - USA (Wisconsin) 990116210032\nListeriosis, meat recalls - USA (Arkansas & Ohio) 990124005341\nDate: Mon, 01 Feb 1999 18:51:14 -0500\nFrom: \"Robert A. LaBudde\" <ral@lcfltd.com>\nSource: FSNET\n\nCHICAGO -- Consumer products maker Sara Lee Corp. was cited as saying\ntoday that it had added more brands to the list of packaged meat\nproducts it recalled in December because of possible contamination by\nListeria.\nThe story says that while the foodservice operators stopped using the\nSara Lee products at the restaurants, hospitals and other venues they\nserve, they may have sold them at outlet stores before the recall date.\nSara Lee spokeswoman Theresa Herlevsen was cited as saying the\nadditional recalled brands total about 200 000 pounds of meat, and that\nit expects to recover a total of about 15 million pounds of meat in the\nmassive recall.\nThe additional brands being recalled were sold by Grand Rapids,\nMich.-based Gordon Food Service, which operates about 70 stores; Allen\nFoods, which has one outlet store in St. Louis; Sara Lee's PYA Monarch\nfoodservice unit, which runs two stores in Montgomery, Ala.; and a Bil\nMar Country Store outlet in Zeeland, Mich.\n***\n[2\nDate: Mon, 01 Feb 1999 18:53:19 -0500\nFrom: \"Robert A. LaBudde\" <ral@lcfltd.com>\nSource: FSNET\n\nUPI 31 Jan 1999 [edited\nGRAND RAPIDS, Mich. -- To date, the deaths of 12 people, three\nmiscarriages, and more than 70 illnesses nationwide are blamed on\nListeria-tainted meat.\nMore than 15 million pounds of meat have been recalled since Sara Lee's\nDecember announcement.\nDr. Paul Mead, an epidemiologist with the U.S. Centers for Disease\nControl was cited as... telling the Grand Rapids Press the CDC recall\nrecommendation came several days after an epidemiologist from the\nMinnesota Health Department urged a recall, adding, \"Recalls are always\neither too early or too late. If you're right, it's always too late. If\nyou're wrong, it's always too early.\"\nHe was further cited as saying it's unclear whether an earlier recall\ncould have saved lives or prevented more illnesses.\nHe also noted that CDC investigators are trying to determine if dust at\nthe Bil-Mar plant may have led to the Listeria outbreak because\nofficials think there was a \"construction event\" in the building that\nsprayed dust onto the equipment. The dust is suspected to have contained\nListeria, which is commonly found in soil and water.\n[ProMED-mail often faces the same dilemma; do we post without\nconfirmation and risk having to retract, or wait for confirmation and\nallow more cases to occur for lack of timely warning? So far, we have\nonly had to retract 3 minor outbreak reports out of several thousand\nposted - Mod.JW\n***\n[3\nDate: Mon, 01 Feb 1999 18:57:01 -0500\nFrom: \"Robert A. LaBudde\" <ral@lcfltd.com>\nSource: New York Times, 27 Jan 1999 via FSNET [edited\n\nByline: Marian Burros\nThere are only 1000 to 2000 reported cases of listeriosis in the United\nStates each year; an accurate figure cannot be obtained, the story says,\nas health professionals do not routinely test for it and many cases go\nundetected.\nBut health officials find it especially troubling because, based on the\nnumber of reported cases, the percentage of people who die from it is\nmuch higher than from most other food-borne bacteria. And, the story\nadds, the incubation period is much longer, up to 70 days before\nsymptoms appear.\nIn addition to causing miscarriages and stillbirths, Listeria can cause\nfatal blood infections and meningitis.\nAmerican scientists began to take Listeria seriously in 1985, when 18\ndeaths were traced to the eating of Jalisco brand soft cheese. (The\ncompany is now defunct.) There were also 30 stillbirths and deaths of\nnewborns.\nAnother 142 people became ill.\nListeria is carried in the intestines of animals and can easily come in\ncontact with dairy products, uncooked meats, fish, poultry and\nvegetables as well as precooked meats like the ones responsible for the\nAugust\noutbreak. The investigators say they do not know how the Listeria\ncontaminated the cooked meats at Bil Mar Foods.\nThe centralization of food production has turned what might previously\nhave been a small local problem into a global one. Products from the Bil\nMar plant, for example, are distributed all over the United States.\nIn the Bil Mar Foods case, the Agriculture Department left the\nannouncement of the recall to the company. The agency does not announce\nrecalls until it has proof that a sealed product contains the\ndisease-causing bacteria, and it did not have that proof until 31 Dec\n1998, nine days later.\nWhen the company announced the recall, a spokesman for the Agriculture\nDepartment, Andrew Solomon, was cited as saying that reporters who cover\nthe agency were notified and the information was put on the agency's Web\nsite and on its consumer-information line (800-535-4555).\n\nDale Morse, the director of the division of infectious disease of the\nNew York State Health Department, say there can never be enough\nnotification. In Broome County, in upstate New York [he said Meals on\nWheels was still serving the Bil Mar products to elderly clients eight\ndays after the recall, because it had not been notified.\nThe story goes on to say that unlike many other disease-causing\nbacteria, Listeria can grow in a refrigerator that has a normal\ntemperature of 40 degrees, which means leftovers should be reheated.\nPublic health officials strongly urge those at greatest risk from\nListeria to stay away from all soft cheeses,\nincluding feta and blue-veined cheeses like Roquefort and Camembert.\nThey also say that it is essential to cook hot dogs until the internal\ntemperature reaches 165 degrees, by either steaming or frying. Cooking\nin the\nmicrowave is not recommended. And unless people at risk are willing to\neat salami, corned beef and pastrami cooked. they should not eat them\nat all.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@usa.healthnet.org>\n................................jw\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The reader assumes all risks in\nusing information posted or archived by ProMED-mail. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "listeriosis", "meningitis"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["1999-02-01 00:00:00", "2021-12-16 00:00:00", "1999-02-01 00:00:00", "1999-01-31 00:00:00", "2021-12-16 00:00:00", "1999-02-01 00:00:00", "1999-01-27 00:00:00", "1985-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-08-16 00:00:00", "1998-12-31 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Zeeland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "CHICAGO", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Montgomery", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "GRAND RAPIDS", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Grand Rapids", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Jalisco", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New York", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "St. Louis", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ala.", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Missouri", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Broome County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mich.", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United \n States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Wisconsin", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2197318", "headline": "PRO/AH> Listeriosis - France (04)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2197318", "date": "1999-02-04 23:50:00", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS, MEAT RECALLS - USA: EXPANDED\n****************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.healthnet.org/programs/promed.html>\n<http://www.fas.org/ahead>\nSee Also\nListeriosis, meat recall - USA (Missouri) 990117112746\nListeriosis, meat recall - USA (Wisconsin) 990116210032\nListeriosis, meat recalls - USA (Arkansas & Ohio) 990124005341\nDate: Mon, 01 Feb 1999 18:51:14 -0500\nFrom: \"Robert A. LaBudde\" <ral@lcfltd.com>\nSource: FSNET\n\nCHICAGO -- Consumer products maker Sara Lee Corp. was cited as saying\ntoday that it had added more brands to the list of packaged meat\nproducts it recalled in December because of possible contamination by\nListeria.\nThe story says that while the foodservice operators stopped using the\nSara Lee products at the restaurants, hospitals and other venues they\nserve, they may have sold them at outlet stores before the recall date.\nSara Lee spokeswoman Theresa Herlevsen was cited as saying the\nadditional recalled brands total about 200 000 pounds of meat, and that\nit expects to recover a total of about 15 million pounds of meat in the\nmassive recall.\nThe additional brands being recalled were sold by Grand Rapids,\nMich.-based Gordon Food Service, which operates about 70 stores; Allen\nFoods, which has one outlet store in St. Louis; Sara Lee's PYA Monarch\nfoodservice unit, which runs two stores in Montgomery, Ala.; and a Bil\nMar Country Store outlet in Zeeland, Mich.\n***\n[2\nDate: Mon, 01 Feb 1999 18:53:19 -0500\nFrom: \"Robert A. LaBudde\" <ral@lcfltd.com>\nSource: FSNET\n\nUPI 31 Jan 1999 [edited\nGRAND RAPIDS, Mich. -- To date, the deaths of 12 people, three\nmiscarriages, and more than 70 illnesses nationwide are blamed on\nListeria-tainted meat.\nMore than 15 million pounds of meat have been recalled since Sara Lee's\nDecember announcement.\nDr. Paul Mead, an epidemiologist with the U.S. Centers for Disease\nControl was cited as... telling the Grand Rapids Press the CDC recall\nrecommendation came several days after an epidemiologist from the\nMinnesota Health Department urged a recall, adding, \"Recalls are always\neither too early or too late. If you're right, it's always too late. If\nyou're wrong, it's always too early.\"\nHe was further cited as saying it's unclear whether an earlier recall\ncould have saved lives or prevented more illnesses.\nHe also noted that CDC investigators are trying to determine if dust at\nthe Bil-Mar plant may have led to the Listeria outbreak because\nofficials think there was a \"construction event\" in the building that\nsprayed dust onto the equipment. LaBudde\" <ral@lcfltd.com>\nSource: New York Times, 27 Jan 1999 via FSNET [edited\n\nByline: Marian Burros\nThere are only 1000 to 2000 reported cases of listeriosis in the United\nStates each year; an accurate figure cannot be obtained, the story says,\nas health professionals do not routinely test for it and many cases go\nundetected.\nBut health officials find it especially troubling because, based on the\nnumber of reported cases, the percentage of people who die from it is\nmuch higher than from most other food-borne bacteria. And, the story\nadds, the incubation period is much longer, up to 70 days before\nsymptoms appear.\nIn addition to causing miscarriages and stillbirths, Listeria can cause\nfatal blood infections and meningitis.\nAmerican scientists began to take Listeria seriously in 1985, when 18\ndeaths were traced to the eating of Jalisco brand soft cheese. (The\ncompany is now defunct.) There were also 30 stillbirths and deaths of\nnewborns.\nAnother 142 people became ill.\nListeria is carried in the intestines of animals and can easily come in\ncontact with dairy products, uncooked meats, fish, poultry and\nvegetables as well as precooked meats like the ones responsible for the\nAugust\noutbreak. The investigators say they do not know how the Listeria\ncontaminated the cooked meats at Bil Mar Foods.\nThe centralization of food production has turned what might previously\nhave been a small local problem into a global one. Products from the Bil\nMar plant, for example, are distributed all over the United States.\nIn the Bil Mar Foods case, the Agriculture Department left the\nannouncement of the recall to the company. The agency does not announce\nrecalls until it has proof that a sealed product contains the\ndisease-causing bacteria, and it did not have that proof until 31 Dec\n1998, nine days later.\nWhen the company announced the recall, a spokesman for the Agriculture\nDepartment, Andrew Solomon, was cited as saying that reporters who cover\nthe agency were notified and the information was put on the agency's Web\nsite and on its consumer-information line (800-535-4555).\n\nDale Morse, the director of the division of infectious disease of the\nNew York State Health Department, say there can never be enough\nnotification. In Broome County, in upstate New York [he said Meals on\nWheels was still serving the Bil Mar products to elderly clients eight\ndays after the recall, because it had not been notified.\nThe story goes on to say that unlike many other disease-causing\nbacteria, Listeria can grow in a refrigerator that has a normal\ntemperature of 40 degrees, which means leftovers should be reheated.\nPublic health officials strongly urge those at greatest risk from\nListeria to stay away from all soft cheeses,\nincluding feta and blue-veined cheeses like Roquefort and Camembert.\nThey also say that it is essential to cook hot dogs until the internal\ntemperature reaches 165 degrees, by either steaming or frying. Cooking\nin the\nmicrowave is not recommended. And unless people at risk are willing to\neat salami, corned beef and pastrami cooked. they should not eat them\nat all.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@usa.healthnet.org>\n................................jw\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. (The\ncompany is now defunct.) There were also 30 stillbirths and deaths of\nnewborns.\nAnother 142 people became ill.\nListeria is carried in the intestines of animals and can easily come in\ncontact with dairy products, uncooked meats, fish, poultry and\nvegetables as well as precooked meats like the ones responsible for the\nAugust\noutbreak. The investigators say they do not know how the Listeria\ncontaminated the cooked meats at Bil Mar Foods.\nThe centralization of food production has turned what might previously\nhave been a small local problem into a global one. Products from the Bil\nMar plant, for example, are distributed all over the United States.\nIn the Bil Mar Foods case, the Agriculture Department left the\nannouncement of the recall to the company. The agency does not announce\nrecalls until it has proof that a sealed product contains the\ndisease-causing bacteria, and it did not have that proof until 31 Dec\n1998, nine days later.\nWhen the company announced the recall, a spokesman for the Agriculture\nDepartment, Andrew Solomon, was cited as saying that reporters who cover\nthe agency were notified and the information was put on the agency's Web\nsite and on its consumer-information line (800-535-4555).\n\nDale Morse, the director of the division of infectious disease of the\nNew York State Health Department, say there can never be enough\nnotification. In Broome County, in upstate New York [he said Meals on\nWheels was still serving the Bil Mar products to elderly clients eight\ndays after the recall, because it had not been notified.\nThe story goes on to say that unlike many other disease-causing\nbacteria, Listeria can grow in a refrigerator that has a normal\ntemperature of 40 degrees, which means leftovers should be reheated.\nPublic health officials strongly urge those at greatest risk from\nListeria to stay away from all soft cheeses,\nincluding feta and blue-veined cheeses like Roquefort and Camembert.\nThey also say that it is essential to cook hot dogs until the internal\ntemperature reaches 165 degrees, by either steaming or frying. Cooking\nin the\nmicrowave is not recommended. And unless people at risk are willing to\neat salami, corned beef and pastrami cooked. they should not eat them\nat all.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@usa.healthnet.org>\n................................jw\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed.
