For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "listeriosis", "meningitis"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["1999-02-01 00:00:00", "2021-12-16 00:00:00", "1999-02-01 00:00:00", "1999-01-31 00:00:00", "2021-12-16 00:00:00", "1999-02-01 00:00:00", "1999-01-27 00:00:00", "1985-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-08-16 00:00:00", "1998-12-31 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Zeeland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "CHICAGO", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Montgomery", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "GRAND RAPIDS", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Grand Rapids", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Jalisco", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New York", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "St. Louis", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ala.", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Missouri", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Broome County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mich.", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United \n States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Wisconsin", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2197313", "headline": "PRO/AH> Listeriosis - France (02)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2197313", "date": "1999-02-04 23:50:00", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS, MEAT RECALLS - USA: EXPANDED\n****************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.healthnet.org/programs/promed.html>\n<http://www.fas.org/ahead>\nSee Also\nListeriosis, meat recall - USA (Missouri) 990117112746\nListeriosis, meat recall - USA (Wisconsin) 990116210032\nListeriosis, meat recalls - USA (Arkansas & Ohio) 990124005341\nDate: Mon, 01 Feb 1999 18:51:14 -0500\nFrom: \"Robert A. LaBudde\" <ral@lcfltd.com>\nSource: FSNET\n\nCHICAGO -- Consumer products maker Sara Lee Corp. was cited as saying\ntoday that it had added more brands to the list of packaged meat\nproducts it recalled in December because of possible contamination by\nListeria.\nThe story says that while the foodservice operators stopped using the\nSara Lee products at the restaurants, hospitals and other venues they\nserve, they may have sold them at outlet stores before the recall date.\nSara Lee spokeswoman Theresa Herlevsen was cited as saying the\nadditional recalled brands total about 200 000 pounds of meat, and that\nit expects to recover a total of about 15 million pounds of meat in the\nmassive recall.\nThe additional brands being recalled were sold by Grand Rapids,\nMich.-based Gordon Food Service, which operates about 70 stores; Allen\nFoods, which has one outlet store in St. Louis; Sara Lee's PYA Monarch\nfoodservice unit, which runs two stores in Montgomery, Ala.; and a Bil\nMar Country Store outlet in Zeeland, Mich.\n***\n[2\nDate: Mon, 01 Feb 1999 18:53:19 -0500\nFrom: \"Robert A. LaBudde\" <ral@lcfltd.com>\nSource: FSNET\n\nUPI 31 Jan 1999 [edited\nGRAND RAPIDS, Mich. -- To date, the deaths of 12 people, three\nmiscarriages, and more than 70 illnesses nationwide are blamed on\nListeria-tainted meat.\nMore than 15 million pounds of meat have been recalled since Sara Lee's\nDecember announcement.\nDr. Paul Mead, an epidemiologist with the U.S. Centers for Disease\nControl was cited as... telling the Grand Rapids Press the CDC recall\nrecommendation came several days after an epidemiologist from the\nMinnesota Health Department urged a recall, adding, \"Recalls are always\neither too early or too late. If you're right, it's always too late. If\nyou're wrong, it's always too early.\"\nHe was further cited as saying it's unclear whether an earlier recall\ncould have saved lives or prevented more illnesses.\nHe also noted that CDC investigators are trying to determine if dust at\nthe Bil-Mar plant may have led to the Listeria outbreak because\nofficials think there was a \"construction event\" in the building that\nsprayed dust onto the equipment. The dust is suspected to have contained\nListeria, which is commonly found in soil and water.\n[ProMED-mail often faces the same dilemma; do we post without\nconfirmation and risk having to retract, or wait for confirmation and\nallow more cases to occur for lack of timely warning? So far, we have\nonly had to retract 3 minor outbreak reports out of several thousand\nposted - Mod.JW\n***\n[3\nDate: Mon, 01 Feb 1999 18:57:01 -0500\nFrom: \"Robert A. LaBudde\" <ral@lcfltd.com>\nSource: New York Times, 27 Jan 1999 via FSNET [edited\n\nByline: Marian Burros\nThere are only 1000 to 2000 reported cases of listeriosis in the United\nStates each year; an accurate figure cannot be obtained, the story says,\nas health professionals do not routinely test for it and many cases go\nundetected.\nBut health officials find it especially troubling because, based on the\nnumber of reported cases, the percentage of people who die from it is\nmuch higher than from most other food-borne bacteria. And, the story\nadds, the incubation period is much longer, up to 70 days before\nsymptoms appear.\nIn addition to causing miscarriages and stillbirths, Listeria can cause\nfatal blood infections and meningitis.\nAmerican scientists began to take Listeria seriously in 1985, when 18\ndeaths were traced to the eating of Jalisco brand soft cheese. (The\ncompany is now defunct.) There were also 30 stillbirths and deaths of\nnewborns.\nAnother 142 people became ill.\nListeria is carried in the intestines of animals and can easily come in\ncontact with dairy products, uncooked meats, fish, poultry and\nvegetables as well as precooked meats like the ones responsible for the\nAugust\noutbreak. The investigators say they do not know how the Listeria\ncontaminated the cooked meats at Bil Mar Foods.\nThe centralization of food production has turned what might previously\nhave been a small local problem into a global one. Products from the Bil\nMar plant, for example, are distributed all over the United States.\nIn the Bil Mar Foods case, the Agriculture Department left the\nannouncement of the recall to the company. The agency does not announce\nrecalls until it has proof that a sealed product contains the\ndisease-causing bacteria, and it did not have that proof until 31 Dec\n1998, nine days later.\nWhen the company announced the recall, a spokesman for the Agriculture\nDepartment, Andrew Solomon, was cited as saying that reporters who cover\nthe agency were notified and the information was put on the agency's Web\nsite and on its consumer-information line (800-535-4555).\n\nDale Morse, the director of the division of infectious disease of the\nNew York State Health Department, say there can never be enough\nnotification. In Broome County, in upstate New York [he said Meals on\nWheels was still serving the Bil Mar products to elderly clients eight\ndays after the recall, because it had not been notified.\nThe story goes on to say that unlike many other disease-causing\nbacteria, Listeria can grow in a refrigerator that has a normal\ntemperature of 40 degrees, which means leftovers should be reheated.\nPublic health officials strongly urge those at greatest risk from\nListeria to stay away from all soft cheeses,\nincluding feta and blue-veined cheeses like Roquefort and Camembert.\nThey also say that it is essential to cook hot dogs until the internal\ntemperature reaches 165 degrees, by either steaming or frying. Cooking\nin the\nmicrowave is not recommended. And unless people at risk are willing to\neat salami, corned beef and pastrami cooked. they should not eat them\nat all.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@usa.healthnet.org>\n................................jw\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. If you're right, it's always too late. If\nyou're wrong, it's always too early.\"\nHe was further cited as saying it's unclear whether an earlier recall\ncould have saved lives or prevented more illnesses.\nHe also noted that CDC investigators are trying to determine if dust at\nthe Bil-Mar plant may have led to the Listeria outbreak because\nofficials think there was a \"construction event\" in the building that\nsprayed dust onto the equipment. In Broome County, in upstate New York [he said Meals on\nWheels was still serving the Bil Mar products to elderly clients eight\ndays after the recall, because it had not been notified.\nThe story goes on to say that unlike many other disease-causing\nbacteria, Listeria can grow in a refrigerator that has a normal\ntemperature of 40 degrees, which means leftovers should be reheated.\nPublic health officials strongly urge those at greatest risk from\nListeria to stay away from all soft cheeses,\nincluding feta and blue-veined cheeses like Roquefort and Camembert.\nThey also say that it is essential to cook hot dogs until the internal\ntemperature reaches 165 degrees, by either steaming or frying. Cooking\nin the\nmicrowave is not recommended. LaBudde\" <ral@lcfltd.com>\nSource: FSNET\n\nCHICAGO -- Consumer products maker Sara Lee Corp. was cited as saying\ntoday that it had added more brands to the list of packaged meat\nproducts it recalled in December because of possible contamination by\nListeria.\nThe story says that while the foodservice operators stopped using the\nSara Lee products at the restaurants, hospitals and other venues they\nserve, they may have sold them at outlet stores before the recall date.\nSara Lee spokeswoman Theresa Herlevsen was cited as saying the\nadditional recalled brands total about 200 000 pounds of meat, and that\nit expects to recover a total of about 15 million pounds of meat in the\nmassive recall.\nThe additional brands being recalled were sold by Grand Rapids,\nMich.-based Gordon Food Service, which operates about 70 stores; Allen\nFoods, which has one outlet store in St. Louis; Sara Lee's PYA Monarch\nfoodservice unit, which runs two stores in Montgomery, Ala.; and a Bil\nMar Country Store outlet in Zeeland, Mich.\n***\n[2\nDate: Mon, 01 Feb 1999 18:53:19 -0500\nFrom: \"Robert A. LaBudde\" <ral@lcfltd.com>\nSource: FSNET\n\nUPI 31 Jan 1999 [edited\nGRAND RAPIDS, Mich. -- To date, the deaths of 12 people, three\nmiscarriages, and more than 70 illnesses nationwide are blamed on\nListeria-tainted meat.\nMore than 15 million pounds of meat have been recalled since Sara Lee's\nDecember announcement.\nDr. Paul Mead, an epidemiologist with the U.S. Centers for Disease\nControl was cited as... telling the Grand Rapids Press the CDC recall\nrecommendation came several days after an epidemiologist from the\nMinnesota Health Department urged a recall, adding, \"Recalls are always\neither too early or too late. If you're right, it's always too late. If\nyou're wrong, it's always too early.\"\nHe was further cited as saying it's unclear whether an earlier recall\ncould have saved lives or prevented more illnesses.\nHe also noted that CDC investigators are trying to determine if dust at\nthe Bil-Mar plant may have led to the Listeria outbreak because\nofficials think there was a \"construction event\" in the building that\nsprayed dust onto the equipment. The dust is suspected to have contained\nListeria, which is commonly found in soil and water.\n[ProMED-mail often faces the same dilemma; do we post without\nconfirmation and risk having to retract, or wait for confirmation and\nallow more cases to occur for lack of timely warning? So far, we have\nonly had to retract 3 minor outbreak reports out of several thousand\nposted - Mod.JW\n***\n[3\nDate: Mon, 01 Feb 1999 18:57:01 -0500\nFrom: \"Robert A. LaBudde\" <ral@lcfltd.com>\nSource: New York Times, 27 Jan 1999 via FSNET [edited\n\nByline: Marian Burros\nThere are only 1000 to 2000 reported cases of listeriosis in the United\nStates each year; an accurate figure cannot be obtained, the story says,\nas health professionals do not routinely test for it and many cases go\nundetected.\nBut health officials find it especially troubling because, based on the\nnumber of reported cases, the percentage of people who die from it is\nmuch higher than from most other food-borne bacteria. And, the story\nadds, the incubation period is much longer, up to 70 days before\nsymptoms appear.\nIn addition to causing miscarriages and stillbirths, Listeria can cause\nfatal blood infections and meningitis.\nAmerican scientists began to take Listeria seriously in 1985, when 18\ndeaths were traced to the eating of Jalisco brand soft cheese. (The\ncompany is now defunct.) There were also 30 stillbirths and deaths of\nnewborns.\nAnother 142 people became ill.\nListeria is carried in the intestines of animals and can easily come in\ncontact with dairy products, uncooked meats, fish, poultry and\nvegetables as well as precooked meats like the ones responsible for the\nAugust\noutbreak. The investigators say they do not know how the Listeria\ncontaminated the cooked meats at Bil Mar Foods.\nThe centralization of food production has turned what might previously\nhave been a small local problem into a global one. Products from the Bil\nMar plant, for example, are distributed all over the United States.\nIn the Bil Mar Foods case, the Agriculture Department left the\nannouncement of the recall to the company. The agency does not announce\nrecalls until it has proof that a sealed product contains the\ndisease-causing bacteria, and it did not have that proof until 31 Dec\n1998, nine days later.\nWhen the company announced the recall, a spokesman for the Agriculture\nDepartment, Andrew Solomon, was cited as saying that reporters who cover\nthe agency were notified and the information was put on the agency's Web\nsite and on its consumer-information line (800-535-4555).\n\nDale Morse, the director of the division of infectious disease of the\nNew York State Health Department, say there can never be enough\nnotification. In Broome County, in upstate New York [he said Meals on\nWheels was still serving the Bil Mar products to elderly clients eight\ndays after the recall, because it had not been notified.\nThe story goes on to say that unlike many other disease-causing\nbacteria, Listeria can grow in a refrigerator that has a normal\ntemperature of 40 degrees, which means leftovers should be reheated.\nPublic health officials strongly urge those at greatest risk from\nListeria to stay away from all soft cheeses,\nincluding feta and blue-veined cheeses like Roquefort and Camembert.\nThey also say that it is essential to cook hot dogs until the internal\ntemperature reaches 165 degrees, by either steaming or frying. Cooking\nin the\nmicrowave is not recommended. And unless people at risk are willing to\neat salami, corned beef and pastrami cooked. they should not eat them\nat all.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@usa.healthnet.org>\n................................jw\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. USA (Arkansas & Ohio)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2194996", "date": "1999-01-09 23:50:00", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS, MULTIFOCAL - USA (06)\n**********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.healthnet.org/programs/promed.html>\nSee Also\nListeriosis, multifocal - USA 981218202551\nListeriosis, multifocal - USA (02) 981222233534\nListeriosis, multifocal - USA (03) 981223215708\nListeriosis, multifocal - USA (04) 981225202759\nListeriosis, multifocal - USA (05) 981229223451\nDate: Fri, 08 Jan 1999 09:41:59 -0800\nFrom: Dr. James Chin, CDPC-mail <jchin@CDPC.com>\nSource: MMWR, Vol. 47 / No. 51 & 52, 8 Jan 1999\n\nUpdate: Multistate Outbreak of Listeriosis - United States, 1998-1999\n-------------------------------------------\n>From early August 1998 through January 6, 1999, at least 50 illnesses\ncaused by a rare strain of the bacterium _Listeria monocytogenes_,\nserotype\n4b, have been reported to CDC by 11 states. Six adults have died and two\npregnant women have had spontaneous abortions. Reported illness onset\ndates\nwere during August 2-December 13, 1998. CDC and state and local health\ndepartments have identified the vehicle for transmission as hot dogs and\npossibly deli meats produced under many brand names by one manufacturer.\nThis report updates the investigation of this outbreak...\n[MMWR Editorial Note: Healthy persons rarely develop severe illness\nfrom\n_Listeria_. The illness primarily occurs in pregnant women, newborns,\nand\npersons with impaired immunity caused by serious illness, such as\nacquired\nimmunodeficiency syndrome or cancer. _Listeria_ infections during\npregnancy\nmay cause an influenza-like illness with fever and chills, and may lead\nto\nloss of the fetus. In other persons, early symptoms can include fever,\nsevere headache, and stiff neck. Illness can begin 2-8 weeks after\neating\nthe contaminated food.\nConsumers who have the affected product should not eat it, but rather\nshould discard it or return it to the point of purchase. The risk for\ndeveloping _Listeria_ infection after eating a contaminated product is\nlow.\nPersons who have eaten a contaminated product and do not have any\nsymptoms\ndo not need any special medical evaluation or treatment, even if they\nare\nin high-risk groups. However, persons in high-risk groups who have eaten\nthe contaminated product, and within 2 months become ill with fever or\ninfluenza-like illness, should inform their physicians about this\nexposure.\nBecause of this long incubation period, cases may continue to occur and\nbe\nreported for several weeks after an effective recall.\nConsumers who have questions about the recall or the products involved\nshould contact Bil Mar Foods, telephone (800) 247-8339. Persons who have\nquestions about Listeria should call their physicians or their local or\nstate health departments or visit CDC's World-Wide Web site,\n<http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/diseases/foodborn/lister.htm>. General\nquestions\nabout meat handling should be directed to the U.S. Department of\nAgriculture's Meat and Poultry Hotline, telephone (800) 535-4555, Monday\nthrough Friday from 10 a.m. to 4 p.m. eastern time.\n--\nProMED-mail\ne-mail: promed@usa.healthnet.org\n[This thread had been cut, but the current update informs us of\nadditional\ncases and provides more specific strain characterization information. -\nMod.ES\n......................................es/jw\n\n\n--\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Six adults have died and two\npregnant women have had spontaneous abortions. Reported illness onset\ndates\nwere during August 2-December 13, 1998. CDC and state and local health\ndepartments have identified the vehicle for transmission as hot dogs and\npossibly deli meats produced under many brand names by one manufacturer.\nThis report updates the investigation of this outbreak...\n[MMWR Editorial Note: Healthy persons rarely develop severe illness\nfrom\n_Listeria_. In other persons, early symptoms can include fever,\nsevere headache, and stiff neck. Illness can begin 2-8 weeks after\neating\nthe contaminated food.\nConsumers who have the affected product should not eat it, but rather\nshould discard it or return it to the point of purchase. The risk for\ndeveloping _Listeria_ infection after eating a contaminated product is\nlow.\nPersons who have eaten a contaminated product and do not have any\nsymptoms\ndo not need any special medical evaluation or treatment, even if they\nare\nin high-risk groups. However, persons in high-risk groups who have eaten\nthe contaminated product, and within 2 months become ill with fever or\ninfluenza-like illness, should inform their physicians about this\nexposure.\nBecause of this long incubation period, cases may continue to occur and\nbe\nreported for several weeks after an effective recall.\nConsumers who have questions about the recall or the products involved\nshould contact Bil Mar Foods, telephone (800) 247-8339. Persons who have\nquestions about Listeria should call their physicians or their local or\nstate health departments or visit CDC's World-Wide Web site,\n<http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/diseases/foodborn/lister.htm>. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "listeriosis", "influenza-like illness"], "syndromes": ["influenza-like illness"], "event_date": ["1999-01-08 00:00:00", "1999-01-08 00:00:00", "1999-01-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-19 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Listeriosis - United States", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2194985", "headline": "PRO/AH> Listeriosis, multifocal - USA (09)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2194985", "date": "1999-01-09 23:50:00", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS, MULTIFOCAL - USA (06)\n**********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.healthnet.org/programs/promed.html>\nSee Also\nListeriosis, multifocal - USA 981218202551\nListeriosis, multifocal - USA (02) 981222233534\nListeriosis, multifocal - USA (03) 981223215708\nListeriosis, multifocal - USA (04) 981225202759\nListeriosis, multifocal - USA (05) 981229223451\nDate: Fri, 08 Jan 1999 09:41:59 -0800\nFrom: Dr. James Chin, CDPC-mail <jchin@CDPC.com>\nSource: MMWR, Vol. 47 / No. 51 & 52, 8 Jan 1999\n\nUpdate: Multistate Outbreak of Listeriosis - United States, 1998-1999\n-------------------------------------------\n>From early August 1998 through January 6, 1999, at least 50 illnesses\ncaused by a rare strain of the bacterium _Listeria monocytogenes_,\nserotype\n4b, have been reported to CDC by 11 states. Six adults have died and two\npregnant women have had spontaneous abortions. Reported illness onset\ndates\nwere during August 2-December 13, 1998. CDC and state and local health\ndepartments have identified the vehicle for transmission as hot dogs and\npossibly deli meats produced under many brand names by one manufacturer.\nThis report updates the investigation of this outbreak...\n[MMWR Editorial Note: Healthy persons rarely develop severe illness\nfrom\n_Listeria_. The illness primarily occurs in pregnant women, newborns,\nand\npersons with impaired immunity caused by serious illness, such as\nacquired\nimmunodeficiency syndrome or cancer. _Listeria_ infections during\npregnancy\nmay cause an influenza-like illness with fever and chills, and may lead\nto\nloss of the fetus. In other persons, early symptoms can include fever,\nsevere headache, and stiff neck. Illness can begin 2-8 weeks after\neating\nthe contaminated food.\nConsumers who have the affected product should not eat it, but rather\nshould discard it or return it to the point of purchase. The risk for\ndeveloping _Listeria_ infection after eating a contaminated product is\nlow.\nPersons who have eaten a contaminated product and do not have any\nsymptoms\ndo not need any special medical evaluation or treatment, even if they\nare\nin high-risk groups. However, persons in high-risk groups who have eaten\nthe contaminated product, and within 2 months become ill with fever or\ninfluenza-like illness, should inform their physicians about this\nexposure.\nBecause of this long incubation period, cases may continue to occur and\nbe\nreported for several weeks after an effective recall.\nConsumers who have questions about the recall or the products involved\nshould contact Bil Mar Foods, telephone (800) 247-8339. Persons who have\nquestions about Listeria should call their physicians or their local or\nstate health departments or visit CDC's World-Wide Web site,\n<http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/diseases/foodborn/lister.htm>. General\nquestions\nabout meat handling should be directed to the U.S. Department of\nAgriculture's Meat and Poultry Hotline, telephone (800) 535-4555, Monday\nthrough Friday from 10 a.m. to 4 p.m. eastern time.\n--\nProMED-mail\ne-mail: promed@usa.healthnet.org\n[This thread had been cut, but the current update informs us of\nadditional\ncases and provides more specific strain characterization information. -\nMod.ES\n......................................es/jw\n\n\n--\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Six adults have died and two\npregnant women have had spontaneous abortions. Reported illness onset\ndates\nwere during August 2-December 13, 1998. CDC and state and local health\ndepartments have identified the vehicle for transmission as hot dogs and\npossibly deli meats produced under many brand names by one manufacturer.\nThis report updates the investigation of this outbreak...\n[MMWR Editorial Note: Healthy persons rarely develop severe illness\nfrom\n_Listeria_. The illness primarily occurs in pregnant women, newborns,\nand\npersons with impaired immunity caused by serious illness, such as\nacquired\nimmunodeficiency syndrome or cancer. _Listeria_ infections during\npregnancy\nmay cause an influenza-like illness with fever and chills, and may lead\nto\nloss of the fetus. In other persons, early symptoms can include fever,\nsevere headache, and stiff neck. Illness can begin 2-8 weeks after\neating\nthe contaminated food.\nConsumers who have the affected product should not eat it, but rather\nshould discard it or return it to the point of purchase. The risk for\ndeveloping _Listeria_ infection after eating a contaminated product is\nlow.\nPersons who have eaten a contaminated product and do not have any\nsymptoms\ndo not need any special medical evaluation or treatment, even if they\nare\nin high-risk groups. However, persons in high-risk groups who have eaten\nthe contaminated product, and within 2 months become ill with fever or\ninfluenza-like illness, should inform their physicians about this\nexposure.\nBecause of this long incubation period, cases may continue to occur and\nbe\nreported for several weeks after an effective recall.\nConsumers who have questions about the recall or the products involved\nshould contact Bil Mar Foods, telephone (800) 247-8339. Persons who have\nquestions about Listeria should call their physicians or their local or\nstate health departments or visit CDC's World-Wide Web site,\n<http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/diseases/foodborn/lister.htm>. General\nquestions\nabout meat handling should be directed to the U.S. Department of\nAgriculture's Meat and Poultry Hotline, telephone (800) 535-4555, Monday\nthrough Friday from 10 a.m. to 4 p.m. eastern time.\n--\nProMED-mail\ne-mail: promed@usa.healthnet.org\n[This thread had been cut, but the current update informs us of\nadditional\ncases and provides more specific strain characterization information. -\nMod.ES\n......................................es/jw\n\n\n--\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. CDC and state and local health\ndepartments have identified the vehicle for transmission as hot dogs and\npossibly deli meats produced under many brand names by one manufacturer.\nThis report updates the investigation of this outbreak...\n[MMWR Editorial Note: Healthy persons rarely develop severe illness\nfrom\n_Listeria_. The illness primarily occurs in pregnant women, newborns,\nand\npersons with impaired immunity caused by serious illness, such as\nacquired\nimmunodeficiency syndrome or cancer. _Listeria_ infections during\npregnancy\nmay cause an influenza-like illness with fever and chills, and may lead\nto\nloss of the fetus. However, persons in high-risk groups who have eaten\nthe contaminated product, and within 2 months become ill with fever or\ninfluenza-like illness, should inform their physicians about this\nexposure.\nBecause of this long incubation period, cases may continue to occur and\nbe\nreported for several weeks after an effective recall.\nConsumers who have questions about the recall or the products involved\nshould contact Bil Mar Foods, telephone (800) 247-8339. I propose that seen is the wrong verb; the disease is only DIAGNOSED\nin the above group. I have had listeriosis reported in a relatively healthy\nadult male. The situation was that he had flu-like symptoms and went to the\nemergency room for treatment. Because he had a history of rheumatic fever, a\nblood culture was drawn. He was discharged and recovered without event. Two\nweeks later the blood culture results returned with _L. monocytogenes_. I\nhave felt since that it is likely that only the very young, very old and\npregnant women become sick enough to be diagnosed.\n--\nFrances Taylor, MD, MPH\nretired from San Francisco DPH,\nCommunicable Disease Control\n[Many years ago when I first joined MAFF and attended my first annual\nmeeting of the VIOs at Weybridge I remember that Ivor Field, then D/CVL,\npresented one speaker, a VIO from the Midlands, with the comment that his\nwas the only VIC diagnosing listeriosis and would everyone pay careful\nattention. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "listeriosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-07 00:00:00", "1998-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "MD", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "San Francisco DPH", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2192862", "headline": "PRO/AH> Listeriosis, risk assessment using mouse model", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2192862", "date": "1998-01-13 23:50:00", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS, CONTAMINATED FISH - SWEDEN: 1994/95\n************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nSee Also\nFood-borne disease outbreaks - worldwide 970826110829\nDate: Mon, 12 Jan 1998 20:13:01 -0500\nFrom: Robert A. LaBudde <ral@lcfltd.com>\nSource: FSNET (D. Powell, Univ. Guelph) & Smittskydd (10-97) via Per Nilsson\n\nDuring the second half of 1994 and the first half of 1995 there were nine\ncases of listeriosis reported in Varmland. Usually there is not more than\none case each year in Varmland. Six of the cases were men over 70 years old\nand three cases were pregnant women.\nAlmost everybody had eaten salmon-like fish (in most cases rainbow trout)\nduring the last six months. The fishes had been fermented or smoked.\nSeveral of these people had eaten rainbow trout from the same manufacturer\nA. Samples were collected from several food shops and from the manufacturer\nA. Six of the samples from the humans had typing (biochemical\ncharacterization, serotyping, phage typing and REA + PFGE) belonging to the\nsame clone as the _Listeria monocytogenes_ which had been isolated from the\nrainbow trout from manufacturer A.\nProbably six cases of nine had been caused by consuming rainbow trout from\nmanufacturer A.\nA longer version of this article will be or has already been published:\nEricsson, H. et al. An outbreak of listeriosis suspected to have been\ncaused by rainbow trout. Journal of Clinical Microbiology (in press).\n--\nProMED-mail\ne-mail: promed@usa.healthnet.org\n[While the sentinel population, pregnant women and the elderly, is as\nexpected the source is not one commonly considered. Would anyone with\nspecial knowledge of this disease, and especially of this Swedish series,\nplease comment. - Mod.MHJ ......................................mhj/es\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The reader assumes all risks in\nusing information posted or archived by ProMED-mail. ISID\nand its associated service providers shall not be held\nresponsible for errors or omissions or held liable for any\ndamages incurred as a result of use or reliance upon posted\nor archived material.\n************************************************************\nVisit ProMED-mail's web site at <http://www.promedmail.org>.\nSend all items for posting to: promed@promedmail.org\n(NOT to an individual moderator). If you do not give your\nfull name and affiliation, it may not be posted. Send\ncommands to subscribe/unsubscribe, get archives, help,\netc. to: majordomo@promedmail.org. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["listeriosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1998-01-12 00:00:00", "1997-10-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Varmland", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2192549", "headline": "PRO/AH> Listeriosis, contaminated fish - Sweden:1994/95(02)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2192549", "date": "1998-01-13 23:50:00", "main_text": "LISTERIOSIS, CONTAMINATED FISH - SWEDEN: 1994/95\n************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nSee Also\nFood-borne disease outbreaks - worldwide 970826110829\nDate: Mon, 12 Jan 1998 20:13:01 -0500\nFrom: Robert A. LaBudde <ral@lcfltd.com>\nSource: FSNET (D. Powell, Univ. Guelph) & Smittskydd (10-97) via Per Nilsson\n\nDuring the second half of 1994 and the first half of 1995 there were nine\ncases of listeriosis reported in Varmland. Usually there is not more than\none case each year in Varmland. Six of the cases were men over 70 years old\nand three cases were pregnant women.\nAlmost everybody had eaten salmon-like fish (in most cases rainbow trout)\nduring the last six months. The fishes had been fermented or smoked.\nSeveral of these people had eaten rainbow trout from the same manufacturer\nA. Samples were collected from several food shops and from the manufacturer\nA. Six of the samples from the humans had typing (biochemical\ncharacterization, serotyping, phage typing and REA + PFGE) belonging to the\nsame clone as the _Listeria monocytogenes_ which had been isolated from the\nrainbow trout from manufacturer A.\nProbably six cases of nine had been caused by consuming rainbow trout from\nmanufacturer A.\nA longer version of this article will be or has already been published:\nEricsson, H. et al. An outbreak of listeriosis suspected to have been\ncaused by rainbow trout. Journal of Clinical Microbiology (in press).\n--\nProMED-mail\ne-mail: promed@usa.healthnet.org\n[While the sentinel population, pregnant women and the elderly, is as\nexpected the source is not one commonly considered. Would anyone with\nspecial knowledge of this disease, and especially of this Swedish series,\nplease comment. - Mod.MHJ ......................................mhj/es\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. LaBudde <ral@lcfltd.com>\nSource: FSNET (D. Powell, Univ. Guelph) & Smittskydd (10-97) via Per Nilsson\n\nDuring the second half of 1994 and the first half of 1995 there were nine\ncases of listeriosis reported in Varmland. Usually there is not more than\none case each year in Varmland. Six of the cases were men over 70 years old\nand three cases were pregnant women.\nAlmost everybody had eaten salmon-like fish (in most cases rainbow trout)\nduring the last six months. The fishes had been fermented or smoked.\nSeveral of these people had eaten rainbow trout from the same manufacturer\nA. Samples were collected from several food shops and from the manufacturer\nA. Six of the samples from the humans had typing (biochemical\ncharacterization, serotyping, phage typing and REA + PFGE) belonging to the\nsame clone as the _Listeria monocytogenes_ which had been isolated from the\nrainbow trout from manufacturer A.\nProbably six cases of nine had been caused by consuming rainbow trout from\nmanufacturer A.\nA longer version of this article will be or has already been published:\nEricsson, H. et al. An outbreak of listeriosis suspected to have been\ncaused by rainbow trout. Journal of Clinical Microbiology (in press).\n--\nProMED-mail\ne-mail: promed@usa.healthnet.org\n[While the sentinel population, pregnant women and the elderly, is as\nexpected the source is not one commonly considered. Would anyone with\nspecial knowledge of this disease, and especially of this Swedish series,\nplease comment. - Mod.MHJ ......................................mhj/es\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed.
